CUBITT, MAYOR. SECOND MAYORALTY.CENTRAL CRIMINAL COURT.

A star (*) denotes that prisoners have been previously in custodyâ€”two stars (**) that they have been more than once in custodyâ€”an obelisk (â€ ) that they are known to be the associates of bad charactersâ€”the figures, after the name in the indictment denote the prisoner's age.
PRESENTâ€”The Right Hon. the LORD MAYOR; Mr. Ald FINNS; Sir
ROBERT WALTER CARDEN , Knt. Ald.; Mr. Ald ROSE; and Mr. Ald. BESLLEY.

div1.p:
501.
EDWARD VILLIERS CROTTY (48), was indicted
for a libel; to which he
PLEADED GUILTY .

Recommended to mercy by the prosecutor.â€”
Confined Twelve Months l.,
and two sureties in 50l. each, to be of good behaviour for Two Years.

502.
JOHN CANNON (44)
, Stealing 12 pieces of leather, 10 pairs of uppers, and other articles, the property of
David Josephs and another. Second Count, feloniously receiving the same.

WILLIAM SMITH (City-policeman). On 20th March, from information I received, I went, about the middle of the day, to 19, Blue Anchor-alley, the prisoner's shop and residenceâ€”I saw him on the other side of the counterâ€”I told him I was an officer, and said, "Have you any uppers in your possession?"â€”he said, "No; I have nothing of the sort"â€”I said, "Have you any uppers at all; or anything of the sort?"â€”he said, "No; I have not, who do you mean?"â€”I said, "Messrs. Hickson's, of Smithfield"â€”he I said, "No; I have none of their's"â€”I said, "I have reason to believe you have some here, will you allow me to look?"â€”he said, "Where is your warrant?"â€”I pulled out my book and showed him my warrant-card, which plain clothes officers carry with them as an authorityâ€”he opened the door, and I walked in behind the counterâ€”he went to a corner, and took down a curtain which covered a recessâ€”I commenced searching, and the first lot I laid hold of were some of Messrs. Hickson's, and two pairs of uppers, and two pairs of soles tied to themâ€”the soles had Messrs. Hickson's stamp upon themâ€”I asked him to account for those goodsâ€”he said that he could not, no more than that he bought themâ€”I said, "Who did you buy them off?"â€”he said, "I do not know; if they want them back again I will sell them with a little

profit to myself"â€”I found a great quantity of uppers, but I called his atten
tion to these firstâ€”I said, "Do not you keep a book?"â€”he said, "Only that one"â€”this book (produced) was lying on the counter, and I said, "What does this relate to?"â€”he said, "To a few shillings which I lend to the neighbours in the court"â€”I searched further, and found 152 pairs of uppers, 132 soles and pieces of leather for making soles, and about 21 pairs of boots unfinishedâ€”there was some of Mr. Josephs' among themâ€”here are three pieces of leather, and an odd boot, not quite finished, stamped with Josephs' stampâ€”I took possession of all the articles, and took the prisoner in custodyâ€”while I was talking to him one of Hickson's men came inâ€”after I had made the charge at the station, the sergeant asked what account he could give of the articlesâ€”he said, "I know who I had them of, but I do not know where they live"â€”he was asked the names, and said that he knew them, but he did not tell them to us.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. He did not tell the names, but did you not find them on the tickets? A. Here is, "4, Ball, 2s." on this ticket, and "Stone" on thisâ€”there were tickets, I believe, on some articles, not on every one, because they were tied up in bundlesâ€”they have been untied, and I believe the tickets have been taken off, there have been so many people to look at the propertyâ€”I believe there were tickets on all the lots, each showing a sum of money, and the name of some person and a dateâ€”I do not think there was any numberâ€”I do not think there are other packets also claimed by Mr. Josephs, besides these in the names of Ball and Stoneâ€”these are the only tickets I can findâ€”the prisoner said that he regretted having had anything to do with the businessâ€”after I went in I waited for the arrival of Mr. Hickson's man, two or three minutes after meâ€”I beckoned him in with my umbrella, and his wife afterwards came in with Mr. Battenâ€”I mean to convey to the jury that I first asked the prisoner whether he had any uppers at allâ€”he keeps a sham pawnbroker's; what we call a leaving shopâ€”I got the Excise-officers down to the police-court by instructions of Mr. D'Eyncourt, the Magistrate, when the case was heardâ€”I do not know whether the attorney for the prosecution endeavoured to induce them to prosecute; I was not presentâ€”the Excise-officers were down there before we had an attorney in the caseâ€”we could not prove a pawning or redemptionâ€”the Magistrate did not discharge the prisoner on this chargeâ€”Joseph's charge was not gone intoâ€”he was there, but did not give evidence; and the evidence in his case has never been gone into till to
dayâ€”I believe the Magistrate committed on Messrs. Hickson and Bent's charge.
MR. GIFFARD. Q. Is there any indication to the public at large that there is a pawnbroker's business carried on there? A. Not at all.

JOSEPH TAYLOR . About two years and a half ago, I was foreman to Messrs. Hickson and Sons, wholesale boot and shoe manufacturersâ€”the prisoner was in their employment three or four months previous to my leaving, and was there when I leftâ€”he behaved very well, and was very regularâ€”he was honest as far as I know.

DAVID JOSPHES . I am a wholesale boot and shoemaker, of Skinner-street, Snow-hillâ€”these uppers are my propertyâ€”I have a very large stockâ€”I should be unable to miss a few, but I never sell uppers till they are con
verted into perfectly made bootsâ€”they must have been taken by some of our cutters, packers, errand-boys, or warehousemenâ€”this boot bears my stamp, and is mine; it is unfinished, and in an unsaleable conditionâ€”the last is still in itâ€”(Taking it out)â€”this last has my stamp on it, "J"â€”I had
no persons named Ball or Stone in my employment in Marchâ€”the articles I identify are worth 14s. or 15s.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know the names of the workmen? A. Pretty wellâ€”I can say that I have had no workman named Ball for the last six monthsâ€”I have not gone so far back as two years, because this boot has been cut out within the last six monthsâ€”the names of all the workmen are entered in the work-book by a clerk, named Castleâ€”he is not hereâ€”he could only tell you by the list the same as I doâ€”he does not make a list of the names so that he might omit one; but he enters the names of the men in their accountsâ€”the book is not hereâ€”I have had no such person as Stone, a workman, during the last seven or eight monthsâ€”work like this is given out to workmen to be made into boots, which they bring back madeâ€”these uppers were cut out on 21st February, and these others about, the middle of Januaryâ€”I know that by certain marks on them, which lead me to the men, and by referring to the men's books I know the timeâ€”the cutter is not here, or his book; but there are several references as to each individual cuttingâ€”I also recognise them as bearing my stamp, and as cut from my leatherâ€”I cannot tell when any of them were taken awayâ€”the cutter is in my service stillâ€”I take security from the workmen when work is given out, and if they do not return it we get the price of it, when we can, from the securityâ€”we very rarely have to come upon the securityâ€”the workmen never get a loan on the deposit of their work with my permission or knowledgeâ€”they have to find thread and wax, and those trifling things, but nothing moreâ€”I have heard of shops where they get supplied with those things, and leave the leather until they can take it out with the money they obtain; they are called "leaving shops," and are a great curse to our trade, for the money is generally obtained for drinkâ€”our principal reason for taking security from a workman, is that he shall not run away with the work, or dispose of itâ€”uppers and soles are to be bought separately, but not stamped with the initial of any particular firmâ€”they are regularly dealt in to a very large extentâ€”from inquiries I have made, I can say that these have not been given out to be made up.

MR. GIFFARD. Q. How would you become acquainted with the names of the workmen in your employment? A. From the work-bookâ€”that is the book kept by Mr. Castle, and which I have to look at frequently for the general superintendance of the businessâ€”this is the book (produced), and that gentleman sitting under you is Mr. Castleâ€”I had not the least idea that he was here; he must have been sent for.

MR. METCALFE. Q. How often do you see those entries? A. I look at them from time to time, frequently over a fortnight, but sometimes three or six weeks may elapseâ€”I can undertake to say that I looked at that page within a fortnight of it's date, April 28thâ€”the book was never at the police-court.

EDWARD CASTLE . I keep this bookâ€”I have not looked at it to ascertain whether any person named Stone or Ball have been in the employ during the last six monthsâ€”I know of my own knowledge that they have not.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know whether such persons have been in the employment of Mr. Josephs at all? A. Not since I have been there, which was last Augustâ€”there is a William Hodges to whom work has been given out, and he has some women's work out stillâ€”these boots are women's, and these others, men'sâ€”workmen sometimes pawn their work, and we then call upon them to pay, and if they do not, we come down upon the securityâ€”I never knew a workman to come for work again when he has made away

with the goods, and we have got the amount from the securityâ€”if I say that 5l. has been paid by defaulter's securities in the last six months I shall be within the markâ€”we give out work value 1l. and 30s. and 2l.â€”Hodges has not paid for any work, nor has anybody on his behalfâ€”I cannot tell, by reference to the book, that this work has not been paid for during the last six months, because we have so many pairs alikeâ€”I enter work when it goes out and when it comes inâ€”I can tell by my book how many pairs are out, and can come down upon the security if it is not brought inâ€”I know what every man makes, because one man seldom makes two or three kindsâ€”there is stock unpaid for at the present time, but I cannot say whether it is this or some other portion of the stock.

MR. GIFFARD. Q. Who would know what money had been received from the sureties? A. I shouldâ€”I do not know of their paying for any such work as this, but women's work is very much alike; but as to the men's I could tell by referring to the book.

COURT. Q. Can you tell whether this stock has been given out? A. I cannot swear to that pair as being the pair given outâ€”by referring to the cash-book I can tell whether they have been paid forâ€”this is not the cash-book.
WILLIAM SMITH (re-examined). I have looked at the prisoner's book, and do not see any entry of this transaction, or of the names of Ball or Stone.

p.hi: contended that there was no case against the prisoner, as in order to prove a receiving, a stealing must first be shown; that there was no proof of their being taken out of the stock, and that if they had been given out to a workman who had become a defaulter, he would have purchased through his surety the right to the goods; and even if the surety had not paid for them, the workman only received them as a bailee, and his committing a breach of trust would not make him guilty of larceny.
submitted that it was a question for the jury in what way the goods left the establishment.

div1.p: COURT to DAVID JOSEPHS. Q. When work is given out, do you supply the lasts? A. Yesâ€”only those persons to whom work is given out are called journeymen.

p.hi: could not say that there was no evidence that the goods were stolen from the premises, but would reserve the point if it became necessary.
The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

503.
JOHN CANNON was again indicted
for a like offence.

The evidence of William Smith was read over to him, to which he assented, and added: I also found nine pairs of uppers, and twelve pairs of solesâ€”I found a ticket on some of the articles, I cannot say whichâ€”they were tied up in separate lotsâ€”there were two tickets in the name of Ware, one dated October 28, and the other, I think, October 26â€”I do not know what has be
come of them, the things have been so pulled about with one and another looking at the propertyâ€”I heard from Mr. Bent of a person named Wareâ€”I could not find him, but I found his wife.
Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. You found the things ticketed? A. Yes; I cannot say every oneâ€”they were arranged on shelves, from the bottom to the topâ€”the recess was full.
JOSEPH TAYLOR . The evidence given by this witness in the former case was read over to him, to which he assented.
GEORGE BENT . I am assistant to James Bent, a boot and shoemaker, of 3, Beech-street, Barbicanâ€”on 22d October last, I gave to Mrs. Ware ten

pairs of uppers and ten pairs of soles, to be made up by her husbandâ€”I know that by looking at my bookâ€”it is not here, but I also know it independently of my bookâ€”it was this sort that she had, but here is only a portion of themâ€”I identify these six pairs of uppers with the blue lining, as given to Mrs. Ware; they are just in the same state as when I gave them outâ€”I can also speak to these nine pairs of solesâ€”they ought to have been worked up and returned to me, but they have never been returnedâ€”that is the only instance of goods going out and not being returned within the last two yearsâ€”I went in search of Ware, three days after giving her the work, but they had moved away, and I could get no tidings of thenâ€”we have not taken security from the workmen for the last two yearsâ€”we do not sell uppers or soles in this state.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you mean to say that you cannot buy uppers in the market? A. Not children's plain leatherâ€”I have not had notice to produce my book; it is at my father'sâ€”it was not at the police-courtâ€”we enter in it the names of the personsâ€”the numbers are the only mark we put upon them, but I know these because they are the only ten pairs we lost during that orderâ€”I know by the book that they were intended for that orderâ€”I have not seen Mrs. Ware since she had them outâ€”I went to where she had lodged, but made no complaintâ€”Ware had only worked for us a few weeks; he had nine or ten pairsâ€”they ought to have been returned in two days or soâ€”if a workman does not return them, we make him pay for them, if we can find him, and if not we have to put up with the lossâ€”my father would not take any trouble about themâ€”he is not here.
MR. GIFFARD. Q. Does your father take any part in the management of the business now? A. Not much; he never cuts out anythingâ€”Ticket read, "October 28â€”6, Ware."

COURT. Q. There are one or two others, do yon know anything about them? A. They were given out to another man, not to Ware; they belong to my fatherâ€”these three pairs of soles have his stamp upon them, and the figures on the toe are my own markâ€”there were some tickets on the boots at the station, but they got mis-matchedâ€”the name of Reynolds was on some of them.
MR. METCALFE. Q. Was Reynolds in your father's service? A. Yes; my father turned him off after these goods were seized; he was working for us up to that time.

GUILTY
on the second count. â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

p.hi: There were three other indictments against the prisoner.

div1.p:
504.
WILLIAM COOK (60)
, Unlawfully obtaining 115l., the property of
William Joynson by false pretences.

JAMES JONES . I am groom to Mr. Joynson of North Gray, Kentâ€”on 28th March, I went by his direction to a stable in Cleveland-row, St. James'sâ€”I had this advertisement with meâ€”(Read: "For sale, a pair of handsome dappled-grey geldings, six years old, fifteen hands three inches high; step and go well together, fast action, good hunters, warranted sound, a trial allowed, price moderate. To be seen at 1, Russel-court, Cleveland-road, St. James's")â€”I did not see the defendant that day, but I went on the Monday following and saw the groom, who said he would fetch his master, and brought the prisonerâ€”I told him that I had come about that advertise
mentâ€”the prisoner told me that his name was Henry Sinclair, he had had the horses two years, and driven them at Malvern and Bath last summer,

that they were perfectly free from vice, and he could warrant them perfectly sound in every description; and that they had never been in any dealer's handsâ€”he said that his estate was in Leamington in Warwickshire, that his son had ridden one of the horses in hunting, which was the reason he did not carry so much flesh as the other, that his daughter had ridden the other, but had given up doing so, as she was under medical treatment, and that was the reason he was parting with themâ€”he asked me if his servant had told me anything respecting the horses, and I said that he had given me a very good character with themâ€”the groom was the man whom I had seen on the Saturdayâ€”Mr. Dorkin went with me, on 1st April, to pay for the horsesâ€”I did not see him pay for them, but I heard the prisoner tell his servant to deliver them up to me, which he didâ€”the prisoner told me not to go away without seeing him, and after the horses were paid for, he came back, gave me a sovereign, and told me to get some refreshment, and then I took the horses homeâ€”on the Monday the prisoner gave me the note to take home to my masterâ€”(This note stated that Mr. Sinclair had many times refused 100 guineas for the horses, the price of them being 120 guineas, that they were six years old, and he would warrant them free from vice or blemish, and would return the money at any time within three months if the horses were not approved of)â€”The prisoner said, on the Monday, that he was in no particular hurry to sell the horses as he should not require the stables till he and his family came up from Leamington at the end of May, when he should require them for a pair of cobsâ€”I took the horses away, and by the time I got to Westminster-bridge, I found that they were both roarers, but I took them homeâ€”I went back to the stables next day, but could neither find the prisoner or the groomâ€”no
body knew anything of themâ€”I believed that he was a private gentleman at Leamington, and told my master soâ€”if I had known that he was a dealer, I should not have advised my master to buy the horses.

Cross-examined by MR. GIFFARD. Q. There was nothing in the stable but the two geldings? A. Noâ€”the groom had a room upstairsâ€”he came down when I rangâ€”they were very fine horses to look atâ€”they are now in the possession of a farmer, a friend of my master's, and are turned out in a straw-yardâ€”I swear that Leamington was mentioned on the Monday, 31st Marchâ€”it was the appearance of the prisoner and of the horses that caused me to recommend my master to purchaseâ€”I told my master the prisoner was a perfect gentleman, that he lived at Leamington, that his estate was there, and therefore my master thought he was dealing with a gentlemanâ€”Leamington was mentioned before the money was paidâ€”I am certain of that, but I did not think of it at the first examinationâ€”the prisoner mentioned it on the Mondayâ€”the bargain was concluded on 1st April; he agreed what to pay on Monday, but he was to let me have the horses on trialâ€”I gave him my master's note, and he said that he would not go across the stable door to inquire at master's bankers, as several people wanted the horsesâ€”I was not present when the receipt was givenâ€”he said nothing about Leamington when he gave me the sovereignâ€”my master is a papermaker, and has large mills; he is a gentleman all the same for thatâ€”the veterinary surgeon who valued the horses is hereâ€”I have ridden them with a saddle two or three timeâ€”I next saw the prisoner at Vine-street.

HENRY DORKIN . I live at Upper Tooting, and am a private gentlemanâ€”Mr. Joynson is an intimate friend of mineâ€”he gave me, on 1st April, what money he had, about 90l., and asked me to pay for these horses; I made up the amount, 115 guineas, and met his servant at the prisoner's stable by appointmentâ€”the prisoner was sent for by the groom who had charge of the

horses, and on his coming, I said that I came on the part of Mr. Joynson to pay for the horsesâ€”he said that they were horses which he had a great regard for, he had had them some time, they were quiet to ride and drive in single and double harness, and had been used by his daughter and wife, but on account of ill health he no longer wanted them, haying another pair which were more suitable for his purpose; and he spoke of Leamington, in War
wickshire, where he had some place or estate, and where the horses were very well knownâ€”the other person was dressed as a groom; he had a blue coat with bright buttons, and when I asked fur Mr. Sinclair, he said he would fetch his master, and went away, and returned with the prisoner, who gave directions to him as a groom, saying, "Mind you feed them before they go out of the stable," and the groom said, "Yes, Sir"â€”I paid the 115l. 10s., and he gave me this receipt on black-edged paper, "1, Russel-court, St. James's, 1st April, 1862. Received of W. Joynson, Esq., 115l. 10s., for my two grey geldings, which I hereby warrant sound and free from vice or blemish of any kind, and if not approved of in one or three months, I will take them back at the price I now receive for them. Henry Sinclair"â€”I should not have parted with the money if I had not believed that he was not a horse-dealer, but that they were his own private propertyâ€”I believed his state
ment that they were used in his own familyâ€”he said that it was usual to give a gratuity to the grooms eachâ€”I said, "Very well, I shall give your groom a sovereign"â€”he said, "I shall do the like."

Cross-examined. Q. Your authority was simply to pay the money and get the receipt? A. The receipt and the warrantyâ€”I had nothing to do with exercising any judgment about itâ€”the prisoner told me about Leamington before the money was paid, and I do not think he mentioned it afterwards.

WILLIAM JOYNSON . I live at St. Mary Cravâ€”I sent my servant, James Jones, up to London, in consequence of an advertisement I saw in the Times, on 31st March, to look at a pair of geldingsâ€”he came back and said that he had seen a pair of very fine horses belonging to a gentleman who had considerable property at Leamington, who had lately lost his wife, whose daughter was very ill, and under the care of some of our great professional men; in consequence of which these horses were useless to him, and he wished to get rid of them, having a pair of cobs which would answer his purposeâ€”my man's impression was that he was a gentleman, that all was right, and therefore he never tried the horses, as he ought, as the prisoner said when he asked for the carriage to try the horses, that it had been sold, and they had no harnessâ€”I paid the 115l. 10s. in consequence of the im
pression made on my mind that they were really valuable, good horses; that it was a gentleman who wished to give them up; that they had been driven two years; that one of them had been ridden by his daughter; and that they were worth the moneyâ€”I had not time to go to London to buy themâ€”I should not have bought them had I known the prisoner to be a dealer.

Cross-examined. Q. Have they been tried? A. No, because my coach-man could not get them alongâ€”I sent them to a farm-house to a gentleman, who has driven one of them, but the other he cannot get to go at allâ€”it was in consequence of the report of my groom that I gave Mr. Dorkin the money to pay for themâ€”I have never applied to get the money from the prisoner, because I could not find himâ€”I have never spoken to him yetâ€”I do not know that an offer was made to return the money.

EDWARD WHITE (Policeman, D 16). I took the prisoner, on 12th April, in Whitefriars, and told him I apprehended him on a charge of obtaining 115l. 10s. from Mr. Joynson, of St. Marv's Cra on the sale of two horses

â€”he said, "What horses?"â€”I said, "That pair of greys at Russel-court"â€”he said, "You are quite mistaken"â€”I said, "I shall take you on suspicion of being the man"â€”he said that he had never sold any horses thereâ€”I have known him between four and five years by the names of Tom Cook and Old Tom, and have seen him, on an average, two or three times a week regu
larly, and some weeks every dayâ€”I have seen him showing horses, and about places where I have seen horses advertised for saleâ€”I believe he has a wife, but he has no daughter to my knowledge.

JOHH LUND . I have been chief superintendent of police at Leamington between three and four yearsâ€”previous to that I was a superintendent in London, where I knew the prisoner, but I have never seen him in Learning
tonâ€”I knew him for seventeen or eighteen years in London by the name of Cook, and connected with horse-chauntersâ€”I know Leamington wellâ€”he has no estate there.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you ever see him sell a horse in your life? A. Noâ€”I was twenty-four years in the metropolitan policeâ€”I knew the prisoner to be the constant associate of a horse-chaunter, who I had con
victed at this Courtâ€”a horse-chaunter is a penon who sells broken-winded horsesâ€”I know all the rateable property in Leamington, because the poor
rate book is kept in my officeâ€”that gives the occupiers, but the owners' names are also insertedâ€”the book is not hereâ€”I do not know all the owners, but I know all those of the name of Cookâ€”there are four Cooks, but no Sinclair; I have searched the book within these three days to seeâ€”Leamington is all one parishâ€”it extends half a mile into the country on each side, but it is all in the parish.
COURT. Q. If the prisoner had constantly driven a pair of horses there, must you have seen them? A. Yes.
PHILIP ROCK . I am a veterinary surgeon, of Chelsfield, in Kentâ€”on 4th April, I saw a pair of grey horses at Mr. Joynson'sâ€”they were not sound; they were both roarers.

Cross-examined. Q. How did you try them? A. By giving them a little more exertion than walking exerciseâ€”I had them exercised up and down the road, on purpose to listen to their windâ€”a horse may not be a very good one, and yet a roarerâ€”roarers are used by their owners, but they are not valuedâ€”they are not very fit subjects for racingâ€”I never knew a roarer run a raceâ€”I do not know that a roarer ran for the Two thousand, a few days ago.

WILLIAM RITCHIE . I reside at Staines, and am managing clerk to Mr. May, of Russel-squareâ€”I have known the prisoner seven years, under the names of Mr. W. T. Cook, the Rev. Mr. Clark, and Mr. Sinclair, engaged in selling horsesâ€”I saw him on each occasion.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you mean that you yourself were engaged with him in selling horses? A. No; I was employed to bring actions against himâ€”on the first occasion he told me that he had sold a horse; on the second he offered me a horse; and on the third he offered me these very horses which Mr. Joynson boughtâ€”that was about the beginning of Aprilâ€”the last time was about four years before that, and the first time was seven years ago.

NICHOLAS ROBERT BROWN . I am a colonel in the army, and live at 4, Cleveland-row, St. James'sâ€”the prisoner hired this stable of me, personally, in the name of John Clarkâ€”I sent the agreement to him, which he returned to me signed, and I gave him his copy to keepâ€”it is dated 25th February, but I think he took possession a day or two before, as
he was anxious to get his horses inâ€”he has not given up possessionâ€”the stables are locked, and he left the place altogether somewhere about 1st April.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you the agreement here? A. Yes, that and a note he wrote me is the only mode I have of knowing his nameâ€”the agreement is for a year, but the rent is payable in six months.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. Is this (produced) the note he wrote to you? A. This is the note I receivedâ€”I do not know whose writing it is, but it is a similar siguature to that on the agreementâ€”when I saw him before the agreement was signed, he gave the name of John Clark.

JOHN CHARLES AUSTIN . I am an officer of the Court of Bankruptcyâ€”I produce the proceedings in the bankruptcy of a person named William Thomas Cookâ€”he is the petitioner himselfâ€”he signs the petition.

GEORGE PHILPOTT . I am managing-clerk to Messrs. Aldridge and Brom
ley, the Crown Solicitors in Bankruptcyâ€”I know the prisoner; but as to whether he is William Thomas Cook, I cannot sayâ€”I have seen him in Whitecross-street Prisonâ€”these proceedings relate to the bankruptcy of William Thomas Cook, who I believe to be the prisonerâ€”(The petition was dated March 17th, 1862, from William Thomas Cook, commission agent, a prisoner in Whitecross-street, of 13, Princes-street, and of Lambeth, in the County of Surrey; which was accompained by his affidavit, stating that he had not the meant of paying the fees.)

JOHN CHARLES AUSTIN (Cross-examined). Q. Is he not compelled, under the new Act, to petition? A. Not at allâ€”it is not one of the cases where the Registrars went to clear the gaolsâ€”there would be no petition thereâ€”the prisoner was not there when the Registrar went, but the Registrar might go again after the prisoner had filed his petitionâ€”I believe it is not usual to ascertain whether a bankrupt has given the right addressâ€”he has to swear to the truth of it.

EDWARD WHITE (re-examined). I found this paper in the prisoner's pocketâ€”(This was a protection order of the Court of Bankruptcy to William Thomas Cook, dated 6th April, 1862.)
GUILTY. **â€”Recommended to mercy by the Jury on account of his age.
The officer stated that the prisoner had been three times charged with similar offences, but had compromised the matter by return
ing the money, and that he had had Seven Years' Penal Servitude for stealing a horse and chaise and harness.

505.
CHARLES SIMMONDS (18)
, Embezzling 1l. 4s. 5d. the property of
Francis James, his master, having been before convicted; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

506.
ROBERT JAMES PARISH (24)
, Embezzling 10l. the property of
Edward Homenham Cox, his master; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY.â€”Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor. â€”
Confined Nine Months.

507.
THOMAS WILLIAMS (19)
, Stealing 1 glass shade and stand, and 22 pencils, the property of
Frederick Charles Fisher and another, having been before convicted; to which he
PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Eighteen Months.

508.
CHARLES TAPSON (16)
, Embezzling the sums of 1s.â€”1s. and 7 1/2 d. the moneys of
George Hollis Brett, his master; to which he
PLEADED GUILTY .â€”and the officer stated that he had been embmling small sums all the time he had been at Mr. Brett's.â€”
Confined Six Months

div0.p: PRESENT.â€”Mr. Ald. FINNIS; Mr. Ald GABRIEL; Mr. Ald. DAKIN;

div1.p:
509.
DANIEL CATER, (23),
WILLIAM HAYES (23),
JOHN QUINLAN (25),
JOHN REGAN (29), and
DAVID SHEHAN (23), were indicted for
a riot, and assaulting
William Milsom and
Charles Harding; to which they
PLEADED GUILTY .

SHEHAN.**â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

REGAN.â€”
Confined Nine Months.

CATER, HAYES, and QUINLAN.â€”
Confined Six Months each

510.
JOHN MCIVAN (25)
, Breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
George Haanant, and stealing therein 1 watch, 1 coat, and other articles, his property, having been previously convicted; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY . **â€”
Five Years' Penal Servitude.

511.
MARY MCNELLY (30)
, Stealing 1 purse, 3 postage-stamps, a piece of foreign silver coin, and 5s. 11d. in money, the property of
Emma Thurston, having been previously convicted; to which she

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

512.
MICHAEL TOOLE (40)
, Breaking and entering the shop of
Thomas West, and stealing 8 chains, value 20l. his property; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

513.
JOHN WILLIAMS (28)
, Feloniously assaulting
Charles Winter, and stealing from his penon 1 brooch, his property.

CHARLES WINTER . I live at 13, Sydenham-park, and am a gentlemanâ€”on 14th March I was at the corner of New Oxford-street, about ten minutes to 10 at night, waiting for an omnibusâ€”the prisoner seized me by the coat, and then, with his right hand, I think, he took a valuable brooch form my scarf, and then struck at me and I fell on the groundâ€”it was a thrusting hit from him, not a severe blowâ€”he turned and ran away immediatelyâ€”I saw him within two minutes afterwards in custodyâ€”I was shook very muchâ€”when I got up he was in custody of the policeâ€”I am quite sure he is the man.
Prisoner. You were in liquor, and there was a crowd of people round you.

Witness. I was not in liquor at all; it is not true that I was drunk and that the bus man would not take me; there were several people round watting for omnibuses; I was not flourishing my umbrella about, but merely holding it in my hand; I could have caught you if my hand had been at liberty; my umbrella was not up; merely by my side; it was not raining.

WILLIAM SMALLMAN . I live near Gray's-inn-lane, and am a porterâ€”on 14th March I was coming down by New Oxford-street about 10 o'clockâ€”I saw the prisoner take a brooch out of Mr. Winter's scarfâ€”Mr. Winter fell downâ€”the prisoner ran away, and I ran after him from the corner of Tottenham-court-road to the corner of Crown-streetâ€”I had him in sight all the while

â€”I put out my hand to catch him, but missed him, and he ranâ€”I caught him a second time and we struggled togetherâ€”he tried all he could to get away, but I was his masterâ€”he tried to kick me, but missed the first time, the second time he kicked me violently between the legsâ€”he aimed the blow there; and he also tried to kick me a third timeâ€”when he was on the ground he tried to bite me, but could notâ€”I was a-top of him when police
man, E 32, came upâ€”we were both on the groundâ€”I did not see anything of the broochâ€”he was taken in custodyâ€”if I had looked for brooch I should have lost himâ€”I am all right now, but I have lost my situation through attending the Court, and have been out a month and four days.
Prisoner. It is quite false; he knocked me down directly he got hold of me, and put both his knees on my chest.
Witness. That is not true.

EDWARD FISHER (Police-sergeant, E 32). I saw the prisoner running near New Oxford-street and the last witness after himâ€”I went in pursuit, and when I got up, I found Smallman and the prisoner on the ground, kicking at him, I took the prisoner in custodyâ€”I saw nothing of the brooch.

GUILTY . â€ â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

p.hi: The Court directed a reward of 2 l. to be given to Smallman.

div1.p:
514.
RICHARD HEALEY (22)
, Feloniously forging and uttering a request for the payment of 3l. 6s. with intent to defraud.

THEOPHILUS WESTHORPE . I live at the Manor House, East India-roadâ€”on 12th April the prisoner brought this paper (produced) and showed it to me to obtain the moneyâ€”my clerk was presentâ€”I said, "I do not think this is Captain Whitney's writing; I am sure it is not"â€”he said, "No; Captain Whitney did not write it, but he signed it; I got another man to write it, and he blamed the man for writing it so badly"â€”he went on to say that Captain Whitney was suffering from severe rheumatism, which I knew to be the caseâ€”I said I had men on board the ship which Captain Whitney commanded, could they identify himâ€”he said, "I was not at work on board the ship, but at Captain Whitney's private house"â€”believing that to be his signature, I ultimately directed Mr. Taylor, my clerk, to give him the moneyâ€”I had seen the prisoner beforeâ€”he gave the name of Russell

ANDREW MURRAY TAYLOR . I am clerk to the last witnessâ€”I was present when the prisoner brought this paperâ€”I have heard what Mr. Westhorpe has said about itâ€”that is correctâ€”he said that he was working at Captain Whitney's private houseâ€”I am pay-clerk, and gave him the moneyâ€”I saw him again and got back the money, and then got Mr. Westhorpe's authority and paid it a second timeâ€”I paid him 3l. 6s.â€”Mr. Westhorpe was not in when I first paid; it then I got the money back and afterwards paid it a second time.

THOMAS CHARLES WHITNEY . I am captain of the ship Southampton belonging to New York, and now lying in the London Docksâ€”this paper purports to be an order by me upon Mr. Westhorpeâ€”it is not my writingâ€”I did not write it, or authorise anybody to write itâ€”I had never seen it before I saw it in Mr. Westhorpe's possessionâ€”I have known the prisoner for yearsâ€”he has been about the shipsâ€”he would know me certainlyâ€”he worked for me several timesâ€”I never gave him any authority to get or transact anything relating to this order.

HENRY EDGILL (Policeman, K 318). On 17th April I took the prisoner in custody, and said he was charged with forging an order on Mr. Westhorpeâ€”he said, on the way to the station, "I am guilty of it"â€”at the station he
said that if Mr. Westhorpe would take it, he would pay it weekly by instalments.
Prisoner's Defence. I was intoxicated at the time.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

515.
ALEXANDER STOCKMAN (37)
, Embezzling and stealing a note of the
Bank of France, for the payment of 100 francs; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”MR. SLEIGH, for the prosecution, stated that the prisoner had given up the note immediately on being taxed with it. MR. METCALFE, for the prisoner, stated that he had for a long time borne a very respectable character.â€”
Confined Three Months

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. Ald. FINNIS; Mr. Ald. GIBBONS; and ROBERT MALCOLM KERR, Esq.

div1.p:
516.
CHARLES PINKSTONE (19), was indicted
for feloniously forging and uttering 2 orders for the payment of 200l. and 100l. respec
tively, with intent to defraud; to both which he
PLEADED GUILTY .

p.hi: Roger Godson, solicitor, Steven Hugh Price, solicitor, and John Simms, solicitor, in each of whose employment the prisoner had been as clerk, deposed to his good character. Recommended to mercy by the prosecutor, believing it to be his first offence, and that he had been led astray by bad associates.

div1.p:
517.
JOHN COOPER (33)
, Stealing 5 bottles of oil, and other articles, value 4l. 9s. the property of
William Valentine Wright and another; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

518.
THOMAS TOMLINSON (20)
, Stealing a handkerchief of a man unknown, from his person, having been before convicted; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY . **â€”
Six Years' Penal Servitude.

p.hi: It was stated that the prisoner had been seven times previously convicted.

div1.p:
519.
THOMAS PAPWORTH (23)
, Stealing 60 yards of ribbon, value 30s. the property of
Thomas Sutton and another, having been before con
victed; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Ten Years' Penal Servitude.

p.hi: A Warder from the House of Correction stated that the prisoner had been eleven times previously convicted.

div1.p:
520.
ELIZA EVANS (28)
, Stealing a watch, value 8l. the property of
Thomas Lithgow, from his person; to which she

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

521.
THOMAS WALTERS (24)
, Stealing 1 watch, value 10l. the property of
Frederick Clarke, from his person, having been before con
victed; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY **â€ â€”
Ten Years' Penal Servitude.

p.hi: The prisoner had been twice before convicted, besides ten summary convictions.

div1.p:
522.
EDWARD GISS (17), and
HENRY JOHNSON (18)
, Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Edward Pritchard and another,and stealing therein 2 bags, value 4d. and 49l. in money, their property. Second Count, Feloniously receiving the same.

WILLIAM SMITH . I am a detective City-officerâ€”on 26th April, at a quarter to 9 in the morning, I was sent for to Messrs. Pritchard and Burton's, and found that an entrance had been effected by the removal of a pane of glass, after which a hand had been put through to remove the sash, by which means a person had got inâ€”there is a high wall in St. John's-court, adjoining the premises, from that to the window is a wall with iron spikes at the topâ€”they had got on to the palisades, tied a rope to them, and let themselves down to the windowâ€”three desks had been broken open, one in the private counting-house, and two in the clerks counting-houseâ€”I found in the yard two pairs of socks, and a bit of a lucifer-match under the kitchen windowâ€”these two pieces of matches were handed to me in the counting-houseâ€”they have been lightedâ€”I cut the rope from the railings, and took it to the stationâ€”I received this chisel from Mr. Burtonâ€”Inspector Leonard examined the floor with me, he was then going to Camomile-street, and on my way to the station I accompanied him to Jewin-street, and when we were at the Fore-street end, I saw the prisoners and another person on the other side of the wayâ€”it was then about 10 o'clockâ€”they had new boots on, and I thought new caps as wellâ€”I followed them into Aldersgate-street, to the end of Edmund's-place, where there is a pawnbroker's shopâ€”Giss went in at the side door, and Johnson and the other man stood at the end of the place; I passed them and then went into the lobby of the pawnbroker's, and saw Giss present a duplicate to the pawn-broker's assistantâ€”I went in front of the shop to look what the duplicate related to, and found it related to a coatâ€”I went back to the box where Giss was, and beckoned him out into the passageâ€”I told him I was an officer and should like to know where he got the money from to buy those boots with which he was wearingâ€”he said, "I worked for it and saved it"â€”I said, "Where do you work?"â€”he said Taylor and Greenings, of Grey-stock-placeâ€”I said, "You have got some parties waiting outside for you at the end of the place"â€”he said, "I have not"â€”I said "You have, for I saw you come together along Jewin-street"â€”he said, "I have never been near Jewin-street this morning"â€”I said, "Go in and get your coat"â€”he went into the box, and I stepped aside and beckoned to Johnson, who came up to meâ€”I told him I was an officer, and should like to know where he got the money from, to buy the new boots he was wearing?â€”he said, "Worked for it and saved it, to be sure"â€”I said, "You are waiting for some one here"â€”he said, "I am not"â€”I said, "You are, for I saw you come along Jewin-street together"â€”he said, "I am not waiting for any
body"â€”I caught hold of his collar, and we commenced struggling, he lifted up his fist but I stopped the blowâ€”while the struggle was going on, Giss came out with the coat under his arm, and I then noticed that his left
hand trousers pocket was very bulky, I put my hand on it and it appeared to contain moneyâ€”the assisant came to my assistance, and ultimately Gale, No. 670, seeing the struggle, came up, and we took the prisoners; Johnson endeavoured to put his hand into his pocketâ€”I told him, on the way to the station, that I should charge them on suspicion of committing a burglary, at Messrs, Pritchard's, King-street, Snow-hillâ€”they both said "We will make you prove it, and you shall pay for this"â€”I searched Giss at the station, and found, in the watch-pocket of his trousers, this bag con
taining 15l. 10s. in gold, and in his pocket I found 7l. 13s. 9 1/2 d. in silver

and copperâ€”I also found this key on himâ€”they were asked at the station where they got the money, they said that they had saved itâ€”I saw Johnson searched, and 21l. 7s. 6 1/2 d. I think, found on him, 13l. of it was in goldâ€”Mr. Burton said that he thought the bag found on Johnson was his, but that some of his clerks would be able to identify it no doubt, when Johnson said "That is my aunt's bag"â€”the prisoners both refused to give their addressesâ€”the fourpenny and threepenny bits found on them both, amounted to 4l. 19s. 6d.â€”this one with a hole in the centre was found on Gissâ€”I have ascertained Giss' address, but could hear nothing of him at the place he said that he worked at; I met Mr. Taylorâ€”I know him personally.
Johnson. I bought the boots of Mr. Gees, of Golden-lane, on the Friday. Witness. They were bought that morning before 10 o'clock.

ELIJAH GALE (City-policeman, 670). I was called about 10 o'clock, and found Johnson struggling with the pawnbroker's assistant outside the shop-doorâ€”he got away, but I stopped himâ€”I took him to the station, searched him, and found 8l. 7s. 6d. in silver in this canvas bag in the inside breast pocket of his coat, and in his trousers pocket this tobacco pouch containing 13l. in gold, 6 1/2 d. in copper, and a little tobaccoâ€”he refused his address.

ALFRED BURTON . I am a tobacconist and cigar manufacturer, at 33, King-street, Snow-hill, in St. Sepulchre's parishâ€”I have one partnerâ€”we have a housekeeper named Susannah Reedâ€”there is a warehouse door leading to the street, and a private door at the side of itâ€”St. Johns-court runs at the side of our premises, and we have a pair of gates into itâ€”on the night of 25th April, I left the premises secure, leaving the housekeeper thereâ€”the window which was afterwards broken, was then shut and boltedâ€”next morning, at a little after 8, I found a burglary had been committed and the desks broken open, but some of our people were there before meâ€”I ultimately missed nearly 50l. and a cigar case, from a desk in the private counting-houseâ€”I missed coppers to the amount of 8s. or 9s., and a small bag containing 7s. 6d. in silverâ€”it was not broken open, it had not been lockedâ€”the traveller's desk had been broken open, and a bag of cash taken away which had been brought home the previous nightâ€”I found a chisel in a disk, and gave it to the constableâ€”a box of cigars was also taken away.

CHARLES REED . I am clerk to Messrs. Pritchard and Burtonâ€”on 26th April, at 8 o'clock, I went to the premises, and was admitted by the house
keeperâ€”her apartments are distinct from the warehouse and shopâ€”I was the first to arrive, I opened the shop-door leading from the passage, and saw a parcel of tobacco, about 11b. lying on the counting-house floorâ€”a window was broken, and two of the clerk's desks forcedâ€”everything was left in the same state until Mr. Burton arrivedâ€”I afterwards missed the traveller's money, which had been deposited there the night before, to the extent of about 50l.â€”the tills were empty, except a few stray coinsâ€”one till, of which I had the charge, which had contained about 30s. in silver, loose, was entirely empty.

WILLIAM HENRY SAUNDERS . I am a traveller to Messrs. Pritchard and Burtonâ€”on Friday evening, 25th April, I left in my desk 23l. 7s. in gold and silver, and 5s. in copper; there might have been 5s. or 6l. in silverâ€”the money was in this bag (The one found on Giss)â€”I have not the slightest doubt of itâ€”I have had it under my eye every day for three monthsâ€”next morning I found my desk broken open, and the money goneâ€”there were a number of 3d. or 4d. pieces; one 4d. piece had a hole in it similar to this, it attracted my attention when taken.
Giss. I bought this bag down the lane, and gave a halfpenny for it. Witness. It has never been out of my possession from the time it was new, nearly three months.

WILLIAM GURNEY . I am a traveller to Meesrs Pritchardâ€”on 25th April, I deposited in my desk 21l. 4s. 6d.; there was a quantity of silver among it and a great many 4d. and 3d. piecesâ€”I found the desk broken open next morning and the money goneâ€”a great many of the 4d. pieces were in a paper and some in a bag of this description, but this is not the bag.
GEORGE WOOD . I am clerk to Messrs. Pritchardâ€”I imaged 7s. 6d. in a bag from the desk in the inner counting-houseâ€”this is the bag, I have not the least doubt of it.
JOHNSON. Q. I am positive it does not belong to you; how can you prove it? A. From it's general appearance, and it only having one string most of our bags have two.

THOMAS IRVING (City-policeman, 267). On the night of the 25th, about 11 o'clock, I was near Messrs. Pritchard's premises, and saw Giss and six or seven others, standing about two yards from St. John's-court, and a hundred yards from the place where somebody afterwards got inâ€”I did not notice who the others wereâ€”about 3 o'clock in the morning Johnson came up to me in St. John's-court, about the same place as I saw the othersâ€”I go up St. John's-court into West-street.
JOHNSON. I was never there at all. Witness. I am sure of you both.
Giss' Defence. I saved the money up. I used to go out with a cart selling fruit. I got it by hard work.
Johnson's Defence. I saved up the money with the intention of buying stock for the winter.

GUILTY on the second Count *â€ â€”
Four Years' each Penal Servitude.

523.
DAVID HAYES (34)
, Feloniously uttering a forged 10l. Bank of England note; also a forged 5l. note, with intent to defraud; having been before convicted; to both of which he

PLEADED GUILTY.â€”
Eight Years' Penal Servitude.

524.
THOMAS JARVIS (40)
, Feloniously uttering a forged 5l. Bank of England note; also another forged 5l. Bank of England note; also feloniously having in his custody 2 forged Bank of England notes, having been before convicted at this court, in October, 1853; to all of which he

PLEAED GUILTY .â€”
Six Years' Penal Servitude.

525.
JOHN AYRES (23)
, Feloniously cutting and wounding Edward Page, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm; he

PLEADED GUILTY to unlawfully wounding. â€”
Confined Twelve Months

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. Ald. CHALLIS; Mr. Ald. ABBESS; and Mr. COMMON

div1.p:
526.
GEORGE CHAPMAN (46)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin, having other counterfeit coin in his possession; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Fifteen Months.

527.
WILLIAM BURGESS (56)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin twice within ten days; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months

528.
ELIZA M'DONALD (28)
, Feloniously uttering counterfeit coin.
MESSRS. CRAWFORD and COOKE conducted the Prosecution.

ELIZABETH NORMAN . I am the wife of William Henry Norman, who keepe the Queen's Arms, at Knight's bridgeâ€”on Saturday, 19th April, the prisoner came to the bar, between 8 and 9 in the evening, and called for a half-quartern of gin, which came to 2 1/2 d., and tendered a bad crownâ€”I bent it in the detector, which made a mark on the edge of itâ€”I said that it was bad, and returned it to the prisoner, as she said that she had taken it for wages having drank a little of the gin, she put down a penny for it, took up the crown, and leftâ€”I sent my waiter after her.

MARY MOORE . I am barmaid at the Rising Sun, at Knightsbridgeâ€”I was serving in the bar on 19th April, between 7 and 8 o'clock in the evening, and a woman named Hopkins came in, and asked for three-halfpennyworth of rum,â€”I served her; she tendered a bad half-crownâ€”I told her it was badâ€”she said nothing, but turned and went out of the houseâ€”she had drank the rum, but did not pay for itâ€”I kept the half-crown and gave it to Mrs. Williams, the landlady; it was given to the oonstable the same evening.

JOHN CLARK (Policeman, A 273). On Saturday night, 19th April, I was on duty in the neighbourhood of Knightsbridge, near the Queen's Arms public-house, and in consequence of something that was said to me, I watched the prisonerâ€”she was alone; she stood against the barracks for twenty-five minutes or half an hourâ€”I had followed her about two hundred yardsâ€”the then crossed the road, in company with Hopkins and a man named Johnson, and they went towards Kensingtonâ€”Johnson went to the Rising Sun public-house, and M'Donald and Hopkins went on to the Trevor public-house, about a hundred yards from the Rising Sunâ€”I went up to them, and said to the prisoner, "I shall take you in custody for attempting to past a bad 5s. piece to Mrs. Normanâ€”she said she had not been anywhere, but I saw her hand move and saw something dropâ€”I picked up a 5s. piece and a halfpenny, close to where she was standingâ€”I said, "I expect this is the bad 5s. piece you have been to Mr. Norman's with"â€”she made no replyâ€”I said to Hopkins, "I shall take you in custody for passing a bad half-crown at the Sun, Mr. Williams'"â€”she said she had not been thereâ€”Johnson then came up; I took him and told him it was for being concerned with the two women in uttering counterfeit coinâ€”he said he did not know them, and had patted no bad moneyâ€”I searched Johnson at the Sun and found on him a florin, six shillings, eight sixpences, two 3d. pieces, a 4d. piece, and 1s. 3 1/2 d. in copper, all good moneyâ€”on M'Donald was found a basket and tome bread; this half-crown (produced) was given to me by Mary Moore.
ELZABETH HARMAN (re-examined). This half-crown is the same that I bent in the detector.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . This is a bad half-crown.
Prisoner's Defence. I hope you will have mercy on me, it it my first time.
GUILTY .â€”She was further charged with having been before convicted.

JAMES GALL (Policeman, N 276). I produce a certificateâ€”(Read: "Central Criminal Court, May, 1859. Eliza M'Donald, convicted of feloniously uttering counterfeit coin.â€” Confined One Year)â€”The prisoner it the personâ€”I was the constable in the case, and was so also when she was convicted in 1858.
Prisoner. I never was convicted before.
GUILTY.

529.
ELIZA M'DONALD was again indicted, with
ANN HOPKINS (25), and
CHARLES JOHNSON (30)
, for unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

p.hi: The evidence of Mary Moore, Elizabeth Nortnan, and John Clark, given in the former case, was read over to them, to which they assented.

div1.p: COURT to JOHN CLARK. Q. What did she say when you charged her with passing the half-crown at the Rising Sun? A. She said, "I have not been in the house at all."
MR. COOKE. Q. Were you in uniform? A. You; it was about half-past 9 when I saw then together.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . This crown and half-crown are bad
Hopkin's Defence. I have no knowledge of either Johnson or M'Donald.
Johnson's Defence. I deny all knowledge of it, and I knew nothing about these two women. I was going home to my lodging.

M'DONALDâ€”
GUILTY . *â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

HOPKINSâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

JOHNSONâ€”
NOT GUITLY .

530.
WILLAM ATKINS (18), was indicted
for a like offence.

JOHN TUNBRIDGE . I am a clerk in the money-order office, Chancery-laneâ€”on Wednesday, 30th April, between 2 and 4 o'clock, the prisoner came and asked for three shilling's worth of postage stampsâ€”he gave me a half-crown and two threepenny-pieces, and leftâ€”I directly took up the half-crown, and detected that it was counterfeitâ€”I put it by itself, and next morning gave it to the policeman F 178â€”next day, Thursday, 1st May, the prisoner came again, about half-past 12, and asked for three shilling's worth of stampsâ€”I recognised him immediatelyâ€”I gave him the stamps, and he put down three shillingsâ€”I looked at themâ€”one was counterfeit, two were goodâ€”I told him I had been anxiously waiting, and wanted to see him, for he gave me a bad half-crown last nightâ€”he said he had never been at the shop beforeâ€”I detained him, and gave him in custody with the bad shilling.
Prisoner. I was never the shop on the Wednesday.

JAMES STANLEY EYRE (Policeman, F 198). The prisoner was given into my charge on 1st May, by the last witness, with this half-crown and shilling (produced)â€”the prisoner said that he had never been in the shop before; that a gentleman who was standing over the way at the corner of Bream's-buildings had sent him for three shilling's worth of postage stamps, and that if he got them he would give him 6d.â€”I looked, but there was no one thereâ€”on the prisoner was found two good shillings, two halfpennies, and a tobacco-box.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . This half-crown and shilling are counterfeit.
Prisoner's Defence. I never passed any had money anywere. I always got my living honestly; I have got masters to prove it. The two shillings on me were two of the three shillings.
COURT to JOHN TUNBRIDGE. Q. Did you return the two shillings to him?
A. Yes.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

531.
WILLIAM MILMAN (28), was indicted
for a like offence.
THOMAS ROGERS . I keep a beer-shop, at 46, Stafford-street, Maryleboneâ€”on Wednesday, 30th April, the prisoner came there between 9 and 10, I

should say, at night, and asked for a glass of ale, which I gave himâ€”it came to 2d.â€”he put down a florin, and I gave him changeâ€”he drank about half the ale, and left with the changeâ€”I then examined the florin, and found it was counterfeitâ€”I put it in a bureau, where there were shillings and sixpences, but no florin or half-crown, and kept it by itself till Friday sight, 2d May, when he came again, and asked for a glass of aleâ€”I drew it, and be gave me a florin, which I was quite certain was bad; I tried itâ€”I went out from the bar, took hold of his collar, and said, "How many more of this sort have you got?"â€”he seemed confused, and did not know how to answerâ€”he said, "What do you mean?" or something to that effectâ€”I said that he had passed another on me the night before lastâ€”he made no replyâ€”I sent for a constable, detained the prisoner, and gave him in custody with the two florins.

ANN ROGERS . I am the wife of the last witness, who also keeps a tobacconist's shop, No. 47, next door to the beer shopâ€”I always attend to the tobacconist's shopâ€”on Thursday, 1st May, the prisoner came for half an ounce of tobacco, and gave me a shilling, and I gave him 10 1/2 d. changeâ€”I put the shilling in the till for a moment till he was gone, and then took it out and examined itâ€”there was no other shilling in the tillâ€”I found it was bad, and gave it to the policeman on the Saturdayâ€”I did not put it in the drawer again.

WILLIAM FARLEY (Policeman, D 297). On 2d May, the prisoner was given into my custody on a charge of uttering counterfeit coin, and I re
ceived these two counterfeit florins (produced) from Mr. Rogers, and next day I received from Mrs. Rogers, his wife, this shilling (produced)â€”I searched the prisoner, and found on him a penny, a key, a knife, and some tobacco.

WILLIAM WEBSTER . These coins are badâ€”the two florins are from the same mould. The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate was here read as follows: "I deny being at that man's house on Wednesday, or on May 1st. I was at the Exhibition on 1st May."

Prisoner's Defence. On the Tuesday evening, as I was returning home, I met three men, who asked me to go to a concert in Vauxhall-road; they said they would pay my share. We went, and stopped very late, and I drank too much, and was very ill the next morning. I went that afternoon to Notting-hill, and stopped there all the afternoon. As I was coming back, I met my brother, and stopped with him till about a quarter to 9, when I left him, and went to a house in Piccadilly to have some stout. I went home, and was in bed before the dock struck 10. On Thursday we started from home at half-past 10 to go to the Exhibition, where we remained till half-past 6 in the evening, and then my wife went home. I went to St. James's-street, and stayed there till about half-past 9. On the Friday, I went out to try and get something to do. I went up to the Edgeware-road. A man said, "I will give you half-a-crown and something to drink if you will help beat these carpets." I said, "Very well." It was about half-past 1. We stopped till nearly half-past 6, and then came back as far as Port-man-market, where I said, "I can't go any further," and we parted. He gave me the half-crown, and I bought threepenny worth of cheese with it, and received a two shilling-piece and a threepenny-piece change. I went to St. John's-wood, where I stopped about two hours and a half, and then I came back by this man's house, and, feeling rather thirsty, I went in and asked for a glass of the best ale. He drew it, and I was going to drink it when I saw him looking at something in his hand on the other side of the

bar. I was going to ask him if it was a bad coin, but he came round and collared me, and gave me in custody. I have a seven years character from one of my employers, and it is not likely I should forfeit that for a two shilling piece.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

532.
GEORGE GREEN (15), was indicted
for a like offence.

HENRY JAMES PAXTON . On 22d April, I was at home at my father's, for the holidays; I generally go to schoolâ€”my father is a stationer, and sells receipt stampsâ€”on 22d April, about half-past 12 in the day, I was in the shopâ€”the prisoner came in, and asked for a pound's worth of receipt stampsâ€”I got them, and was folding them up when my father came up to the counter.

WILLIAM PAXTON . The shop at 23, Skinner-street is mineâ€”on 22d April I was in the shop, and saw the prisoner come in, and heard him ask for some receipt stampsâ€”my son went to get them, and they were brought to the prisonerâ€”I asked the prisoner for the money, and he threw down what appeared to be a sovereign, which I at once perceived to be spuriousâ€”I took it up, and found it was badâ€”I did not tell him it was badâ€”I said, "Who are the stamps for?"â€”he said they were for himselfâ€”I said, "What are you going to do with them?"â€”he said, "To send them to my brother at the Cape of Good Hope"â€”I said, "Where did you get the money from?"â€”he said he had saved it upâ€”I called in a police-constable, and gave the prisoner in custodyâ€”I said nothing about the sovereign being bad, I felt so convinced he knew itâ€”I gave it to the policemanâ€”I stood at the door when I called the policeman inâ€”the prisoner made no answer as to where he got the sovereign from.

JOHN BAKER (City-policeman, 255). I was called into the shop, and the prisoner was given into my custodyâ€”I took him to the station, searched him, and found on him a good two shilling-piece, two shillings, a sixpence, a threepenny-piece, and 5 1/2 d. in coppersâ€”I asked him how he came by the sovereignâ€”he said the same as to Mr. Paxtonâ€”I asked him whereâ€”he said, "45, Charles-street, Drury-lane"â€”I asked him what his father wasâ€”he said, "a tailor," and that he was known at 45, Drury-lane, by the name of Cloggerâ€”a small key was found on him, which I took there, and it opened a box belonging to a boy named Cloggerâ€”I could not learn anything of any George Green, who occupied that roomâ€”I received this sovereign (produced) from the last witness.

Prisoner. Where I was lodging, they did not know me by the name of Green, but by a nickname; the landlord knew me by the name of Green. Witness. It was the landlord that I sawâ€”I do not know the difference between the landlord and the deputy landlordâ€”it ia a very low lodging houseâ€”the policeman with me said the person I saw was the landlordâ€”the box was a small one; this is the key.

Prisoner. I was called Clogger because I wore a pair of clogs at one time. The box was what I kept my clothes in. My father is a tailor. I used to work with him; he could not maintain me, and I left him and went to sell fish.

WILLIAM WEBSTER . This is a bad sovereignâ€”it is of the ordinary kind, made of the same metal as the shillings, and then colouredâ€”it is as near as possible about two-fifths of the weight of a real sovereignâ€”it is cast in a sovereign mould, and afterwards gilt over by the ordinary process.
Prisoner's Defence. I expect I look the sovereign down in Billingsgate; I go about selling fish.

GUILTY.Strongly recommended to mercy by the jury, who considered that he had been an instrument in the hands of others. â€”
Confined Four Months

533.
HANNAH WILLIAMS (28), and
EMMA BLACKMORE (17), were indicted for
a like offence.

JAMES LEGGATT WHITTAKER . I keep the Blue Last public-house, Dorset-street, Fleet-streetâ€”on 4th April the prisoners came in togetherâ€”Blackmore asked for half a quartern of gin and hot water, which was 2 1/2 d.â€”I served herâ€”she gave me a half-crown and I gave her changeâ€”I put the half-crown in the till, where there was no other half-crownâ€”they drank the gin and water, and both left at the same timeâ€”a few minutes afterwards I went to the till, and the half crown was given me by the barmaidâ€”I never left the barâ€”I looked at the half-crown and found it was badâ€”I had not received any other in the mean timeâ€”I kept it apart from other money, and afterwards gave it to the constableâ€”on 22d April the prisoners came in again togetherâ€”Blackmore asked for half a quartern of gin and peppermint, which was 2 1/2 d.â€”I served her, and she gave me a half-crownâ€”I looked at it, and found it was badâ€”I said nothing particular, but went to the door, and sent for a constablesâ€”gave them both in custody with the half-crownsâ€”I have not seen them in the house before, except on 4th Aprilâ€”I am quite certain they were the same two that were there on the 4th.

Williams. Q. How can you swear I was in your house on 4th April? A. Because I found the half-crown directly afterwards, and knew I took it of youâ€”I knew you, and expected you would come back againâ€”I knew you by your featuresâ€”I said at the police-court that I was rather busy on 4th April, and that was how I came to take the half-crownâ€”I did not notice it particularly. Witness. I was not too busy to notice the womenâ€”I am quite certain of themâ€”the barmaid took the half-crown out of the till, and give it to meâ€”she made some remark about itâ€”I marked it at Guildhall.

Blackman. You said at the other Court that you were not certain that I was the person? Witness. I never said soâ€”I did say that I was not sure which of you gave the first half-crown, but my belief is that it was you.

PHILIP MONK (City-policeman, 334). On 22d April, I was called to the house of last witness, and the prisoners were given into my custodyâ€”the landlord said they had attempted to pass a bad half-crown, and had also passed one on 4th Aprilâ€”I said, "Well, under the circumstances, you must come to the station-house"â€”Williams said, "We are as well there as any where else"â€”I took them to the stationâ€”on Williams I found a halfpenny and two duplicatesâ€”they gave correct addresses, but they had only been living there about three weeksâ€”they were both Irving at the same placeâ€”Mr. Whittaker gave me one of these half-crowns ( produced,) and produced the other at the station-house.

Williams. Q. Did not the man say "No," when they asked him whether he had marked the half-crown? A. No; the chief clerk there told him to mark it so as to know it againâ€”I gave him something to mark it with, and he said he had already marked it.
WILLAM WEBSTER . These half-crowns are bad.
Williams's Defence. I am not guilty of being in that man's house on 4th April, and I think he has sworn to me very falsely.
Blackmore's Defence. I am not guilty of the first half-crown; I am of the
other. I had it given to me, and did not know it was bad, or I should not have given it to the gentlemen.

BLACKMOREâ€”
GUILTY . **â€”
Confined Nine Months.

WILLIAMSâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
Confined six Months.

534.
GEORGE HASTINGS (28)
, Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Raphael Josephs, with intent to steal.

HENRY WARRINGTON (Policeman, G 141). On Thursday morning, 17th April, about half-past 3 o'clock, I was on duty in Leather-laneâ€”I missed the padlock off the iron gate leading into the cellar of No. 82â€”I also found the window pushed back, and the gate tied up with a piece of twineâ€”I had seen the padlock safe about twenty minutes beforeâ€”I got the assistance of another constable, and we undid the twine, opened the gate, and turned our lights on into the cellar, and I saw the prisoner trying to hide himself under a shelf which projected out from the cellar window insideâ€”I reached down, and said, "Prisoner, all right, come out of it"â€”I took hold of him, and he said, "All right; I'll come out"â€”I called up the proprietor, who gave him in custodyâ€”I took him to the station, searched him, and found a small pen
knife and some matches (produced)â€”he gave no explanation of his being there.

ROBERT MILLER (Policeman, G 178). About a quarter past 3 o'clock, on the morning of 17th April, I was called by Warrington to Mr. Josephs"â€”I went down into the cellar and found this spike formed into a jemmyâ€”it was bent at the endâ€”the prisoner was endeavouring to conceal himselfâ€”I also found this wax-taper at the same spot, and this padlock out in the street, which he had wrenched off the front gateâ€”the prosecutor was called up, and gave the prisoner in custody.

RAPHAEL JOSEPHS . I live at 82, Leather-lane, and am a metal dealerâ€”on 17th April my cellar was properly padlockedâ€”I was called up by the police about half-past 3, and round the cellar broken open and the prisoner in custodyâ€”he had no right to be in the cellarâ€”I kept some old metal thereâ€”a person can get from that cellar into my house; it is part of my dwelling-houseâ€”it also gives access to some of the neighbouring houses, by coming up the cellar stairsâ€”I have not lost anything that I am aware ofâ€”the prisoner gave no explanation of his being thereâ€”my house is in the parish of St. Andrew's, Holborn.

Prisoner's Defence. I was walking in Leather-lane, between 2 and 3 o'clock, and I found the cellar door and the window open. I had been walking about all the previous day; it was coming on to rain, and I went in to get some rest. I had no intention to rob Mr. Josephs or his house. I never saw these articles before they were produced in Court.
COURT to RAPHAEL JOSEPHS. Q. Was this spike in the cellar the night before? A. No, and there was no taper in the cellar.
GUILTY .â€”He was further charged with having been before convicted.

MICHAEL FLANNAGAN (Policeman, S 229). I produce a certificateâ€”(Read: Central Criminal Court, April, 1861, George Franklin, convicted on his own confession, of burglary.â€” Confined One Year)â€”the prisoner to the same man as the Franklin there mentionedâ€”I was present, and had him in custody.
Prisoner. It is not me; he has made a mistake. Witness. I will swear he is the person.

GUILTY. **â€”
Four Years' Penal Servitude.

535.
WILSON LUCKING (21), and
JOHN PERCIVAL (16)
, Robbery on
Thomas Edgings, and stealing from his person a watch, a box, and a handkerchief, his goods.

THOMAS EDGINGS . I am a paperhanger, and live at 18, William-street, Stepneyâ€”between 12 and 1 o'clock, on the morning of 26th May, I was in High-street, Whitechapelâ€”I had been spending the evening with some friends at Lambeth, and having something to drink, but I was soberâ€”I knew what I was aboutâ€”as I was walking in the High-street two females came up to me, and I had some conversation with themâ€”I walked a little distance with themâ€”they wanted me to go somewhere, andâ€”went to Flower and Dean-streetâ€”we were standing outside the houseâ€”I would not go inâ€”I did not like the place, and I said, "No, I am going home"â€”I was then suddenly seized by the prisoner Luckingâ€”he put his hand round my neckâ€”when he let go I called out "Police!" but I could not call out while he was holding meâ€”he held me too tightâ€”I was put in that fear that I could not halloo nor speakâ€”before he came up, I had a silver watch in my right-hand waistcoat-pocket, this metal tobacco-box in my left-hand pocket, and a silk handkerchief my coat-pocketâ€”they were all gone when Lucking went awayâ€”the watch was fastened to my dress by this silver chain, which was round my neckâ€”when he went away it was broken as it is nowâ€”I saw some one else about that time, who I believe to be Percival, but I will not swear to himâ€”he was, it might be, two or three yards from Lucking at the time it happenedâ€”the handkerchief and the watch all went while Lucking had got hold of meâ€”as soon as Lucking's hand was removed from my throat, they both ran away; one, one way, and the other, the otherâ€”I can swear to the man that held meâ€”when I was released, I met a policeman walking up the streetâ€”I said, "I have been robbed of a watch"â€”I had called out "Police!" before thatâ€”I do not know whether they ran in the same or different directionsâ€”they were not brought back at allâ€”Percival was shown to me by a constable some few minutes afterwardsâ€”the constable said, "Should you know the man again?"â€”I said, "Yes, I should"â€”I went with him, and said, "That is the man"â€”the constable did not take me to Lucking's houseâ€”after he had taken Lucking, he went and fetched Percivalâ€”I did not accompany the policeman to a houseâ€”I gave four guineas for the watch.

Cross-examined by MR. DICKIE. Q. Do you still adhere to the story that you were not in the house? A. I was not in the houseâ€”I did not go inâ€”I was outsideâ€”I told no policeman about Lucking seising me by the throatâ€”the policeman took me to the houseâ€”the person that robbed me had a blue jacket on, something of the sort that Lucking has on nowâ€”I do not know what they call itâ€”that is the manâ€”when he was shown to me, I at once swore to himâ€”I had not seen him before that night, but I know him to be the man who throttled meâ€”his body was close against mine when he was throttling meâ€”I will not swear to the other one handling me, but I believe him to be the one that took my handkerchief out of my back coat-pocketâ€”there were several other men and women, but they were away from usâ€”I was not turned out of a house with two girlsâ€”I did not invite them up to some room, and get turned out by the landlordâ€”there was no quarrel about moneyâ€”there were two girls when I was stopped on my road homeâ€”they said, "Where are you going?"â€”I said, "I am going home"â€”they said, "Won't you go with us?"â€”I went, and when I found the place I was in, I said, "No, I won't stop here"â€”I had been at work at Lambeth before

I spent the evening thereâ€”we had porter and gin and water there, that was allâ€”I did not treat these people to anything, when I met them in Whit
chapelâ€”I did not have a drop with themâ€”I had nothing to drink in Whitechapel, nor in that neighbourhoodâ€”when I got to the house, I said, "Is this the place you are going to take me into?"â€”they said, "Yes"â€”I said, "Then I won't go"â€”I had money in my pocketâ€”I did not lose my moneyâ€”this case was before the Magistrate twice before I made my appear
anceâ€”I declined to come on the two first occasionsâ€”I was at last taken by a police-officer with a warrant: a summons first and a warrant afterwardsâ€”I was locked up there all night, the day before I gave evidenceâ€”it was about three weeks afterwards that the examination of these men took place at the police-courtâ€”I meant to put up with the lossâ€”I have not recovered any of my thingsâ€”it was a few minutes from the time I was robbed, to the time I saw Lucking and Percivalâ€”I drank nothing after I left Lambethâ€”I do not know how many miles it is from Lambethâ€”I can walk it in about three quarters of an hour.

MR. ROWDEN. Q. Are you sure Percival was the man who was within two or three yards of you when Lucking was robbing you? A. Well, I won't swear to Peroival, but I believe him to be the manâ€”there was no one else there but he.
COURT. Q. But are you sure it was he? A. Well, no, I am not sureâ€”I won't swear.

RICHARD EBONS (Policeman, X 297). On 26th March, I was in the H division of police, No. 96â€”on that night, or early on the following morning, I was on duty in Flower and Dean-street, Spitalfieldsâ€”I saw a crowd and heard a cryâ€”I saw Lucking and Percival coming out of the crowd, runningâ€”one went one aide of the road and the other the other sideâ€”as soon as they saw me they stopped and walkedâ€”I asked Lucking what was the matter up thereâ€”he said, "Nothing particular"â€”about ten minutes after
wards Edgings came up to me and said, "Constable, I have lost my watch"â€”I said, "Would you know the men that took your watch if you saw them"â€”he said, "Yes; I would"â€”I said, "Come with me;" and I took him to Lucking's house at the corner of George-street, Spitalfieldsâ€”I knocked at the door and called Lucking out, and as soon as he came to the door, Edgings said, "That is the man that has throttled me, and taken my watch"â€”Lucking made no reply to thatâ€”I then told him he must come with me to the station, and took him thereâ€”I then went back to search for the watch, and saw Percival amongst the crowd, opposite Lucking's house, just in the centre of the roadâ€”I told Percival he must come with me down to the station, that I wanted him down thereâ€”he made no reply, but came with meâ€”the prosecutor was at the station.

COURT. Q. Did you tell Percival the charge? A. Yes; I said, "You must come with me, you are charged with being with Lucking and robbing a man"â€”he made no replyâ€”I then took him to the station, and the prosecutor said, "That is the man that was along with the man that took my watch; I will swear to him being in company with the man that took my Watch"â€”Percival made no replyâ€”the crowd in Flower and Dean-street was about fifty yards from Lucking's houseâ€”Lucking's house is just at the corner of George-street, that runs out of it.

Cross-examined. Q. When you saw the prisoners running, were they not in their own street first of all? A. No; Percival lived at a lodging houseâ€”they both lived in Flower and Dean-streetâ€”the prosecutor said he could not positively swear that Percival did take his handkerchiefâ€”he charged

Lucking with stealing his watchâ€”I heard the cry of two or three voicesâ€”I suppose there were about twenty people there when I got upâ€”I was about fifty yards off when I first heard the cryâ€”the prosecutor was sober, but appeared very much flurried and hurt, as if he could not speak very plain when he first came up to meâ€”he was quite soberâ€”he gave me no descrip
tion of the prisonersâ€”the going to Lucking's house was my own idea, seeing those men run out of the crowd, as soon as the man mentioned that he had lost his watch, I fancied it was those twoâ€”I went to Lucking's house and called him outâ€”that was in George-street, Spitalfields, leading into Flower and Dean-street, between Whitechapel and Spitalfieldsâ€”I searched the house after I went back, but found nothingâ€”I have not up to this time found anything connected with the robberyâ€”I had to take the prosecutor on a warrantâ€”I had a summons first, and then a warrant to make him appearâ€”it is about six weeks ago that it took placeâ€”I have had to watch the prosecutor all the whileâ€”I had a great deal of trouble to keep him here to day.

SARAH SMITH .
