I live at Brick-lane, Sarah's-placeâ€”about the end of last March, I met the prosecutor in Bishopsgate-street, about 9 o'clock at nightâ€”there was another female besides myselfâ€”we got into conversation and were two hours 'with him, and he spent half-a-crown with asâ€”we went to two or three different public-houses, and when we came out he would not leave us, but would follow usâ€”he drank old ale during that time, nothing elseâ€”he treated us, and kept following usâ€”he invited us to a houseâ€”we did not go inâ€”we did go in with him but he had not any money, and we came out againâ€”I made a mistake when I said we did not go inâ€”we were turned out of that house by the landlordâ€”no one attacked him in Bishopsgate street when he came outâ€”he said he would go with us, and then three men came upâ€”one had on a blue Guernsey, and another had a shepherd's plaidâ€”I never saw them beforeâ€”I could swear to one of the menâ€”the one that went against the prosecutorâ€”I interfered, and called out "Police! murder!"â€”neither of these prisoners are the menâ€”I do not know either of the prisonersâ€”I could swear that they are none of the threeâ€”the police did not come up thenâ€”I do not know whether they did afterwardsâ€”I was so afraid that I went home.

Cross-examined by MR. ROWDEN. Q. How long have you been living at Sarah's-place? A. Five yearsâ€”I know Fashion-streetâ€”I go through there a great many timesâ€”I know a public-house called the Queen's Headâ€”I have had a glass of ale thereâ€”I know nothing of either of these prisonersâ€”on my oath I do not know Luckingâ€”I have never drank with him in my lifeâ€”I have never been in the Queen's Head with Luckingâ€”I do not know a constable or detective named Deebleâ€”I have not been in the Queen's Head with Lucking and seen Deeble there.â€”(Deeble was here pointed out to the witness)â€”well I have seen himâ€”he does not know anything of me, I am sureâ€”I have never seen him in the Queen's Head public-houseâ€”he has never met me walking with Luckingâ€”I have never seen him beforeâ€”I have never seen him before to-day, to my knowledgeâ€”I was not at the police-courtâ€”I do not know the manâ€”it was at the corner of Archey-lane, in Bishopsgate-street, that I met the prosecutor, about 9 o'clock by the clock in the beer-shop.
MR. DICKIE. Q. Is Lucking a friend of yours, or not? A. No; no friend of mineâ€”it was Bishopsgate-street, not Whitechapel.
COURT. Q. You do not know Lucking? A. No, not before; I came here because I was told.

LUCKINGâ€”
GUILTY . â€ â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

PERCIVALâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”The Right Hon. the LORD MAYOR, Mr. JUSTICE WILLES; Mr. BARON CHANNELL; Mr. Ald. FINNIS; Mr. Ald. ABBISS; Mr. Ald GIBBONS; and ROBERT MALOOLM KERR, Esq.

div1.p:
536.
JOHN HAYNES was indicted
for feloniously killing and slaying
Thomas Mitchel; he was also charged on the Coroner's inquisition with the like offence.
MR. METCALFE, for the prosecution, offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

537.
GEORGE WAITE (40)
, Feloniously wounding
Maria Waite, with intent to murder her. Second count, with intent to do her some grevious bodily harm.

WILLIAM WARREN (Police-sergeant, D 27). On Thursday, 1st May, about half-past 1 in the morning, I heard cries of "Murder" and "Police," in Carlton-terrace, Harrow-roadâ€”in consequence of hearing those cries I went thereâ€”I saw the prisoner's wife in her night-drees, or chemise, standing in front of the terrace, with her night-dress saturated with bloodâ€”she com
plained of some one to meâ€”in consequence of what she said I went with her to where she lived, and knocked at the doorâ€”the landlord of the house opened itâ€”while we were waiting for the door to be opened, she was bleeding very much: I should think there'was a pint of blood on the stone in front of the doorâ€”when the door was opened, I went up stairs to the third floor front-room, and found the prisoner there dressing himselfâ€”I said, "This is a very serious case; you are charged with assaulting your wife with some blunt instrument"â€”his wife was then in the front-roomâ€”he said, "It is a good job she got away from me, or it might have been worse"â€”I then took him to the station, and sent for a surgeon to attend the wifeâ€”at the station she said, while the prisoner was by, that he had struck her with the axe on the side of the headâ€”she said, she saw the axe coming and stood on one sideâ€”she also said, he had tried to stab her with a file, more than onceâ€”I saw several wounds, one on the neck, and one on the fingerâ€”in consequence of what I heard then, I went back and searched the pri
soner's room, and there found this axe (produced) under some fire-wood in a corner of the roomâ€”there were marks of blood on it then, and nowâ€”I also found this file (produced) under the bedâ€”there were no marks on thatâ€”there was blood on the floor of the room.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Where was he when you entered the room? A. Standing by the side of the bedâ€”he had got his trousers on, and was putting his waistcoat on, but had not got his boots onâ€”there was a candle in the roomâ€”he was not in an excited state at that timeâ€”he got more excited after he was at the stationâ€”I noticed that after he was locked up, when I went to see how he was getting onâ€”his hands where tremblingâ€”there were no other signs of excitementâ€”he was not shouting or calling outâ€”his eyes did not look wildâ€”he was only tremblingâ€”he was not at all like a man insaneâ€”of course he felt very sorry for what had occurredâ€”he answered every question that I put to him reasonably enoughâ€”there were other constables there who saw himâ€”they are not hereâ€”he
remained in the cell from half-past 4 o'clock till 1, and then I took him to the police-courtâ€”he was quite well then.

MARIA WAITE . I am the prisoner's wifeâ€”on 30th April, we went to bed about 10 o'clockâ€”about half-past 12 my husband awoke me for the pur
pose of giving him some medicineâ€”he had not been well; he was in a very strange stateâ€”I gave him his medicine, and got into bed again after a short time; he told me to come to bedâ€”after I had got into bed again he tried to pierce me with a file in the stomachâ€”he had not said anything before he did thatâ€”he did not pierce me with the fileâ€”I got it from him after a long time, and threw it under the bedâ€”I had several scratches from it about my bodyâ€”I tried to get away from him as much as I couldâ€”he then got the axe from behind some fire-woodâ€”we were out of bed at that time; in the struggle we got out on to the floorâ€”he struck me on the left side of the head with the axeâ€”I was standing up at the time, trying to get out of the door away from himâ€”I could not say what part of the axe he hit me withâ€”it out my head, and the blood flowed on to my chemiseâ€”when I got from him I ran down stairs as fast as I possibly could, and he threw the axe after me on to the first landing, but it did not come near me.

Cross-examined. Q. Had he been in a strange state for some time? A. Yes; from the Saturday nightâ€”this happened on Thursday, 1st Mayâ€”he could not workâ€”he had not been confined to his bedâ€”he could not sleep, or rest at allâ€”there did not seem any rest in himâ€”he had been drinking very hard for a fortnight, continually, every dayâ€”it was on Saturday night that he was first taken so ill that he could not go outâ€”I had no one to attend himâ€”I offered to go for a doctor
ing of parties being in the room: he even went down to my landlady's room and looked about her private apartments, and in the cow-shed, and underneath the cowsâ€”he had never done such a thing beforeâ€”that was in the morning part of the Wednesdayâ€”sometimes he was a great deal worse than he was at othersâ€”after he had slept in the afternoon he seemed much better, and I was in hopes that he had overcome itâ€”he said nothing more about it before we went to bed about 10â€”I can't say whether he went to sleepâ€”I fell asleep myselfâ€”he was a very good husband to me when he was soberâ€”I never gave him any ground of complaintâ€”he is a timber sawyerâ€”the axe is used for the timberâ€”it was placed in a corner behind some fire wood with other toolsâ€”the file is used to sharpen the sawâ€”I don't know where he took that from; he generally carried it in his pocketâ€”he had got out of bed before he tried to stab me with the file.

GEORGE BROWN . I am a surgeon at Kensal-greenâ€”on 1st May, about half-past 9 in the morning, I was called to examine the prosecutrix at her houseâ€”I found two incised wounds on her head, one over the left ear three inches in extent, and one over the right ear about an inch in length; they

were to the boneâ€”this axe would be calculated to produce such woundsâ€”I found a great number of scratches and bruises on the belly, as if caused by the sharp point of a fileâ€”there was also a blunt wound on the right side of the belly, as if produced by the blunt edge of the fileâ€”I afterwards saw the prisoner at the stationâ€”I asked him how he came to do itâ€”he said, he had had delirium tremens, and it was through jealousy of one Jem Trotman.

Cross-examined. Q. I suppose you are familiar with what is called delirium tremens? A. Yes; a very aggravated state of it makes a a man insane, so that he would not know what he was doingâ€”he would not then know the difference between right and wrongâ€”I have heard the evidence of the prosecutrixâ€”if I had been called in I might have advised some stimulants to be administeredâ€”suddenly depriving a man of stimu
lants after he has been drinking might bring on delirium tremensâ€”it may last some days, until the man gets a good sleepâ€”I did not see him in a tremulous stateâ€”the symptoms described by the prosecutrix are such as occur in an aggravated state of delirium tremensâ€”the only way in which I can account for there being no recurrence of the fit, was his getting plenty of good sleepâ€”possibly his being locked up might have some effect, but delirium tremens if a formed disease, and I should hardly think it would have been so.

COURT. Q. Was he suffering from delirium tremens when you saw him in the morning. A. No; if the delirium was the mere result of drunken
ness, it would pass away.

MR. RIBTON. Q. Was his appearance consistent with having been suffer
ing from delirium tremens the night before. A. Yes; quite soâ€”he might have been suffering from it even up to 12 o'clock on the Wednesday nightâ€”the comparatively quiescent state in which I found him, I took to be the result of finding himself in the position in which he was; and the excite
ment had passed off.

prosecutrix.â€”
Confined Eighteen Months

538.
JEREMIAH WHALEY (23), was indicted
for a rape upon
Ann Elizabeth Richardson.

GUILTY .â€”
Four Years Penal Servitude.

539.
HENRY LAWRENCE (36)
, Rape on
Ann Lawrence.

GUILTY .â€”
Penal Servitude for Life.

540.
FREDERICK CLARKE (53)
, Rape upon
Adelaide Elizabeth Sophia Butler.

GUILTY of the attempt. â€”
Confined Twelve Months

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. BARON CHANELL; Mr. Ald. ROSE; and Mr. Ald. GABRIEL.

div1.p:
541.
FREDERICK ASTON DRIVER (20)
, Stealing out of a Post
letter 2 half-sovereigns, the property of
Her Majesty's Postmaster-General; to which he
PLEADED GUILTY .

p.hi: He received a good character, and Mr. John Day, hotel-keeper, of Great Russell-street, Bloomsbury, engaged to take him into his service.

div1.p:
542.
HENRY DUFOUR (31)
, Feloniously uttering a forged 5 l. Bank of England note, with intent to defraud.

p.hi: The evidence was interpreted to the prisoner.

div1.p:
JAMES OAKLEY . I am foreman to Mr. Hodges, of Oxford-streetâ€”on 26th March, about 8 in the evening, the prisoner came and looked at a pair of bootsâ€”the young man was going to look for some more, but he said, "Never mind, these will do"â€”he spoke English; I could distinctly under
stand himâ€”he took out his portmannaie, but said that he had not enough silver, and asked if I would change this note (produced)â€”I identify it by this endorsementâ€”it did not appear to be genuine, and I went and spoke to Mr. Hodges, and in consequence of what he said, I went out, crossed the road to get the opinion of a neighbour, from whose shop I tapped a police
man on the shoulder, who was passing, and directly I did so, I saw the prisoner outside the shop, talking to a second man about twenty yards from meâ€”I had left the prisoner in the shop, saying, in his hearing as I went out, that I must go for changeâ€”when the prisoner saw me touch the policeman he started off running as fast as he couldâ€”from the first shop I went to I went to a second neighbour; and if the prisoner had been at the door of our shop, he must have seen all that I didâ€”I immediately cried "Stop thief!" and the policeman caught the prisoner.

Cross-examined by MR. PATER. Q. I suppose he could wear the boots? A. Yesâ€”I do not think Mr. Hodges took the note in his hand, the endorse
ment on it was spelt in French: there was an "A" for "Half"â€”Mr. Hodges was not capable of giving an opinion about the noteâ€”he is not hereâ€”he was not before the Magistrateâ€”I was away from the shop about ten minutesâ€”I took the note to Mr. Gardiner the money changerâ€”he is not hereâ€”the prisoner was taken three or four minutes after I spoke to the policemanâ€”I did not charge him with stealing the boots; the charge I made was trying to pass a forged noteâ€”he was brought back to the shop in four or five minutesâ€”he made no reply to the chargeâ€”he speaks English imperfectly, but I could understand him quiteâ€”I lost sight of him for a moment turning the cornerâ€”I do not know the other man, but I saw him afterwards at the police-court, in company with a woman, who instructed Mr. Lewis to defend the prisonerâ€”Mr. Hodges has been in business forty years, and I have been in his employment fifteen years.

MR. METCALFE. Q. How far were you from him when he turned the corner? A. Twenty or thirty yards; and when I turned the corner I saw him again, and have no hesitation in saying that he is the manâ€”I took the note from the prisoner's hand and walked with it to Mr. Hodgesâ€”I went first to Gardiner's the money changer's, but the note was not out of my sight thereâ€”he was not at home, but his young man wasâ€”I next went to Johnson's the hosiers, it was out of my sight for a moment there, while the assistant had it; he just took it to the back of the shop and showed itâ€”he was out of my sight as well as the noteâ€”I am sure I got back the same note from him; I know it by the endorsement.
JOHN BIRCHER (Policeman, D 37). On 26th March, Mr. Oakley came to

me in the street, and said something, in consequence of which I went to
wards Mr. Hodges' shopâ€”I there saw the prisonerâ€”as we walked towards the shop Mr. Oakley shouted, "Stop thief!" and I noticed the prisoner run
ning from the pavement into the roadâ€”I had not noticed him beforeâ€”I ran after him three or four hundred yards, and caught himâ€”he turned out of Oxford-street into Union-streetâ€”I did not lose sight of himâ€”he turned round when I got within a few yards of him, and said, "Me done nothing"â€”I took him into custodyâ€”I took him first to Mr. Hodges' shop; he was there charged with uttering this note, and then I took him to the station.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know whether the prisoner ran after "Stop thief" was called, or before? A. I did not Bee him before "Stop thief" was calledâ€”I saw him running after "Stop thief" was calledâ€”he said, "Me done nothing" when he was in the streetâ€”he did not persist in saying that when he was in the shopâ€”I cannot remember what he said in the shopâ€”he might have repeated more than once, "Me done nothing"â€”I was about thirty yards from the shop when I first saw him, and he was about three or four yards from the pavement.
COURT. Q. Did he stop before you got up to him? A. He stopped when I got within three or four yards of him.

JOSEPH RICE . I am a shoemaker, of 384, Oxford-streetâ€”on 4th February, I came home and found the prisoner in the shop, being served with a pair of bootsâ€”I went up, fitted him, and then took the boots to pack them upâ€”he was fumbling about with his portmonnaie, as I supposed getting the money to pay for them, and all at once he said, "Me not money enough," at the same time showing me his portmonnaie, which contained a few shillings and what appeared to be a 5l. noteâ€”he took the note out and presented it to meâ€”I took it and said I would change itâ€”I took it to the desk and en
dorsed my name on it, "J. Rice"â€”this is the same note; it has my signa
tureâ€”this "Mr. Rice" on the back was written by another personâ€”I gave the prisoner four sovereigns and 7s. 6d. change; 12s. 6d. was the price of the bootsâ€”he went away with the change and the bootsâ€”the note was returned to me on 7th Februaryâ€”I next saw the prisoner at the police-court, on 17th March, in custodyâ€”he was first shown to me the passage leading to the Courtâ€”it was very dark, and I did not recognise himâ€”I afterwards saw him in the Court where it was light, and became certain, and I recog
nised his voiceâ€”I have not the least doubt he is the man who passed that noteâ€”I said in Court, "He has got on the same boots that he purchased of me at the time."

Cross-examined. Q. I believe when you heard his voice, it was after you expressed your uncertainty as to his being the man? A. Yes; but I saw him in Court ten minutes or a quarter of an hour after that, and recognised the general character of his person, though I was not sure of him until he spokeâ€”it was not by his broken English that I recognised him, because he did not speak English at all, it was by the general voice, not the wordsâ€”not by his voice alone, but by his general character as wellâ€”I did say before that I did not notice what dress he wore at the time he purchased the bootsâ€”I also know the marks inside the bootsâ€”they were made expressly to my order, by Mr. Hatton of Northamptonâ€”I do not think there are any others of the same classâ€”I have a boot here which will match themâ€”the marks on them are "7 C. S." which constitues the quality and the sizeâ€”the private mark was outside and would be worn offâ€”when I first entered the shop my shopman was servingâ€”I had him at the police-court, but the Magistrate refused to hear further evidence, and he is not here to-dayâ€”the prisoner

handed the note to me, and I endorsed my name on it, "J. Rice," at the momentâ€”the prisoner was standing at the back of the desk, while I went to the front of it to do soâ€”I did not notice this endorsement, John Dellanoir, on itâ€”it was between the lightsâ€”I immediately sent my shopman to a shop-keeper, across the road to ask him if be would change it, and he brought me back five sovereignsâ€”it was about a month after the prisoner entered the shop that I saw himâ€”I had not seen him since.
COURT. Q. Can yon take upon yourself to say that you did not receive any other 5l. note that day or the day after? A. I canâ€”I always put my name on a note before I send it out to get change.
JOSEPH BUMSTEAD . I am inspector of notes to the Bank of Englandâ€”these are both forgeries in every respectâ€”they come from the same plate, and are on the same kind of paper.
Cross-examined. Q. Are the numbers the same? A. The numbers are put on afterwardsâ€”it is not a water-mark at all, only an imitation.

GUILTY .â€”
Six Years' Penal Servitude.

543.
MARGARET PLEASANT (24)
, Robbery, with three other person, on
Adam Dean, and stealing from his person 1 watch, 1 chain, and money, his property.

ADAM DHAN . I am a civil engineerâ€”on 4th April, I was staying at Gregory's Hotel, Cheapsideâ€”on that morning I met with two womenâ€”the prisoner is one of them; I will swear to herâ€”I met them in Long-acre, and accompanied themâ€”I treated them, and afterwards accompanied one of them to her house, which I afterwards ascertained was at No. 9, Coal-yard, Drury-laneâ€”it was the first door out of the passage to the leftâ€”it was both a sitting-room and a bed-roomâ€”after I had been there some time there was a knock at the door, and the girl that was along with this woman went outâ€”I said, "Where is she going?"â€”the prisoner said, "I will go and fetch her"â€”she went away and brought anotherâ€”I said, "I am going to leave, I sha'nt stop here;" and when I said that, two men came in and made an attack on meâ€”the prisoner was with me thenâ€”I said, "I am going;" and the men stopped meâ€”I said, "It will take you all your time"â€”they rushed on to me; I struck light and left; they struck too; and one of them said, "Have you got it?"â€”I had an overcoat onâ€”I belong to a country town where they know how to use their feet, and I believe I could have licked the whole fourâ€”I knocked one of the men over; I dropped himâ€”the women got hold of me by the collar of my coat, tore my scarf off, and hung on to my throatâ€”I had the men under me; I was giving it to them; I meant mischiefâ€”I did not like to lose my propertyâ€”they got me down, and when I was on the ground my gold watch and guard were taken outâ€”the prisoner was throttling me at this timeâ€”it is a very difficult position to be placed inâ€”I rushed out of the house after the menâ€”I was after the man to knock him downâ€”I had seen my watch and chain safe perhaps about an hour, or half an hour before thisâ€”I looked at it when I left a party, a little after 12â€”I met the women, perhaps, an hour after
wardsâ€”when the man said, "Have you got it?" I heard no reply, all I saw was a dartâ€”they put their hands up and made a dartâ€”they opened my overcoat while I was standing on the defensive, and I felt my watch go, but did not see itâ€”I felt in my pocket and missed itâ€”the men then left me, and I followed themâ€”I did not succeed in catching the prisonerâ€”I met the policeman, returned, and pointed out the house to him, but it was closedâ€”we had had a drink, and I cannot tell you how long I was in the prisoner's company before the men came in.

Cross-examined by MR. COOPER. Q. Had you had a good deal of drink before you met her? A. Yes; and I might have had one glass of ale or a dozen glasses with her, for anything I knowâ€”she assisted me in drinkingâ€”I do not know how many glasses I have had since I came hereâ€”I dare say I have had a bellyfull since then, for I have been hero every day since Mon
day morning.

JOHN MATTHEWS (Police-sergeant, 13 F). I took the prisoner on the night of 4th Aprilâ€”I asked her if she lived at 9, Coal-yardâ€”she said, "Yes"â€”I said I should take her for being concerned with two men and a woman in robbing a gentleman of a watch and chain, about 3 o'clock that morning, at 9, Coal-yardâ€”she said nothing thenâ€”I took her to the station, fetched the prosecutor, and placed the prisoner with three other females, and he identified herâ€”I saw him that morning about 3 o'clock; he was then slightly under the influence of liquor, and very much excited, but he ap
peared to know perfectly well what he was doingâ€”the watch has not been found.
Cross-examined. Q. What state was she in when you took her? A. Quite sober.

JAMES COSTELLO (Policeman, 129 F). On 4th April, about 3 in the morning; I met the prosecutor in Drury-lane, and accompanied him to 9, Coal-yardâ€”he pointed out a room to me, the door of which was lockedâ€”I got in by the parlour-window, and found there his hat, brace, collar, and neck tie.

HYAM FIRSH (Policeman, 156 F). On 5th April, about 3 o'clock, I met the prisoner at the top of Coal-yardâ€”she was quite sober, to all appearanceâ€”I said, "What is the matter?"â€”she said, "Nothing," and went away, and shortly afterwards I saw the prosecutor with his clothes torn and with
out scarf or collarâ€”his waistcoat was torn, and he had only one brace, and no hatâ€”the prisoner was meeting me, coming from No. 9, towards Drury-lane, and as I got nearer to No. 29 I met the prosecutor standing in the middle of the streetâ€”he made a complaint to me.

The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate was here read as follows: "The prosecutor had been drinking with me and others; two bottles of gin were brought to my place; if I had not been drinking such a thing would not have occurred in my place; I do not know whether it occurred or not."

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

544.
ELIZA CLARK (25)
, Feloniously uttering a forged 1l. note of the Bank of Scotland, with intent to defraud.

JAMES MILLS . I live at 103, Edgeware-road, and am a pawnbrokerâ€”I occasionally deal in Irish and Scotch bank notesâ€”on Saturday, 19th April, the prisoner called at my shop with a note in her handâ€”she asked me if I changed Scotch notesâ€”I said that I did, and gave 19s. 6d. for themâ€”she said, "Yes, that is right, I have six of them"â€”she produced the other five from her purse, and placed them on the counter with a half-crown and sixpenceâ€”I had had some information, in consequence of which I looked at the notes and asked the prisoner her sameâ€”she said Eliza Andersonâ€”I asked her where she lived the said 32, Grafton-place, Camden-townâ€”I asked whose notes they wereâ€”she said, "My own"â€”I asked her where she got them fromâ€”she said that they were given to her by a gentleman with whom she had been staying at Windsor for a weekâ€”I asked his nameâ€”she said, "George"â€”I asked his other name she said

she did not knowâ€”I asked her what be wasâ€”she said that he held a situa
tion in the City, but she did not know whatâ€”I had previously sent for a constable, who then arrivedâ€”I told him, in her presence, that I had heard there were a number of forged Scotch notes about, and I had reason to believe these formed a part of themâ€”she was then taken to the station, and I handed the notes to the officer.

Cross-examined by MR. PATER. Q. Have you any Scotch notes in your window to inform the world that you change notes? A. Yes; and Irish notes as well, and a little bowl with foreign gold and silver coin, and I have it written up as wellâ€”there are different charges made for changing notes: we should do a number of them at less than oneâ€”I did not tell her that I should send for a policemanâ€”I did not leave the shop; I only went to the back of it, and celled some of my peopleâ€”the prisoner could have opened the door and gone outâ€”the shop is divided as pawnbrokers shops usually are, the pledging part at the back, and the sale part in the frontâ€”when I went to the back I was behind the divisionâ€”it is a large shopâ€”my assistants were most of them down at dinner, and I called through the door to them to come upâ€”I went out of the prisoner's sight, but was scarcely absent a secondâ€”the prisoner gave her answers with great readinessâ€”I have not inquired whether Anderson it her maiden name.

COURT. Q. Can you recollect at what part of the conversation it was that you stepped back and spoke to your assistants? A. I asked her her name and address, and then went to the back and called my assistants.

â€”TOMPKINS (Policeman, D 221). On 19th April, about 2 o'clock, I was called to Mr. Mills's shop, and found the prisoner in front of the counterâ€”he asked me, in her hearing, if I knew anything concerning some Scotch notes, which had been stolen or forcedâ€”I said noâ€”he said that the prisoner came and asked him if he changed Scotch notes; that he told her he did, and offered her 19s. 6d. for one, upon which she produced five others, with 3s.â€”the had the 3s. in her handâ€”he told me to ask her where she got them, as his modesty forbad him to tell meâ€”I asked her, and she said she had been staying with a man nemed George for a fortnight at Windsorâ€”Mr. Mills said that he was not satisfied with the answer she gave, and I took her to the station, detained her while I made inquiries, first at 37, Haymarket, and then in the Cityâ€”Mr. Mills then charged her with uttering forged notesâ€”she said that it was very hard that she should be chargedâ€”she gave her name Eliza Anderson at first, but six hours afterwards, when I had made the inquiries, and the charge was being taken, she gave the name of Clarkâ€”I went to Camden-town, but could not find Grafton-placeâ€”I found Grafton-place, Kentish-town, but there was no No. 32; the highest number was 12â€”I made inquiries about there, but could learn nothing of any woman named Elisabeth Anderson or Clark.

Cross-examined. Q. Did she not say in your hearing that Clark was her marriage name, and Anderson her maiden name? A. Noâ€”she told me she was living separate from her husbandâ€”that was when she made the change of nameâ€”I was outside the office when Funnell was thereâ€”he made no inquiries in my hearing.
MR. SLEIGH. Q. Are these (produced) the notes Mr. Mills gave you? A. Yesâ€”I wrote my name on them.

JACOB PERKINS BACON . I am manager of the firm of Perkins, Bacon, and Co. of Fleet-streetâ€”they are printers to the National Bank of Scotlandâ€”these six notes are our genuine work, as far as the printing and numbering it concernedâ€”we have missed from our premises a packet of notes with

the top number 176 T, which we have never sent to the bank for issueâ€”they were on our counter, waiting to be sent to the Bank, and when we looked for them, having our suspicious aroused, they were gone.

COURT. Q. The letter T and the 176 would apply, I suppose, to all the impressions of 1l. notes? A. No; T does, but 176 applies to our booksâ€”the bottom number varies, and runs on numericallyâ€”these notes were printed with the view of being reissuedâ€”we did not miss the packet till 10th April, but it might have gone any day between the 3d and the 10thâ€”No. 500 would be the highest number we should strike offâ€”we were sending 5,000 out, but, after 500, the top number would be changedâ€”when we finished the impression we should send them to the Bank of Scotland direct in a box, and not to any London agent.

JOHN GIFFARD . I am cashier to the National Bank of Scotland, at their head office in Edinburghâ€”it is an incorporated bankâ€”the issue of notes is under my special superintendanceâ€”the signatures to these six notes are not genuineâ€”I know a person bearing one of the names, Mr. John Addisonâ€”he signs for the manager, "pro" but this is not his signatureâ€”there is a Mr. A. R. Warner in the bank, but not H. R Warner, nor is this Mr. A. R. Warner's signature.

COURT. Q. Have you any persons in the bank of the names of Addison or Warner, but the two gentlemen named? A. Noâ€”I keep a book in which I enter the notes I issue, and then place them before those gentlemen to signâ€”it is my duty to regulate the issueâ€”there are notes with the letter T in my possession, but not issuedâ€”the series of notes come down to the bank, and then I determine whether I issus the old series or the newâ€”I place the new notes before somebody for their signatureâ€”I never received any notes T 176â€”they could not be issued without passing through my handsâ€”I then take a note of the numbers, and after signature they are re
handed to me for issue.

Cross-examined Q. How are you able to say that notes with the numbers of these series have not been entered? A. Because I have not them in the bookâ€”the book is not hereâ€”I never received the blank forms of series T 176 from the engraver, and it it my duty in the first instance to receive them for signing and issuingâ€”these notes are dated 11th November, 1861â€”that is according to the instructions which we give to the engraver.

COURT. Q. There would be no entry in your books until you received the notes? A. Noâ€”I begin by crediting the bank 500 on one side, and 500 on the other, but before they are issued they must bear the signature of two accountantsâ€”it is my duty to receive the forms.

EDWARD FUNNELL . I am a detective City-officerâ€”on 19th April, I was at the John-street station when the prisoner was chargedâ€”I asked her where she got the notes from she had thereâ€”she told me a gentleman gave them to her, who she had been staying with for a weak at Windsorâ€”I said, "Where at Windsor?"â€”she said, "Eaton-place"â€”I asked her what numberâ€”she said that she did not know the number, but that it was at an eating-houseâ€”I asked her what the gentleman's name wasâ€”she said that she knew him by the name of Georgeâ€”I asked her where she was in the habit of meeting Georgeâ€”she said, "In an Alton ale-house in Newgate-street"â€”I said, "Where in Newgate-street?"â€”she said, "Down a passage, where he goes and has his lunch, ale, and sandwiches."â€”I do not know such a place as that, and 1 am pretty well acquainted with Newgate-streetâ€”I asked her what part of Newgate-streetâ€”she said, "On the other side of the Blue Coat School"â€”I went down to Windsor, but could find no Eaton
place

â€”I found one at Eton, but no eating-house or place of refreshmentâ€”I have searched for the passage described in Newgate-street, but have not been able to find one which corresponds with the description.

I COURT. Q. Then there is not near Christ's Hospital, any passage leading to a house of refreshment? A. Not to an Alton ale-houseâ€”the prisoner, when before the Magistrate, said that there was a passage leading down a court to the Post-office; 1 said, "Well, I know that house; that is kept by Mr. Gibson"â€”the hotel is in Newgate-street, and the passage leads into St. Martin's-le-grandâ€”when you get into Newgate-street, and go a little way down, Christ's Hospital is on the leftâ€”there is no passage opposite that point leading to a house of refreshment, but a little further up, on the right hand side, there is a passage leading to two houses of that kind, the Saluta
tion and the Grapes.

Cross-examined Q. I believe you have been very active in this matter? A. I have made all the inquiries I couldâ€”I have seen the prisoner's fatherâ€”I have not offered him a reward to give me informationâ€”I swear I have made no proposition to himâ€”the prisoner said she was in the habit of meeting him down a passage opposite the Blue-Coat Schoolâ€”there is a passage opposite the Blue-Coat School, known as Three Ton's-passage; there is one entrance to it out of Ivy-lane, another from Newgate-market, and another from Newgate-street, with a butcher's shop at the cornerâ€”there is in that passage, besides the Grapes, a house called the Ship, and another called the Dark Houseâ€”I did not call and make inquiries at a gay house in Windsor: I do not' know oneâ€”I inquired for Eaton-place, at the Post-office, the police, and the bankersâ€”no number was given of Eaton-place; No. 32, was Grafton-placeâ€”I inquired at the Ship.

MR. GIFFARD. Q. Did she make one statement or two about the passage? A. She made another statement before the Magistrateâ€”she said that it was not opposite, but on the same side as the school, and that she went down the passage by a hairdresser's shop at the corner, which led through to the Post-office, and I found an Hotel there kept by Mr. Gibson Iâ€”that statement was after I had been examined as to her first statement, she said that I was wrong and this was her correction of my statement.

MR. PATER. Q. Did not the Magistrate observe to you that your state
ments were very unsatisfactory? A. No; he made no such remarkâ€”I have got the prisoner's landlady here; I found out where she lived.
FREDERICK ROBERTS . I am the proprietor of the Grapes public-house, Newgate-streetâ€”I have not the slightest knowledge of the prisoner or of any person named George, frequenting my house.
Cross-examined. Q. You do not know everybody who takes lunch at your bar? A. No.
MARY BROOKS . I manage the Queen's-arms, Newgate-street, of which Mr. Gibson is the proprietorâ€”I know no one named George, or Mr. George, frequenting the house.

ANN HOWLE . I live at 5, Little Charles-street, Hampstead-roadâ€”the prisoner lived in my house about six months, till Easter, when I missed herâ€”until that time she was not absent from the house for a week together, except when she had an illnessâ€”they had company in the room on Good Friday, but 1 do not know who was thereâ€”I do not recollect seeing her after Good Friday, but it was a day or two after before I actually missed her, and I inquired and heard that her mother-in-law was ill, and she was attending herâ€”I have not seen her since, until this morningâ€”I live on the first floor, and she in the parlourâ€”I do not think she was absent for a day
up to Good Fridayâ€”she was generally out in the day, and came home after I was in bed at nightâ€”they went by the name of Mr. and Mrs. Hayward, husband and wife as I understood

Cross-examined. Q. You say that you missed her some time in Easter week? A. yes; and I asked her sister where she wasâ€”I did not see her after thatâ€”she had never slept away from the house to my knowledgeâ€”they did not get up till 11 in the morningâ€”their little parlour is close to the street door, and they have a keyâ€”I did not wait on themâ€”I never knew them till they came after the apartmentsâ€”they appeared to be living as man and wifeâ€”they occupied one little parlour at 2s. 6d. a weekâ€”I never heard that she ran away from him.
HENRY BARKER . I am a waiter at the Salutation, Newgate-streetâ€”I know no gentleman named George, or Mr. George, frequenting the house I do not know the prisoner.
Cross-examined. Q. How far is the Ship from your place? A. I only know the Ship in Aldersgate-street; I know no house of that name in that passage.
MR. PATER to JOHN GIFFARD Q. Are there a great many parties who sign for the manager of the bank? A. Yes; but they each sign his own proper name, and not one for the other.

COURT. Q. Do you know any of those whose signature is attached to this paper? A. No; there are about 150 persons in the Bankâ€”it is necessary for notes to be signed by the manager, by procuration of some
body, and by the accountant, by procuration of somebody, and until it has those two signatures it is not a note, but only a piece of paperâ€”this is not the signature of the person authorized to sign for the accountant, and he has no power to give authority to anybody else to sign a note.

p.rs: GUILTY.Recommended to mercy by the jury believing her to be the tool of another person.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. Ald. FINNIS; Mr. Ald. GIBBON; and ROBERT MALCOLM

div1.p:
545.
CATHERINE WILSON (17)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin

CHARLES JOHN SUNMAN . I keep a general shop at 14, Mate-street, Bethnal-greenâ€”on 7th April, the prisoner came and asked for a penny candle, and tendered a counterfeit shillingâ€”I broke it in two, chucked it back to her on the counter, and asked her how many more she had got like thatâ€”she said, "What is the matter with it?"â€”I said that it was a bad one, and that I thought she had paid me a visit before on Saturday night, for we had one of the same date thenâ€”she picked up the pieces and went away, taking them with herâ€”I followed her down the street, and at the corner of North-street, she sat down on a door-stepâ€”she had not sat there long before three young men joined herâ€”I heard some awkward words from them; they saw I was watching them; I let them go up one street, and I went up another; I saw the prisoner leave the three men; she went up the Bethnal-green-road, and into Mrs. Howes shopâ€”I was standing outside the window and saw her tender a shilling, and saw Mrs. Howes break it in

twoâ€”I went to the door, and said, "Hallo, my lady, this is the second uttering; I will give you in charge"â€”and then she declared she had never seen me beforeâ€”a constable was called in, and she was given in charge.
Prisoner. When I went into the shop I spoke to a young woman first
Witness. Yes; you asked her for the candle.

COURT. Q. Did the young woman take the shilling into the parlour A. Yes; and gave it to meâ€”it was a piece of counterfeit money, which I broke in twoâ€”I showed it to the prisoner firstâ€”I saw the shilling chucked on to the counterâ€”I was just inside the bar parlour at the time, and I saw the young woman take it up, and I never lost sight of it till it came into my handâ€”I am certain of that.
MR. CRAWFORD. Q. When the prisoner left the shop did she take the candle with her or not? A. No; I could see from the parlour what was taking place in the shop; it is all glass.

SAMUEL HOWES . I am a baker, at 180, Bethnal-green-roadâ€”on 7th April, the prisoner came into the shop; I was at one counter and my wife was against the scalesâ€”the prisoner asked her for a half-quartern brickâ€”when it was weighed she put a shilling down; my wife took it, broke it in two, and threw it downâ€”I still kept my position, and Mr. Sunman came in, put his two hands across our door, and said, "Hallo, my lady, we have got you now; you were just in my shop and gave me one"â€”I came round to the door, picked up the shilling, called a policeman, and gave the prisoner in charge with the pieces of the shilling.

COURT. Q. Did Sunman say, "That is the very same shilling she offered to me." A. No; he said she had been in his shop with one, and he broke it in pieces, and she took them awayâ€”his shop is more than a quarter of a mile from mine.

GEORGE TUTTY (Policeman, X 206). I was formerly 309 of the K divisionâ€”I took the prisoner on Monday, 7th April, and received these broken pieces (produced) of a shilling from Mr. Howesâ€”I told the prisoner the chargeâ€”she said, on the way to the station, she was sorry for it, if I would let her go she would never do the like againâ€”she was searched and nothing found on her.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These are two pieces of a bad shilling.

p.hi: The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate was here read as follows: "It is the first I passed anywhere, and the first time I have been in prison."

div1.p: Prisoner's Defence. I did not know it was a bad shilling.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

546.
ROWLAND ROBINSON (33), and
GEORGE CHURCH (34)
, Stealing 3 gallons of gin, the property of
William Harmar and others, their masters.

STEPHEN MILLER . I reside at 7, Red Cross-street, and am clerk to Messrs. Harmar and others, distillers and rectifiers, who carry on their business in that streetâ€”the prisoners were, last month, in their employ as carmen, and had been so, I think, rather more than three yearsâ€”Mr. Chap
man of the Gate-house Hotel, Highgate, is a customer of Messrs. Harmar and Pearsonâ€”on Monday morning, 17th April last, I was about to send a cask of gin to Mr. Chapman'sâ€”it left the warehouse about 9 o'clock in the morningâ€”the prisoners were the carmen who were to take itâ€”I have nothing to refer to now, but I think it contained 101 gallons when it left the warehouseâ€”I put down at the time, how much it containedâ€”I have not that entry with meâ€”I tested that gin about 8 o'clock that morning, and

found it seventeen under proofâ€”it is not possible that anything could have been taken out of that cask between the time I tested it and the time was sent away, without my seeing itâ€”the cask was under my eye from half-past 8 to 9â€”no one could have touched it between that time without my seeing themâ€”I did not see it between 8 and half-past; I was not thereâ€”Mr. Frederick Pearson was thereâ€”he is a son of one of the partners, and is a partner himselfâ€”the cask was quite full when I tested it, with the excep
tion of the sample that was taken outâ€”that deficency was filled up from the vat that the gin was drawn from originallyâ€”the deficiency was about a pintâ€”I saw the prisoners leave the distillery with the waggonâ€”Mr. Chapman's name, the contents, and the strength, were written on the cask with chalkâ€”we always send out a delivery-note with casks sent out in that wayâ€”the delivery-notes are kept in a bookâ€”we do not usually tear them outâ€”the book is delivered to the carman, and he gets the receipt signedâ€”the delivery-note that was given to the prisoners is not in my possessionâ€”the carman should deliver it to the publican, and he would sign itâ€”the carman, if he comes home after the warehouse is shut up, would deliver it to me the next morning; if not, he would deliver it when he came backâ€”the delivery-note was brought back to me by the prisoners the same evening, Monday, 7th April, about 7 o'clockâ€”the whole book was given to meâ€”the note was not then torn out; it was in the bookâ€”this (produced) is the same delivery-noteâ€”Church gave it to meâ€”it mentions 102 gallons as the quantity, and the strength seventeen under proofâ€”Robinson was present when Church gave me thatâ€”Church gave me the book, and said that he had had a row with Mr. Chapman at the Gate House, Highgateâ€”he had accused them of tampering with the gin, and that he had said to Mr. Chapman that he had never been accused of anything of that kind before, and he threatened to kick Chapmanâ€”Church said, in Robinson's presence, that it had been raining all day, all the time they had been out, and a little water might have got in the cans, which they supposed accounted for the deficiency that Mr. Chapman foundâ€”he meant deficiency in the strengthâ€”Robinson corro
borated the statement of Churchâ€”the prisoners appeared soberâ€”they said that Mr. Chapman accused them of being tipsyâ€”I received a telegraphic message the same evening from Mr. Chapman, about ten minutes before the prisoners arrivedâ€”Mr. Chapman came the next morning, and gave me a bottle sealed up, containing ginâ€”I tested it's contents in order to ascertain the strength, and found it fifty-three per cent under proofâ€”I tested it with the hydrometer and thermometer togetherâ€”those instruments sometimes get out of order, but we always keep a standard in our officeâ€”I do not know about there being many hydrometers made inaccuratelyâ€”they get inaccurate.
COURT. Q. Did you test it, and find it fifty-three under proof with the same hydrometer that you had tested it with in the morning, and found it seventeen under proof? A. Yes.

MR. REES. Q. When you sent the prisoners away with this gin, did you give them an excise certificate and also an invoice? A. Yes, these two (produced)â€”if you put a gallon and a half of water to two gallons and a half of gin of seventeen under proof, it would reduce it about thirty per cent in strengthâ€”it would bring it down from seventeen to about fifty or thereaboutsâ€”I afterwards went to Mr. Chapman's, at Highgate, the day after Mr. Chapman came; I think, the Wednesdayâ€”I tested the contents of a twelve gallon cask that I saw there, and found it thirty-seven under proofâ€”this that I am looking at is a calculation made by myself to tell me how

much gin must have been taken out of that cask, (supposing it to have been full originally of gin at seventeen under proof,) and replaced by water, in order to bring it down to thirty-sevenâ€”I cannot tell when I made this calculationâ€”it is necessary to take out about three gallons of gin, and replaces it by three gallons of water.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. (For Robinson). Q. Did you test it with your own instrument? A. With the instrument belonging to the firm, a similar one to that with which I had tested the gin, and found it seventeen under proof but not the sameâ€”the instrument that I tested and found fifty-three per cent with was the same that I had tested the seventeen per cent withâ€”there was also a vat at Chapman's, which I tested at forty-four under proofâ€”I was not asked about that on the part of the prosecutionâ€”there was nothing at fifty per cent that I tested; nothing besides the bottle and the twelve-gallon cask which I have mentioned was fifty-three under proofâ€”I did not say I had tested a gallon and a halfâ€”when I tested the cask, I had it stirred up, and took it from both the top and bottomâ€”I took a separate sample from each, and tested them separately, and both top and bottom tested at forty-fourâ€”I did that because it might not have been stirred up, and of course then there would have been a differenceâ€”there wit also 250 gallons of gin, seventeen under proof, sent out that dayâ€”there was no sweet
ened gin sent out that day by the prisoners; I am sure of thatâ€”I do not know what was sent out on the previous dayâ€”sweetened gin is gin sweetened with sugarâ€”the quantity of sugar varies; some people put more than others; it depends on the kind of ginâ€”we have various kinds of gin; say about half a pound of sugar to a gallonâ€”that would not reduce it in strength at allâ€”there were not fifty gallons of sweetened gin sent that dayâ€”I have not got the book hereâ€”I think I made a mistake; I think there was fifty gallons, which they were to deliver to a customer in these very same cansâ€”they would not have to deliver that immediately before they went to Mr. Chap
man'sâ€”I am sure about thatâ€”I did not know you would require the books to be brought; we should have had to bring three or fourâ€”I was not told to bring themâ€”it is all enteredâ€”the load that they took out is not entered in three or four booksâ€”that can be produced if you wish itâ€”this loading list (produced) will tell me all that the prisoners took outâ€”it is not what is called a way-bill in other businessesâ€”it is made by Mr. Pearson.
COURT. Q. Did you check it? A. Yes, I entered the prisoners' load, all the goods they took out from this, and saw that they took these goods.

MR. METCALFE. Q. Then you do find from that that they did take out unsweetened gin? A. Yes, fifty gallonsâ€”they took 200 gallons of un
sweetned gin, and 50 gallons, to Mr. Kent, of St. Pancras-road; I am not sure whether that was sweetened or unsweetened; 100 gallons of un
sweetened, and 50 of sweetened, to Mr. Davis, of the Edinburgh Castle Tavern, Mornington-road; 100 gallons of unsweetened to Mr. Chapman, and five bottles containing cordialsâ€”I made an error; the first fifty was taken to another manâ€”this is only a rough thingâ€”the book I have left at home would tell whether it was sweetened or unsweetened ginâ€”Mr. Chapman tested the vat with meâ€”I told the solicitor for the prosecution that I had tested the vat, and the quantity and proof at which I had tested it.

Cross-examined by MR. LEWIS (For Church). Q. How many gallons of gin would the vat contain? A. About seventyâ€”I should think it would take about ten gallons of water to reduce seventy gallons at seventeen under proof to forty-four under proofâ€”it would take about ten gallons of water to reduce the vat to the proof at which it was, I should thinkâ€”I tested

altogether 102 gallons or thereaboutsâ€”I should think altogether about fifteen gallons of gin must have been removed, and fifteen gallons of water, or diluting power, put to it to average the test at which I found itâ€”the gin in the vat was represented as being gin which had been delivered by our men, with the exception of a small quantity which was in the vat beforeâ€”the small quantity was, I should think, about two gallonsâ€”the remainder of the gin was put into a cask in which there were fifty gallons, which I tested and found twenty-nine under proofâ€”the men brought me home the receipt, on which was written, "Received 102 gallons of something called gin, fifty-five per cent under proof"â€”I did not know what to believe when they brought me that paper; they told me one tale, and that said anotherâ€”the men said it had been raining all the time they were out, and they accounted for the deficiency in strength by saying that water had got into the cansâ€”I did not believe, when I received their statement and the telegram of Mr. Chapman, that it was fifty-five under proof, knowing that it was seventeen when it went outâ€”we sent the men on duty the next three daysâ€”I showed this piece of paper and a telegram to my superiorsâ€”the men were continued on the duty after I came back, having tested the gin myselfâ€”I do not know that they were watched in the mean time.

MR. GIFFARD. Q. Is there any book at Redcross-street from which you will be able to tell us the exact contents of everything that delivery-order refers to? A. Yes, it is in one bookâ€”(MR. GIFFARD directed the witness to fetch it at the close of his examination)â€”I tested about eleven and a half gallons in a twelve-gallon caskâ€”I ascertained the quantity in that caskâ€”that was thirty-seven under proofâ€”the next that I tested was in the large vatâ€”I ascertained that there were ninety-two gallons in thatâ€”Chapman told me he had put in seventy gallons, and when I got there, there were ninety-two gallons in, of what Mr. Chapman called "something"â€”that was forty-four under proofâ€”I tested another cask, but did not take any means to ascertain the quantity that was in itâ€”I should conjecuture that there was about fifty gallons in itâ€”that was twenty-nine under proofâ€”that is all, except the bottle, which was fifty-three under proof.

FREDERICK PEARSON . I am a partner in the firm of Harmar end Co.â€”I was at the warehouse between 8 and half-past 8 on Monday morning, April 7thâ€”I have heard of the cask that was sent to Mr. Chapman'sâ€”if any one had touched that cask between 8 and half-past 8 on that morning I must have seen itâ€”nobody touched itâ€”it was under my eye.

Cross-examined by MR. LEWIS. Q. What are your duties from 8 to half past 8? A. To be in the place and see the people who come inâ€”no one came inâ€”I was not watching close over the caskâ€”I was io the counting-house where I could see if it was touchedâ€”there were not many persons about the placeâ€”there were two men in the warehouse whose duty it was to fill the casks up, and after that they had nothing more to do with them.

JOSIAH CHAPMAN . I keep the Gate House Tavern at Highgate, and am a customer of Messrs. Harmarâ€”on Monday, 7th April, the two prisoners came thereâ€”I received this invoice and permit (produced)â€”the gin is not allowed to be removed without an excise certificateâ€”the prisoners came and reported having brought the ginâ€”they said they had some gin for meâ€”Church spoke, I believe, but I should not like to swear itâ€”I told him I was going down in the cellar on some business, and would open the flaps in about ten minutes or a quarter of an hour, and take the gin inâ€”before opening the flaps I came out of the cellar again, and had occasion to go into the gardenâ€”upon going along the passage I met Robinson with two large stable pails, capable

of holding about three gallons and a half eachâ€”they were not full of waterâ€”I asked him what he wantedâ€”he said that he wanted some water for his horsesâ€”I then took the trouble to show him where the pump was to get itâ€”the pump was inside the house, in the passageâ€”I then left himâ€”I saw Thomas Lee just previous to opening the flaps, and stationed him at the flaps, and told him to be sure and not leave them, but to watch these men; more espe
cially to see that the cans were fullâ€”when I was in the cellar I chalked the number of the measures that were deliveredâ€”the measure was a four-gallon measureâ€”a few minutes after I had been in the cellar, Lee came and made a statement to me, upon which I looked at one of the copper cans, standing on the pavement, and one that was under the syphon, apparently full of ginâ€”I then returned to the cellar and directed Robinson to fill a twelve-gallon cask firstâ€”he said we had better fill the vat first, containing sweetened ginâ€”I said, "No;" I wished the small cask to be filled first to retain it for unsweetened ginâ€”the large vat contained sweetened ginâ€”he again objected to do it, and said that it would be just as well to fill the small cask last, it would be more convenient to himâ€”I insisted upon his filling the small cask and he commenced doing so, and put ten gallons in itâ€”I did not measure what was in the small cask, there might be about from three quarters of a gallon to a gallon, of strong unsweetened gin, in it before he began to fill itâ€”I asked him to give me a sample out of the second four gallon can that he brought downâ€”we were then filling the little caskâ€”it was from the second four gallon can that was poured inâ€”Thomas Lee, the pot-boy, was by me at timeâ€”I put the sample aside on a caskâ€”the jug was an empty oneâ€”I fetched it myselfâ€”it was hanging up in the bar, and was quite clean and dryâ€”the first can full, was put into the twelve-gallon caskâ€”the second, out of which I took the sample, was one of those that I had seen on the pavement either filled or being filledâ€”the remainder of that from which I took the sample was put into the twelve-gallon cask, making the second can that had best emptied into it, less the quantity which I took out for the sampleâ€”we put ten gallons, two cans full and a half, into the small cask, and I then bunged it upâ€”we then began to fill the vatâ€”I said nothing to Robinson or the other man about the sampleâ€”after the small cask was filled, Robinson said it was not right for me to take a sample out of that can, as he had been doing some
thing with gin at Holloway, and wanted me to take it out of anotherâ€”that was just after filling the small cask, while we were filling the vatâ€”I told him that whatever he had been doing with gin at Holloway it could not possibly affect mine, as mine was in one cask by itself, and it ought to be all alikeâ€”he said several times afterwards that it was not his fault, and that he had had nothing to do with itâ€”I do not know what he alluded to as not being his fault, except it was the sampleâ€”Church was drawing it from the cask, and was not within hearingâ€”I heard some conversation between Lee, Church, and Robin
son, in fact, I entered into it myself, because they disputed the tally, both before and after Robinson made that statement to meâ€”the men had both been drinkingâ€”they were just sober enough to carry the cans alongâ€”Robinson had spilt about a gallon of gin in the cellar; he could not hold the can steady to pour it inâ€”there was a dispute about the gin, the sixteen gallons; they wanted to make it eighteen, and they kicked up a row with the potman, and swore at him very much, and the man came to me, and I told them that if they did not deliver their gin in a proper way, I would not take any more inâ€”I keep a tally down stain, and every can that came down, I chalked on the cask it went intoâ€”after taking all the gin, I tested the sample that I had takenâ€”the cask was empty, turned bung down in the waggon, drained out;

I saw itâ€”I closed the flaps and called Thomas Lee, who was down in the cellar, to come up to me in the bar parlourâ€”I received 102 gallons within a little; I suppose there might have been a quart or so, shortâ€”I tested the sample and found it 55 per cent. under proof, instead of 17â€”that was taken from the four-gallon measure before it got into any of my vesselsâ€”the test was made from the sampleâ€”I then poured it into two bottles and sealed them up in Lee's presenceâ€”I sent one to the distillery, and gave the other to Leeâ€”one of them has been sealed up ever sinceâ€”I told the prisoners what the strength of the gin wasâ€”Church was abusive; I told him he had attempted to rob me, and that he was a scoundrelâ€”Church, or both, I should not like to swear which, said that it had been raining, and that some rain water must have got in the cansâ€”it was not raining at the timeâ€”there had been very little rain in Highgate that day, and if it had been raining the whole of the day, not a quarter of a pint would go into those cans, for they are so small at the mouth and they expand at the bottomâ€”Miller came on the Wednesday and tested the twelve-gallon cask, into which the ten gallons had been put by the prisoners.

COURT. Q. Had it been disturbed? A. It had never been touchedâ€”I locked the cellars up and gave the distillery notice of the factâ€”I objected first to give a receipt at all, but upon second consideration I thought I was in duty bound to give a receipt for something, so I gave that one, and immediately afterwards telegraphed to the distilleryâ€”when they left, Church said he would kick my bâ€”so and so, if he lost his situation through it.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. When Robinson asked you about the pump, he told you he wanted the water for his horses? A. Yesâ€”I have not measured the cans, but I should say they would hold fully three gallons and a half each, and perhaps moreâ€”I did not hear him say that he had had sweetened gin at Holloway in his cansâ€”I do not remember his saying anything about sweetened ginâ€”he might have said he had sweetened gin in the cans at Holloway; I should not like to swear positivelyâ€”he said he had been doing something with gin; I will not undertake to swear whether he said it was sweetened gin or notâ€”it was out of the copper can that I took the sampleâ€”I put ten gallons into the twelve-gallon cask, seventy-four gallons of the strong mixing gin in the vat, and eighteen gallons in the Old Tom cask, making in all 102 gallonsâ€”I suppose there might have been about thirty gallons in the Old Tom cask previouslyâ€”it is a very strong ginâ€”that which was in there previously was very strongâ€”it is the strongest gin we sell, only it is very much sweetenedâ€”I did not then sweeten the eighteen gallons which I put in the Old Tom; it is sweetened nowâ€”the gin which was previously in there was sweetenedâ€”the eighteen gallons was sweetened by mixing with the sweetened ginâ€”we have put in sweetening material since, to make it Old Tom, to make the cordialâ€”I cannot test sweetened ginâ€”at the distillery they can, because they re-still itâ€”I can test unsweetened ginâ€”Mr. Miller tested the unsweetened gin with me, and the strong mixing-ginâ€”he did not test the Old Tomâ€”I took it up to the distil
lery, and left it thereâ€”I took five gallons of each, to see the strength of it; that was afterwardsâ€”Mr. Miller tested the twelve-gallon cask, and attempted to test the gin in the large vat, where we had put the seventy-four gallons; there was only about two gallons of sweetened gin in previously, which would not affect it very much, still it would affect itâ€”you could not test it cor
rectly on account of the sweeteningâ€”three gallons in seventy would perhaps make a differerence of 6 or 7 or 10 per cent.â€”there was none put in after the seventy-four gallonsâ€”I have never measured the vatâ€”I should say it

would hold quite 160 gallons, perhaps moreâ€”I cannot swear what he tested that atâ€”I think it was 44 per cent, but I should not like to swear to itâ€”he did not attempt to test the Old Tom, because it was no useâ€”he did not test it at my placeâ€”if he did I did not see itâ€”I did not see him test any other besides the twelve-gallon cask and the vatâ€”it would be matter of im
possibility to test the strength of the Old Tom at anything approaching to the truthâ€”the sugar destroys the effect of the instrumentâ€”no water was put into the vat after the gin was put in, and no more gin at allâ€”I locked the cellars and did nothing till after I had communicated with the distilleryâ€”I told Mr. Miller that fifteen gallons of water had been put into a hundred the day before to reduce the strengthâ€”no more gin had been put inâ€”we don't sell gin so strong as they do at the distilleryâ€”wears obliged to reduce our spirits; sometimes we get rum at 44 over proof, which we are forbidden to sell.

COURT. Q. The fifteen gallons of water was to reduce the hundred that you expected to come in? A. Yes, this very hundredâ€”gin seventeen under, proof is very strong, the strongest the distillers send out.

MR. METCALFE. Q. Was the hundred gallons to be mixed with the fifteen gallons of water so as to make it less strong? A. If it is to be done I like to have the pleasure of doing it myselfâ€”it is done throughout the tradeâ€”I do not know that Mr. Miller tested as a very strong gin at twenty-nine that which we sell as Old Tomâ€”if he did, I did not see himâ€”there was not water put in thatâ€”sugar was put inâ€”there was not a drop of water in the twelve-gallon caskâ€”it was ail genuineâ€”that is a more expensive gin; we get a higher price for it, you can buy gin at any strengthâ€”they disputed the tallyâ€”I got 102 gallons, or within a fraction, but they admitted they were wrongâ€”if I had admitted I was wrong, I should have lost sixteen gallons of ginâ€”it was either at six or seven, and they wanted to put it down at sixteen or eighteen, and if I gave way to them I should have lost sixteen or eighteen gallonsâ€”I went up and saw the cask turned over, and that proved that I was right.

Cross-examined by MR. LEWIS. Q. Assuming that there had been sweetened gin in the cans, the mouths of which were so small, that would have reduced the strength at once, would it not, of the gin? A. I cannot see that that was possibleâ€”the sweetened gin in the vat reduced it 10 per cent.â€”it is not very likely they would leave gin in the cansâ€”I cannot say anything as to whether, if there had been some sweetened gin in the four gallon measure, it would reduce the strength of that which was poured on itâ€”I do not know how it would act on the instrumentsâ€”the fact of a little gin being in the can I do not think would affect it at allâ€”if there had been water in, of course that would have diluted the gin which was poured on itâ€”if there were sweetened gin it would depend on whether the sweetened was watered or notâ€”I sent this receipt home, "Received 102 gallons of something called gin, 55 under proof"â€”that is trueâ€”the men said the sample was not a fair sampleâ€”I could not test that which was in the large vat, nor what was in the Old Tom.

STEPHEN MILLER (re-examined). I have got my book now, and can state the destinations and the quantities that I sent out by the prisoners on the morning of 7th Aprilâ€”there was nothing entrusted to them for Holloway that morning.

COURT. Q. Have you tested the hydrometer while you have been gone? A. I tested it, after I had tested Mr. Chapman's gin, at Highgateâ€”I tested the hydrometer I had used there, with the one I had used at home, and
tested them with the standard which we keep in our office, and found them right.

MR. METCALFE. Q. Is this your book which shows what you have sent out by the prisoner? A. Yesâ€”the leaf which you see torn out it the receipt which Mr. Chapman signedâ€”it is the delivery-book in which I entered the things that went out, and in which I entered the prisoner's loadâ€”the following items constituted their load, "Mr. Davis, 101 gallons of 17 gin, and 50 gallons of Old Tom;" that is the sweetened gin I mentioned; "Mr. Kent, 253 gallons of 17 under proof gin;" that was unsweetened; "Mr. Crosland (A private customer), 4 gallons of old Tom and 4 gallons of British brandy;" they were in sealed bottlesâ€”I have read all that were in the casksâ€”Mr. Davis' address is the Edinburgh Castle, Mornington-road, Regent's-park.

THOMAS LEE . I am potman to Mr. Chapman, of the Gate House Hotel, at Highgateâ€”on Monday, 7th April, about 4 o'clock in the afternoon, Messrs. Harmar & Co's. waggon came thereâ€”the two prisoners came with itâ€”Robinson asked me for a pail to give the horses some waterâ€”I went to the stables, fetched him an empty pail, and directed him where to go and get the water fromâ€”he went and got some and brought it back in the pailâ€”I only noticed the cask of gin in the waggonâ€”I do not know whether there was any name on itâ€”there were two copper cans on the road which had come with the waggonâ€”when Robinson returned with the pail, he emptied the water into one of the four-gallon cans, and then returned for moreâ€”he fetched two pails full of water, one of which he emptied into the other four-gallon canâ€”he did not quite fill the cansâ€”I then went to my master to tell him what I had seenâ€”he was down in the cellarâ€”after I had told him I came up the cellar steps to the flapâ€”I did not notice any pails there thenâ€”I did not see the horses watered at allâ€”I never noticed any water on the ground under the horses' headsâ€”Church was there when I returnedâ€”I saw him just fill one can up with gin and put it on the pavement, and then fill the other up from the syphon, from the caskâ€”those were the two same cans I had seen beforeâ€”I saw him begin to fill both of those cans from the caskâ€”they did not take as long to fill as they usually do when they are empty, a much shorter timeâ€”shortly after this my master came up out of the cellar, and Robinson took one of the cans down into the cellarâ€”I took the other can myselfâ€”when I got down with the second can I saw Robinson emptying the first can into a twelve-gallon caskâ€”I then gave him the can which I hadâ€”he was about emptying that into the twelve-gallon cask, when my master asked him to give him a sampleâ€”Mr. Chapman had a jug to put the sample in, and Robinson filled it from the second canâ€”I then left the cellar and went up to the flapâ€”Robinson came up shortly afterwardsâ€”Church was there, and Robinson said to him, "He has had a sample out of my can; I don't know how you will like it"â€”Church made no replyâ€”the prisoners had been drinkingâ€”when five cans had been taken down Church said it was sevenâ€”I kept a score of the cans as they went downâ€”when six
teen had been taken down, Church said it was eighteenâ€”he and I had some little dispute about itâ€”I then left to speak to my master, and we agreed as to the number of cans that had been taken downâ€”the gin was taken out of the cask till it was perfectly emptyâ€”Robinson told my master he had better have another sample, as that was not a fair one that he had gotâ€”he said nothing about where the sample should be taken fromâ€”after the gin had all been emptied out of the cask, I went with my master to the bar-parlour, and he gave me the sample that had been taken out of the second can, and sealed

it upâ€”I saw him making a test of itâ€”I did not look and see what proof it wasâ€”after the sample was tested it was divided into two bottles, which were sealedâ€”I have got one of themâ€”it is not here; I have not brought itâ€”it is still in the same state as it was when it was sealedâ€”Church asked my master to sign the delivery-note, and he said he would not, at which Church used an expression.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. As soon as you saw the water put into the cans you went down into the cellar? A. Yes; and told my masterâ€”I remained down there three or four minutesâ€”I cannot tell you whether the hones were wateredâ€”I did not go to their headsâ€”I noticed no water on the ground; I did not look for it.

WILLIAM JARVIS . I am a city detective police-officerâ€”on Friday, 11th April, in consequence of something, I went to Messrs. Harmer and Pearson's premises, about 9 o'clock, in the morningâ€”the prisoners were called before Mr. Harmar, who was then in the counting-houseâ€”he said to them, "I have had great complaints about the gin delivered by you; these are two officers, and you must consider yourselves in custody"â€”Church was about to make a reply, and Mr. Harmar said, "You must explain that before a Magistrate"â€”I took them to the station, searched them, and found on Robinson about 7s., and about 2s. 7 1/2 d. on Church.
Cross-examined by MR. LEWIS. Q. Chruch gave you a correct address, did he not? A. Yes; both of them did.

Church received a good character.â€”
GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Month each.

547.
JOHN DAVIS (22)
, Stealing 18 lbs. of mutton, the property of
William Moss.

JOHN ALLISON . I was servant to Mr. William Moss, a butcher of, Worm-wood-street, London, but have now leftâ€”about 10 minutes past 8, on 27th April, I was minding the shopâ€”there were then several quarters of mutton hanging on hooks in the gateway near the shopâ€”I saw one of the hooks swinging, and looked up the court and saw two men, and the prisoner who had the mutton under his armâ€”I saw him clearlyâ€”I went out after himâ€”he ran up the steps at the top of the courtâ€”he saw me coming and ran awayâ€”the two men tried to stop meâ€”I could not see whether the prisoner had the mutton then or notâ€”I did not see him throw it downâ€”he ran into St. Helen's-place, where there is no thoroughfareâ€”I saw him at the top, and I know it was him, because I watched him as he ranâ€”he had a cloth in his possession when the constable took himâ€”the value of the mutton was 16s. I believe.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not say before, that I had thrown it down the area or over the wall? A. I said you had thrown it away.
Prisoner. I never had the meat in my possession.

COURT. Q. What a clock was this? A. About 8 o'clock at nightâ€”it was rather duskâ€”it was so clear that I could seeâ€”there were no other men running up the courtâ€”I have no doubt whatever about the prisoner.

CHARLES RATCLIFFE (City policeman, 635). On 27th April, about 8 in the evening, I was on duty in Peahen-court, and saw the prisoner running out of that court with a long cloth flying under his armâ€”he ran into St. Helen's-place, Bishopsgateâ€”there is no thoroughfare thereâ€”I went after kirn, and took himâ€”I told him what he was charged with, and he said had made a mistake, he thoughtâ€”I found nothing on him but the clothâ€”it was a large butcher's cloth, perhaps a yard and a quarter squareâ€”he gave me a false addressâ€”I did not find he lived there.
Prisoner. Q. The cloth I had in my possession was used for horse rubbing? A. No; it is similar to a butcher's cloth.

GUILTY . *â€”
Confined Two Months.

div0.p: PRESENT.â€”Mr. JUSTICE WILLES; Mr. Ald. ABBISS; and Mr. Ald. GIBBONS.

div1.p:
548.
MARY BURNS (45)
, Feloniously and knowingly uttering a forged 1l. note of the National Bank of Scotland.

JOHN MATTHEWS . I am in the service of Mrs. Massey, a money-changer, of Leadenhall-streetâ€”on 29th April, the prisoner came to our office with two Scotch notes, purporting to be two notes of 1l. each of the National Bank of Scotlandâ€”she held them in her hand, and said, "Will you change these?"â€”I looked at them, and immediately saw that they formed a portion of notes that I had had information respectingâ€”I asked her where she got themâ€”she said, "I brought them from Edinburgh nine months ago in a boxâ€”I said, "These notes have not been printed nine, months; how can that be?"â€”she said, "Indeed, I did"â€”I told her they were forged notesâ€”she said, "I beg your pardon, they are good"â€”I said I must detain themâ€”she said, "Well, then, you must detain me too"â€”I said, "A policeman will soon settle that"â€”she did not make any reply to thatâ€”I sent the boy for a policeman whom I saw passing the door at the time, and gave her in charge to him with the notes.

Cross-examined by MR. PATER. Q. Who was present besides you and the prisoner while you were having this conversation? A. The boyâ€”he is not hereâ€”I am sure that what the prisoner said was not that she ought to have had them nine months ago, and had only got them just nowâ€”she said most distinctly, that she brought them from Edinburgh nine months ago, in reply to my first question where she got them fromâ€”I do not remember her saying anything to the effect that she ought to have had them some months agoâ€”this was about 5 o'clock in the afternoonâ€”I did not leave the shop at allâ€”I did not decline to change the notes and hand them back to herâ€”she was about three minutes in the shop.

JACOB PERKINS BACON . I am manager to the firm of Perkins, Bacon and Co., bank-note engravers, of Fleet-streetâ€”these notes are part of a batch of 500 with the same top numbers, that were stolen from our premisesâ€”the number at the top is 176; the bottom number varies with each oneâ€”we have nothing to do with the signatures; only the printed formsâ€”we print the forms all but the signatures, and send them to the bankâ€”we have not sent these two to the bankâ€”they have been missed from our premises.

Cross-examined. Q. What are the numbers? A. T 176 is the top number of each, and the bottom numbers are 117 and 193â€”I cannot tell at what date they were printedâ€”the date is a nominal date, put by order of the bankâ€”it has nothing to do with the real dateâ€”it is in the printing 11th November, 1861â€”the note was complete with the exception of the two signaturesâ€”this batch of notes was lost some time between the 3d and the 10th of Aprilâ€”we did not find out that they were gone until the 10thâ€”our letter book would show when they were sent to
the bankâ€”we should send a kind of Invoice and letter with themâ€”we do not keep such a book as a bank would keepâ€”we have letter books and receipt books which show everything we send out.

JOHN GIFFARD . I am cashier to the National Bank of Scotland, at their head office, in St. Andrew's-square, Edinburghâ€”it is my duty to issue the notes of the bankâ€”the bank has not issued any notes of this seriesâ€”I dis
tingnish the series by the upper number 176 and the letter Tâ€”there is a gentleman named Addison in the bank, who sometimes signs notesâ€”the signature of John Addison to these notes is not his signatureâ€”we have another gentleman in the bank named Warren, whose initials are A.R.â€”we have no gentleman of that name whose initials are H.R.â€”this signature to these notes is not Mr. Warren'sâ€”these notes are forgeries.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you speak to the handwriting itself, or only from the initials? A. I speak to the handwritingâ€”I am quite certain neither of the initials are those of the gentleman I speak ofâ€”I have seen him sign frequently and know his signature perfectly.
MR. GIFFARD. Q. Is that signature like Mr. Warren's writing? A. No; it is not a good imitation.
COURT. Q. Do you say that no notes of the series T 176 have been issued? A. No; they were never even received from the engravers.

CHARLES RATCLIFF (City-policeman, 635). On the evening of 29th April, I met the prisoner in Leadenhall-streetâ€”she asked me if I could tell her where she could get some Scotch notes changedâ€”I told her most likely at Mr. Massey'sâ€”she went thereâ€”I followed her, and stood against the door outsideâ€”I heard Mr. Matthews say the notes were forged, and tell his boy to fetch a constableâ€”I went inâ€”the notes were handed over to me, and I took her into custodyâ€”on the way to the station I asked her where she got them fromâ€”she said she had received them that morning of a man named McDonald, who lived with her in Edinburgh about three years ago, and that she had given him 10s. change, and she was to meet him by the Royal Exchange about 5 o'clock that dayâ€”she said she did not know where he livedâ€”she gave her own right address.
Cross-examined. Q. I believe you directed her to Mrs. Massey's shop? A. Yesâ€”I was in uniform.

EDWARD SALTER (city police-inspector). On 29th April, the prisoner was brought to the Bishopsgate station-house a little after 5â€”I told her the charge against herâ€”she said she was a widow, and had received the notes, in part payment of rent, from a man of the name of Wilson, who had lodged with her about two months at Glasgowâ€”she further said that she had then an appointment to meet the man by the Royal Exchange, to receive a further sum of money from him.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you hear her say anything about a person of the name of McDonald? A. I did notâ€”it is our invariable practice to ask any party charged with an offence if they have anything to sayâ€”supposing a prisoner gives a satisfactory account, I should discharge herâ€”I am quite positive that Wilson was the name the prisoner mentionedâ€”I mentioned the conversation within five minutes to Foulger, my brother-inspector.

JOHN FOULGER (City police-inspector).
