After the prisoner was locked up I went to her, in consequence of not being able to find out the address she had givenâ€”I said to her, "It is of importance to you to find out this man who you say gave you the notes"â€”she said, "I do not know where he lives; his name is Jack McDonald; I met him in Cheapside about 2 o'clock to
day; he gave me the two notes for lodging that he owed me in Edinburgh,

about three years ago; he wanted some change, and I gave him 10s., and was to meet him again at 5 o'clock by the Royal Exchange, to receive some more money"â€”at a subsequent period of the same evening, I went to her again with another officerâ€”he said to her, "You say you got these from Jack McDonald; I know him very well; he is a fighting man"â€”the said, "No; it is not Jack; his name is Joseph McDonald"â€”she afterwards said at the Mansion-house that his name was Thomas Mc Donald.
Cross-examined. Q. I believe the address was found to be correct? A. Yes; I found it the second timeâ€”I did not hear her say that Wilson was the employer of McDonald; I heard nothing about Wilson.

The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate was read as follows: "If I had any guilty knowledge I should not have asked the constable where I could change the notes, and then go to the place where I knew I should be detained with them; I might have left the notes and gone away if I had not insisted upon staying where my money was. I did not know anything about their being bad."
GUILTY .

p.hi: The prisoner was further charged with having been before convicted at the Surrey Sessions, in March, 1854, of larceny from the person, when she was sentenced to Six Months' imprisonment. To this she

div1.p:
PLEADED GUILTY. **â€ â€”
Four Years' Penal Servitude.

549.
THOMAS HENRY JOHNSON BROWN (40)
, Feloniously forging and uttering a receipt for 6l. with intent to defraud.

p.hi: In the course of his opening, Mr. Sleigh, having stated that he proposed to call Mr. Netherclift and other experts who had examined the document in question, with glasses, with a view of explaining to the Jury the manner in which the alleged forgery was effected,

interposed, and expressed his opinion that such evidence could not be received in a criminal case. Algernon Sidney had been convicted of high treason upon such evidence, and at the Restoration, an Act of Parliament was passed reversing that conviction; in civil proceedings such evidence was admitted, but he could not receive it in a criminal case: it was a question for the Jury to decide upon, they might, if they desired it, have the aid of glasses to assist them in the examination, but he could not permit them to be influenced by a scientific lecture in the witness box.

div1.p:
WILLIAM EDMUND JONES . I am a clerk in the branch Bank of London, 450, Strandâ€”the prisoner kept an account at that bankâ€”on 18th Decem
ber, 1861, he gave me instructions as to the payment and non-payment of certain cheques, this (produced) is the letter, it is in his handwritingâ€”that is the letter upon which I acted (Read: "2, Robert-street, Adelphiâ€”Dear Sirâ€”I gave a Mr. W. Brittain three cheques for 4l. 10s., 7l. 5s., and 7l. respectively, to enable him to purchase some building materials for some works upon which he is engaged; from information just received, I have reason to believe that the whole of those cheques have been misappropriated, and unless I hear to the contrary, of which I will apprise you, I will thank you to refuse to pay them upon presentation")â€”On the 23d of that same month, these three cheques (produced) were presented through the Islington branch of the London and County Bank.

COURT. Q. Were either of the three one of those mentioned in that letter? A. Yes; the one for 7l. 5., it is dated 17th December, 1861, (marked B)â€”the other two cheques are for 7l. 5s. 6d., dated December 11th, 1861 (C), and the third is for 7l. dated 14th December (A)â€”the two latter were paid.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. Subsequently to that 23d December, between that and in early day in January, did the prisoner call and get his pass-book? A. Yes; I believe he didâ€”in the course of business the pass-book is returned to the customer with the cancelled chequesâ€”on 3d January, he came to the bank and brought with him these three chequesâ€”he stated that the cheque for 7l. was a forgery, and that he believed Brittain, the payee, was the man that forged itâ€”he then gave or sent to me, immediately afterwards, a written statementâ€”this (produced) is the document he leftâ€”I handed that and the cheques to Mr. Mullens.

Prisoner. Q. On what day did I receive the pass-book from the Bank? A. That I cannot sayâ€”I do not know who I delivered it to, or whether I delivered it at all; you must have had it away or you could not have become possessed of these chequesâ€”I think a day or two previous to the 3d January, you came to the bank and asked to see Mr. Rogers the manager; you called on the 3d Januaryâ€”I do not recollect your accompanying him into his private roomâ€”he did not send for me into his room and tell me that you had brought back the cheque for 7l. stating that it was a forgery, and ask me how I came to pay itâ€”it was not Mr. Rogers that first named the matter to me; you first mentioned it when Mr. Rogers was not there, a day or two previous to 3d January; I don't think he was in when you first called, for I told you had better refer it to him, and you made an appointment for the 3dâ€”I might have said that if the cheque had come through a private hand I might have remarked the signature more closely; that was not in reply to Mr. Rogers asking how I came to pay itâ€”I received this written statement from Mr. Rogersâ€”I first saw it on the same day that I took it to Mr. Mullens, on Saturday, 4th January; I can't say for cer
tain whether I received it on the 3d or 4th, or whether I received it from you or Mr. Rogers, I was there at the time you brought it; I think it was sent by post the night before, and I saw you next morning with Mr. Rogersâ€”you either sent it or brought itâ€”I can't state positively when I received this note dated, 18th December, it was sent to Mr. Rogers, and he handed it to me (Read: "Particulars relative to forged cheque for 7l. On the 14th December last, William Brittain, having left my employment as fore
man of works at Bennett's-court, Drury-lane, and having taken a contract to the amount of 150l., to do certain works for the Central London. Dwellings' Improvement Company, Limited, asked me to advance him 7l. to enable him to procure some deals and timber to carry out his contract. I told him it was inconvenient for me to do so. He pressed me very hard, and I told him if the person of whom he was going to purchase the good, would take my cheque, dated for the 21st of December, I would oblige him. On the afternoon of that day, ie. the 14th, he told me that he could do with a cheque dated for the 21st, and thereupon I gave him one for 7l. dated the 21st December. This cheque, by his own statement, he was going to pay to Mr. Putney, timber merchant, Elm-street, Gray's-inn-lane. On the morning of Wednesday, December 18th, about noon, Brittain came to me, and said that Mr. Putney's bankers would not take the cheque dated the 21st; and he asked me to give him in exchange a cheque for 7l. of the current date, on the understanding that it should not be presented until the coming Saturday, the 21st of December. I did so, and he presently sent me the cheque which I had given him on the previous Saturday, and which cheque, believing the transaction to be quite regular, I destroyed. In con
sequence of information which I received on this 18th of December, I requested the Bank of London not to pay this cheque, and two others,

dated the 17th instant, in Brittain's favour, for 7l. 5s. and 4l. 10s. re
spectively. On Friday, the 20th of December, I gave Brittain in custody on a charge of obtaining money by false pretences, and he was remanded for a week; and on the evening of the name day, Mrs. Williams, the land-lady of the Harlequin Tavern, Drury-lane, called upon me and stated that she held my cheque for 7l., dated the 18th December, which cheque I produce, and said as follows, viz.: that on Saturday, December 14th, Brittain lad asked her to change a cheque for 7l., and she had said that she could not do so, and that on Monday he had made a similar request to her, and that she changed it for him. That she paid said cheque away on Tuesday, December 17th, and that it was returned to her and refused, by reason of its being post-dated for the 21st December. That she there-upon applied to Brittain for a cheque of the current date, which he promised to procure for her, and that shortly afterwards he brought her a cheque (now produced), dated the 18th of December, whereupon she gave him back the post-dated cheque. This cheque Brittain returned to me, and I de
stroyed, same as before stated. I gave Mrs. Williams' cheque for 7l. (now produced) in lieu of that of which payment had been stopped. The first intimation which I had of the existence of the cheque for 7l, which I say is a forgery, was on Wednesday morning last, January 1st, when a Mr. Smith, baker, of 10, Peter-street, Islington, called upon me and stated that he was the holder of the cheque for 7l. 5s., the payment of which I had ordered to be stopped, and that he had cashed for Brittain three cheques, viz., one for 7l. 5s. one for 7l. 5s. 6d., and one for 7l.; that he had sent them in together to his bankers, the London and County Bank, Islington branch; that the two latter had been paid, but the former had been returned to him on the 23d ult. Since which time be said he had applied to Brittain and his wife for my address, and that he could not and did not obtain it until the after
noon of that day. I told him that I knew nothing of any cheque of mine for 7l. being out; that I had only given Brittain one cheque for that amount, which cheque I had found out that he had cashed at the Harlequin public-house, Drury-lane. On the following morning, Thursday, January 2d, I obtained from the Bank of London the cheque for 7l. produced, and which I presume is the cheque referred to by Mr. Smith, as it appears to have passed through the Islington branch of the London and County Bank. I at once recognised it as a forgery. No part of it is in my handwriting, although, in many respects, it has ft similarity. I believe the cheque to be in the handwriting of Brittain, although I cannot speak positively on this point. This much I know, that on the 14th of December I gave him no other cheque for 7l. than that whioh was dated the 21st of December, and which cheque, it can be indisputably proved that he changed at the Harlequin Tavern, as before stated, and afterwards received in exchange for same the cheque dated the 18th of December, also before stated. I was in the habit of carrying a few blank cheques in my pocket for business pur
poses, and about the 14th of December I lost or mislaid a roll of these. Brittain was daily at my office, and my impression now is that he found them, and that the cheque in question is one of those which I lost. I named my loss to him. I had such confidence in him that I would have trusted him to any amount at that time, and therefore took his word that he had not seen the cheques I had lost. On searching at Brittain's office, in the works at Bennett's-court this day, I found a piece of paper (herewith pro
duced), on which certain attempts to copy my signature are made. I believe them to be in Brittain's handwriting. He is at present out on bail, being

committed to take his trial at the next Middlesex Sessions, for obtaining money by fraud and false pretences, full particulars of which charge have appeared in the newspapers. I believe the total amount of his frauds upon me, as discovered to the present date, are about 60l. There are one or two charges of embezzlement, and several of forged receipts. I have not the least doubt that he forged and uttered the cheque in question.
"THOMAS H.J. BROWN, "January 3d, 1862. 2, Robert-street, Adelphi, W.C.")

RICHARD MULLENS . I am a solicitor carrying on business at 7, Poultryâ€”I am solicitor to the London Bankers Associationâ€”the Bank of London are subscribers to that associationâ€”on 4th January, I received from Mr. Jones the statement which has just been read, with the cheque for 7l. dated 14th December, alleged to be forged, and one or two other cheques which were either annexed to that statement, or which he brought in his hand as speci
mens of Brown's handwritingâ€”in consequence of that, I saw Mr. Brown that name evening, at his office in Robert-street, Adelphi; I had the state
ment with me, and I went through it with him, paragraph by paragraph; he repeated to me almost in the same words as are in the statement, the facts which are alleged in it, with many others, relating to his money transactions with Brittain; be particularly pointed out to me the paper of signatures, which is annexed to this statement, which he said he had found in Brittain's desk at his (Britain's) office in Bennett's-court, where he was clerk of the worksâ€”he told me that Brittain was to surrender at Clerken-well Sessions on the Monday, this being Saturday evening; and I made an appointment to meet Brown at the Clerkenwell Sessions-house at 10 o'clock on the Monday morningâ€”he told me that Brittain had been committed for obtaining money by false pretences; charging more for the men's wages than he had paidâ€”I met him at the Sessions's-house on the Monday; he then made a more detailed statement of his money transactions, for the purpose of showing why he thought Brittain should have committed the forgery, and he handed me this cheque for 6l. (marked K), either on that occasion, or on the Saturday evening, I will not be positive which, he said he had given to Brittain, on 14th December, and also this cheque for 7l. dated 18th December (marked O)â€”I made some inquiries during that day, on the Tuesday. I placed the matter in the hands of Sergeant Packman, and on Wednesday, 10th January, Brittain was taken into custody for uttering the cheque for 7l. dated 14th Decemberâ€”the examination took place that same day, and there was then a remand, Brown being examined as a witnessâ€”I was present when he was sworn and saw him sign both these depositionâ€”(The depositions were here put in and read, together with a paper of signature annexed thereto)â€”in consequence of a statement that he made to me about other forged cheques, which he said he believed Brittain had uttered, I applied to the bank for information as to what cheque, had been presented, and then I wrote to Brown a letter, dated 8th Januaryâ€”the prisoner has had notice to produce that letter (it was here handed in by the prisoner and read; "Do you know anything of the undermentioned cheques, viz. 3l. 3s. to Doxey, 5l. to Palmer, 3l. to Spratt"â€”in reply I received this letter from Brown, dated 9th Januaryâ€”he says, "Palmer and Short's cheques an right, Doxey's I know nothing of"â€”the letter contains a long explanation of some transactions with Doxey, which has nothing whatever to do will this case; but, at the latter part of it, he says, "I inclose you a cheque for 13l. 9s. 6d., which Brittain yesterday asked for, and also the cheque for 7l. 5s. given to Brittain to purchase bricks"â€”that is the cheque marked B,

which had been returned, and which had afterwards come into his handsâ€”my clerk wrote a letter to him, by my direction, and I received this answer to it on 11th Januaryâ€”"I cannot come into the City this morning, my cheque-books are at your service when and where you please"â€”I, or my clerk, wrote to him on 13th, 'telling him to call on me, and bring his counterfoils, cheques, and so forth, and he called on me on the 13th previous to the examination (referring to hit diary), I find I did not see him till the 16thâ€”I wrote to him, requesting him to callâ€”he did not; but I received this letter from him on the 14th, explaining circum
stances which had occurred to him in the meantimeâ€”I next saw him on the 16th, the day of Brittain's second examinationâ€”on that occasion he brought me Brittain's receipt for 13l. 9s. 6d. of which he had previously sent me a cheque, and he also had with him two books of the counterfoils of his chequesâ€”we went at some length into a statement of accounts between him and Brittain, and be read to me from the books several of these counterfoils, I cannot now tell which; he had the book in his hand; and he read occasionally counterfoils to me, and then we went together, or shortly after each other, to the police-courtâ€”I dare say I might have had an opportunity, if I wished it, of looking at the counterfoils, but he had the book in his handâ€”at the second examination Brittain repeatedly stated that the 7l. cheque, which he was charged with uttering, he had received from Brownâ€”it was stated in the presence of the prisoner and the magistrateâ€”he said, I received that cheque in part payment of 20l. which the prisoner owed me for my work"â€”after the examination I asked Brown to send me a statement showing how the 20l. had been paid to Brittain, as he denied that the 20l. had anything to do with the 7l. chequeâ€”I afterwards received from him this letter, dated 24th January, inclosing Britain's contract (Read: "2, Robert-street, Adelphi, January 24, 1862. Dear Sir,â€”I forward the required particulars as to the 20l. I have to apologise for not doing so before, but I have been so busy with other, matters that it escaped my memory. On 3d December last Brittain, much against my wishes, having induced the Company to let him have some work on contract, as his term of employment was nearly ended, signed the contract which I inclose; he had no means with which to procure materials for the work, and he bor
rowed of me for the purpose. He commenced the work in the week ending December 14th, and during that week he borrowed of me as fellows:â€”December 9th, cash, 2l. 14s. 6d. 10th, cheque, 4l. 11th, ditto, 7l. 5s. 6d.; total, 14l."â€”there are two crosses against these items, with a note at the bottom, "you (meaning myself) have both these cheques"â€”("On 14th December, I gave a certificate to him to receive 20l. on account of his contract, and he gave me a receipt for 20l. when I gave him a cheque for 6l. which was the balance then due to him, and at the same time I returned him an I.O.U. for 14l. (exactly of similar kind to the one you now hold of his), the two sums of 6l. and 14l. making up the sum of 20l. for which I had given a certificate, and received his receipt, which receipt I handed to the secretary of the company. He then, December 14th, as I have before stated, wanted to borrow some more money, and I let him have a cheque, dated on the 21st, for 7l. On Tuesday, the 17th December, I went to the works at Bennett's-court, about 10 in the morning, and found that he was not getting on so fast as I could wish, and complained to him about it He said that he was standing still both for bricks and cement (I had not at this time an idea of anything being wrong with him), and that he could not pro
cure them without cash. He said that both Messrs. Scoles and Wood, and

Mr. Ferguson, would take my cheques, and accordingly I went into the office in Bennett's-court and there wrote, him two cheques, one for 4l. 10s. 0d. (which you have) to be paid to Messrs. Scoles and Wood for cement, and one for 7l. 5s. 0d. to be paid to Mr. Ferguson for bricks. Neither of which, as we know, he so appropriated, but cashed one with Mr. Smith, and the other with Mr. Putney, and actually got both the bricks and cement in my name, notwithstanding he was supplied with the funds to pay for them. His gave me an I.O.U. for the 7l. on the 14th December, and when he came to my office early in the morning of the 19th December, I gave him back the I.O.U. for the 7l. which he put into the fire, and then he gave me the I.O.U. which you now hold, for 18l. 15s. 0d. with authority to deduct the amount of it from the next payment received by him on his contract. But of this money I have been completely defrauded. It was on the evening of the 19th December that I became convinced that the charges alleged against him, of which I first heard on the afternoon of the 17th, for falsifying his paysheets, while in my service, were unfortunately too true, and after some further investigation, on the morning of the 20th, I gave him into custody on that charge. There is another charge of forgery now to be preferred against him. It is forging a signature to a receipt, and thereby obtaining from me 5l. It is my intention to prefer a bill for this on Monday")â€”The I O U for 8l. 15s. referred to in that letter is this: "London, December 19th, 1861; I O U Mr. Brown 18l. 15s., which I agree that you shall deduct from the money I may receive on my contract at Bennett's-court, on Satur
day next; 7l. 7l. 5s., 4l. 10s.: total, 18l. 15s. (Signed) WM. BRITTAIN, 19/12/61"â€”he had stated in the letter of the 24th that one of the cheques for 4l. was in my possessionâ€”I could not find it, and sent him a telegram that I had not got it, and he sent me a letter stating, "I find, on looking over my papers, that the 4l. cheque is with me, and I inclose it"â€”on Monday, 27th January, the indictment against Brittain was preferred at this Courtâ€”on that morning, I asked the prisoner for further particular about the receipt which he said Brittain had given him for the 20l., and who the person was to whom he delivered it, the letter having stated that he had delivered it to the secretary of the company; and on that day he wrote out this paper in the waiting-room of the grand jury-room, while we were waiting to go before the grand jury: "Mr. S.C. Bosanquet, of 6, Old-square, Lincoln's-inn, is the person that bad the receipt. I received from Brittain, December 14th, receipt for 20l.; I took this to Mr. Bosanquet, told him I had advanced Brittain 14l. on account of the contract, and he gave me open cheque for 20l., telling me that I could pay myself; I then gave Brittain cheque for 6l., and returned him his I O U for 14l."â€”In con
sequence of that statement, I subpÅ“aed Mr. Bosanquet to produce the receipt for 20l.â€”I think it was on the morning of Wednesday, while I was waiting in Court for the trial to come on, that the prisoner put this paper (produced) into my handsâ€”it purports to be a receipt for the 6l., the subject of the present indictment: "London, Dec. 14/61, 6l. memorandum, that Mr. T.H.J. Brown has by cheque for 6l. paid to me the balance due to me out of the sum of 20l., for which he gave a receipt on account of my contract for works in Bennett's-court, for the Central London Dwellings' Improvement Company. Dec. 9th, cash, 2l. 14s. 6d.; 10th, cheque, 4l.; 11th, 7l. 5s. 6d.; 14th, 6l.: total, 20l. Received the above, WM. BRITTAIN, 14/12/61."â€”He told me that he had forgotten that Brittain had given him a second receipt, but that, on looking through his papers, he had found this and brought it to meâ€”I had never heard of any receipt given by Brittain,

relating to the 20l., except the one which had been given to Mr. Bosanquet, until he brought this paperâ€”on the Friday Brittain was tried, on the two charges preferred against him by Brown, in the New Court, before the Common Serjeantâ€”he was acquitted on bothâ€”the trial for the forgery of the 7l. cheque was to have taken place on the Saturday, but Brown was taken ill, and not able to get to the Court, and the trial was adjourned till the following session; the result was, that no evidence was offered, in consequence of something which occurred between me and Brownâ€”Brittain was also acquitted on that chargeâ€”that was on Monday, 3d Marchâ€”I next saw the prisoner on 20th Februaryâ€”I had an interview with him of several hours, in consequence of the facts which had come out on his cross-exami
nation on Brittain's trial, to see if they could be explained awayâ€”I knew that he would be subjected to a like cross-examination on Brittain's re
maining trial, and I wished to see if the circumstances could be explainedâ€”on that occasion he told me that he wished to prefer another charge of forgery against Brittain, and he put into my hands certain documents which, after looking at, I returned to him; one of them was a receipt, purporting to be signed by Brittainâ€”those documents are in the possession of Mr. Avory, who has been subpÅ“naed to produce themâ€”I examined the different documents which have been put in evidenceâ€”(MR. SLEIGH proposed to ask Mr. Mullens at to the alleged alterations in the document, but THE COURT was of opinion that it was altogether a question for the Jury)â€”among the papers which I found belonging to the prisoner, I produce a paper, purporting to be a note written by Mr. Bosanquetâ€”they were found among Brown's papers after his arrest by Packman and myselfâ€”Packman brought a large parcel of them to my officeâ€”I examined them in his presence, and found this amongst them.

Prisoner. Q. On the evening of 4th January, when you called upon me, did not I produce the book of counterfoils, the ledger, and some others? A. Only your ledgerâ€”you showed me that account written on pages 37 and 38â€”there are several items on those pages having reference to the sums contained in the receipt and the I O Uâ€”there is an entry here; headed "Bennett's court contract, 1861: Dec. 9th, cash on loan, 2l. 14s. 6d; 10th, ditto, cheque, 4l.; 11th, ditto, 7l. 5s. 6d.; 14th, ditto, for deals, 7l.; 17th, ditto, cement, 4l. 10s.; ditto, bricks, 7l. 5s.â€”the letter to Mr. Rogers that has been read, dated 18th December, was written nearly three weeks before you showed me this bookâ€”there is no item there of your having paid Brittain 6l.â€”there is on the debit side of the ledger a credit given to Brittain for 14l. received by you from Mr. Bosanquetâ€”that 14l. and the 6l. would make up the sum of 20l.â€”the 6l. being due to Brittain from Mr. Bosanquet, it would not be necessary for you to enter it in your ledger, supposing the entries to be genuine entries; there is no reference to any cash-book hereâ€”there was no cash-book whatever among your papersâ€”the whole of these entries that I have read in the ledger were evidently written at the same timeâ€”I saw that they were there on 4th Januaryâ€”you gave me this cheque for 6l. (marked K) either on Saturday evening or Monday morningâ€”you did not tell me at that time that you had a receipt from Brittain for the 6l., but that you had mislaid it; nor did you tell me that Brittain was indebted to you in the sum of 18l. 15s.â€”you put this book on the tableâ€”I saw it, and it was then in the same state as it is nowâ€”we did not go into the accountâ€”you told me that Brittain owed you over 80l.â€”(Prisoner. I say so now; he owes me over 100l.)â€”No sum of 18l. 15s. was mentioned on that occasionâ€”you put the book before me to show the state

of Brittain's account with you, but we did not go into any details of itâ€”I think you produced several other cheques of yours on that occasionâ€”I did not look at those cheques with a magnifying-glassâ€”I am not in the habit of carrying a glass, only an eye-glassâ€”I did not look at these cheques, and say that looking at them through the glass, the forgery became more apparentâ€”I am not certain whether some person who opened the door to me was not present on that occasionâ€”your wife was not present; she merely looked into the room just before I left; she was certainly not there during the greater portion of the timeâ€”the next time I saw you was a little before 11 in the morning; we were talking together for more than an hour on that occasion upon your transactions with Brittain, and the circumstances which you conceived threw suspicion upon him, and you related to me his mode of carrying on his business, and your mode, and so onâ€”you did not tell me at that time that you had called at Mr. Goodson Smith's shop, but had not been able to see himâ€”that was on the Tuesdayâ€”I do not recollect telling you then that I had called, and was unable to see him, and that I was going to call in the eveningâ€”I could not have told you so, because I did not call upon Mr. Smith at all till the Monday eveningâ€”I did call on him on the Monday eveningâ€”I did not see himâ€”on the next morning (Tuesday) I saw you again at the Sessions House, Clerkenwellâ€”I think I had arranged to meet you there for this reason, that if I had seen Mr. Smith, and he had told me he had received the cheques from Brittain's hands, I should have given Brittain into custody on the Tuesday morning, but as I had not seen Mr. Smith, I declined to do so.

Q. Did you not tell me on that occasion that Mr. Smith had treated you very cavalierly; that he had refused to give you any positive information, and had told you that he had not paid the cheque into a bankers, and re
fused to tell you to whom he had paid it, and you wished me to see him? A. That was later in the dayâ€”I think I saw you three times that dayâ€”I told you that Mr. Smith had behaved rather roughly to meâ€”I don't recollect wishing you to go and see him, and to meet me in the City, and tell me what had taken placeâ€”I believe something of the sort took place, but whether you offered to go, or I asked you to do so, I am not sureâ€”when you called on me in the afternoon, I do not recollect that you told me you had seen Mr. Smithâ€”you did not tell me that he had refused to give you the name of the party to whom he had paid the chequesâ€”I do not recollect anything of the kindâ€”I rather think you came to me that after
noon to know whether I had made up my mind to give Brittain into custody or notâ€”I had told you on the Monday evening that if you saw Moss, the detective, to tell him to come to meâ€”I did not say it was for the purpose of giving Brittain into custodyâ€”Brittain was examined at the police-court, on 8th Januaryâ€”you had your book of counterfoils in your hand thereâ€”you produced it before the Courtâ€”it was not handed to the Magistrate; you offered to show it to himâ€”there was not the slightest concealment about itâ€”when you called on me, on 16th January, I was not looking over your cheque-bookâ€”I am certain that I did not see the cheque-book until after you cameâ€”I am not aware that you had left it with Mr. Base, my clerk, the evening beforeâ€”the book was never in my hands, or on my tableâ€”you had it in your hands, and as I went over the facts, you turned over the counterfoilsâ€”I do not think I even cast my eyes upon the book: it was a book I could not make any use ofâ€”there was no appearance of withhold
ing the book from meâ€”I did not notice any attempt at concealment on your partâ€”Brittain's contract came with one of the letters; I think the

one dated 24th Januaryâ€”my object in applying for it was in consequence of Brittain's repeated statement before the Magistrateâ€”you sent it me as part of the statement relating to the supposed payment of the 20l. by you to Brittainâ€”there was no attempt on your part to withhold documents from me; you inundated me with documentsâ€”when I met you at this Court, on 27th January, you did not tell me that Brittain had given a receipt for 20l. in the course of the day, which you had handed to Mr. Bosanquet, and that at the time you paid him the balance you took his receipt for 6l.â€”you did not give me the receipt on the Tuesday; not until the Wednesdayâ€”I speak with some degree of certainty, because by entries in my diary I was not here on the Tuesdayâ€”(referring)â€”I beg your pardon, I was here on the Tuesdayâ€”you did not give me the receipt on the Tuesdayâ€”I am all but certain that a day intervened before I had itâ€”Monday, the 27th, was the first day of the Sessionâ€”the indictment against Brittain was preferred thenâ€”I had a conversation with you about the receipt referred to in your letter, which you said you bad given to the secretaryâ€”no reference was made in our conversation to any other receipt than thatâ€”the documents were in my possession from the dose of that Session until I saw you on 20th February, but they were not opened by me at allâ€”it was only on the approach of the March Session that I sent for you and opened the docu
mentsâ€”it was after my interview on 20th February that I made what I supposed to be the discovery that they were not genuineâ€”I refer to cheque Aâ€”it remained with me six weeksâ€”I think I told you at the conclusion of Brittain's trial that Mr. Bosanquet had said something about my conduct being very improper in prosecuting Brittain at all, and that he should make some complaint upon the subjectâ€”I overheard him say that as he left the Courtâ€”I did not tell you a few days Afterwards that I had had an interview with Mr. Glyn, and that I had said something to him about the fact of my having been threatenedâ€”you saw me several times between 20th February and 1st Marchâ€”I do not recollect that I asked you to furnish me with other documentsâ€”I received no farther papers from youâ€”I may have done so, but I cannot recall itâ€”this letter of 26th February (produced) is my writingâ€”this states, "I think you said you had some memorandum signed by Brittain about his debt to you; if so, be so good as to bring it with you"â€”that was after I had discovered that these documents were not genuineâ€”I did not consider that all the conversations that took place between us were of a confidential characterâ€”on Thursday, 20th February, you promised to send me a copy of all your correspondence with Mr. Bosan
quetâ€”you called at my office on Saturday, the 22d, but did not see meâ€”I did not ask you on that day to furnish me with a statement of matters as regarded Mr. Bosanquet and Brittain, and copies of the various letters you had received from Brittain and had written to himâ€”that was on the 20thâ€”I afterwards received that statement from youâ€”you called on me after I received that statementâ€”you called continually up to the morning of 3d March, and I particularly drew your attention to a portion of the corre
spondence respecting the arrest of Brittainâ€”I do not recollect remarking that nothing could be more fair or straightforward than the course you had pursuedâ€”I do not think I made any such observation with reference to the letters; I had not got the letters at that timeâ€”I recollect seeing you upon this correspondence on Thursday, 27th Februaryâ€”that was after I had got this copy correspondenceâ€”I recollect reading over two or three letters relating to Brittain's arrest, and pointing out to you that the dates seemed to be inconsistent, and then you said that Mr. Bosanquet pretended that

one letter was written by him after he knew of Brittain's arrest, and asking you not to arrett himâ€”this is the letter (produced)â€”it was found amongst your papersâ€”at the latter part it states "the bearer of this can bring back Mr. Beaumont's contract, and anything else you may have to send me"â€”there is an entry of Mr. Bosanquet's name in your call-book on the 20thâ€”I do not know who made itâ€”you called on me on Saturday, 1st March, and had a long conversation with meâ€”I do not recollect producing, or proposing to produce to you, several of the papersâ€”the principal part of our con
versation was with reference to the additional charge which you said you intended to press against Brittainâ€”I don't recollect asking you to tell me, when I gave you the paper referring to Mr. Bosanquet, in order to refresh my memoryâ€”I did not produce a bundle of papers, and find one or two missingâ€”I will not say I might not have sent for Mr. Base, my clerk, and said, "I cannot think where this paper has got to"â€”I kept part of the papers, and my clerk might have someâ€”as you were going away, I asked if you would be at home in the eveningâ€”I said I was going to a consultation with counsel, and probably I should have to see you in the eveningâ€”I did not say I wanted to see certain letters of Mr. Bosanquetâ€”you did not tell me I was welcome to see anything you hadâ€”you were trying to find out what I was going to do on the Monday, and I did not choose to tell youâ€”I sent you a letter to the effect that counsel had advised under the circumstances that no evidence should be offered against Brittain on the Monday morningâ€”you came to my house early on Monday morningâ€”I did not tell you that, in consequence of his having been acquitted upon two other charges, counsel thought there would be a pre
judice in his favour, and that consequently an acquittal might possibly be the resultâ€”this is the letter that was written to you by my clerk, at Mr. Giffard's chambers, immediately after the consultation, "Temple, March 2, 1862, half-post 4. Sir,â€”Mr. Mullens desires me to inform you that the result of the consultation is, that counsel are of opinion, under all the cir
cumstances, that the Bankers' Committe should not further press the prose
cution against Brittain; it will, however, be open to you to continue the prosecution on your own account, if you think fit; and I send you this information at once, in order that you may instruct Mr. Abrahams, or any other gentleman, without delay"â€”You called on me after that with that letter, and asked what was meant by the last part, and I told you that although the Bankers' Committee did not wish to press it, it was open to you, if you pleased to instruct counsel on your own behalfâ€”I do not recollect your saying if it was useless for me to carry it on, it was folly for you to do soâ€”I do not know that it was in consequence of the receipt of that letter that you did not appear as a witnessâ€”you made an appointment to meet me at this Courtâ€”I did not, at that interview, tell you that I had reason to suppose any of the documents in question were not genuineâ€”on the after
noon of that day, I gave you into custody on the charge of forging this chequeâ€”the police had instructions on the subject before Brittain's acquittalâ€”I have a letter of yours dated the 26th, and one dated the 24th, but none dated the 25th of Februaryâ€”I have no letter from you stating that you had heard it had been put in circulation by Brittain, or his party, that you were guilty of the forgery of this cheque; this is the letter I got from you on the 25th, "I could not manage to spare time to give you a call yesterday; I was told last night that a charge of forgery and perjury is to be preferred against Brittain to-day by a man named Edkins, of Bow-street, with whom he had some transactions;" I hare no letter of the 25th; that was the last

letter I had from you until 18th Marchâ€”no such letter as you refer to was sent to meâ€”this is your letter-bookâ€”I do not recollect the contents of this letter in this book at allâ€”it is not with my papers, and I believe I have brought every paper hereâ€”you told me something about one Julia Ryanâ€”I have every paper here, and the letter you speak of is not among themâ€”you gave me a paper in which something was said about your servant, Julia Ryanâ€”you put it into my hands in Courtâ€”I am afraid I have left that paper behind meâ€”I had no lien of any kind whatever on those documents of yours.

JOHN ABRAHAMS . (This witness being called upon to produce certain docu
ments upon a subpcena, duces tecum, stated that he had been professionally retained by the prisoner to conduct the prosecution against Brittain, and the documents in question had come into his hands in the course of those pro
ceedimgs, and under these circumstances he desired to know whether he ought to produce them. MR. JUSTICE WILLES (after hearing MR. SLEIGH upon the subject) considered that the witness was bound to produce them. They were ac
cordingly handed in.)

Prisoner. Q. On 27th December, I believe, Mr. Bosanquet met me at your office? A. I cannot charge my memory; he might have done, soâ€”I recollect seeing Mr. Bosanquet once, but I cannot speak as so the dayâ€”I think you were with him, but I should not like to say positively.

RICHARD MULLENS (re-examined). With the exception of the instructions for the indictment, these were the documents which the prisoner produced to me on 20th February, upon which be requested me to institute a prose
cution against Brittain, which I declined.

THOMAS EDMEADS . I am clerk in the branch bank of the London and County Bank, in High-street, Islingtonâ€”Mr. William Beckingham, of Southgate-road, Islington, keeps an account with usâ€”on 23d December last, he paid into our bank, to his own account these three cheques for 7l., dated 14th December, 7l. 5s., dated 17th December, and 7l. 5s. 6d., 11th, marked respectively A B C; they are crossed cheques, and all on the Bank of Londonâ€”the cheques for 7l. and 7l. 5s. 6d. were paid; the one for 7l. 5s. was returned unpaidâ€”I noticed the cheques when they were paid inâ€”I believe the cheque for 7l. 5s. is not in the same state now as it was when it was paid into the bankâ€”the words "for bricks, 20, Bennett's-court" have been addedâ€”I believe they were not there when the cheque was paid into our bankâ€”I returned the cheque to Mr. Beckingham.

WILLIAM BECKINGHAM . I live at Sussex-terrace, Southgate-road, South
gateâ€”on 23d December, last, I received from Mr. Smith, a baker, of Islington, these throe cheques for 7l., 7l. 5s., and 7l.. 5s. 6d.â€”I paid them into my bank, the Islington branch of the London and County Bank, on 23d Decemberâ€”on the 24th the 7l. 5s. cheque, marked B, was returned to me dishonouredâ€”I returned it to Mr. Smithâ€”that cheque is not now in the same state as when I handed it back to himâ€”the words "for bricks for Bennett's-court" were not on it at that time.

GOODSON SMITH . I am a baker, of 10, St. Peter-street, Islington; in December, 1861, I received these three cheques from Brittainâ€”he was a customer of mineâ€”I used to change cheques for him when hs asked weâ€”the cheque for 7l., dated 14th December, I received from him on Satur
day the 14thâ€”the one for 7l. 5s. 6d. I received on the 11th, and the other on the 17thâ€”I kept them until the 23d, and then paid them to Mr. Beckingham, my landlordâ€”next day I received back from him this cheque for 7l. 5s.â€”I went with it to the prisoner's office, in Robert-street, Adelphi,

on the 30th, and told him that I had had the cheque returned dishonoured; and he said he would send me an open cheque for it by post, and I could return this; I did not get oneâ€”I went to see him again on the Friday, but did not see himâ€”at last I got this note from him, dated 3d January: "Sir, I am sorry that I was not at home when you called this afternoon; have the goodness to call here on Monday morning with the cheque, and I will settle the matter"â€”I called on the 6th and got a crossed cheque from him for 7l. 5s., and returned the otherâ€”he asked me what cheques I had changed, or what others I had in my possessionâ€”I think he asked whether I had changed the cheque for 7l.â€”I said, "Yes;" and he said, "That is a forgery "â€”this cheque marked B is not in the same state as when I gave it to the prisonerâ€”the words, "for bricks, Bennett's-court" have been added to itâ€”those words were not on it when I first had it, or when I returned it to him.

Prisoner. Q. When do you say you first called on me with reference to this cheque? A. On Monday, 30th Decemberâ€”it was not the 31st; it was in the eveningâ€”I do not know the timeâ€”it was about 7 or 8; I had to wait about half an hour before I could see youâ€”I took a friend with meâ€”you did not at that time state to me that the 7l. cheque was a forgeryâ€”I did not state at Clerkenwell that you had told me on the 30th that you had not given Brittain the cheque for 7l.â€”(the witness deposition was here read)â€”there is a mistake there; I remember it wellâ€”I did not know whether it was at the first or second interview that I had with you, and it was put down as the first; that was on the 30th, but you never stated anything to me about the cheque being a forgery until 6th Januaryâ€”I received the dishonoured cheque back from Mr. Beckingham on 24th Decemberâ€”it remained in my hands six days before I communicated with you, because I did not know where to find youâ€”I could not get your addressâ€”Brittain did not refuse itâ€”I asked Mrs. Brittain, and she said she would go with me to your house one eveningâ€”at that time Brittain was in the House of Detentionâ€”there was no correspondence going on between me and Brittain at that timeâ€”I did not know himâ€”I knew his wifeâ€”I had not seen him above once or twice before thenâ€”I had only known him a very few weeks, while he had been dealing with meâ€”I knew him when he brought the first cheque to be cashedâ€”he was not a stranger to me; he was a customer, but he had of been in the neighbourhood many weeksâ€”I had cashed other cheques of yours, and they were all rightâ€”the first cheque I cashed for him was to oblige you, his masterâ€”I am not aware that he made any particular statement to meâ€”I think he told me that his baker at Notting-hill had been in the habit of doing it for himâ€”he said they were his master's cheques, Mr. Brown'sâ€”he said that you were in the habit of paying him with chequesâ€”I cannot tell you about what time it was that I cashed the first cheque for himâ€”sometimes I was not at home, and they were left till the next morningâ€”I found the cheques all right until the last oneâ€”when I first went to you, I asked why you had ordered the cheque not to be paidâ€”the words "Ordered not to pay" are written across the chequeâ€”I forget what you saidâ€”I don't recollect your saying it was in consequence of the misappropriation by Brittain of three cheques which you had given him, of which that was oneâ€”your wife was not present at this conversationâ€”I took a friend with me, but I left him in a back placeâ€”what I said was, I had got one of your cheques dishonoured, and I should be glad if you could pay meâ€”I was examined at Clerkenwell Police-courtâ€”I remember Mr. Moald, the cheif clerk there, guaranteeing to see the cheque paid, but it has never been paid

â€”I did not ask you on 30th December why you had written on the cheque "Ordered not to be patd"â€”I aaked you the reason it was returnedâ€”I did not tell you that I had paid it with two others through my bankenâ€”I told you that I had paid it to my landlordâ€”I remember calling on you on 6th Januaryâ€”I went three times one day, and could not see you; you came to meâ€”I do not know whether it was on the 7thâ€”I forget now what you called forâ€”you asked me if I had paid the cheques into my bank, and I said no, I had got no bankâ€”you said, "Who did?" and I said, "I do not know, you must go to the bank and see"â€”I did not know who had paid them into the bank; I knew who I had paid them toâ€”I do not think I told Mr. Mullens who I had paid them toâ€”I forget now whether I refused to tell him how I had disposed of the chequesâ€”I don't remember your saying when you called, "You have had a gentleman calling on you about the forged cheque; why tell him one story and me another?"â€”I did not reply that I had a right to say what I likedâ€”I did not refuse to give you the name of the bank where they were paid inâ€”I told you I had received the 7l. cheque on the Saturday evening, and deducted a small account out of it of 11s. or 12s.â€”my books are at home.

WILLIAM BRITTAIN . I did live at 17, Hanover-street, Islingtonâ€”I have removed from there now, I lived there at the time these matters were pendingâ€”I now live at 2, Grosvenor-streetâ€”I am a builder in a small way of businessâ€”I have known the prisoner about five years; two or three years ago I was unfortunate and had to pass through the Insolvent Court, since then I have done several little jobs by contract for the prisoner, and he recommended me as clerk of the works in Bennett's-courtâ€”in the latter part of last year he was appointed as architect and surveyor to the Central Lon
don Dwellings Improvement Companyâ€”I occupied the position of clerk of the works there, so far as Bennett's-court was concerned; the secretary engaged me; during the week it was my duty to make petty disbursements, and on the Friday to render an account to the prisoner of what those disburse
ments were, and also to furnish him with a pay-sheet of the wages of the menâ€”I generally drew about 2l. on the Monday for the petty cash, and rendered an account of it, about 10 o'clock on the Saturday, on the pay-sheets which be used to give meâ€”I took a contract to do a portion of the work myself about the latter end of November or the beginning of Decem
ber, I cannot say the dateâ€”I continued to act as clerk of the works, as regards the remainder of the worksâ€”a person of the name of Beaumont was contractor for that part of the works of which I was clerk, and another builder; they were doing the work for the companyâ€”the prisoner had nothing to do with the contract, beyoud certifying when the work was doneâ€”I could not charge money on account of my contract unless I had a certificateâ€”on Friday, 13th December, I handed to the prisoner this pay-sheet, amounting to 13l. 9s. 6d., but it has been altered since I delivered it; there was a balance-sheet filed with the time-sheetâ€”I had been previ
ously doing some work on my own portion of the contractâ€”on the Satur
day, I went to his office about half-past 9, and told him I wanted 25l.â€”he said he could not let me have more than 20l.â€”he wrote out a receipt and asked me to sign itâ€”I did sign it, and he said if I would come at 10 o'clock, the usual time, he would give me the money; the receipt was for 20l.â€”I went to him in the afternoonâ€”according to his statement there was an amount of 13l. 9s. 6d. due for the men's wages, for the day workmenâ€”he gave me a cheque for that amount, that settled the wages part of the matterâ€”he said he could let me have 13l., and that was by an open cheque for 6l.

and a crow-cheque for 7l., and he could let me have some more on the Tuesday followingâ€”I said I would make shift with that; this cheque for 7l., dated 14th (marked A), is the cheque that be gave me that dayâ€”he owed me 7l. previous to this Saturdayâ€”he had not advanced or lent me an amount of 2l. 14s. 6d. on 9th Decemberâ€”I cannot recollect his giving me a cheque for 4l. on 10th Decemberâ€”I think it is very likely he might have done soâ€”I got this cheque (produced) from him, if I recollect right it was on account of petty cash, the balance-sheet to be given on the following Saturday, and I think he had 2l. out of this, but I cannot recollect for certain; I did not have it or any part of it as a loan, or advance for my own private use, it was received on account of petty cash accounts for the week, and I think Mr. Brown had 2l. out of it; he was in the habit of giving me the cheques for a certain amount, and I was in the habit of taking certain portions of it back again to himâ€”I cannot recollecd whether he had any money out of this or not, if not, it is accounted for in the balance-sheetâ€”I received this cheque for 7l. 5s. 6d., dated 11th Decem
ber, from the prisoner; that he had the money for; I bad the cheque dis
counted and gave him the cash, that I can swear to distinctlyâ€”I frequently got cross-cheques cashed through Mr. Smith, nearly every week, I gave Brown the money; I got this 7l. cheque cashed the same evening I received it, I think on the 14th, by Mr. Smith the bakerâ€”previous to his cashing it, I asked Miss West, the barmaid at the Harlequin, if they could do it, and they could notâ€”I remember the Tuesday following, the 17th, I went to the prisoner that morning for some money, and he said he wanted to see me as he wanted 15l. or 16l. that day very badlyâ€”I said I wanted some as well, and he then wrote out three cheques, one for 7l. 5s., one for 7l., and one for 4l. 10s. and he said, "Here are three cheques for 18l. 15s., bring me 15l. 10s. out of that, and keep the rest yourself," that was on Tuesday the 17thâ€”he said, "Bring me 15l. 10s. and keep the rest yourself "â€”I had 3l. 5s.â€”I took the 7l. cheque to Miss West, and in the afternoon they cashed it; they were not all dated the 17th, the 7l. cheque was a post-dated cheque, but I was not aware of it at the time, it was dated the 21st, the Saturday follow
ing; in the afternoon, they got it cashed for me, by the landlord signing his name to it, and I took that 7l. directly down to Mr. Brown and gave him the seven sovereigns which I receivedâ€”Mr. Osborn, a carpenter, and his brother, were with me at the time I got the money; I got the money in goldâ€”Osborn went with me as far as Brown's, and stayed outside while I went inâ€”I saw Brown and gave him 7l., and then rejoined Osbornâ€”he and I went back to the Harlequin, and had a pint of ale; after paying for it in coppers, 1 missed a sovereign, there was a search made for it, I turned out every pocket of course, it was the only piece of money I had about me; in the presence of Osborn and his brother; the sovereign was afterwards fount by Miss West among the copper, I had given it her in mistakeâ€”I took the 7l. 5s. cheque to Mr. Smith, and he gave me the money next morning; before I took that to Mr. Brown, I took the 4l. 10s. cheque to Mr. Putney's and bought some timber, I gave them the 4l. 10s. cheque, and they gave me the difference outâ€”those two cheques are before meâ€”I gave Brown eight sovereigns and four half-crowns out of the other two cheques, making the 15l. 10s. as he required, and keeping 3l. 15s. as he had promised meâ€”that was on the 18thâ€”on the Wednesday I received a message from the Harle
quin which caused me to go thereâ€”in consequence of a communication that was made to me there, I went to the prisoner and told him he had given me a post-dated chequeâ€”he said, "I thought you asked for one"â€”I said, "Cer
tainly

not"â€”be then gave me another one which I took to the Harlequin, and the landlord sent me over to the post-officeâ€”I got the post-dated one away, inclosed it in an envelope, and sent it by poet to Brownâ€”this is the substituted chequeâ€”there is this memorandum on it, "Paid Mr. Brittain, in exchange for cheque dated 21/12/61â€”I did not, on 14th December, ask him to lend me a cheque post-dated for the 21stâ€”I did not tell him that I was going to buy timber at Mr. Putney's, and that they had told me if I would bring a cheque dated 21st December they would take itâ€”I never on any occasion asked him to lend me a cheque for 7l. dated 21st Decemberâ€”I did not on that 14th December receive any cheque from him for the 7l., save and except the 7l. cheque that has been placed in my hands to-day, dated the 14thâ€”that was the only 7l. cheque I received that dayâ€”I was not in the habit of giving him receipts on blank paperâ€”I have lent him my acceptance several times, but have always had his acknowledgment for itâ€”in the course of business he used always to make out the receipts for me, and I have then signed my name across the penny adhesive stampâ€”I always did that when I received the pay-sheetsâ€”this is the receipt for the 20l. on account of my contract, which I gave the prisoner to hand to Mr. Bosanquetâ€”(Read:"Received this day for payment of Mr. Brittain, for contract of work to be done in Bennett's-court, 20l. 14/12/61.")â€”that is the paper I signed in anticipation of receiving the 20l. from him as I expectedâ€”the body of this IOU, told the writing on the stamp, is mine, I believe, but the other is notâ€”I never signed that stamp on that paper, and I never owed Brown 18l. in my lifeâ€”we handwriting in the body of it is Brown'sâ€”I certainly never wrote my name across that stamp, when it was affixed to that paperâ€”I never saw this paper until after Brown was in custodyâ€”I believe the writing on the stamp is mine; indeed, I have no doubt of it, but when I so wrote on that stamp it was not on that paperâ€”the letters just before the stamp, and the finishing of the letters after the stamp, are not mine, or made by my authorityâ€”there is no truth in the statement that is made on this I 0 U about my owing him that sum of 18l. 15s.â€”it is entirely falseâ€”the body of this paper, which purports to be a receipt for 6l., is in the prisoner's handwritingâ€”the writing on the stamp which is affixed to it, I believe, is mine, but when I se wrote on that stamp it was not affixed to that paperâ€”it must have been affixed to one of the time sheetsâ€”whatever there is that is genuine on this stamp written by me, when I so wrote it, was not affixed to that paperâ€”just before the stamp there are portions of the words "Received the above"â€”that is not in my handwriting, or written by my authority; nothing but what is on the stampâ€”the word "Received" is on the paper, and "the above" is on the stampâ€”the word "Received" is not in my handwriting at allâ€”the "Wm." is not in my writing; the words "the above" are mine, except the final "e" of the word "above"â€”I always signed the pay-sheets on a stamped receipt, with the words "Received the above," the date and my nameâ€”here is one of the pay-sheets for 18l. for November, 1861-that is my writingâ€”there is no receipt to thatâ€”when I parted with that I should say it was not on that half-sheet of paper as it is nowâ€”it had no receipt to it when I handed it to the prisonerâ€”I used to hand them to him on the Friday night, and then affix the stamp on the Saturday, when I received the moneyâ€”I have not the least doubt in the world that when I received the money on the Saturday I put a receipt to it over the receipt stampâ€”this paper seems to have been out since I delivered itâ€”this (produced) is one of the pay-sheets entire, receipt and all; that is how I used to sign
them allâ€”I never gave a pay-sheet without a receipt but once, and that was when Brown had been out all night, and he asked me to go home and make friends with his wife.
MR. MULLENS (re-examined). I only kept the pay-sheets of November and Decemberâ€”the prisoner's attorney applied for the others, and they were returned.

WILLIAM BRITTAIN (continued). On 19th December, Mr. Bosanquet came to my office on the worksâ€”I do not know whether he went to Brown's officeâ€”at that office there were no books and papers belonging to Brown; they belonged to the company, which I kept my accounts inâ€”Mr. Bosanquet made an examination of certain books and papers there in Brown's absence; that was Mr. Charles Bosanquet, not Mr. Samuel Bosanquet, the secretaryâ€”I cannot recollect whether or not I communicated to Brown, on his return, that Mr. Bosanquet had been there and examined the books and papersâ€”I fancy I did, but I could not say positivelyâ€”it was on the next morning that I was given into custody, Friday, 20th Decemberâ€”the body of this memorandum of September, 29, 1860, is Brown's writingâ€”the signature across the stamp is not mine, or written by my authorityâ€”I did not see Brown again until after proceedings were instituted against me
(THE COURT was of opinion that this evidence could not be pursued, as it raised a collateral issue).

Prisoner. Q. Whereabouts was my banker's office situated? A. 450, Strand, at the corner of King William-street, about two minutes walk from your officeâ€”on 11th December, I received from you a cheque for 7l. 5s. 6d. which I cashed for you, and handed you the proceedsâ€”(The prisoner re
quested that his pass-book might be handed to the Jury to show that he had an ample balance that day at his bankers)â€”on 12th December here is credit given you for 2l. on the balance-sheetâ€”I have not given you credit here for 4l. on the 10thâ€”I used to get you money so often that I cannot say whether any part of the 4l. cheque was placed to your credit, but I am quite certain our account has been rendered correctly, and I have not the least doubt that that credit of 2l. on 12th December is in reference to this cheque for 4l.â€”I only received money on account of petty cash once a weekâ€”on December 2d I have given you credit for 2l. petty cash, and on December. 12th 2l.â€”I sometimes used to have a cheque for itâ€”(Looking at the book) here is no cheque for 2l. on 2d Decemberâ€”I always received open cheques from you for petty cash if it was only the amount asked for; if it was only 2l., but sometimes you gave me a larger chequeâ€”here is no cheque booked to me at all on 2d Decemberâ€”on 3d December, here is a cheque for 7l. 12s. 4d., which I got cashed, and gave you some out of itâ€”in this book (The prisoner's diary) here is a cheque for 2l. entered on 2d December, but it might be 200l. or 2,000l.â€”I never saw the book before; how can I tell what you put down?â€”I did not receive the 7l. 5s. 6d. from you on my own accountâ€”I entered on this contract for 150l. on 3d Decemberâ€”I was then decidedly worth 5l. both in money and other thingsâ€”when I was taken in custody my wife had 2l. and I had paid away between 17s. and 18s. on your account that very morning which I have never had backâ€”I was in a position to carry out the contrast of 150l. without borrowingâ€”I did not want to borrow of you, I asked you to let me have 5l. to buy some joists, on 4th or 5th December to go to Osborn's building, because I had been lending Osborn moneyâ€”I told you at the time that it was irregular to take the certificate and the re
ceipt, unless I was in your debt, and you said that you were going there for

the wages, and would bring the moneyâ€”you asked me if I was afraid to trust you, and I said, "Certainly not"â€”it is usual when builders are in difficulties to do it in that way, but it was not so then, and I complained at the time that it was not a regular way of doing businessâ€”on 13th Decem
ber, I owed you 5l. which I had lent you on 4th December, but that was irrespective of my contract, and you agreed to take it back at 10s. a week: I have no memorandum to show thatâ€”I always obtained from you an under-taking for the bills I accepted for you except twoâ€”I know that I was equally liable on those cheques, which I cashed for you, and I always asked you if they were rightâ€”I have no memorandum from you to show that I have re
ceived the money from youâ€”I was led foolishly to trust you, and bitterly I have paid for itâ€”I have no books to show it, it was not business transac
tions with the Company, it was done to oblige youâ€”I have no other papers or documents to support my statementâ€”on 14th December you owed me 20l.â€”I did not receive a 6l. cheque in payment of the balanceâ€”I received the 6l. cheque, and the 7l. crossed cheque, and I believe the cheque-book will prove itâ€”I received three cheques on 17th December, and you then owed me 7l. the balance of the 20l.â€”when I got your cheques cashed I did not think there was any necessity to ask you for a memorandum, the more fool that I was, but I thought you were an honourable manâ€”your own cheque-book will substantiate my statementâ€”on 14th December, when I called upon you, your wife was in and out of the office several times during the inter
view; she was not there the whole timeâ€”she was speaking about the beer-money for the menâ€”I called to give you the 7l.â€”on the afternoon of Tues
day, 17th December, I called on you and told you of the reports which were going about, that I had not been paying the men the amount that had been booked to them, and said that you ought to clear my character; I did not say that Mr. Bosanquet had been making inquiries about me, and wished to know what your opinion wasâ€”I believe it was on the 20th you gave me the cheque, or I brought you the money, I should not like to say for certainâ€”Mr. Fergusson, of Paddington, was supplying me with bricks directly I began the contract at 33s. a thousandâ€”I do not know that I only had 4,500, I paid him 6l. 13s. for themâ€”I did not order any quantity, but when I wanted any I sent him an orderâ€”4,500 bricks would come to 7l. 8s. 6d. and not 7l. 5s., the amount of the cheque you gave meâ€”nothing was said to me about discountâ€”I do not know your arrangementsâ€”what bricks I had were delivered in my own name, and I paid for themâ€”I believe I can swear I never gave you the tickets, but I may be mistakenâ€”I had at that time had some dealing with Messrs. Schole's and Wood for the purchase of limeâ€”I did not take an order for those goods, amounting to 4l. 10s.â€”Mr. Wood did call upon me at Bennett's-court, to know under what circumstances I required them, but that has nothing to do with you; they were goods to go to Notting-hillâ€”I recollect a conversation about it, and I may have said that if he would supply them, I would get an order from you making them all right, and be delivered at Bennett's-court, on 16th or 17 th, one yard of grey lime, and seven sacks, thirty bushels of Roman cement, amounting to 4l. 10s. 4d., and I used that lot on the work set forth in my contractâ€”I did not obtain those goods in your nameâ€”being in your employment at Ben
nett's-court, in October, I went to Mr. Wood and opened an account in the joint names of Brittain and Osborn; that was for goods to go to Notting-hillâ€”I stated that I would pay for them on the Saturday week, but I did notâ€”I owe Mr. Wood 4l. 10s.â€”I think I can swear it is not over 5l.â€”I did not make use of your name in order to obtain those materialsâ€”I did not represent my
self

as being in partnership with Mr. Osborn, I said that he was going to build, and I was going to lend him some money, which I didâ€”the goods were supplied in our joint names, because Mr. Wood had had business with him beforeâ€”I have had several transactions with Mr. Osborn at various timesâ€”this letter, (produced) addressed to you is my writingâ€”the Mr. Osborn mentioned in it is the same personâ€”I told you that Mr. Osborn had had me arrested, but afterwards I found that he was innocentâ€”I do not know a Mr. Allenâ€”there is a Mr. Allen named in this letter. (Produced by the prisoner, and dated Whitecross-street)â€”it says, "Allen was discharged to
day," but who he is I do not know, it must have been some of your acquaint
ances, I never had any business with himâ€”this letter is addressed to Mr. Taylor; I know himâ€”I do not know of any transactions between him and meâ€”a bill of exchange for 21l. 10s., dated 17th May, 1860, and accepted by Willett and Co. was put into my hand when before the Magistrate, and I admitted it to be my writingâ€”I did not say, "I have not made an affi
davit stating that it is a forgery, because the bill I believed to be a forgery was not that bill at allâ€”(The affidavit was here put in by the prisoner) the bill shown to me at Bow-street was not the same bill that I was sued onâ€”I do not know whether this bill (produced) is the one shown me before the Magistrateâ€”I do not believe it isâ€”I swore before the Magistrate that I was not at your house at all on 19th December; I only saw you in the streetâ€”I do not know whether your little boy was christened on 19th De
cemberâ€”I called at your house and saw your wife, who said that you had gone to Bennett's-court, and I saw you about 2 o'clock, which was the only time I saw you on the 19thâ€”I did not come into your private office, nor did your wife give me a glass of wine, and tell me to drink the boy's health as he was going to be christenedâ€”I called, but I did not see you that day till I met you in Drury-lane between 1 and 2 o'clock; Mr. Osborn was with meâ€”it never happened but once that I did net give a receipt to the pay-sheet, and that was when yon came on a Saturday and brought me four 5l. notes, and I had not got the pay-sheet with meâ€”this pay-sheet of 6th De
cember has no receipts to itâ€”I think there has been one to this pay-sheet of November 8, but I should not like to sayâ€”there is some writing on it which is not mineâ€”I never received any money from youâ€”you lent me 5s., but you had it back within a monthâ€”I have been a bankrupt once and got an immediate certificateâ€”I have been insolvent twiceâ€”Mr. Lewis, of Wilmington-square, got me through the Courtâ€”the first time was in the name of William Brittain, and the second William Richard Brittainâ€”it was not five times; it was about the same number of times that you have been, but mine has been through misfortuneâ€”I have not been in the habit of taking building ground and running up carcases and leaving themâ€”I have not built at Holloway or Highgate; I have at Kentish-townâ€”I received 100l. upon them, and ought to have had 360l., but I never had anymoreâ€”I received the materials as part of the improved ground-rentâ€”I have not built at Islington or Hackneyâ€”I was building at Finchley when I became bankruptâ€”I built four carcases at Stratford and sold themâ€”Mr. Hammitt, the surveyor, did not accuse me of obtaining the bricks for those houses, but I gave him bill of your's for themâ€”it was repudiated, and I sued you, and got judg
ment against you for itâ€”I commenced an action against Mr. Hammitt, and lost itâ€”that was for taking my bricksâ€”previous to going into Whitecross-street Prison, I had some transactions with Mr. Gold; I got him to advance me money on billsâ€”I may have represented that they were genuine billsâ€”I wrote you a letter at Whitecross-street, concluding, "I feel very uneasy

about Wednesday, and shall feel obliged If you will call on me in the course of the day, to let me know what course Mr. Lowe means to adopt"â€”he did not accuse me of having obtained money from him on fictitious billsâ€”he says that of all the bills I brought him he could only find the acceptor of one, because two of them had run awayâ€”one of them was not a relative of mineâ€”it was Mr. Lance, and it was for money I lent himâ€”"he went through the Insolvent Court, and lives there now, and I lost the money through itâ€”I had not bill-transactions upon Osborne, in which Messrs. Kidder and Willetts took me in executionâ€”they are not numerousâ€”I could not put the bill of 21l. 10s. in May, 1860, into my schedule, because I did not know anything at all about itâ€”I stated before the Magistrate that I had never been in custody before; that was trueâ€”I did not receive a cheque from you, in March 1st, for 3l. 3s., to pay for some laths; it was for work I had doneâ€”I did not go and pay Mr. Pye, of Hammersmith, for the laths; you paid him, and stopped it off meâ€”I did not, on the day after you gave me in custody, 28th March, agree to arrange and settle for those lathsâ€”I was bound down to keep the peace, because I came to demand my money, which was owing to meâ€”I did not, after I came out on bail, use a number of threats to various people, as to what I would do with youâ€”I charged you 4s. 6d. a load for a man named Forsyth casting away rubbishâ€”I paid him 4s. 6d.â€”I am not aware that Forsyth gave you information that he only received 4s.; you have got the bills, and his own receipts to themâ€”Matthews has been paid the various sums which are charged, except one or two little jobs owing for nowâ€”I did not, on 2d March, pay 16s. to a man named Short, for shovesâ€”I do not know him, and never had transactions with himâ€”I saw Mr. Samuel Bosanqnet at the Sessions-house, Clerkenwell, on 2d Januaryâ€”he gave me some money to engage some one to defend me, because he knew you were prosecuting me for what I was not guilty ofâ€”I have not got the letters I received from him with meâ€”while I was in Pack-man's custody, I met Mr. Edward Dyer, and asked him to come and identify your writingâ€”he said that he had seen the cheque, and did not think it was your writing, but it was not producedâ€”with reference to 17th December, you gave me the cheques, and told me you had an accountâ€”you said that you wanted to keep a good balance, and as you said that you had a balance there, I got them discountedâ€”I have done that week after week, because you said that you wanted to keep your name good, and did not want to draw your account too closeâ€”I brought you 7l. 10s. that night, and 8l. next morning:

MR. SLEIGH. Q. Look at that cheque for 7l. 5s.; is that in the state in which you received it from the prisoner? A. No; the words, "Re bricks, Bennett's-court," have been written in sinceâ€”it was paid away by me; and in this cheque for 4l. 10s. the words, "Re coals and wood," have been added since.

EMMA ASHBY WEST . I am the niece of Mr. Williams, the proprietor of the Harlequin public-house, Drury-laneâ€”I have seen the prisoner there occasionallyâ€”I know Brittain; he used to come there generally during the dayâ€”on Saturday, 14th December, he came there, and asked me to change a chequeâ€”I took it into my handsâ€”this cheque looks like itâ€”I declined cashing it; handed it back to him, and he leftâ€”I particularly noticed that it was dated the 16th, the very day on which it was brought to meâ€”next day, the 17th, he came again with Osborne, and brought a chequeâ€”I did not look at it, but sent a servant out with it, and it was cashed by a neigh
bourâ€”I took the money, 7l., from the servant, handed it to Brittain, and

he left with Osborneâ€”they both came back the same evening, and had something to drinkâ€”he missed a sovereign; a search was made for it, and it was found among some coppersâ€”he turned his pockets inside out, and I do not think there could have been any other money in themâ€”on the next day the cheque was brought back, and I made a communication to Brittain, who afterwards brought me another cheque, and I gave him the origial one.

Prisoner. Q. I think you called on me on 20th December in reference to the cheque? A. I cannot tell you the dateâ€”I am positive of the date of the cheque, because it was a money transactionâ€”I called twice on one dayâ€”I had heard then that Brittain was given in custody, but I cannot say it was that day.

COURT. Q. What did you do? A. I called to inquire of Mr. Brown how it was that the cheque was dishonouredâ€”I am speaking of the cheque which was given instead of the post-dated chequeâ€”it was not brought back by Brittainâ€”it was sent from the bankers, and "Not to be paid" written on itâ€”the cheque I changed on Tuesday, the 17th, came back to me, because it was post-dated, and I gave it back to Brittain in lieu of another dated the 18th, which was given to Mr. Hales, the person who had first of all cashed the chequeâ€”the first cheque was not paid, in consequence of which it was that I went to the prisoner on 20th December.

Prisoner. Q. Did I not tell you that it was in consequence of some cheques which I had paid to Brittain being misappropriated that I stopped payment? A. Yes; I said that it was inconvenient, for me to cash it at that timeâ€”on the following Monday morning, when he came in for some ale, I made it con
venient to cash itâ€”he said that he had not got it with him then, his wife had got itâ€”his wife came down about 1 o'clock on the Mondayâ€”it was on Tuesday the cheque was cashedâ€”he did not apply to me for it till Tuesday, about 4 o'clock, and I was under the impression that it was the same cheque, though I did not think it necessary to look at it, but it could not have been, because I am quite sure the one I looked at on the Saturday was dated the 14thâ€”I cashed it at 4 o'clook on Tuesday afternoonâ€”it was not returned to me about 7 in the eveningâ€”I do not recollect telling you anything at that time about Brittain being short of moneyâ€”I do not think I had the second cheque in my hand till after it was returnedâ€”it was my im
pression that it was the 7l. cheque, nothing was said to the contrary: in fact. I did not think much about it.

HENRY OSBORNE . I am a carpenter, residing at Hammersmithâ€”I have known Brittain for some years; I was with him in the middle of December; when he went to the Harlequin public-house and obtained change for a 7l. chequeâ€”I did not exactly see him receive 7l. in gold, but I saw the cheque sent outâ€”I went with him to his office and waited outside while he went inâ€”he was absent about half an hourâ€”we then went back to the Harlequin and he had a pint of beer, and missed a sovereignâ€”he turned his pockets out to see if it was there, and I saw that he had no money thereâ€”the sovereign was found by Miss West among some coppers.

Prisoner. Q. You cannot say the date? A. No; just previous to that I had asked Brittain to lend me some money to ride home by omnibus, and he told me he had noneâ€”I afterwards said, "You said just now that you had no money; "and he said that he had got it to pay awayâ€”he had no cheques when he turned out his pocketsâ€”I was never in partnership with himâ€”I was not building houses jointly with him at Notting-hillâ€”I paid a joint account to Scohles and Wood, for two yards of lime, but he was

never a partner of mineâ€”I remember your coming to Nottlng-hill, on December 20th, with a police-constableâ€”I do not know whether it was for some iron piping which had been removed from Bennett's-court, Drury-laneâ€”I offered to remove it, and I ran away as I told you would have to doâ€”I have never been insolvent or bankruptâ€”I know Messrs. Kidder and Willett, of Calthorpe-street, Gray's-inn-laneâ€”I did not take them a certain bill of exchange and tell them I had received it for building a stable.

WILLIAM REDRUP . I am in the employ of Mr. Hale, of 100, Drury-lane, who keeps a post-officeâ€”on 17th December, I changed a cheque for 7l. dated 21st or 22d December, which was brought to me by the servant of Mr. Williams of the Harlequinâ€”next day I noticed that it Was post-dated, and got back one dated 18th December in lieu of it.

ROBERT DOLLING . I am in the employ of Mr. Picktering, a builder, of Elm-street, Gray's-innâ€”on 18th December, Brittain bought some timber I there, and gave me in payment this cheque for 4l. 10s.â€”these words "Re Scholes and Wood, "were not on it then.
Prisoner. Q. I think, on 28th December, you called at my office and I gave you cash for that? A. One day in December.

SAMUEL COURTHOPE BOSANQUET . I am a member of the Bar of Lincolin's-inn, and one of the Directors of the Central London Dwellings Improvement Societyâ€”we employed the prisoner in 1861 as surveyor and architect, and Brittain as clerk of the works, and he afterwards had a contract on his own accountâ€”on 14th December, the prisoner called on me in reference to the works, and handed me this receipt for 20l. signed by Brittain, telling me that he had advanced the money to Brittainâ€”this letter of 19th December, directed to the prisoner, is in my writingâ€”before I wrote it I had had some conversation with the prisoner about some charges against Brittainâ€”the date has since been altered to the 20th without my authorityâ€”(This letter stated: "We hope, if you find the charges against Brittain are true, you will not take any steps against him till we have talked the matter over together.")â€”the prosecutor was arrested on the 20th without my authorityâ€”I know the prisoner's writing, and should say that this 7l. cheque, marked A, is his writing; it resembles it, and I believe it to be hisâ€”I have had the opportunity of becoming acquainted with his writingâ€”I believe none of these papers (produced by the officer) are my writingâ€”I am sure two of them are not, but they are very like itâ€”this one purports to be the beginning of a letter of some sort; it is not in my writing, but it is very like itâ€”this letter to Brown, "December 19th, 1861," signed S. C. Bosanquet:â€”"Dear Sir, I decline to see Brittain; we propose that if you find he is guilty you shall give him in custody according to promise; please let your clerk bring me Mr. Bowman's contract;" is not my writingâ€”I never wrote such a letter as that

Prisoner. Q. I think at this time there are two actions in which I am plaintiff? A.
