I do not recollect seeing more than one writ myselfâ€”I have received one personally and one in my capacity of Secretaryâ€”there was a a suggestion made by our solicitors on one occasion to pay some money into Courtâ€”I have never looked at your books or papersâ€”Mr. Mullens showed me a pay-sheet in Brittain's writing, and another paper that contained some accountsâ€”I suppose they had been taken by Packmanâ€”I cannot say when it was resolved not to pay anything on account or into Courtâ€”I very strongly objected to it from the beginning, and I believe our solicitors have declinedâ€”I do not remember finding fault with you while employed by the Company, except for not sending the account inâ€”I told you on one occasion that the

works were going on too slowlyâ€”when you called on me on 14th December, the impression you conveyed to my mind was, that you bad advanced 20l. and I gave you another cheque for 25l. I think, and I believe, I said, "There, I have made it an open cheque, it will not require Brittain's endorsement, and you can pay yourself"â€”I think it was on 17th December that you attended at my office by appointment, at about half-past 11 or 12 o'clock I should thinkâ€”we spoke about the charges against Brittain, and we told you that charges bad been made against him by certain workmen, and we thought it desirable that you should know itâ€”I do not think you informed me that you had a high opinion of Brittain, and did not believe he was guilty of anything of the kindâ€”you may have said that he was unfortunate in buisness, but was still an honest manâ€”I do not remember saying, "Well, Mr. Brown, if Brittain has been defrauding you, we have been defrauded too," but it is very possible you said that you could find out whether it was true or not, and parted from me with the clear understanding that you were to sea a policemanâ€”I believe I received a communication from you on the subject that afternoonâ€”you saw me next day, the 18th, on the same subject, and I think it was understood that if you found there was no question on the subject, Brittain should be prosecutedâ€”here is a letter dated the 19th or 30th, I can say positively that it reached me before the 20thâ€”I believe it was sent by the hands of my clerk, but I had an answer from you, that is hereâ€”I know that it was receivedâ€”no letter was sent before the day that Brittain was taken upâ€”you had not my instructions, on 19th December, to give him into custody, it was the 18th I saw you lastâ€”I de not remember receiving a letter from you, asking whether I should not like to see him firstâ€”I know I wrote you this letter telling you not to proceed without our instructions, and I subsequently received another saying that what we wished should be doneâ€”I never wrote a letter instructing you to give Brittain in custodyâ€”on 27th December, I wrote you this letter. (Looking at it)â€”the transaction had not at that time my entire approval, you had proceeded without our authorityâ€”I met you at his office, and you showed me a number of papers, and mentioned several charges against Brittainâ€”I cannot say whether you produced an I.O.U. for 18l. 15s. 0d., you went fully into nothingâ€”you told me that you had received information that after instigating you to prosecute Brittain, I was defending himâ€”I denied that the Company were assisting himâ€”I cannot say whether you called on me, on Saturday, 11th January, about half-past 11 in the morningâ€”I re
member you callingâ€”you said something about my having acted towards you in an unfair manner, instigating you to prosecute Brittain, and then finding him the means of defenceâ€”I remember that by letter, or word of mouth, you said that persons bad seen me giving Brittain money, on Monday after
noon, at the Sessions-house, Clerkenwell, and that it was useless to deny it any longer; but I do not remember saying that I did it as a matter of charith, though it would be very trueâ€”I did give him something, I do not deny that; but I do not think I said soâ€”I made an appointment for you to see me on the afternoon of that day, at your chambersâ€”I told you that if you wanted the money, you must bring me the account by 2 o'clock that afternoonâ€”I have seen Mr. Bowman's writingâ€”I do not know that I could swear to it, I have had much more of yoursâ€”his address is, 19, Lincoln's-inn-fieldsâ€”I called on you once to ask you to give me up a paperâ€”a girl, named Julia Ryan, came to my chambers in reference to the charge against Brittainâ€”I do not remember using any threat to Mr. Mullins with reference to the prosecutionâ€”I never laid that I should
bring the fact of Mr. Mullans prosecuting Britain before the Banker's Association.

ROBERT PACKMAN . I am a City detective-officerâ€”on 5th January, I took Brittain in custody, on a charge of forgeryâ€”I took the prisoner on 3rd March, on a charge of forgeryâ€”I searched him, and also his rooms, at Robert-street, Adelphiâ€”I produce a quantity of papers which I found, they are marked No. 1 to 40 inclusive.

Prisoner. Q. When you took me did I not request you to search a black bag in my presence, containing a least and some other documents? A. I have no recollection of it; there was such a bag, and you asked me on the next day, at the waiting-room at Bow-Street, to produce certain papers and docu
ments which were in itâ€”they were not producedâ€”you gave me notice that you required their production on the next occasion, and I made an entry of itâ€”these accounts were produced before the Magistrateâ€”your solicitor came down, and some arrangement was made between him and Mr. Mullensâ€”I do not recollect to whose account the papers related the books, papers, and documents, have not remained in my possession ever sinceâ€”Mr. Mullens selected what he thought proper, and I marked themâ€”I cannot say whether they are in the same state nowâ€”these are some of them, here are my initials on themâ€”I am not answerable for the custody of documents after they leave my hands.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. Were you present when Mr. Mullens searched the papers? A. Yesâ€”the solicitor for the defence bad access to themâ€”I was in Mr. Mullen's office on one or two occasions when Mr. Abrahams was there.

The prisoner handed in a paper objecting to the reception of the scraps of papers produced by MR. BOSANQUET; he having received no notice of any such evidence, and knowing nothing wharever of the papers.

ROBERT PACKMAN (re-examined). These scrape of paper with writing upon them, were found in the. waste-paper basket under the writing-table in the prisoner's officeâ€”they were in the same state as they are now.

Prisoner to WILLIAN BRITTAIN. Q. You stated that you had sued me upon bill of exchange, and obtained judgment against me; can you give me the name of the solicitors you employed. A. Yes; Garnett and Lynch, of Gracechurch-Streetâ€”it was at the latter end of 1859 or 1860â€”I am not sure whichâ€”the judgment was filed with my affidavit when I made you a bankrupt.

p.hi:
The prisoner, in the course of a very long address, entered into the circum
stances of his acquaintance and connexion with Brittain down to the time of his employment on the works at Bennett's Court, and contended that the statement which he had all along made in relation to the manner in which the cheques and other documents, was the true one, and that the inspection of his books and papers (which he called for and handed to the Jury), would corroborate that statement. He entered into a detailed account of the circumstances connected with each of the cheques and paper in substance to the same effect as his cross-examination of the witnesses; and with respect to the alleged tampering with the returned cheques and the counterfoils of his cheque-book, he stated that it was his habit to enter upon them the purpose for which the cheques were given.

div1.p:
GUILTY .â€”
Ten Years' Penal Servitude.

p.hi: There were other indietments against the prisoner.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. BARON CHANNELL; Mr. Ald. ROSE; and ROBERT MALCOLM

div1.p:
550.
JAMES POYSER (28)
, Stealing 1 coat and other articles, the property of
William Wright, in his dwelling-house; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

551.
JOHN HENRY JOSEPH COX (52)
, Feloniously cutting and wounding
Caroline Cox with intent to murder her. Other Counts, varying the manner of laying the charge.

CAROLINE COX . I am the prisoner's wife, and live at 42, High-street, Spitalfieldsâ€”on 13th April, my daughter came home about half-past 9 o'clock, and before she came in the prisoner told her that she should go out of doorsâ€”I said, "Where is the little girl to go to with no father to pro
tect her?"â€”he said that she should go in the street, he would be dâ€”d if she should not," and ran to kick herâ€”she was in the room then, but she ran out into the passageâ€”he then locked the room door that she should bide outâ€”he took the key out and then knocked me down, and after I recovered myself I got up and made her come inâ€”the door was not looked, I took the key out before he locked itâ€”he then gave me more blows with his fists and knocked me along the roomâ€”he then twisted the leg off his arm-chair and beat me about the head, and shoulders, and arms, with it, and I cried for mercyâ€”he beat me with it a number of times, till he split it in two, and it went in halfâ€”my daughter was in the passage up to this time, and the door was wide open, she was half in and half out, she was afraid to come inâ€”I implored for mercy, and he said, "Yes, I will give you mercy you bâ€”r," beating me all the while with the leg of the chair (produced)â€”I was almost exhausted with screaming, and he took me up and threw me across the room like a cat, he then jumped on my stomach till the blood gushed out of my mouthâ€”I said, "Oh, I shall die"â€”he said, "You, never die," and he took this flat-iron (produced) and gave me several blows with it on the back of my headâ€”as soon as my daughter saw the iron used, she ran for a policemanâ€”I then became insensible; I felt him take me up, but my eyes were so blinded that I could not see, and he flung me over the stairsâ€”I was taken by the police to Spital-square, where Dr. Edwards examined my head, after which I did not know where I was for some days, till I found myself in the hospitalâ€”I am still an out-patient, but am too ill to go there as I cannot see.

Prisoner. Q. Where did I find that flat, it was never in my sight since you hammered the table to pieces with it? A. You had it on Sunday to fling at your little childâ€”I did not hit you on the head with itâ€”it was all over blood the next day.

COURT. Q. How lately before this attack had you seen the prisoner? A. I saw him two or three times in the dayâ€”he was in the room while I was trying to get my supper, we were not more than usually good friends before my daughter came in, he was never kind to meâ€”he had been drink
ing ever since Saturday, but was not drunk then; this was on Mondayâ€”he always told me he would be hung for meâ€”we lived on the first flight, but there are two pairs of stairs and a landing between.

CAROLINE ARCHER . I am seventeen years old, the prisoner is my father-in-lawâ€”on 14th April, about half-past 9, I came home, he was at home and said that I should go out to the street, for I should not have anything there to eat unless I didâ€”I would not go out, and he got up to kick me out, my mother tried to prevent my being put out, but I ran out into the passage that he should not hit meâ€”my father-in-law and mother then took to quarreling with each otherâ€”the door was half open and half shutâ€”I was just inside the door peeping inâ€”my mother went to take the key out of the door and the prisoner struck her twice with his fist, and she fell on the floor, he also struck her with this chair leg, which he twisted off, he then took her up off the floor and threw her across the room like a cat, to the fire-placeâ€”she cried for mercy, and he said, "Yes, you bâ€”r, I will give you mercy"â€”she said that she should die, and he said, "No, you won't die," and took up this iron from the fire-place, where she was lying, and hit her on the head with itâ€”I then went out to get a policeman, leaving her lying there, and when I came back I found her lying at the front-doorâ€”we live up two pain of stairs, and she had been thrown down two pairs of stairsâ€”she was wounded and was bleeding very much from the back of her head, and from her nose and mouth: she was insensible, and remained so for two days; I got a policeman, and she was taken to the hospital, she remained there speechless for, I think, three daysâ€”she was there upwards of a fortnight, and was an out-door patient after that.

Prisoner. Q. Were you not in the street when this row occurred? A. No; you took the flat from the corner of the fender, it was always there, it was kept there; you had it the night before going to hit the child.

EDWARD GWYNN . I am house-surgeon at the London Hospitalâ€”on 15th April, the prosecutrix was brought there in a state of great prostration, and unable to speakâ€”I found extensive bruises all over her chest and abdomen, and a large bruise on the back of her head, a lacerated woundâ€”her face was much swollen and contused, the left side especially, which was caused, most likely, by the fistâ€”an iron like this, used edgeways, would be likely to cause the cut on the head, but the flat part would only bruiseâ€”the injuries to the chest and abdomen were very serious, it seemed as if some heavy body had fallen upon herâ€”a jump or a persons knee would be just the sort of thing to do itâ€”for the first two days I was afraid she would die from the shockâ€”she remained in the hospital till the 3d May, nearly three weeks, when she was made an out-patientâ€”the sight of her left eye is permanently injured owing to a blow.

EDWIN ROUSE (Policeman, H 145). On the night of 14th April, I was taken by a girl to 18, Old Montague-street, and found the prosecutrix lying behind the street door insensible, and bleeding from a wound in the headâ€”she could not speakâ€”I went up stairs and found the prisoner on the first-floorâ€”I asked him if he knew that he had very nearly killed his wifeâ€”he said, "A bâ€”y good job too, I will murder the bâ€”r before I have done with her"â€”I took him in custody, and had him and the prosecutrix con
veyed to the stationâ€”the prosecutrix was taken to the hospital on the next afternoon, between 1 and 2 o'clockâ€”Caroline Archer gave me the iron next morning.
Prisoner. Q. How can you stand there and say that I said that, did not I say that I would come with you directly? A. Yes.

Prisoner's Defence. This girl of hers will go out to nurse children at 2s. a week, when she can earn 7s. or 8s. a week at binding boots; I have told her if she will be a good girl what kindness I will do her, but if her mother locks the door, as soon as my back is turned she jumps out at the window;

her mother complained to me about her, and called me a bâ€”y Irish bastard, though I am not Irish, and flung a cup of hot tea at me; if I buy anything she breaks it all to pieces. On this evening we went out and had a glass of ale apiece, and both got very nearly drunk; we took three quarts home with us. The girl wanted to be in the street, and I said, "Let her bide, we have always had this bother about her, let her go and get her living the best way she can. Her mother kept calling me names, and pulled my whiskers and nose, and shook me; I said, "If you do not let me alone I shall knock you down;" she said I am a bâ€”y soldier's daughter, and so long as I have got blood in me, I will fight She struck me and I hit her, she got a poker 18 or 22 inches long, but I took it out of her hand and put it under the grate. I said, "I will go out;" she took me by the collar and threw me back, and said, "You bâ€”r, you shall not go out till I have revenge. She fell against the box, and I on top of her, but as to striking her on the head, I did not know it was done till I got to the station house. I had not seen the flat for two months or ten weeks, since she hammered the table to pieces with it.

COURT to CAROLINE COX. Q. Have you heard what the prisoner has stated? A. Yes; I deny it allâ€”I did not strike him or call him namesâ€”I am on my dying oath, I would not tell a lie before God to deceive youâ€”I did not see him bring home any beer that night, we had no beer together, I was frying beef steaks for supper.

rs.hi: of feloniously wounding with intent to do grievous bodily harm.

div1.p:
552.
JOHN BRITNELL (23)
, Feloniously cutting and wounding
James Lucas, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

JAMES LUCAS . I am potman to Mr. Ward, who keeps the Hoop and Grapes, 112, St. George's-street, Whitechapelâ€”on 9th April, between 10 and half-past, some comic singing was going on in the large roomâ€”the prisoner was there with two companions, and I bad two young men with me, friends of mineâ€”two Germans went up to the stage, to give the players some money, and the prisoner malted some of the companyâ€”Mr. Ward, my master, asked me to put him and his two companions out, which I proceeded to do with Mr. Ward at my elbowâ€”I persuaded them to go, and they went quietly till they got to the threshold of the door, when the prisoner made a blow and a kick at meâ€”I prevented the blow, but received the kick on the shin
boneâ€”I went over the threshold, and asked him what he meant by kicking meâ€”he stepped into the road, and struck me a deliberate blowâ€”I tried to save it with my left armâ€”I could not see whether he had anything in his hand, but I received a very heavy blow at the top of the muscle of the left shoulderâ€”I found I was wounded, by the blood pouring outâ€”I staggered to the kerb, and then ran after him as well as I couldâ€”he had a belt round him like mine, like a sailorâ€”I could not see whether there was any sheath to it, but I afterwards saw the policeman with itâ€”a constable stopped him at the corner of Pennington-street, 200 or 500 yards from the houseâ€”I re
mained in the hospital ten or twelve days.

JAMES FERGUSSON . I am a labourer, of 112, St. George's-streetâ€”I was in the concert-roomâ€”the prisoner was there with three friendsâ€”a disturbance took place, and Mr. Ward asked the last witness to put the prisoner and two of his friends outâ€”I told them to go quietlyâ€”they made a blow and a kick at Lucas at the doorâ€”he said, "What did you do that for?"â€”the prisoner put his hand behind him, and I saw Lucas receive a blow on the shoulderâ€”

he cried out, "I am stabbed!"â€”I saw no weapon in the prisoner's handâ€”he ran off very fast, and the people after himâ€”he was brought back by a policeman, and charged at the station with stabbing the potmanâ€”they found a belt and an empty sheath on him, and he said he had got a bâ€”y sheath, but no knifeâ€”he appeared soberâ€”the knife is usually worn behind, on the right hip.

Prisoner. Q. As soon as my companion iusulted the Frenchman, did not I say, "Come on, and do not fight?" and did not you say, "You can't shine here?" A. I said, "Why do not you go quietly? you can't shine here?"â€”that is a phrase among the Americans.

RICHARD THOMPSON . I saw the prisoner stopped by a policeman at the corner of Old Gravel-laneâ€”I afterwards picked up this knife (produced) at that placeâ€”it is 200 or 300 yards from the public-houseâ€”I gave it to the policeman.

Prisoner. Q. You said at the Thames Police-court that you saw me strike the man on the shoulder, and I had no knife? A. I distinctly saw you strike him, but could not see what you bad in your handâ€”I saw blood follow when you took your hand awayâ€”it was not for want of light that I could not see.

RICHARD NEALE (Policeman, A 504). I saw the prisoner running down Old Gravel-lane, and Thompson and others alter himâ€”somebody called out, "Stop him!" and I did soâ€”the prosecutor came up bleeding very pro
fusely from the left armâ€”he said, in the prisoner's presence, "This man has stabbed me, and I give him in custody"â€”when I got him to the station, I found he was wearing this belt, with a sheath to itâ€”this knife was delivered to me by a witness; it fits the sheath, with the handle just out.

EDMUND GWYN . I am house-surgeon at the London Hospitalâ€”the prosecutor was brought there fainting from loss of blood, and bleeding a little, but his wound had been temporarily dressed by a surgeonâ€”it was on the upper part of the arm, at it's junction with the shoulderâ€”it was two inches long and one inch broadâ€”it must have been a violent blowâ€”this is just the sort of knife which would have produced itâ€”I should say that the blow had been aimed at the front part of the body, and warded off by the arm, because the mouth of the wound was the lowest part of it; had it gone into the chest, it would have been very dangerous.

Prisoner's Defence. There were some performers on a bit of a stage at this public-house, and a foreigner wanted to give then some money to buy bread and cheese. One of my companions felt affronted, and wanted to fight. I said, "Let us go;" and, as I passed by the prosecutor, he said, "You can't shine here." I said, "I do not want to shine." I turned round to see if my companions were there, and the potboy struck me in the mouth, and knocked my cap off. I picked it up, walked to the middle of the room, and heard somebody say, "Let him have it." I retreated several paces; the potboy still followed me up; a policeman stopped me, and the potboy gave me in charge for stabbing him, but I had no knife; I lost it at sea before I came to London. The men who were with me have gone to sea; they were struck also. I had a scar when I was first locked up, and my mouth was swelled.
JAMES LUCAS (re-examined). I did not push or kick the prisoner; I merely put my arm behind his shoulder, and passed him to the threshold of the door.
COURT to RICHARD NEALE. Q. Did you see any marks of violence on the prisoner? A. No, he was perfectly free from any marks.

GUILTY of unlawfully wounding. â€”
Confined Six Months

553.
WILLIAM DAVIS (29)
, Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Sugden, and stealing therein 9 spoons, 25 forks, and other articles, his property.

W ILLIAM MARSH (Policeman, N 170). On Sunday morning, 6th April, at a few minutes before 6, I was on duty in Park-road, Holloway, that in very near to Hillmarton-villas, Cam den-roadâ€”I saw the prisoner in front of 18, Hillmarton-villasâ€”I had looked in that direction a second before and there was no one thereâ€”he was hastening towards the Holloway Catsleâ€”I passed on, not seeming to take any noticeâ€”there are no houses there, only a field, so that I was able to see himâ€”when he came to a port where houses were, he looked round each way, and they looked down a turning the Penn-roadâ€”I followed up the Park-road until I came in a line with the Penn-road, and there saw him again watching two personsâ€”I turned back, crossed a field, waited in a recess for about twenty minutes without seeing himâ€”I then went into the Penn-road, and saw him come out of a gateway at the back of Penn-road-villasâ€”I followed him back into the Camdin-road, and asked him what his business was thereâ€”he said that he had been to ease himself, having asked permission of a man who was on a ballast-heapâ€”I asked him his nameâ€”he said William Davis; that he lived at Highgate, near where the omnibuses started, but he could not tell me that name of the street or houseâ€”I took him in custody, having watched his movements three quarters of an hourâ€”I found this knife (produced) on him at the stationâ€”I was afterwards called to 18, Hillmarton-villas, Camden-roadâ€”I took the prisoner's boots with me, and tried them, with Sergeant Gould, to some footmarks in Mr. Sugden's garden, and in the gardens of Nos. 14, 15, 16, 17, and 18â€”they corresponded, and we traced them distinctly to what Sergeant Gould found the property in my presence, concealed under some old building wood, at the back of a garden, about 600 yards from No. 18â€”that is a very exposed place, quite open, a person can get in with very little difficultyâ€”a square of glass had been removed, and an iron bar taken out from some stone work, the cavity in which was filled up with cement, which this knife might have assisted in removingâ€”the bar was outside and must have been removed before the glass.

Prisoner. Q. Were my boots clean or dirty when you took me? A. Dirty, but you washed them in the cellâ€”they had mud on the sides and on the solesâ€”I had been walking about all night, and had mud on the soles of my shoesâ€”an impression was made with your boots by the side of the footmarks, and it corresponded.

COURT. Q. Would the boot when it was clean correspond. A. It will a very wet morning, and the clay would not stick in large quantities, it only smudged the polishâ€”the impression perfectly correspondedâ€”the sides of the boots were muddy, but the soles were clean.

MR. GENT. Q. Was it partly garden mould and partly clay. A. Yes; some places had been freshly dug up, and footmarks might be traced dis
tinctlyâ€”I made several impressionsâ€”I only traced footmarks of one person, but of both feetâ€”there were no thick clods of clay on the boots.

ROBERT GOULD (Police-serjeant, 40 N). On Sunday morning, 6th April, I accompanied the prosecutor from the station to his house, at a few minutes to 9, and found that an entry had been made by removing a thick bar, which had been fastened with cement at the bottomâ€”it was loose at the topâ€”this knife would remove the cement and puttyâ€”I first saw the knife when Marsh brought it to the station, it then had cement and putty on it, as if

it had been rubbed aganist the compoâ€”I traced footsteps from No. 14 to the rear of No. 18â€”they came out of the side gate of No. 18 into Camden-road. where I found similar impressions, and the property wrapped up in two or three different parcels (produced)â€”it was concelaed behind some old build
ing materials, timber, about 400 yard, from the prosecutor's houseâ€”I took the boot, made an impression by the side of the footmark, and it corres
ponded exactlyâ€”there is a peculiarity about the boots, they are rather high in the waist, as if they had been half-soled and stitched together, and that impression was in the markâ€”the sloes had been carried nearer to the heel than is usual, it is half-soleing, or rather I should say three-quarterâ€”they were only the impression of one person's feetâ€”it was in garden mould and was very distinctâ€”the boots were quit free from dirt when I made the Comparison.

Prisoner. The knife is hardly able to out a piece of board, and the waist of this boot is higher than the sole. Witness. The sole is higher than the waist, and there was that peculiarity in all the impression.

COURT. Q. Where is the rise? A. Where the new sole is joined to the old oneâ€”near the heel, and it goes further back towards the heel than is usualâ€”here is part of the old sole leftâ€”that is the part I call the waistâ€”it is raised by the stitches.

JOHN SUGDEN . I am a warehouseman in the City and live at 16, Hill
marton-villas, Camden-roadâ€”on Saturday night, 6th April, about 11 o'clock, I saw everything fast before I restored to restâ€”these are the boots I took off that eveningâ€”they were left in the kitchenâ€”this property is all mine, and all was safe on that nightâ€”soon after 7 the next morning, I was disturbedâ€”an iron bar had been removed from the sill of the pantry window outside, fastened in cementâ€”it could be easily removedâ€”that is at the back of the premisesâ€”the slightest instrument would remove it; there would be no difficulty whatever.

Prisoner. Q. Do you ever walk in your garden in wet weather? A. Yes; after it has been very wetâ€”I never find the mould stick to my shoes to any extentâ€”my paths are all gravelâ€”we traced the footmarks on the mould.

COURT to ROBERT GOULD. Q. Were the footmarks with which you com
pared the boots, in the garden, or at the back of the garden? A. In the back garden, from No. 14 to 18, right across No. 16â€”they were leading from the mould on to the gravelâ€”there were some marks on the gravel, trod off the mouldâ€”the footmarks turned toward, the camden-road when they got to No. 18â€”there are very low walls between the gardens.

Prisoner's Defence. The policeman says he found marks of some person having trod on the mould, and then on the gravel where the mould remained, and if he left it on the gravel, it would be off his shoes, and then he could not leave the mark of shoes if he had fetched the mould off them; when my shoes were measured with the footmarks, they were quite clean, so that they must go into the footmarks and a bigger shoe would go in it.
GUILTY .

He was further charged with having been before convicted at this Court in September, 1854, in the name of
William Ward , and sentenced to Six Years' Penal Servitude; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY. **â€”
Six Years' Penal Servitude.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. COMMON SERJEANT; and ROBERT MALCOLM KERR, Esq.

div1.p:
554.
FREDERICK OSBORNE (22), and
THOMAS WHITE (22)
, Stealing 1l. 14s. 6d. in money, the money of
William Riley. White having been previously convicted; to which they

PLEADED GUILTY . **â€”
Three Years' each Penal Servitude.

555.
JAMES NICHOLLS (27)
, Embezzling the sums of 6l., 19s. 7d., and 2l. 2s. 6d., also 11l., 9l. 11s. 8d., and 10l. 10s. 9 1/2 d.; also 6l. 1s. 4 1/2 d., 4l. 10s., and 2l. 5s., the monies of
Joseph Harris Stretton, and others, his masters; to all of which he

PLEADED GUILTY. â€”MR. ROBINSON for the prosecution, stated that the prisoner had been in the prosecutor's service three or four years, and that until last you his character was unimpeachable, that his family was very respectable, and that the prosecutors recommended him to mercy.â€”
Confined Nine Months

556.
JOHN JONES (45)
, Stealing a coat, value 18s., the property of
Charles Buss.

JAMES BACON . I am foreman to Mr. Charles Buss, tailor, of 34, Holborn-hillâ€”on 14th April, a little before 7 in the evening, our shopman and lad were both oat, so I went into the shop to attend to a customer, and whilst doing so I saw the prisoner come in with three bundles of wadding, apparently to sell, which is a usual thing in our trade for such menâ€”I saw him very rapidly takes a coat off the nest, in which some coats were kept, and conceal it under the waddingâ€”I was then standing on a chair, getting some goods to show to the customerâ€”I jumped down, placed myself between the door and the prisoner, and said, "What do you want?"â€”he said, pointing to the wadding, "Do you want any wadding?"â€”I said, "You have taken a coat off that nest"â€”he said, "No, I have not"â€”I said, "You have, you have stolen a coat"â€”he attempted to get awayâ€”I seized him by the collar, and called our young man, who was at the back; the prisoner struggled hard with me, and I with him; I clung to him, and he got me out on to the pavement some eight or nine yardsâ€”I kept hold of himâ€”I saw this coat (produced) drop from him in the shopâ€”it was afterwards found in the lobby, where no coat ought to beâ€”it was taken to the stationâ€”it is my master's propertyâ€”it cost us 18s.

JOHN FOULGER (City-police-inspector). I was passing Mr. Buss's shop about 7 o'clock in the evening of 14th April, and saw the prisoner rush out of the shop in great haste, the last witness having hold of himâ€”I assisted to take him back into the shop, and saw the bundles of wadding lying at the further part of the shop scattered, as if thrown down in great hasteâ€”I picked up this coat in the lobby, by the street door, while the prisoner was inside.

EDWIN SOUNDY (City-policeman, 250). I was called, and took the prisoner to the stationâ€”I searched him, and found 5 1/2 d. on himâ€”he said nothing relating to the chargeâ€”he refused his name and address.
Prisoner's Defence. I knocked the coat down accidentally. I did not steal it.

COURT to JAMES BACON. Q. How far is the lobby where the coat was first picked up, from the nest where it was taken? A. Three yards, I should think; the coat was folded carefully on the nest, it was anything but
folded in the lobbyâ€”there is a door between the nest and the lobbyâ€”it was standing open.
GUILTY .

p.hi: He was further charged with having been twice before convicted.

div1.p:
JOHN FARROW (Policeman, N 396). I produce a certificate ( Read: Ses
sion House, Clerkenwell, November, 1857. John William, convicted on his own confession, of larceny; having been previously convicted.â€”Four Years' Penal Servitude)â€”the prisoner is the man referred toâ€”I was the officer in the case.

GEORGE MADDOCK (Policeman, G 162). I produce a certificate (Read: "Worship-street Police-court, 22d July, 1861. John Williams, convicted on his own confession, of Stealing a pair of trousers.â€” Confined Six Months)â€”the prisoner in the man.

GUILTY .â€”
Six Years' Penal Servitude.

557.
WILLIAM SEWLING (23)
, Stealing 2 opera glasses, the property of
John Charles Dennis.

p.hi: The prisoner having stated, in the hearing of the jury, that he would plead guilty, the jury returned a verdict of

div1.p:
GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

558.
JOHN DINGLEY
the younger (18),
Stealing, on 11th April, 3 yards of cloth, the property of
Adolph Bimbaum, his master; and
JOHN DINGLEY
the elder (50), and
WILLIAM BOOTH (32),
Feloniously receiv
ing the same; to which JOHN DINGLEY the younger,
PLEADED GUILTY .

URIAH TREW (City-police-sergeant, 36). On 11th April, between 7 and 8 in the evening, I stopped the prisoner Booth in Fenchurch-street, with this parcel (produced) under his arm, done up as it is nowâ€”I asked him what he had got there (I had received some information)â€”he said, "A piece of cloth"â€”I asked him where he got itâ€”he said, "A man gave it me over there in that house," pointing to the Angel public-house, in Fenchurch-streetâ€”I said, "Come with me and point him out"â€”we went and opened the door, and he pointed out the elder Dingleyâ€”I called him out, and asked him if he gave Booth this parcelâ€”he said, "Yes"â€”I said, "Where did you get it?"â€”he said, "I don't know"â€”I then took him into custodyâ€”on the way to the station he said that he had bought it of a man, but did not know who he wasâ€”I have not watched at that public-house more than that nightâ€”another witness will give evidence of thatâ€”Booth had the parcel in his hand in this manner; he was crossing Frederick-street, towards Northumberland-alley.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY (for Booth). Q. You say it was done up as it is now, has it not been opened since? A. Yes, and looked at by the prosecutorsâ€”it was tied up in an ordinary way, and he was carrying it in an ordinary wayâ€”there was no concealment in the matter.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY (for Dingley the elder). Q. Were you in uniform at the time? A. I was.

GEORGE WEBBER . I am a fishmonger, at 28, Dorset-street, Spitalfieldsâ€”I was deputed to watch on this occasionâ€”I stood next door to the prosecu
tor's premises and watchedâ€”on 11th April, shortly after 7 in the evening, I saw the younger Dingley come out with a parcel under the flap of his coat; I could only see part of itâ€”this is the parcelâ€”he first ran across Bishops
gate-street, opposite his employers premises, and went down Bishopagate-street

under an archway; he returned in a minute two, and then went up the opposite side, at a shuffling trotâ€”he met the elder prisoner and took a parcel from under his coat and gave it to him, and he put it under his arm, and then the younger prisoner ran back across the road towards his master's premises againâ€”I lost sight of him, and followed the elder one to the Angel in Fenchurch-streetâ€”he entered, put the parcel on the bar, and leaned his arm on it, like thisâ€”Mr. Booth came up, and he gave him the parceâ€”as he was leaving the place to go to Northumberland-alley, I saw the Sergeant Trew, and told him.
COURT. Q. Did Booth come in immediately after Dingley? A. He was in at the timeâ€”Dingley gave him the parcel, and he leftâ€”he was leaning on the further side of the bar.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. You are described as a fishmonger? A. I am so, and have been thirty yearsâ€”Dorset-street, Spitalfields, is when I lodgeâ€”I have no shop thereâ€”I am a hawking fishmonger in the cityâ€”Shepherd, the police-sergeant, set me to watchâ€”he is an acqnaintance of mine of about twenty years standingâ€”I was carrying on my business as a hawker of fish that dayâ€”I have no barrow, I carry my stock on my headâ€”I was first told by Mr. Shepherd to watch, on the Tuesday previousâ€”I saw nothing relating to this charge that attracted my attention between 2 and 10 minutes past 7â€”I saw nothing the day beforeâ€”the younger Dingley went up the turning before you come to Sun-streetâ€”I was near the prosecutor's premises, sometimes on the opposite side, and sometimes on the same sideâ€”young Dingley, when he came out, crossed towards Piper's-gateway, and then ran up the opposite side of Bishopegate-streetâ€”No. 42, is nearly opposite the Old Paul Pindar, not opposite Sun-streetâ€”he went about two or three houses past his master's premises, on the opposite of the way, near Bishop gate Churchâ€”it was about fifty yards, I should think, from this gateway where he turned underâ€”I have been a witness here once before, upon as assault on a policeman by a soldier named Hainesâ€”I was not employed thenâ€”I assisted the man after he was assaulted.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. Q. Did you hear Booth say he was job
bing about the Angel, and the elder man sent him on an errand? A. I do not recollectâ€”he said he was going to take it to the elder Dingley's lodging I understoodâ€”that was when the sergeant charged himâ€”I did not hear young Dingley say that he was the only guilty party.

ADOLPH BIMBAUM . I am a merchant of 42, Bishopsgate-street, and dead chiefly in cloth on the Continentâ€”the younger Dingley was in my service as errand boy, and to watch the shop and premisesâ€”when he came the elder Dingley presented himself as his fatherâ€”from information I have received, I have missed cloth in considerable quantitiesâ€”I know this piece of clothâ€”I am positive it is part of my goodsâ€”it was brought to me on 11th April, the evening I was called to the police-stationâ€”I had seen it two days before thatâ€”this (produced) is the piece from which it was cutâ€”I have compared them, and they are the same, and the same patternâ€”here is a cut which this piece fits intoâ€”it appears to have been cut with a small pair of scissors, and you can see every little cut.

Cross-examined by MR. DICKIE. Q. Did you buy that from a pattern? A. No; I went to a wholesale house in London and bought itâ€”I doubt whether such cloth as this is to be bought in several wholesale houses; similar cloth might be, but this is an article I bought last summer as a jobâ€”I do not undertake to swear that it cannot be bought in any other warehouse in London.
Cross-examined by MR. COOPER. Q. You do not think that bit would fit any other piece of cloth like that? A. No; I should not think soâ€”the ins and outs fit exactly.

DINGLEY the elder.â€”
GUILTY .

BOOTH.â€”
NOT GUILTY .

559.
JOHN DINGLEY the elder,
JOHN DINGLEY the younger, and
WILLIAM BOOTH , were again indicted for
stealing 3 yards, 6 yards, and 8 yards of cloth, the property of
Adolph Bimbaum, the matter of John Dingley, the younger. Second Count, feloniously receiving the same; to which JOHN DINGLEY the younger,
PLEADED GUILTY .

GEORGE LEWIS . I am a butcher, in the employment of Mr. Hills, of Hart-street, Mark-laneâ€”I know Booth by his coming to the shop for different thingsâ€”he used to run errands, and come for steaks for a house in Fenchurch-streetâ€”about three weeks before I went before the Magistrate, I bought a duplicate of him for a shilling, for this piece of cloth (produced)â€”I do not know where it was pawnedâ€”it was either in Whitechapel or Shoreditchâ€”I saw the duplicate; it was for clothâ€”after purchasing it I returned it to Boothâ€”I told him I had not time to fetch the cloth, and he said he would fetch it for me, and he brought this to meâ€”I wanted it made up into two pairs of trousersâ€”there were four or four and a half yardsâ€”he brought a tailor to me, whom I do not knowâ€”these are the trousers that were made from that cloth.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. Q. What money did you give? A. 8s. 6d.â€”I was to have two pairs; only one had come homeâ€”I did not know then that Booth's father was a tailor; I do nowâ€”I did not know that Booth lodged at his father'sâ€”after I went to the Mansion-house I knew itâ€”the father made the trousers, and the unfinished pair was thereâ€”Booth did not work for me.

WALTER ROBERT SHEPPARD (City-police-sergeant, 32). I went to the lodging of the prisoner, 3, Fireball-court, Houndsditchâ€”I saw his father, and found this pair of trousersâ€”Booth gave me the addressâ€”I went to Mark-lane, and saw the last witness, and he gave me this other pair (produced)â€”they are of the same cloth.
Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. Q. Then it was consequence of what Booth told you that you went to Mr. Lewis? A. Yes.

DAVID RICHARDSON . I am assistant to Mr. Johnson, pawnbroker, 25, Providence-row, Finsburyâ€”I produce a piece of cloth pledged for 6s. on 18th March, in the name of Read, to the best of my belief, by the elder Dingleyâ€”on 28th March, four yards of trousering was pawned in the name of William Taylorâ€”to the best of my belief by the elder Dingley.

Cross-examined by MR. DICKIE. Q. Can you positively swear that it was the elder Dingley? A. Noâ€”we have a great many people in our shop during the dayâ€”we take in a great quantity of that sort of thingâ€”there is only Mr. Johnson and myself there, and I am principally doing the work of the counter, except at meal times, when I am not there.
Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. Q. Are you well acquainted with the pawn broking business? A. Yesâ€”it is not unusual for people to give wrong namesâ€”my idea is that most of them do so.
COURT. Q. Was it the same person who passed both those? A. Yes, to the best of my belief.
WILLIAM MILLS . I am assistant to Mr. George Barker, of Houndsditch, pawnbrokerâ€”I produce two yards of cloth, pledged there on 24th February,
for 10s., in the name of Williamsâ€”I did not take it inâ€”this piece of doe skin (produced) was pledged on 27th March, for 4s. by Booth, in the name of John Smith.
Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. Q. Is it not usual in your business for people to give different names from those which they bear? A. It is very usual.

THOMAS HEATHCOTE PARKER . I am assistant to Mr. George Barker, of High-street, Aldgateâ€”I produce six yards of twill, pledged there by Booth, on 28th March, in the name of Jones, for 12s., and four yards of cloth, pledged by Booth in the name of Smith.
Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. Q. I suppose his giving the name of Jones one time and Smith another did not attract your attention? A. It is very usual.

ADOLPH BIMBAUM . I have examined these two pairs of trousers beforeâ€”the cloth of which they are made is mineâ€”this piece pledged with Mr. Barker, of Aldgate, is also the same clothâ€”I have identified all the property hereâ€”some is of a very peculiar kindâ€”I can swear that it formed part of my propertyâ€”in consequence of that I examined my stock, and have found pieces of cloth containing much less than they contained a month and a half beforeâ€”since the younger Dingley entered my service I have had complaints from abroad of the cloth not being the proper length.
GUILTY .

p.hi: Dingley the elder, received a good character, and

stated that there was very little doubt of the elder prisoner having induced his son to com
mit the robberies; that very large quantities of cloth had been missed, as much as thirty yards having been cut from the centre of some of the rolls, so that they appeared all right until they were unrolled.

div1.p:
DINGLEY the youngerâ€”
Confined Twelve Months.

DINGLEY the elderâ€”
Ten Years' Penal Servitude.

BOOTHâ€”
Six Years' Penal Servitude

560.
JOSEPH FRANKLIN (22), and
MORRIS BLOCK (26)
, Stealing 15 pairs of boots, the property of
William Flatan, their masters. Second Count, feloniously receiving the same.

WILLIAM MILLS . I am assistant to Mr. Barker, pawnbroker, of 91, Houndsditchâ€”I produce seven pairs of new boots pledged with us, one pair on 25th January, at 4s., one pair on 29th January, three pairs on 1st February, and two pairs on 1st Februaryâ€”the prisoner Franklin pledged those on 25th Januaryâ€”I did not take in those of the 29thâ€”the prisoners each pledged a lot on 1st Februaryâ€”these (produced) are the tickets that we attach to them.
Cross-examined by MR. LANGFORD. Q. Were the three pairs on 1st February pledged by Block, and the two pairs by Franklin? A. Yesâ€”they came separately.

JOHN HENRY MONDAY . I am assistant to Mr. John Archbutt, of Bridge-road, Lambeth, pawnbrokerâ€”I produce two pairs of boots pledged there by Franklin, on 22d February, for 5s.â€”I produce one ticketâ€”they are new bootsâ€”I asked him if they were his own propertyâ€”he said, "Yes."

ARNOLD WILLIAM COOLEY . I am assistant to Mr. Jones, a pawnbroker, of 31, Church-street, Spitalfieldsâ€”I produce four pairs of boots pledged with me, one pair on 7th January, by a female, who had been in the habit of pledging at our shopâ€”she gave the name of Franklinâ€”the

other pair was pledged on 24th January, by a female who gave the name of Ann Frehasamâ€”the third pair was pledged on Saturday night, 25th January, by Block, to the best of my beliefâ€”my attention was called particularly at that time, because, while my back was turned, he took up both the ticket and duplicate, and went awayâ€”I was reprimanded for itâ€”I immediately went out to see if he could be foundâ€”I was out for some time, but could not see himâ€”the pair on 5th February was pledged by a woman, in the name of Simon.
Cross-examined by MR. COLLINS. Q. I do not understand you to swear that it was Block? A. I cannot actually swearâ€”I am morally certain.
COURT. Q. Have you any doubt? A. Well, when he came he had a moustache, and it was gaslightâ€”I firmly believe it was Block.

SAMUEL HEZEKIAH COLE . I am a pawnbroker, at 127, Waterloo-roadâ€”I produce two pairs of boots pledged there, on 20th January, for 4s., by Franklin, to the best of my belief, but I am not quite certain, the time is so distant.

WOLFF COHEN (Through an interpreter). I am a shoemaker, and live at 30, Hutchinson-avenueâ€”I have known Block from four months before the Easter holidaysâ€”he called on me at half-past 3 o'clock on Sunday, about three weeks before Easter, and said, "I will tell you something"â€”I said, "What?"â€”he said, "I want you"â€”I said, "Yes; I will go with you"â€”he said; "I will give you tickets"â€”I and, "What tickets have you got?"â€”he Said, "I will tell you"â€”I said, "How many tickets have you got?"â€”he said, "I have got thirty-one tickets"â€”I said, "Where did you get the tickets?"â€”he said, "Never mind; I will give the tickets in hour hand"â€”I said, "What shall I do with the tickets?"â€”he said, "Take the tickets, and go to Spitalfields, and fetch the boots from the pawnbrokers"â€”I said, "I can't, I am a poor man"â€”he said, "Never mind, take the tickets"â€”he gave me the tickets, I put them in my pocket, and we each went homeâ€”I went on Monday to see the governor, Mr. Flatauâ€”I did not see him, and I took the tickets to my house againâ€”I gave them to Mr. Flatau on the Tuesday afterwardsâ€”I have worked for Mr. Flatau three yards and a half.

Cross-examined by MR. COLLINS. Q. Have you ever said you have only known Block three weeks? A. I gave him some work out about three weeks agoâ€”I have been in England four yearsâ€”I swear that I have never pawned anything myselfâ€”when gave the tickets into my hand and said "You may do what you like with them," he did not ask for any money with them.

WILLIAM FLATAU . I carry on business, with Abraham Flatau, at 84, Leadenhall-street, and am a boot and shoe manufacturerâ€”I am one of the prosecutors of this caseâ€”Franklin was in my employment for about four months before the time he was discharged, which was on Saturday, 8th Marchâ€”he assisted in the department for giving out and taking in wortâ€”he was one of our out-door workmen, and had goods given to him to finishâ€”the boots are rivetted, and the bottoms and uppers put on the premises, and then they are given out merely to blacken the soles and to finish themâ€”Block, on some occasions, gave out goods to Franklin and took goods backâ€”I have looked at these goodsâ€”the whole of them are my propertyâ€”I know them by different marks, private marks, and stamps of the different workmen that work on the premisesâ€”the workmen stamp their numbers on the boots, so that if anything is wrong we know which workman to refer toâ€”I have my books in courtâ€”Cohen brought me thirty-one duplicates about two or three days previous to my giving them in charge

â€”I took them to the Bishopsgate-street Police-station, took a detective with me, and we went to two pawnbrokers to see if the things were my pro
pertyâ€”I then directed the prisoners to be taken in custody; we were in search of themâ€”I gave the duplicates to the policeman.

Cross-examined by MR. LANGFORD. Q. Was Franklin an out-door work
man? A. Yesâ€”he came to receive work, and went home and did it, and when he had done it he brought it backâ€”these two pairs that were pledged with Mr. Archbutt are not at all damagedâ€”there is no occasion to look at the rivetting; as soon as a boot is damaged we put our initials on itâ€”the rivetting is quite perfectâ€”the workmen's marks on them show that these boots are perfectâ€”I cannot tell whether they have been returned to my shopâ€”whatever marks there are on them would be on them before they were given out to Franklinâ€”we are rather large manufacturersâ€”we employ about 150 men, and sell many thousands of this kind of boot.

Cross-examined by MR. COLLINS. Q. What wages did you pay Block? A. 10s. a weekâ€”these boots are quite finished, ready for saleâ€”they were never told by atâ€”I know that, because we never sell anything from the shop in pairsâ€”these are not one of a lot sold from our shopâ€”sometimes when workmen return work damaged we make them pay for it or forfeit their wages, and we put private marks on themâ€”we do nothing but a shipping and country tradeâ€”these are ready for sale nowâ€”they would be sold in this Conditionâ€”I cannot swear that they were not parted with by us in the regular way of saleâ€”I was not always present when Booth used to give out workâ€”I used to have the entire management of that department; if I was absent, my brother, or his son, took my placeâ€”there was not one of us always there when work was given outâ€”we have certain days fixed for giving out and taking in work; on some occasions we might be in want of a dozen or so to execute an order, and might say, "Bring those before the regular time"â€”as a rule, either myself, or my brother, or son, was present when Block gave out the goods to workmenâ€”that was the custom of our houseâ€”Block was not employed very late on Saturday nightsâ€”we shut up about 7 o'clockâ€”I cannot tell what time he went; sometimes the same time as the workmen, sometimes a little sooner or laterâ€”he very frequently got away before half-past 8 on a Saturday night.

MR. OPPENHEIM. Q. What time did he come to work on Saturday? A. 8 o'clock was his timeâ€”his brother, who has been in my employment about eight years, told me that his brother was doing nothing, and he would be very glad if I would take him into my employment, although he knew nothing of the trade; but he would not mind if I took him for six months without any wages, he would see that he had sufficient to live on; I said I could not take him with no wages, I would allow him 10s., and if after the expiration of that time he would qualify himself and attend to the business, I would not mind advancing him 5s. a week quarterly, which I did after three monthsâ€”he was in receipt of 15s. a week when he was discharged, and he knew nothing of the businessâ€”all he has done in the business was just the booking, which any schoolboy could doâ€”I used to stand and call out what he was to bookâ€”I cannot tell you exactly when his brother leftâ€”I never directed any of my men to pawn themâ€”we never sell goods, either retail or wholesale, in the London marketâ€”to the best of my belief, these goods were never exported or sent into the country.

JOHN LEONARD (City-policeman, 98). On Friday morning, 11th April, before this charge was made, I took the prisoners in custodyâ€”I received thirty-one pawntickets from Mr. Flatauâ€”I produce a portion of themâ€”a

great number of pawnbrokers gave up their property at the Mansion-houseâ€”I produce the duplicates that correspond with the tickets attached to these goodsâ€”I have examined them, and they correspond exactlyâ€”amongst them are a duplicate and ticket of a similar number, both of the same dateâ€”when I arrested them I charged them with robbing their employers of a considerable amount of boots and shoesâ€”they both said they knew nothing about itâ€”I accompanied Mr. Flatau to nearly all the pawnbrokers when he identified the goodsâ€”I took Block in Trinity-square, Borough; not in his own houseâ€”he was with a Mr. Spronge, a German, I think, a bootmaker, sitting in his roomâ€”(The prisoner's statements before the Magistrate were here read as follows: Franklin says, "I leave it to my solicitor." Block says, "I have been induced to do it; I had a very bad salary, only having 10s. for the first three months, and the witness for the prosecution, Cohen, tempted me the most."

p.hi:
submitted that there was no evidence of Franklin being a servant to Mr. Flatau, as he only received work to do at home, the onus of ser
vitude being that he should receive weekly wages, and that there were express pro
visions made by the legislation for workmen who took their work home; that the prisoner could not be a servant to two masters at one time, and that he received goods from other parties besides Mr. Flatau.

div1.p:
COURT to WILLIAM FLATAU. Q. How was Franklin paid? A. By piece-work; so much for a dozen pairs of boots. (MR. LANGFORD further contended that, assuming him not to be a servant, then he could not be found guilty of any
thing on the first count, as two persons could not be charged each with a different offence, in one count. THE COURT was of opinion that the last case tried was proof to the contrary, telling the jury that if Franklin's mind was honest when he took the boots, and he changed his mind and pawned them afterwards, he would not be guilty of larceny, but only under the summary jurisdiction act.

FRANKLINâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

MORRISâ€”
GUILTY .

p.hi: stated that fifty-nine pairs of boots had been recovered since this charge was made, but that the prosecutors, having had Block's brother in their employ eight years, and knowing his family to be respectable and willing to send him away, recommended him to mercy; and a gentleman stated that he was willing either to send him home or keep him in his employ when he came out of prison.

div1.p:
â€” GUILTY.â€”
Confined Six Months.

div0.p:
PRESENTâ€”Mr. Ald FINNIS; Mr. Ald. GABRIEL; and
ROBERT MALCOLM KERR , Esq.

div1.p:
561.
GEORGE BARTELS (34),
WILLIAM BROWN (25), and
GEORGE ESKUCKEN (19), were indicted for
a riot, and unlawfully assaulting
Conrad Jager. Second count, Unlawfully assaulting
Auguste Sahar.

CONRAD JAGER (through an interpreter). I live at Plumber's-row, White-chapelâ€”I was at a public-house in Fieldgate-street, on Saturday, 22nd Februaryâ€”I left the house about 12 o'clock at nightâ€”as I was coming out these three men and Peter Conse fell on meâ€”Eskucken laid hold of me, and Bartels struck me with a key, on the headâ€”I then became insensibleâ€”I got

up twice, but I do not know what was going on after thatâ€”when I came to my senses I was in the London hospitalâ€”I have been lodging with Bartels for the last yearâ€”I was quite soberâ€”I do not know whether I was kicked when I was downâ€”Eskucken did not want to take me home, he held me.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE (for Bartels). Q. Before the time that you speak of did not you go with several others to Bartels' door. A. I went past thereâ€”I did not pull Bartels down from his door to the ground, nor did any of the people who were with meâ€”the policeman took me away from Bartels, but there were then more then 100 people thereâ€”that was not before the time I have spoken ofâ€”I have been fined since then for assault
ing Mrs. Bartels, but I was fined wrongfully

WILLIAM ROSENBERG . I live at 76, Church-lane, Whitechapelâ€”I had been in Fieldgate-street on this nightâ€”I was there from about a quarter to 72 until, I dare say, near 1â€”I saw Jager there and all three of the pri
soners, and a great many moreâ€”there were two others in company with two of the prisonersâ€”I saw Jager raised from the ground, and I am almost sure it was Bartels shoved him from him, and Eskucken and two others kicked kimâ€”the other two were worse than anybody in the riotâ€”I do not know their namesâ€”I did not see Bartels do anything but give the one blow or Shove away from him, then a crowd gathered, and I was carried awayâ€”they all went into the house after that, I thinkâ€”I cannot say whether the centre one did (Brown), Eskucken didâ€”I did not hear Bartels say anythingâ€”when they were going down to the station-house he said that he would go down and see after his lodgers, or something to that effectâ€”Jager was quite insensibleâ€”he was carried on two or three men's shoulders to the hospital.

PETER WALLHAUSSER (through an interpreter). I am a baker and did live at 62, Cannon-street, at this timeâ€”on 22nd February, I was in the neigh
bourhood of Fieldgate-streetâ€”me and Jager were in a public-house next door to Bartels'â€”Jager went out, and all at once I heard some one call out, "Peter, Peter"â€”I went out and saw these time prisoners on Jagerâ€”I went towards him to help him, and they struck meâ€”I was sober.

Cross-examined. Q. What do you mean by the three being on Jager; what did you see Bartels do? A. He struck him with his fist in the face, on the headâ€”I did not see any moreâ€”I was not one of the men with Jager before that, when they went to Bartels' doorâ€”I had been in the public-house with Jager about half-an-hourâ€”Jager went out, I did not go with himâ€”I did not leave the public-house during that half-hour, before I went out the last timeâ€”there were about four in the public-house with Jagerâ€”Jager went out aloneâ€”he was out about half-a-minuteâ€”no one came in with himâ€”he did not come in againâ€”he did not go out within the half-hourâ€”I have known Jager about eight monthsâ€”I am not often with him.
MR. ORRIDGE. Q. Was Jager drunk or sober. A. Sober.

HEINRICH WEIGE . I live at Brick-lane, and am a bakerâ€”about 12 o'clock on this Saturday night, I came out of the Black Horse public-house, in Feildgate-street, there was a rowâ€”I went down there and saw Jager lying on the groundâ€”the three prisoners were all striking him at once, and the policeman picked him upâ€”they then went into the house, and I went with themâ€”they after
wards came out again, and Jager and another friend of his, Wallhausser, and I came back to look after their capsâ€”as soon as they came out of Bartels' house they said, "They are rogues and thieves, they have come back again," and Brown and Eskucken struck Jager, and knocked him down, and he was

lying on the ground like deadâ€”all three of them pitched into Jagerâ€”after that Bartels said, "Now come inside, he has got enough, the bâ€”â€”has got enough," and stamped on, him with his feetâ€”they then all went in, and me and my friend halloo'd, "Police."â€”the door of Bartels' house was looked, and the police went in the back way and took them outâ€”I did not see Jager taken to the hospital, because I went for the policeâ€”when they came put of the house, I saw the police had got themâ€”Bartels was there with a lot moreâ€”all that were in the houseâ€”Jager's face was fleeding all overâ€”I lifted him up and wanted to speak to him, and he could not speakâ€”he laid down againâ€”he was insensible.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you mean that the police came out of the house with Bartels? A. There were a lot of them; I cannot say whether they brought Bartels outâ€”my friend is not hereâ€”his name is Ferdinand Shevinesâ€”he saw the whole of thisâ€”I did not strike anybodyâ€”I did not kick Jager, I swear that, nor strike him in any wayâ€”the police pushed me into Bartels' houseâ€”I did not say that I had given Jager a good lickingâ€”I have not said to anybody that I struck Jagerâ€”when I came up I did not say, "Where is the bâ€”," and then go up and strike himâ€”I used no expression of that kindâ€”I had been in the Black Horse public-house with my friendâ€”that was not the same public-house in which Jagar had been.

MR. ORRIDGE. Q. What did Eskucken say to you when you were in the house? A. I cannot say; they came out and wanted to strike Jager againâ€”Eskucken kicked Jager two or three timesâ€”I went out of the house, and the police pushed me inâ€”that was an hour afterwardsâ€”I have never had any quarrel with Jagerâ€”my friend was not bound overâ€”he is at work.

AUGUSTE SAHAR . I live over London-Bridgeâ€”on Saturday night, 22nd February, I was in Fieldgate-streetâ€”I saw Jager and the three prisoners thereâ€”I saw Eskucken holding Jager, and the other two struck him and knocked him down, and as I was going to pick him up, George Bartels beat me twiceâ€”he had a key in his handâ€”I did not see him do anything to Jager when he was on the ground.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see Weige there? A. You; I spoke to himâ€”I did not see him strike Jagerâ€”he did tot do anythingâ€”he stood at one side and was looking at themâ€”he went into Bartels' house at first, and came out againâ€”I do not know that Bartels was pulled down from his doorâ€”I had been in the King's Arms public-houseâ€”I cannot say how long Jager had been thereâ€”I only saw him there about a couple of minutesâ€”I was by myself.
MR. ORRIDGE. Q. Was Jager drank or sober? A. He was not drunk.

CARL KHRUMM . I am a tailor of Greenfield-street, Stepneyâ€”on the night of 22nd February, I was in Fieldgate-street, standing at my door, and Jager and another man, who is not here, came past, singingâ€”there was a row before this rowâ€”I went after them just round the corner, and saw Bartels, and one of the other prisoners, come out, I cannot say which it was, and run at Jager and throw him downâ€”I saw him lying down straight, and he was carried to the hospitalâ€”I cannot say what they did to him when he was downâ€”I saw the rowâ€”I saw them rush at him, and knock him downâ€”I cannot say whether Jager was drunk or sober at the time.

Cross-examined. Q. How long before was the first row? A. Two or three minutesâ€”I don't know whether Jager came to Bartels' door, there were a whole lot togetherâ€”the policeman cleared them away from Bartels' door, Jager was one of themâ€”they did not then go into the public-house again, it was
shutâ€”Jager lived with me after he was brought out of the hospitalâ€”I was obliged to turn him out of my houseâ€”I must say he is very disorderly.
MR. ORRIDGE. Q. What was the first row? A. I can say nothing about that, only I saw the police send them away.

PATRICK GARAGHTY (Policeman, H 159). I was on duty in this street on the night in questionâ€”there are very serious disturbances almost every weekâ€”several hundred Germans assembled there several Saturday nights previous to kick up a row} through some animosityâ€”on this night, I saw the row outside the public-house, which is next door to Bartels'â€”it was partly quashed when I got upâ€”there was another constable thereâ€”I saw Bartels go into his own houseâ€”I also saw Jager thereâ€”we separated them, and then got to the other end of the street, where there was another row, and there we found it necessary to apprehend five; and while we were at the station-house with those five, this row in question took place, and I saw nothing of itâ€”after the first row I saw Jager, and he complained to me that he had lost his capâ€”he was soberâ€”he went and looked for his capâ€”when I came back from the station I found that two of the prisoners had been appre
hendedâ€”I afterwards went into the house, searched, and found Brown behind a sick man, in bedâ€”I took him upâ€”he told me he had just come from London Bridgeâ€”I said I knew betterâ€”I saw him there when the first row took placeâ€”he had blood on his hands.
Cross-examined. Q. You say there was a constable there? A. Yes; 23 Hâ€”he is in Court.

JOHNâ€”(Policeman, H 23). I was on duty in Fieldgate-street, about a quarter to 12 on this nightâ€”there were between three and four hundred Germans thereâ€”at ten minutes to 12, I saw Jager, and told him to go home, and sent Bartels into his own houseâ€”after taking Jager away, about forty or fifty yards from Bartels' door, I told him to go homeâ€”he said he would notâ€”I left him there, and went to the station with five prisoners, and saw nothing more of itâ€”I did not see Jager return towards Bartels.

Cross-examined. Q. Before you drove them away from Bartels' door, did you see Jager pull Bartels down from the door? A. Yes; with several companionsâ€”that was the time I brought them awayâ€”they pulled Bartels down, and got on the top of him, and I got him away from themâ€”Jager was very drunk, scarcely capable of taking charge of himself in the street, and made use of the very basest language to me.
NOT GUILTY .

562.
EDWARD CLARKE (29)
, Unlawfully obtaining goods by false pretences.

JOHN WILLIAM HEPPENSTALL . I carry on business at 20, Old Fish-street, in partnership with Thompson, Heppenstall, and Limer, wholesale stationersâ€”on 8th March, the prisoner called at our warehouse, and pro
duced to me this order, signed by himself, "Edward Clarke, 15, Eversholt-street, Camden-town:"â€”"Messrs. Thompson, Heppenstall, and Limer, for Wiseman and Collier, 12 reams of common, one hand, 17s.; 3 reams of double S. hand, 18s., double column; 3 reams of 18 to D. crown, same quality as samples. If you will get this ready to-morrow we will call for them, Yours truly, Edward Clarke. P.S.â€”Also the samples as promised"â€”in consequence of his handing me that order, I directed the goods there mentioned to be deliveredâ€”at that time I believed that they were for Wiseman and Collier as that representedâ€”previously to that we had sent

one other parcel of goods to Wiseman and Collierâ€”they carry on business at 15, Eversholt-street, Camden-townâ€”we have done business with them once before; about ten days before the 8th of Marchâ€”the prisoner came down to the warehouse and ordered it himselfâ€”I knew Wiseman and Collier from their being in the stationery tradeâ€”I knew there was a Mr. Wiseman and a Mr. Collierâ€”there is no doubt that there is a Mr. Wiseman and a Mr. Collierâ€”I have seen them both; one of them is hereâ€”when the prisoner gave the first order I made inquiries to satisfy myself that Wiseman and Collier were a firm in the trade, and the goods were deliveredâ€”I believed at the time that they were for Wiseman and Collierâ€”I should certainly not have parted with those goods if I had believed that the prisoner was taking them on his own accountâ€”to the best of my belief these two letters of 18th April, inclosing the two halves of a 5l. note, are in the prisoner's hand-writingâ€”(These letters were dated on 18th April, 1862, from Stockton-on-Tees, stating that the prisoner had sent the two halves of a 5l. note, in part payment of goods he had, which were charged for Messers. Wiseman and Co., and that a post-office order for the amount should follow; and asked the witness as a favour not to call for the money till he returned from his journey, and also not to let them know that he had the goods)â€”on receipt of those I placed the money to the credit of Wiseman and Co.â€”I refused altogether to have anything to do with the prisoner in the transactionâ€”I repudiated him altogether till I received that letterâ€”I did not kaow that I was dealing with anybody but Wiseman and Collier.

Prisoner. Q. You say that I brought that order in my hand on 8th March? A. I saw you on 8th Marchâ€”I believe you brought that letterâ€”I saw you when the goods were delivered; we had a glass of ale togetherâ€”I had a glass of ale with you before at Chelmsfordâ€”you were very tipsy thenâ€”I was notâ€”I asked you were Wiseman and Collier's place wasâ€”I had heard of them beforeâ€”I knew them from having had dealings with Messrs. John and Edward Sanders, two or three years agoâ€”I received the letters with the 5l. note on 19thâ€”we sent Messrs. Wiseman and Collier a statement, taking off the 5l., and we applied for it between the 18th and 30thâ€”I cannot tell the date.

COURT. Q. You mean by taking off, giving credit? A. Yes; if I had received the post-office order on the following day, I should have placed that to their accountâ€”Wiseman and Collier said they knew nothing at all about the first orderâ€”we have applied for payment, and they have refused to payâ€”our clerk applied on the following Saturday, the 3rdâ€”I think I never saw the prisoner after he wrote that letterâ€”there was a letter came after
wards, on the 1st or 2nd of Mayâ€”this is it (produced)â€”(This letter was dated from 19, Eversholt-Street, Camden-town, and stated that the balance of the account, 3l. 16s., would be paid on the 3d; that he was sorry that the witness had told Messrs. Wiseman and Collier about the goods, and that he was going to set up in business for himself)â€”Wiseman and Collier gave the prisoner in charge firstâ€”I gave him in charge at Bow-lane Stationâ€”I forget the dateâ€”it was at Wiseman and Collier's requestâ€”I am sure of thatâ€”I knew at that time that he had left their service.

MR. METCALFE. Q. Did you find him at Bow-lane Station? A. Yes; in charge of the police, and Wiseman and Collier there with himâ€”one of them fetched me, in consequence of the policeman saying that I should sign the sheet.
JOSEPH EWIN . I am carman to Messrs. Thompson and Co.â€”on 8th March, I delivered seventeen reams of paper, not packed, into a cartâ€”I do

not know the cart; a lad was outside itâ€”I saw the prisoner in the ware-house, and he directed me where to take it toâ€”it was in consequence of his direction that I took them to the cartâ€”I did not go with the cart; I merely put them in.

JAMES HENNESSY . I am assistant to my father, who is a carmanâ€”he is sometimes employed by Wiseman and Collierâ€”on 8th March, the prisoner came to me for our cart, and told me to go down the street to meet himâ€”that was at the corner of Friday-streetâ€”some goods were put into the cart by the last witnessâ€”the prisoner was not there while he was putting it inâ€”he came soon afterwards, and told me to take it to New Brentford, to Mr. Scoles, a tea-grocerâ€”I took it there, andd elivered all of it to Mr. Scolesâ€”the prisoner went with meâ€”he did not assist in delivering itâ€”he was inside at the time.

Prisoner. Q. Are you quite certain it was New Brentford? A. I am not quite certainâ€”I was always employed through you for Messrs. Wiseman and Collier; I have never been employed by anybody else besides you.

CHARLES HENRY DANCER . I am a clerk, in the employ of Wiseman and Collierâ€”on 13th March, the prisoner gave me something inclosed in an envelope, and told me to get some paper from Thompson and Co's. and take it to Whale's, at Camden-townâ€”I did so.
Prisoner. Q. Who did I say the paper was for? A. For yourself.

MR. METCALFE. Q. You gave the envelope to some one in the counting-house? A. Yes; I can't say who it wasâ€”when I got the paper, I took it to Whale's shop, and a young man in the shop would not take it in, and told me to send it backâ€”I saw the prisoner as I came back, in Wiseman's shop, and he told a boy to take it over to the stable, and I think he did soâ€”I know nothing more about it.

Prisoner. Q. What did I say about it? A. You said, "I am very sorry I charged Mr. Wiseman with it; I will take them down and have the invoice altered"â€”I think that was the same night, not the night after.
MR. METCALFE. Q. How did you know it was charged to Wiseman? A. Because I fancied I saw the bottom of the orderâ€”I did not go back to Mr. Thompson and mention it.
Prisoner. Q. Did I not tell you to mention to Mr. Heppenstall that it was for myself, for my own use? A. Yes; but I did not see Mr. Heppenstall.

MR. METCALFE. Q. When did he tell you that? A. When I took the orderâ€”he told me to say that it was for himselfâ€”he told me to tell Mr. Heppenstall that it was for himselfâ€”I did not tell him, because I did not see himâ€”he said he wanted to make up some money for Wiseman and Collier before he came homeâ€”he said he was money-short on his journey, and wanted to make it up by the time he came homeâ€”I did not tell my employers that I took this load of goods to Whale'sâ€”I told Mr. Wiseman about it when he asked me.

EDWARD COSIER . I am clerk to Thompson and Co.â€”I received an envelope from last witness which contained this order for paperâ€”nothing was said to me about its being for the prisonerâ€”the goods were delivered on the strength of that orderâ€”I ordered their delivery on the belief that they were for Wiseman and Collierâ€”I should not have delivered them if I had been told they were for the prisoner.

JAMES HENNESSY (re-examined). On 13th March, I went with Dancer in a van to Thompson's, where eight reams of paper were delivered to usâ€”I went with it to Whale's first, brought it back, and then, by the prisoner's

direction, took it to the stablesâ€”next day I took it to Hazlewood's, in Tottenham-court-roadâ€”the prisoner met me in Tottenham-court-road before we got thereâ€”his wife was with himâ€”he went with me direct to Hazlewood's, and the paper was delivered thereâ€”it is a large grocersâ€”I did not see the goods delivered, because it was a covered van, and he told me to mind the horse and he would take the paper inâ€”I afterwards drove awayâ€”I know nothing about paper.

THEOPHILUS WISEMAN . I am a partner in the firm of Wiseman and Collierâ€”the prisoner was in our employment, as clerk and traveller, up to the latter end of Aprilâ€”he had no authority to order these goods from Thompson and Co.â€”I knew nothing about the first parcel of goods that he ordered until 1st Mayâ€”I knew nothing about the goods that went to New Brentford, or those taken to Tottenham-court-roadâ€”he had authority to give orders to houses that we have accounts open with, but not to othersâ€”he had no authority to pledge our credit at all to Thompson and Co.â€”I have seen these ordersâ€”he had no authority to give any of them.

Prisoner. Q. You say I had no authority to open a new account; how was it that I opened an account with Barry and Co.; did I not do that? A. No; that was a ready money transaction, no accountâ€”I cannot say whether you bought goods from Drayton and Morganâ€”you had no authority to open accounts, or to order goods without my sanctionâ€”I might have written to you at Northampton, and asked you to get samples from Thompson, Heppenstall, and Limerâ€”they called during my absenceâ€”I was on a fortnight's journey, and it was mentioned to me when I came homeâ€”I deny, on oath, that I wrote to you at Newcastle.

COURT. Q. How long had the prisoner been in your employment? A. About six months, at 20s. a weeks, and 10s. a day travelling expences, no com
missionâ€”we parted with him because he came home 11l. in debt from the Northâ€”he was a pretty fair man of businessâ€”he was to leave, I think, last Saturday fortnightâ€”he was given in custody on 2d May, two or three days after he was to leave our serviceâ€”we originated the chargesâ€”we first requested him to come to Thompson and Co. to settle, and he refused to do so, and we thought it was a case of fraud, by his running awayâ€”we were coming down Holborn-hill and we met him, and requested him to go to Thompson to settle the matterâ€”he refused to do so, and we desired him to step into a cab, and he ran down Fetter-laneâ€”we then gave him in custody, and sent for Mr. Heppenstall, who charged him at the police-court.

MR. METCALFE. Q. You say you may have written to the prisoner to get samples, did you give him any authority to incur debt? A. No; if he got samples he would get a sheet of each, and that would be supplied gratis.
NOT GUILTY .

563.
JOHN BARRY (23)
, Unlawfully assaulting
William Bloomfield, a police-constable, with intent to prevent the lawful apprehension of
William Hayes. Second Count, common assault; he

PLEADED GUILTY to the Second Count. â€”
Confined One Month

564.
JANE MARVIN (18), and
HARRIET PREGNELL (17)
, Unlawfully obtaining, by false pretences, 20 yards of silk, 1 mantle, 13 yards of printed cotton, and other articles, with intent to defraud; to which they

PLEADED GUILTY.â€”Mr. Williams for Pregnell, sated that her father under
took to take care of her when she came out of prison .â€”
Judgment Respited.

565.
JOHN HENDERSON (25)
, Unlawfully attempting to steal a watch, the property of
George Ralph, from his person; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY . **â€”
Confined Two Years.

566.
SIMON GORDON (18), and
THOMAS WAUGH (20)
. Unlaw
fully conspiring together to cheat and defraud the
London and North Western Railway Company, of divert monies.

WALTER CHAMBERS WORLEGE . I am a detective officer in the service of the London and North Western Railway Companyâ€”on 5th May, in the morning, I was on duty at the booking-office, Euston-square, I there saw the two prisoners together, and saw them accost several ladies who were going by the 10 o'clock train, an ordinary train which did not carry persons who had tickets for Marcus' Excursionâ€”I saw Waugh go up to a woman as she was going into the booking-office, and he said, "Where are you going to, is it to Manchester?"â€”she said, "No, to Liverpool"â€”he then showed her this ticket (produced), and then pointed to Gordon, and said, "I will sell you this ticket for 5s., my friend came up with it on Wednesday last, and is not going back"â€”she said, "What can I do with a Manchester ticket?"â€”Gordon said, "If you give 5s. for this ticket, and go to Manchester by the excursion train, when you get there pay 2s. 6d. to Liverpool, and you will go the whole distance for 7s. 6d."â€”Waugh said to her, "You will save by that, because if you went third class you would have to pay 16s. 8d."â€”the woman hesitated very muchâ€”Gordon said, "Go and ask the porter the fare from Manchester to Liverpool"â€”she ultimately gave the 5s. to Waugh for the ticket, and the prisoners both left the station; I sent some one to stop them, and followed the woman to a second class carriage of Marcus' excursion train, which went at ten minutes after 10, ten minutes after the other, it is the Company's trainâ€”I believe Marcus receives a commissionâ€”the woman got into a second class carriage; I went up to her and asked her for the ticket, and she gave it me, it was to Liverpool, second class, 26s. by an ordinary train, I am informed that the third class fare from Manchester to Liverpool is half-a-crown;
