the prisoners were stopped, and I took the woman into their presence, told them I was a detective officer, and that I was present, and had seen them when they were accosting ladies, and heard all they had said, and as it was a very constant occurrence I should take them into custody for defrauding the Companyâ€”the woman then said, "You have got me into a mess"â€”Waugh said, "Yes, we have, we must get you out of it"â€”Gordon said that he had come up from Manchester by the train on the Wednesday previous, and paid 12s. 6d. for it; he gave me this excursion bill, which he said he had received (produced)â€”I asked him if he had read it, and pointed out "Not transferable" to himâ€”he said, "Yes"â€”Waugh said, "I will tell you the truth, we were both in a lodging-house together last night, and we agreed to come up here to sell the ticket as Gordon said he did not wish to go back, Gordon remarked that we should get into trouble if we were caught, and I told him to leave that to me, I would see to that"â€”they were all three taken into custodyâ€”the woman was discharged by the Magistrate, she was an emigrant about to proceed to Americaâ€”no ordinary passengers were allowed to go by the 10.10 train, that was for excursionistsâ€”the woman got to the station six or seven minutes before 10â€”she told the prisoners she was about to pay 26s. for a second class ticket.
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. JUSTICE WILLES; and Mr. Ald. ABBIS. Before Mr. Justice Willis.

div1.p:
567.
JOHN CRAWLEY (52)
, Unlawfully sending to
Newgate-market for sale, 400 lbs. weight of pork, the same being unfit for human food.

CHARLES FISHER . I am one of the inspectors of meat appointed by the Corporation of the City of London, doing duty at Newgate-marketâ€”on Tuesday, 6th March, about 7 in the morning, I was on duty there, and saw the defendant beside a waggon with a man named Jarvisâ€”the defendant took two pigs from the waggon, and took them one at a time into Mr. Burroughs' shop, a salesman in the marketâ€”I saw the last one deposited there, and then went in and saw them both, and found them unfit for human food, they were the carcases of two sows which had died in conse
quence of having recently piggedâ€”their insides were green, and they had evidently been dead some timeâ€”the teats were cut off, and a portion of the milk sacksâ€”the carcases were in a high state of inflammation, and I caused them to be inspected by Dr. Letheby and Mr. Newmanâ€”the carcases had been scalded and dressed in the usual way in which they are dressed for marketâ€”the salesmen receive consignments of meat and sell to the butchers on commission.
Prisoner. I brought them up for the boilers.

DR. HENRY LETHEBY . I am medical officer of health to the Corporation of Londonâ€”on 6th March, I examined the carcases of two sows which had died in the act of farrowing, or immediately afterâ€”the flesh was not fit for human foodâ€”they had been dead some time before they were dressed, and the intestines had lain in their bodies after death, I know that by the green putrefaction of the inner lining of the abdomen

GEORGE RUSSELL . I am a detective City-policemanâ€”in consequence of instructions from the Corporation, I went down to Leighton Buzzard on 7th April, and saw the defendant; he is a higher, and deals in pork, vegetables, and similar articlesâ€”I said that I was a detective officer, and had come from London to make inquiries concerning two sows which had been sent by Mr. Jarvis's waggon to Mr. Burroughs' shop, in Newgate-market, and which Jarvis stated belonged to him, and most likely he would be prose
cuted for sending them, but if he chose to answer any questions he could, but it was most likely I should have to use it against him before a Magis
trateâ€”he stated that he had bought the sows dead and dressed on 5th March, but declined to say of whom or what he gave for themâ€”he said that he bought one of the sows and a calf at the Bell at Hockliff, on the other side of Dunstable, that he went with Jarvis's waggon to London, and when it arrived at Newgate-market he carried the sows from the waggon to Mr. Burroughs' shop, that he never intended Mr. Burroughs to sell them for human food, for he did not think they were fit for it; that he had spoken to Thomas Baker who keeps a public-house at South Minims, as he and Jarvis came up with the waggon; that Baker was an agent to Mr. Elliot, or some other man who was a boiler, that Baker did not want the meat at South Mimms, but would meet him in London and buy it, which he had not done.
BENJAMIN THOMAS BURROUGHS . I am a meat salesman in Newgate-market,

which consists of salesmen's shops in different alleys and streetsâ€”there is no great buildingâ€”my shop is in Warwick-lane, which is in the marketâ€”I have known the defendant four or five years, he has brought a good deal of meat to me on his own and on other people's accountâ€”on 6th March, between 7 and 8 in the morning, I was absent from the shop for a minute or two, and when I came back I found the carcase of a sow lying on one of my blocksâ€”I saw the defendant almost immediately afterwards with another sow which he placed alongside the otherâ€”almost immediately after that Mr. Fisher came in, and in the defendants presence examined the sows, said they were in a very bad state, and seized them as unfit for foodâ€”the prisoner said nothingâ€”meat is never consigned to me for any other purpose than human foodâ€”the prisoner came two or three times that dayâ€”he came three-quarters of an hour, or an hour, after he brought the sows, and said that he did not intend them for sale, but had brought them up for the boilers, and merely placed them in my shop to be convenient, because they were taking some meat of Jarvis's out of the waggonâ€”I told him he should not have brought them there, and that he ought to have told that to Mr. Fisherâ€”he made no replyâ€”I think he has brought me meat three or four times before, not more, and I have paid him for itâ€”we cut quarters up, if butchers require it, and have boards for that purpose at the back of the shop, and it was there that he threw them.
Prisoner. I was not in the shop when Mr. Fisher came. Witness. You brought the meat in and Mr. Fisher followed you in immediately.

Prisoner's Defence. I did not intend the meat for human food, and that has been my statement all along. I put it in Mr. Burroughs' shop, while I took the other meat out of the cart, as there was a good deal of good meat packed on top of it; I was going to take them to the boilers; the inspector was taking meat away, and I thought he would take mine away, so I took them into Mr. Burroughs' shop. Here is the card where to meet me, with his name at the bottom: "George A. Hillier, licensed horse slaughterer to her Majesty, Belle Isle. T. Baker, agent."

THOMAS BAKER . I am a publican, of South Mimms, and agent to a licensed horse-slaughterer, George Augustus Knivettâ€”you called on me to have your supper and bait the horses, when you came up with the waggonâ€”I have told you that I am always a buyer of any meat which would come low for boiling, if you saw anyâ€”I saw you on Wednesday night, 5th March, and you told me to take this meat on to London, and you would meet me at the White Hart, St John-street, where we put up.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Q. Is it usual to dress meat as if it is for the butcher, when it is intended to be boiled down for grease? A. We have it dressed in all ways at times, but we do not have meat packed up in cloths as if it was going to marketâ€”a pig which is intended for the market is scalded, shaved, and dressedâ€”we have had both cows, calves, sheep, and pigs, dressed in that way, sent to usâ€”but they sometimes dress them thinking they will be better afterwards, but if they were fit to go to market I do not think they would send them to usâ€”they dress them for the purpose of trying some of them.
NOT GUILTY .

568.
THOMAS STEPHENSON was indicted
for a like offence.
JAKES NEWMAN . I am one of the inspectors of meat appointed by the Commissioners of Sewersâ€”on 28th March, I was on duty in Warwick-lane,

near Mr. Matthews' shop, and saw a hamper pitched, with this label affixed to it, "H. Matthews, late J. Matthews, Newgate-market, from J. Wildman, Leicester"â€”the man opened it in my presence, and it contained the body of a calf, dressed in the usual manner that meat is dressed, without the skin, and wrapped in clothsâ€”I found it very wet and flabbyâ€”it had evidently died from a disease that is called in the country the scowers, or diarrhoeaâ€”the kidneys were not in the carcase, and they are usually left in, if the carcase is goodâ€”it was decidedly unfit for human foodâ€”it was the worst calf I ever saw sent to market, and there was very little meat on the bonesâ€”it was subsequently shown to Dr. Letheby and Mr. Fisher, and taken before the Alderman.

CHARLES FISHER . I am one of the Inspectors of Meatâ€”I was with Mr. Newmanâ€”this meat was not fit for human foodâ€”the animal was very much diseased; the flesh was very wetâ€”it had met with its death perhaps two days before I saw itâ€”it was not affected by the weather, nor by the length of time it had been dead

DR. HENRY LETHEBY . I inspected this carcaseâ€”it was in a very bad state; quite unfit for foodâ€”it's state was indicative to a butcher of it's being unfit for food, and even to a person not a butcher.

HORATIO BEACH . I live at 6, Drover-street, Leicester, and am clerk to Messrs. Pickford, the carriersâ€”I know the defendent, by seeing him at our place at Leicesterâ€”on 26th March, about 7 in the afternoon, he brought some carcases of sheep, and a calf in a cartâ€”it is usual to lend butchers hampers and cloths, and make a small charge for their useâ€”meat intended for the market is wrapped in clothsâ€”he asked me to lend him a hamper, I did' soâ€”it did not look very good, and I said that it was a strange calf to send to Londonâ€”I am accustomed to see a good deal of meat at our establish
ment, and in my judgment it was not in a fit state for human beingsâ€”he said that it was all right, and proceeded to pack it upâ€”I asked him to whom it was to be consignedâ€”he said to Mrs. Matthews, the widowâ€”we keep printed labels of the different meat salesmen in London, and I tied on the hamper one of the labels of the widow Matthews, and asked the prisoner what name I was to put on itâ€”he said, "J. Wildman," and I find "J. Wildman" on this cardâ€”a clerk in the office wrote it, as I had got something in my handâ€”the meat was despatched to London about half-past 2 in the afternoon, by the Midland Railwayâ€”the meat salesmen pay for the meat at our office in London, and it is remitted to usâ€”the defendant called a few days afterwards, and asked if there had been any return for the meatâ€”I told him that it had been condemned; he made no observationâ€”the condemnation ticket was handed to him by our agent.

Prisoner. It was not handed to me; it was left at your office for Mr. Wildman. Witness. It was handed to you by Mr. Shelly, who asked you where Mr. Wildman livedâ€”you said, "At Dane-hill Cottage"â€”Mr. Shelly wrote that address on it, and asked you whether you would have the ticket, and you said no; you would send Mr. Wildman to pay the carriage to Londonâ€”there was a youth with youâ€”I do not know who he was.

ROBERT WESTON . I am a porter, in the employ of Messrs. Pickford, at Leicesterâ€”I took the hamper to the Midland Railway, at 2 o'clock in the afternoon of the 27thâ€”the train goes out about 3. 30, and it would be in London the same nightâ€”I delivered the hamper to another porter.

Prisoner. Q. Do you remember seeing a label on the hamper? A. Yesâ€”I do not remember seeing a label like it on the pack which went a few days before from Wildman, but I heard you talking about itâ€”I have known
you a long while as a jobbing butcherâ€”there is a person named Wildman at Leicester, I believe.

GEORGE ROBINSON . I am in the employment of Mrs. Matthews, a meat saleswoman, of Newgate-marketâ€”on the morning of 28th March, I received a hamper with this label (produced) on itâ€”I opened itâ€”it contained the carcase of a calf in a very bad state indeedâ€”it was not allowed to be moved out of the hamper by the inspectorâ€”we only buy meat to sell it for foodâ€”we never get meat to go to the boiler's, or for dog's or cat's meat.
Prisoner. Q. Was it not very wet? A. No; I do not remember that it was.

GEORGE RUSSELL (City-policeman). On 4th April, I went down to Leices
ter, by direction, and met with the defendant at 24, Milestone-laneâ€”he told me that he had been a butcher nearly all his lifeâ€”I told him I was a detective officer, and had come from London to make inquiries concerning a calf which he had taken to Messrs. Pickford's office in Kink-street, consigned to Mrs. Matthews, of Newgate-market, which was condemned as unfit for human food, and that most likely a prosecution would follow, and he might be one of the parties prosecuted; if he chose to give me any information concerning the calf he might, but if he did say anything I should most likely use it against himâ€”I took down in writing what he statedâ€”he read it over, and signed itâ€”this is it (produced)â€”he said that on 26th March, Mr. Wildman, of Dane-hill Cottage, Leicester, called at his house, and said that he had a culf he wanted him to look it; that he went to Mr. Wild
man's and saw the calf; which was killed and dressed; and Wildman told him it was more dead than alive, which was why he killed it, and asked his opinion whether it would do to go to London to be sold, as the sheep was which he had sold to Wace, of Newgate-market: and he said that it was; that the kidneys were taken out, and it was put in Mr. Wildman's cart, and Mr. Wildman and he brought it to Pickford's office in Kink-street; that Mr. Wildman's son helped him to pack it, and he requested Mr. Beach to write "J. Wildman, Leicester," upon itâ€”he said that he saw the pluck, and the whole of the sound, and did not see anything the matter with the calf; it was fit for human food; that Mr. Wildman said that it was eating it's head off, and that was why he killed itâ€”I saw Mr. Wildman there; he is here to-dayâ€”he was in Court when the prisoner was examined before the Alder-manâ€”the prisoner did not call him as a witneas.

Prisoner. I told you to ask Mr. Wildman whether the calf had any physic. A. You never asked me anything of the kindâ€”you said something about the weather being wet, it was very wet while I was there.

Prisoner's Defence. I have never been before a jury in my life, except as a witness. When Mr. Wildman called at my house it was almost dark, and I thought the meat was good for human food. I asked him whether he had given it any physic, and he said, "No." I examined the heart, liver, and lights, and found them all sound. I said, "The best way will be to send it to London by the horse and cart. His son and I directed it, packed it up and sent it to London, and Mr. Shelly took Mr. Wildman's address. I heard no more about it till the detective came down. The most I can say is that it was an oversight; I should not have sent it if I had been aware that it was unfit for human food. I did not slaughter it; Mr. Wildman's son and another man killed it and dressed it, and the skin went up to the skin-market. All I did wan packing it up and sending it to market. Mr. Wild
man is here and will not deny it.
JOHN WILDMAN (Examined by the Prisoner.) You have killed pigs for

me for two yearsâ€”you took this calf away and were to give me 6s. for it for dog's-meat, or not to take it awayâ€”it was killed for the dogsâ€”you said that you would sell it to a salesman in London, and perhaps you would get a sovereign, and would give me what you could afford.

COURT. Q. Was it for you that the calf was sent to London? A. Noâ€”I am a farmerâ€”I never slaughter beasts for sale, only for dog's-meatâ€”a man and a boy who work for me slaughtered this calf, and dressed itâ€”the prisoner knew that it was not going on well for mom time before, and asked me to let him have itâ€”I told him it would get all right, and I should not part with it; but if I did I would sell it to him and would let him knowâ€”the calf was killed for the dogs, because it got so very weak from scouring, that it could not get upâ€”it was killed on, I think, Tuesday morning, 25th Marchâ€”I saw the prisoner's wife at the door next day, and she asked me how the calf was getting onâ€”the prisoner came down the same evening to look at itâ€”I asked him what he would give for it; he said, "Well, if I send it to London, it will perhaps bring a sovereign, I will give you all I can affordâ€”I said that he was not to take it away unless he gave me 6s. for it, as it was worth that for the dogsâ€”he asked me to let him carry it in my cart, which was going to Leicesterâ€”I asked him to let it be till next day; hot he said, "We will not delay such things as them."

Prisoner. Q. Did I not ask you if it had had any physic? A. never heard youâ€”I told you I had given it hayâ€”it had no physic, but I did not tell you soâ€”I did not see you look at the pluckâ€”you took the head, the pluck, and the feet with youâ€”it was quite lightâ€”you sent a sheep for me a few days before, and I told you, you ought not to have done such a thing, and never to do it any moreâ€”I did receive the account and the money, but I did not know it had gone to London when you gave me the moneyâ€”I told you never to use my name any more, I can prove thatâ€”you never bought anything of meâ€”you never had any dealings with me, except killing two pigs a-yearâ€”I have seen you buying things in the market regularlyâ€”I do not know who forâ€”I spoke once to my son on the road, but I did not speak to youâ€”he had not a packetâ€”I overtook you on the road, and passed you.

Q. Do you remember on the Saturday before last, you said, "I have got to go to London," and I said, "So have I;" and did not you say, "There is not a bit of it but what you could eat?" A. That it untrueâ€”I recollect you saying something about it being packed so longâ€”I do not recollect saying that the goalf had had nothing but hay, flour, and milk, and there was nothing but what you could eatâ€”I remember the truth, and I will not remember anything elseâ€”I did not call on you when you had gone to market, and tell your wife that the calf had turned out better than I had expectedâ€”I recollect you selling the skin of the sheep, and giving me 3s. less than the value.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. Was the communication you had with the prisoner about the calf, entirely about what it was to fetch for dog's-meat. A. It was; I had not the slightest notion that it was going to be sent to London for human foodâ€”a sovereign would be dog's-meat price.
Prisoner. I never told you what it was worth for dog's-meat; you had a large dog of your own. I slaughtered the sheep, and sent it in your name to London; but the calf I did not.
GUILTY .â€”Dr. Letheby stated that from a ton and a half to two tons of bad meat was sent to market every week.

div0.p: NEW COURT.â€”Friday and Saturday, May 16th and 17th, 1862.
PRESENTâ€”Mr. BARON CHANNELL; and Sir FRANCIS GRAHAM MOON,

div1.p:
569.
BARNARD BURNS (18)
, Stealing a post letter containing an order for the payment of 1l. 5s. 0d., the property of Her Majesty's Postmaster-General; also feloniously forging and uttering a receipt for the payment of 1l. 5s. 0d., with intent to defraud; to both of which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

570.
LEWIS SILVESTER (26)
, Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Joseph Baugh, and stealing therein 3 coats, 3 pairs of trousers, and other articles, his property.

ALBERT COOPER . I am a warehouseman in the employ of Joseph Baugh, a clothier, of 107 and 108, Poplarâ€”I sleep on the premisesâ€”the two houses are thrown into one, internallyâ€”on 22d April, I went to bed at half-past 10, or a quarter to 11â€”we close at 10â€”the premises were then safeâ€”I was alarmed about half-past 1 o'clock by the barking of a dog, and saw the reflection of a light in the glass, it appeared to come from the end of the shopâ€”I jumped out of bed and ran for a rattle, with which I made an alarmâ€”I saw a man running down the back yard, but could not discern who it wasâ€”there is a long garden at the back of the houseâ€”a person came, and I went into the garden, and saw several things lying there which had been on the premises over nightâ€”coats, waistcoats, trousers, shirts, and drawers, value altogether, 9l. 6s. 0d., some of which had been on the shelves, and some on the counter.

Cross-examined by MR. HOLDSWORTHY. Q. Which of the shops did you sleep in? A. No. 108; it was from No. 107 that the things were takenâ€”I found a window open thereâ€”the party wall has been taken down, and the two shops thrown into oneâ€”no one resides in the other house, it is kept locked upâ€”there is a long table in No. 107, there was nobody concealed tinder that; you can see under it, as the floor is on the rise as you pass into the roomâ€”I believe I looked under the table, I generally doâ€”I looked round the shop after I shut up the shuttersâ€”there is only one cupboard, and that was lockedâ€”the staircase to the lower part of the house is outside, you have to go into the garden to itâ€”the window was broken first, and then the button of the shutter forced back.

FEARY WATKINSON (Policeman, K 214). On 23rd April, about half-past I in the morning. I heard a rattle springingâ€”I ran to the prosecutor's shop, and asked where I could get inâ€”I went in through the butcher's adjoining, and over the wall, where I saw the prisoner running away, without shoes or stockings, from the back of the house to the far end of the garden, where I found himâ€”there is a wooden fence there, three feet high, and a ditchâ€”I caught him just as he was getting over the fence, and we both went head foremost into the ditch, where we both became insensible through the mud and waterâ€”we got up and fell again, and I being the stronger man, managed him, or he would have smothered meâ€”I did not leave go of him.
Cross-examined. Q. Is it a small ditch? A. It is eight or ten feet wide, they term it the sewerâ€”the water was up to my belt when I stood upright.

JOHN KNOWLES (Police man, K 138). I heard the rattle springing, and went with Watkinson to Mr. Baughs, and saw the prisoner in the garden running away with something in his hand; I said, "Here he goes and he dropped it at the edge of the ditchâ€”I went there and found three pairs of trousers, which the Magistrate ordered to be given up as they were ordered goods; also these other articles (produced) outside the back door of No. 107â€”the window had been opened, and the shutter put downâ€”that could be done from the outsideâ€”I went to the ditch and saw Watkinson and the prisoner struggling togetherâ€”I found this candle at the bottom of the garden where the prisoner was captured.

Cross-examined. Q. Is it the ordinary back window of a dwelling-house? A. Yes; not a shop windowâ€”it could have been raised from without if the look was left undoneâ€”it is a folding shutter; I do not know how it was fastenedâ€”I saw no marks of violenceâ€”I did not lose sight of the prisoner for a moment till Watkinson captured him.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

571.
CHARLES JAMES (21),
GEORGE CLARK (25), and
JOHN ORGAN (22)
, Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Thomas Foster, and stealing therein 2 counterpanes, his property; to which

JAMES and CLARKâ€”
PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months each.

CHARLES EAST (Policeman, N 342). On Sunday morning, 6th April, at quarter-past 5 o'clock, I was on duty in Wells-street, Hackney, and saw the prisoners walking along the Shore-road; I followed them, and went down Tendor-street to meet them, but missed themâ€”I searched about Wells-street, went into Mr. Foster's front garden, and saw footmarksâ€”it was then quarter-past 5 o'clockâ€”I saw James in the house, Clark standing by the open window, and Organ in the water-close, which is in the yard, but on the premises; Jamas was handing a counterpane out at the window to Clark, who was in the act of taking one off the window-cillâ€”I took Clark and Organ in custody, and Finch, another constable, took Jamesâ€”I took Organ from the water-closetâ€”he was merely standing there; I did not see him take any of the propertyâ€”I asked Clark and Organ what brought them there, and one of them, I cannot say which, said that he thought I had gone awayâ€”the water-closet is alongside the house; you on touch the window-cill from the door of itâ€”these ate the two counterpanes which were taken, (produced).

JANE KENNEDY . I am housemaid to Thomas Foster, of Wells-street, Hackneyâ€”on Saturday night, 5th April, I vent to bed, leaving the house secureâ€”sliding window at the end of the house was quite died but not fastenedâ€”I was called up next morning, and missed two counterpanes, which were safe overnight in the room with the sliding window.

ORGANâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

572.
CHARLES WILLIAM MARSH (29)
, Embezzling part of his personal estate, with intent to defraud his creditors; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Judgment Respited.

573.
JOHN MARTIN (27), was indicted
for wilful and corrupt perjury.
MESSES. RIBTON, POLAND , and MATTHEWS, conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM EDWARD MACKRILL . I am an officer of the Court of Divorceâ€”I produce the petition and other proceedings in a suit of Wheddon against Wheddon and Smithâ€”Edwin Wheddon was the petitioner, Isabella Wheddon,

the respondent, and Joseph Smith the co-respondentâ€”this is the original petitionâ€”I have also the answer that was put inâ€”here is the recordâ€”it is made up, with the poetess on itâ€”this is the document on which the trial takes placeâ€”I also produce some letters which were produced on the trialâ€”I was not at the trial, and cannot say what day it took placeâ€”these letters were impounded by the Judgeâ€”the verdict was for the respondentâ€”I also produce the replication.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. The answer does not at all agree with the record? A. That I cannot say anything aboutâ€”the attorney's clerks make up the recordâ€”you will find one signed by the registrar of the Courtâ€”they are the only papers I was sent with; the only papers that were thought requisiteâ€”I do not know whether they were made up at or after the trialâ€”that is the original answer; not an office copyâ€”I do not know whether the trial takes place upon the originalâ€”it is not in my department.
MR. POLAND. Q. Is it made up by the registrar? A. I believe it isâ€”the registrar has signed it, I believe, at the back.

GEORGE THOMAS BILLING . I am one of the officers of her Majesty's Court of Probateâ€”I was present at the trial of the cause of Wheddon against Wheddon and Smith, on 14th and 15th March last, at the Court of Divorce, Westminsterâ€”the prisoner was examined on 14th March, on behalf of the petitionerâ€”before he was examined I administered the oath to him in the usual form, to speak the truth in reference to the matter in question between the Court and jury, and after that he was examined.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know anything about these documents? A. Yes; they are the original documentsâ€”they are made before the registrar, and he settles the record from the petition and the answer, before the trial; it is before the Court and jury at the time of the trial; if there is no jury there is no recordâ€”if the record does not embody the whole of the answer, I suppose it was not a question for the jury; they only put on record the matters for the jury: the Judge decides the other mattersâ€”the question whether the marriage was consummated did not come before the juryâ€”the finding of the jury is added directly afterwards, in the shape of the postes, made up by the registrarâ€”that is always so; and then these docu
ments are kept by the registrar; not handed over to the parties as at nisi priusâ€”this is the recordâ€”there are many questions in the petition and answer which are never put on the record; for instance, the question of marriage is necessary to be proved before the Judge, but is not in issue before the jury.
COURT. Q. Is this the document upon which the trial by jury proceeds? A. Yes.

RICHARD SEARLE, ESQ . I am a member of the barâ€”I was junior counsel with Dr. Spinks in the case of Wheddon against Wheddon and Smithâ€”I was at the trial on both days, the 14th and 15th, for Mrs. Wheddonâ€”the co-respondent did not appear; he put in no appearance at all, so he had no right to appearâ€”I was present in court when the prisoner was examined, and took this note of his evidenceâ€”(This being read contained, amongst others, the following statements, that he, John Martin, had been introduced to Hayes and Edwin Wheddon, and had been employed in the suit two or three days before 18th November, 1859; that on that evening he was accidentally walking in Newington-causeway, not expecting to see any one, and fell in with Hayes there by accident; that they then went to a public-house in Newingtion-causeway, and there he (Martin) saw a man and woman come in and drink a glass of ale, and when they left he followed them, and saw them go into a house of ill fame in William-street, Newington-causeway, and he knew that the

woman was Mrs. Wheddon; that on 23d December following he saw her alone outside the Alhambra Palace, in Leicester-square, and afterwards, on 5th March, at Westminster; also that he had never spoken to the man, Smith, whom he saw go into the brothel, and that he had never seen any of the letters, produced in the handwriting of Isabella Wheddon)â€”I have not seen the letters since the trialâ€”this one was pat in, I remember, and, I think, this was anotherâ€”there were two copies of this third letter; I do not remember which was inâ€”one was in the handwriting of the respondent, and one in that of Mr. Roberts; he has kept a copy; I think this is the one in Mr. Roberts' handwritingâ€”they were both handed up to the Judgeâ€”the letters that were shown to Martin must have been the letters that were pat in by the petitioner, and so, I think, it cannot have been that letter that was shown to the witnessâ€”I think it was Mrs. Wheddon's writing of which that was a copyâ€”these (pointing them out) must, I think, be the threeâ€”that one which you hare there is a copy in Mr. Roberts' handwriting of a letter written by Mrs. Wheddon.
COURT. Q. The prisoner was asked if he had ever seen them, and he swore he had never seen any of them before? A. Yes.

Cross-examined. Q. I have four here; which are the three? A. The fourth letter, the one not put in, is in the same handwriting as the others; I am not sure that that was shown to the prisonerâ€”this (pointing it out), I think, is the one not shown to the prisonerâ€”I took these notes in the usual wayâ€”I was attending to the caseâ€”I am obliged to supply the leaders with law as they go onâ€”I think there were no short-hand notes taken of the caseâ€”there were a great many other witnesses examinedâ€”Brushfield was one of the first witnessesâ€”in his examination in chiefs he proved a good deal against the ladyâ€”he seemed to be a friend of her husband, the plaintiffâ€”the notes of his evidence are on the briefâ€”I cannot trust to my memory, as to what he proved, without the notesâ€”Brushfield said nothing about the 18th of November, but he spoke about one evening in Carnaby-streetâ€”he said, "I saw her leave the house"â€”he had taken a very active partâ€”he did not say that he followed the lady to a brothel in Carnaby-street; nothing of the sortâ€”he said he followed her and Smith from her own house, in Carnaby-street, to Leicester-square, and then lost her; that Smith was with her.
MR. RIBTON. Q. Are you quite sure that what you took down was said? A. I believe it was, or I should not have taken it downâ€”what I took down was, I believe, substantially said.
COURT. Q. You were taking the notes as the junior counsel for the petitioner? A. was, for the use of my leader.

TIMOTHY HAYES . I am a commercial traveller in the house of Mr. Wilson, brush merchant, in Walbrookâ€”I know the prisoner and Mr. Wheddon, the petitioner in the causeâ€”I was acquainted with the co-respondent in that causeâ€”his name originally was Heathâ€”he was styled Smith during the trialâ€”he was a porter in the same house as myself so that I knew him tolerably wellâ€”I cannot tell how long before that trial he assumed the name of Smithâ€”it was some months as near as I can recollectâ€”I have no wish to say anything against the truthâ€”I put no dates downâ€”it was so long before that I cannot tell when it was assumedâ€”my impression is that it was assumed, but I cannot tell whenâ€”I know Mr. Brushfieldâ€”I had frequently seen him between June, 1860, when the petition was filed, and March, 1862, when the trial took place, and I had also seen Mr. Wheddon very oftenâ€”I cannot tell the date, but I should imagine it was between those two datesâ€”I had seen Martin several times, I cannot tell how oftenâ€”I first saw him about the middle of 1859â€”I saw him with reference to

the petition of Mr. Wheddonâ€”it was not a petition thenâ€”it was in reference to Mr. Wheddon and his wife, not to Mr. Wheddon's caseâ€”there was no case thenâ€”I did not get acquainted with him before I had the communication about Wheddon and his wifeâ€”I saw him several times, but for about a year and a half I never saw himâ€”after 1860 I scarcely saw him till 1862, as far as I can recollectâ€”I saw him several times in 1859â€”I lost sight of him in 1861â€”I do not think I saw him in 1862, till we bad to appear at the Divorce Court, at Westminster, in 1862â€”I was with him, in, the public-house, in 1859â€”I do not think I saw him for eighteen months, as far at I can recollectâ€”having no dates, I cannot tell exactlyâ€”on the evening of 18th November, 1859, I was in a public-house with Martin, at Newingtonâ€”while there, I saw a man and woman come inâ€”the man was Heath, who went by the name of Smithâ€”I knew him then as Heathâ€”Martin and I followed them to a brothelâ€”I cannot tell now whether I went inside or not; it is very possible that I didâ€”as far as I can recollect I did not wait till they came out, but I believe Martin didâ€”I believe, I went awayâ€”that was all I saw of Martin that nightâ€”I do not go to public-houses generally, but I went there to meet Martinâ€”I cannot say how long before the 18th I had spoken to Martin about itâ€”I should not have been there unless I had appointed to meet himâ€”it is three years agoâ€”the appointment was to meet himâ€”the place was mentioned, I forget the timeâ€”there must have been a time mentioned, or I should not have been there I met him by appointmentâ€”I cannot say how long before that the appoint
ment was madeâ€”it was made to point out Smith to Martinâ€”that was the purpose for which we were to meetâ€”I never spoke to Smith that nightâ€”I went there with the intention of showing Martin that Smith was there at that public-houseâ€”the object was to see that Smith went with a certain female, to a certain placeâ€”I said that to Martinâ€”the female with Smith was a person whose name was Buzeyâ€”I cannot say whether I said to Martin who the female was to beâ€”the appointment was made that Martin should see Smith, and a female with him, go into a brothelâ€”I am quite sure that was itâ€”the arrangement was made by letter, I cannot say how long before the 18thâ€”I should say about two postsâ€”the appoint
ment with Martin was not made by letterâ€”I should think it was about two or three days beforeâ€”I had not seen Smith that night, before he came to the public-housesâ€”I had seen him in the course of the dayâ€”I saw him daily at the place of business, passing under the name of Heathâ€”I should say I had never seen Martin and Smith together before that night, because I went there to show Smith to Martinâ€”I do not say that I never had, but I should imagine notâ€”I should not have gone there, to have shown Smith to him, if ha had known himâ€”I cannot say whether I hadseen them there the day beforeâ€”they might have been together without my knowing itâ€”so far as I knew they were unacquaintedâ€”the trial took place in March, 1862â€”I have seen Martin and Smith together at Westminsterâ€”we were all subpoenaed, and were there togetherâ€”I had drink, but not with themâ€”I do not remember whether I saw them drinking togetherâ€”we were waiting eight or nine days before the trial came onâ€”I saw Martin and Smith together, drinking together, on several occasions during that timeâ€”I know Smith's writingâ€”I have seen these letters beforeâ€”I believe they are in his writingâ€”I have not seen the contents but I know the writingâ€”I was shown them on the trial, and said they were his writingâ€”Martin and Smith dined together more than once, to my knowledge, while we were waitingâ€”I did not dine with them.
Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. What are you? A. I am a silk-

buyer for the house 37, Walbrookâ€”Smith has been them, I should think, four or five yearsâ€”I have been there twenty-six or twenty-seven yearsâ€”Brushfield is a hat manufacturer in South warkâ€”he is a friend of mine, by being a large customer to our houseâ€”I have known him about seven years, and by reputation ten or twelveâ€”Wheddon was a customer of Brushfield'sâ€”Brushfield introduced him to me about the beginning of 1859â€”I did not introduce Wheddon to Smith or Heath, until a long time afterwardsâ€”I cannot say how long afterwardsâ€”Brushfield knew Heath by being in the place for so longâ€”I believe Brushfield induced him to assume the name of Smithâ€”I cannot say how long that was before the transaction at Newington-causeway; I cannot rememberâ€”I cannot say whether I was present when Brushfield induced him to take the nameâ€”I do not think I wifeâ€”I think Brushfield told me that he had done itâ€”Wheddon, at that time, was is Bathâ€”he only came up occasionallyâ€”he knew that Heath was to take the name of Smith, for the purpose of inducing the people to believe that he was carrying on a connexion with Mrs. Wheddonâ€”it was not a pretended connexionâ€”I cannot tell that it was a real connexionâ€”I, and Brushfield, and Wheddon, all knew that he was taking the name of Smithâ€”Wheddon told Brushfield and myself that his wife was leading a bad life in London, and he wished to find out whether it was so or notâ€”then he wrote to me asking if I would find a person who would discover whether she was or not; I went to Southwark police-court to inquireâ€”Heath changed his name to go and find out Mrs. Wheddtonâ€”I do not know how he was to find her out by the name of Smith any more than by the name of Heathâ€”I suppose it was because he did not wish his name to be knownâ€”Brushfield took him to the house where Mrs. Wheddon was living, to find her out, and introduced him to her as Smithâ€”he showed Smith the house where she lived, and gave him the means of asking for her, by a letter which you see thereâ€”Brushfield did not give him that letter, but you will find by it the reason why Smith went thereâ€”I have not read the lettersâ€”it will show you the reason, because Brushfield had been there previously by the name of Harrisâ€”I cannot tell you which letter it wasâ€”Brushfield took Smith to the house of Mrs. Wheddon, and gave him some knowledge of how to inquire for her where she was to found, and how he was to be introduced to herâ€”I saw Smith on the afternoon of the day that I saw him at Newington Causewayâ€”Brushfield was not there that day when I saw himâ€”it wag not by arrangement that I saw Wheddonâ€”I saw Smith on the same day at the house of businessâ€”I know he was going thereâ€”I did not know that he was going there with another woman, not Mrs. Wheddonâ€”I am certain of thatâ€”I believed that he was going wills Mrs. Wheddonâ€”I never saw Mrs. Wheddon until last Mondayâ€”he represented to me that he was going there with Miss Buzesyâ€”that was Mrs. Wheddon's maiden nameâ€”Martin knew her by the name of Wheddonâ€”I cannot say whether I spoke of her by her maiden name or by her Married nameâ€”I said that Smith was going there with the person who is Mrs. Wheddonâ€”I cannot say how long before that I had seen Brushfield, because he is a traveller, and he is at home only one a month, and it might have been several days beforeâ€”he is away very often, because he travelsâ€”I have seen him in London two or three times since this matter took placeâ€”I do not believe that he was away on account of the policeâ€”he was inquired for by the Judge, after the examinationâ€”he disappeared, too quickly, and has been away altogetherâ€”Mr. Wheddon was present at the trialâ€”he took no part in the matter at Newington-causewayâ€”of course he know everything that

was being done; it was done at his instigationâ€”he knew that Smith was to be there that nightâ€”I cannot say whether he knew Smith was to be there with Mrs. Wheddon, or with a person who was pretended to be Mrs. Wheddonâ€”my impression was that the party Smith went with was Mrs. Wheddonâ€”I believed that up to the time of the trialâ€”I saw the woman go into a brothel there, and told Martin that it was Mrs. Wheddonâ€”I had told him that I expected Smith would be there with Mrs. Wheddon, so he had every reason to expect it was Mrs. Wheddonâ€”I had never seen Mrs. Wheddon in my lifeâ€”this matter began first of all with Brushfieldâ€”Wheddon asked Brushfield to do a certain thing for him, and Brushfield, travelling about very much, asked me if I would do a little for himâ€”I cannot say how long the matter had been going on between us before the prisoner was spoken to about itâ€”I should say some weeks at all events, and then I went to the police-office and made inquiriesâ€”he is an ex-police constableâ€”he was recommended as a person suitable for the matter.

MR. RIBTON. Q. When you went to the police-court, I believe, they refused to let you have a regular policeman? A. Yesâ€”I cannot say whether Martin knew that Heath was to take the name of Smith, because I could not have introduced or shown Smith to Martin if his name had been any
thing else; it must have been the name of Smithâ€”I cannot say that Smith showed me any letter of Mrs. Wheddon to him, but I saw three addressed to Smithâ€”I read them; at least I am certain I read oneâ€”I think Smith and I went together to get them from the place they were directed to; and therefore I should say Smith received themâ€”I saw them openedâ€”he must have shown them to me, because I had them in my handâ€”he did do soâ€”he spoke about a letter that he bad, to which one of these letters was the answerâ€”he did not tell me what his letter was aboutâ€”he only said that he had written, and I saw the answerâ€”I should think they were not shown to Martin; they were sent off to Bath to Mr. Wheddonâ€”I think I have seen Brushfield and Martin together onceâ€”I think they went to the west-end togetherâ€”that was after the meeting in the public-house, I thinkâ€”I believe that was the only occasion on which I saw them together, except at the Divorce Courtâ€”I never saw the face of the woman who was with Smith on the night, because she had a very thick veil downâ€”Martin was at the same distance from her that I wasâ€”he had the same opportunity of seeing her that I had.
MR. METCALFE. Q. You went away before they came out? A. I didâ€”Martin waitedâ€”I cannot say whether she came out with her veil up or down.

ELIZA STEVENS . I live at 5 1/2, William-street, Newington-causeway; that house is a brothelâ€”in November, 1859, a man and woman came thereâ€”they went to a bedroom; the front parlourâ€”after that I saw two men outsideâ€”the last witness was one of themâ€”he was not dressed as he is nowâ€”the prisoner looks like the man that was with himâ€”my servant went out and spoke to them, and then I went and asked them what they wanted walking up and down before my doorâ€”Martin said, "Have you not got two parties come in your place?"â€”I said, "Yes; I have"â€”he said, "Can't you pull the blind up, or leave the door on the jar?"â€”I said, "Certainly not"â€”they both came into the kitchen, and stood some drink, and shortly afterwards they left, and I did not see either of them again till some time in the present yearâ€”I did not see Martin again till he brought me the subpoenaâ€”I cannot tell how long ago that isâ€”it was since this case has been going on; this yearâ€”I had to go to the City, to Mr. Kent's officeâ€”Martin knocked at my door while I was having my breakfastâ€”he said,

"Well, Mrs. Stevens, I have come to see you again"â€”I had forgotten himâ€”I said, "Who are you?"â€”he said, "Don't you know met?"â€”I said, "No; that I don't"â€”he said, "Don't you remember about the case, about pulling the blind up?"â€”that is how I remembered their being thereâ€”I went to Westminster as a witness when the case came on.

Cross-examined by MR. METCLAFE. Q. Did you see a woman at West-minster whom you believed to be the woman that came into your house? A. Very much like herâ€”I could swear to the man, but not to the womanâ€”I said she looked very much like her.
MR. POLAND. Q. Are you quite sure about the man? A. Yes; it was Smithâ€”I could not swear to the womanâ€”there was a woman there with a black bonnet on, and I said that that was not her.

ALFRED EVERARD . I am a butcher, and live with my fatherâ€”I was at Westminster, on 6th March, Thursday, I believe, and saw a person named Heath and the prisonerâ€”they were together some part of the timeâ€”I saw them go to a public-houseâ€”they talked together, and we went and had some gin together; I and Martin, Mrs. Stevens, a man named Archer, and Mrs. Stevens' friendâ€”Heath was called Joseph Smithâ€”Heath told me not to call him by any other name than Smith, because he was co-respondent in Wheddon and Wheddon's caseâ€”Martin was present thenâ€”I said, "Your name is not Joseph Smith?"â€”I did not hear any conversation between Martin and Smith; not between them especially.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. You took a little too much that day, did you not? A. Noâ€”the landlord did not turn me outâ€”I was not turned out of the public-house that day, nor any other day that I am aware ofâ€”we all went by boat to the Cityâ€”Thursday, the 6th, was the first day I was at Westminsterâ€”I was not turned out of the public-house for being drunkâ€”I have known Heath six or seven yearsâ€”I was quite astonished at his going by the name of Smith.
MR. RIBTON. Q. How long had you known Martin before? A. I had never seen him before in my life till I saw him at Westminster-hall.

JOSEPH SMITH . My name is Thomas Heathâ€”I do not know whether I was co-respondent in the case of Wheddon and Wheddonâ€”I do not know what co-respondent isâ€”I was not at all engaged in the case of Wheddon and Wheddon that was tried in the Divorce Courtâ€”I am subpÅ“naed in the case of Martin for perjury; I know nothing about any divorce easeâ€”I was subpcoenaed when the case of Wheddon and Wheddon was tried, and went to Westminster-hallâ€”I was represented to be the co-respondent in that caseâ€”I do not know a person named Everard (Everard was here called forward)â€”I did not tell him that I was co-respondent in the case; he saw me there, and I only knew him by working in the City; I did not know his nameâ€”to the best of my belief I did not tell him that I was going under the name of Joseph Smith because I was co-respondent in the case, nor tell him to call me Joseph Smithâ€”I never went by the name of Smithâ€”I have seen Mr. Brushfieldâ€”I know Mr. Hayesâ€”I really cannot say now whether I was subpoenaed to go to Westminster-hall, in the name of Smith, I took so little notice of it; I burnt the paper the moment I received it; I do not know what was on it any more than you do; I was told to go there and I wentâ€”I went there in no nameâ€”I never knew I was to pass by the name of Smithâ€”Hayes always called me by my proper nameâ€”I do not remember going to the public-house on the night of 18th November, 1859, or of its being the night that I went to a brothelâ€”I have no recollection of any time when I wentâ€”I know a public-house called

Utley's; I have no recollection of going there with a female on 18th November, or about that that time in 1859, or of going from there to a brothelâ€”I might have gone thereâ€”I do not know whether I went from Utley's; I won't deny that I didâ€”I might have gone to Mrs. Stevens' brothel in William-streetâ€”I do not know whether I did or notâ€”none of these letter are in my writingâ€”I never went with Hayes to receive any letters addressed, "J. Smith, Cannion-tavern, Cannon-street, City"â€”I have never seen this letter beforeâ€”I never went to that address to receive letters addressed to me in the name of Smithâ€”I never saw this letter signed Isabella Buzey, to my knowledgeâ€”I never went with Hayes to receive itâ€”I do say that these are not in my writingâ€”I have known Hayes some yearsâ€”he has often seen me writeâ€”I believe he is well acquainted with my writing, and plenty other people as wellâ€”I mean to swear that this is not my writingâ€”/(the witness was directed to read some of the letters)â€”the thing occurred so long ago that I do not know what I did and what I did notâ€”all of these are not my writingâ€”I do not know that I have seen these four beforeâ€”I cannot swear that none of them are mineâ€”I won't swear they are not my writing

COURT. Q. Don't you know that they are your writing? A. No ; I do not know whether they are or notâ€”I did not swear that they were not when I said I did not write them all, I did not mean that I wrote some of them.

MR. RIBTON. You won't swear whether they are your writing or not? A. I will swear to nothingâ€”I do not know whether they are mine or notâ€”I only know Martin by sightâ€”I might have made an arrangement with Hayes to go to a public-house in 1859, but this has occurred so shortly that I have had nothing to guide me; I have no recolleotion of itâ€”I saw Wheddon at Westminsterâ€”I might have seen him before, but as for time or dates I cannot say.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. Did Brushfield take you to the house of Mrs. Wheddon at any time? A. Yes; onceâ€”he did not intro
duce me to her; he sent me there to 46, Carnaby-streetsâ€”I went there and saw a person, but I do not know whether it was Mrs. W heddonâ€”I cannot say how long that was before I went to this public-house in Newington-camewayâ€”I have no recollection of when it occurred, or howâ€”I cannot tell who the girl was that I took to Newington-causewayâ€”I don't keep a diary of who I meet, it is quite likely that I picked her up in the streetâ€”I can't say whether Brushfield knew I was to do soâ€”it is such a time ago that really I have no recollection of where it occurred, or anything at all about itâ€”I do not know whether I told Hayes that the woman I was coming with would be Miss Buzey, or Mrs. Wheddonâ€”I really cannot say what occurred at the timeâ€”I had known Hayes from my infancyâ€”I had seen him before, on the day I went to that public houseâ€”I have no recollection of the occurrence whateverâ€”I see him every dayâ€”I do not know whether, when I saw him that day, I told him I was coming to that public-houseâ€”I do not know that I said anything to him about Mrs. Wheddonâ€”I do not know whether 1 had seen Mr. Brushfield shortly before thatâ€”I do not know whether I saw Mr. Wheddon at all before that timeâ€”I have seen Mr. Brushfield as a customer at our houseâ€”to the best of my belief, I had not seen Mr. Wheddon before that timeâ€”I am generally in and out with goods, it is very rarely that I see who comes into the place of businessâ€”I had not seen Mr. Wheddon before I went to that public-houseâ€”I have no recollec
tion of itâ€”I really do not know who Mr. Wheddon is, or anything about himâ€”I did not give the name of Smith, that I know of, at any of these

establishments; I always go by my right name, and never by a wrong nameâ€”I do not know that I hate never said to anybody that my name was Smithâ€”if anybody asks me what my name is, I am not bound to tell them

ISABELLA WHEDDON . I am the wife of Edward Wheddonâ€”I was respon
dent in a divorce suit in the month of March last, my husband being the petitionerâ€”the co-respondent in the suit was a person named Joseph Smithâ€”I saw him before the trial of that caseâ€”a man named Harrison came and asked me if I was a waistcoat-makerâ€”I said, "Yes"â€”he asked me if I would work for himâ€”I said, "No; I work for a Mr. Whiteâ€”he said "How many dozen can you make a week"â€”I told him to bring his work and he could then see what I could doâ€”he went away and I saw no more of him for five or six monthsâ€”a man, in the name of Smith, came, not the same man, just before Christmas, 1859, and asked me how many waistcoat I could makeâ€”he said he belonged to the firm of the man who had called on me before, and asked me to make waistcoatsâ€”I asked Smith to allow me to go to Mr. Harrison's firm, knowing that a work person ought to go and see her own work; be refused me that, and said he would bring itâ€”I then said, "I am in a hurry, Sir; it is near 8 o'clock, and at my shop you have to be in at 8," and I left himâ€”I was going to my shop, he was at the doorâ€”I never saw him again until to-dayâ€”a letter came afterwardsâ€”I was not on the 18th November, 1859, at a public-house kept by a person named Utley, at Newington, in company with a manâ€”I never was over London-bridge; I was not, on that 18th November, 1859, in Newington-causeway with any man, nor did I go into a house of ill-fame there.
COURT. Q. In William-street, Newington-causeway? A. No.

MR. MATTHEWS. Q. Do you know the neighbourhood at all? A. I never was in the neighbourhood, neither do I know where it laysâ€”on 23d December, 1859, I went to the'Alhambra in Leicester-square, with Mr. Roberts, my sister's husband, at that time I was living in the same house with my sister and her husbandâ€”before I went to the Alhambra I had received some of these letters (produced), this was one of them, and that was another; this one was not receivedâ€”I had never met the man when this letter cameâ€”this is the first letter that ever came to me, that was before I went to Leicester-squareâ€”(This letter was signed "J.. Smith," to Miss Buzey, and stated that Mr. Wheddon would be in town on Wednesday; that he was going to try for a divorce, and that this letter was sent at a warming; that there was a directed envelops inclosed for witness to answer it, and that he would write again and say how things were going on. )There was a directed enve
lope inclosed, and a 'postage stamp on itâ€”I returned an answer to that letter, this is it. (That was dated 20th December, 1859, from Isabella Buzey to J. Smith, stating that she had received his letter, and was obliged for the infor
mation; that if he really felt an interest in her, the would meet him outside the Alhambra Palace on Friday next, at half-past 9, and asking him to write and say what sign she should know him by.) In answer that, I received this letter, beginning, "Miss Buzey, I received your letter this morning. I will come and see you on Friday, if I possibly can. (This letter also stated that the writer had come to Carnaby-street, about six weeks ago, and asked the witness if she remembered a young man coming about some waistcoatt; it also asked her to write if the did not think the would know him, and that if the did not, he would write and tell her what the could know him by, and to address to him, "Mr. Byrne's, Cannon-lavern, Cannon-street, City"). In answer to that letter, I wrote this. (This letter stated that the witness would

meet him at the Alhambra Palace on Friday night, and that she would be dressed in a tweed cloak, velvet bonnet, and would have a black muff). I went with Mr. Roberts, my brother-in-law, on 23d, to Leicester-squareâ€”I did not see Smith, or any other man, thereâ€”Mr. Roberts did not wish me to go aloneâ€”he did not know who the man wasâ€”I had informed my brother-in-law what had passed between me and this manâ€”I received that letter, I think two or three days after thatâ€”I thought the thing had quits dropped again, as the man had not comeâ€”(This letter was signed "James Smith," and stated that As could not keep hit appointment, as he had to go out of town; but offered to meet the witness at the end of Regent-Street, by half-past 6, near the piilart; and that, if he did not see her, he should call on her)â€”I showed that letter also to Mr. Robertsâ€”I did not go to the corner of Warwick-street, Regent-street, on the date mentionedâ€”when I received the letter, it was past the timeâ€”I received no other letter alter the one just readâ€”this one was not written on 23d Decemberâ€”I cannot say when I received itâ€”this letter must have come on a Mondayâ€”it never came on a Saturdayâ€”it was written for me to meet him on a Fridayâ€”that must have been before 23d Decemberâ€”it was just before Christmas I met the manâ€”(This letter was from Smith to the witness, stating that he would meet her where she liked, and he should like to tell her all he knew, and that if she wrote, to address, "J. Smith, Cannon-tavernt Cannon-street, City")â€”after those letters, which have been read, I heard nothing more from Joseph smith, or saw him againâ€”I know the prisoner by seeing him hereâ€”I did not see him either in or outside the Divorce Court, on 5th March of this yearâ€”Mr. Roberts remained with me the whole of the evening at the Alhambraâ€”he walked home with me, and we walked up and down, side by side, while we were thereâ€”I was not at the Divorce Court at all on the 5thâ€”I do not know whether my sister, Mrs. Roberts, started to go thereâ€”I did not, at any time during the progress of the divorce suit see Martin in or about the Court I was in the Court on the last day of the trial, Saturdayâ€”I was 'called in for the purpose of being identified.

Cross-examined by MR. METGALFS. Q. Where had you been on the previous day; you say you were not at the Court? A. I was at homeâ€”I was expressly kept away by the advice of my counselâ€”my sister was sent for, as I understand, as a witness on my sideâ€”she was not dressed to repre
sent meâ€”I have only one sister, Mrs. Robertsâ€”she was not sent there dressed very much like meâ€”she does not dress in the same way as I doâ€”it is not in her power to dress as 1 do now, she has a family; she is not so well able to dressâ€”she was not dressed rather better than usual for that occasionâ€”the same aa she is dressed to-day, she appeared at the Divorce Courtâ€”I heard that Mr. Wheddon came up and claimed my sister as his wife, and my uncle, Mr. Pearson, and several others, I believeâ€”I was not thereâ€”I went to the Alhambra in consequence of receiving that letter uader the advice of Mr. Roberts.

Q. You say that was to meet a person who had something to commu
nicate, although you took Mr. Roberts with you; you would at some portion of the time go apart from Mr. Roberts? A. No; he was a stranger to me; if he could not have spoken before my brother-in-law, his in
tention could not have been honourable towards meâ€”I knew nothing that I should have been ashamed of my brother-in-law knowingâ€”he never left my sideâ€”I am quite sure of thatâ€”we waited half an hour, and the man never cameâ€”Mr. Roberts did not go and get home refreshment: we were close at homeâ€”there was nobody about thereâ€”it closed at 10â€”there were

very few persons thereâ€”there might hare been persons passing in and outâ€”we went up to the top of Leicester-squareâ€”we waited till 10â€”Leotard was not performing at that timeâ€”I did not see a great many personsâ€”I saw no one as we walked up and downâ€”I thought I should see a man walking up and down, waiting for meâ€”we were home before half past 10, and we live in Carnaby-streetâ€”the Alhambra may have been open later than 10â€”I cannot sayâ€”there were not many persons there on that nightâ€”I dressed in a tweed cloak, a velvet bonnet, and a black muffâ€”I did not go more than once to the Alhambraâ€”I had never been inside the Alhambraâ€”we only went that one nightâ€”my business does not take me into Leicester-squareâ€”I work at 53, Marlborough-streetâ€”I sometimes go to Leicester-square on Sunday for a walkâ€”I nave been there several timesâ€”when I have no work of an afternoon, I have taken a walk out, but my work does not allow me to walk about of a night.

MR. MATTHEWS. Q. You have been asked whether you go to the Alhambra; were you ever walking alone outside the Alhambra at any time? A. No, never; I never walked in Leioester-square of a nightâ€”the letters do not mention about meeting me aloneâ€”I went there on a matter of business, about this divorce suit and thinking it was a matter of business, I took Mr. Roberts with meâ€”I did not go by the name of Mrs. Wheddonâ€”I resumed my maiden nameâ€”my maiden name was Buzey.

SARAH ANN ROBERTS . I recollect the trial at Westminster-hall of this divorce caseâ€”I attended there early in Marchâ€”Mr. Dudman, one of the witnesses, and my husband, were with meâ€”we were all attending as witnessesâ€”on the Wednesday week, before the trial, as we were returning from the Hall, persons crowded about meâ€”Martin was amongst themâ€”Mr. Wheddon placed his hand on my shoulder, and said, "That is my wife; I swear that is my wife:" and my uncle said, "Yes, that is her, my nlece Mrs. Wheddon;" and then Mr. Davis took us to the cabâ€”Martin heard what was saidâ€”my uncle, Mr. Pearson, lives at Bath, he is a friend of Mr. Wheddon'sâ€”he was attending at the Court with Mr. Wheddon during the trialâ€”Martin looked into the cab, and said, "That is Mrs. Wheddon"â€”Mr. Davis took me into the cab, and Mrs. Stevens, and Mr. Kent, the attorney's clerk; and Martin looked into the cab, and said, "That is Mrs. Whedden, who I served the subpoena on"â€”my uncle also said I was Mrs. Wheddonâ€”I had seen him the day before at the Court, and spoken to himâ€”he addressed me then as Mrs. Robertsâ€”I was never over at Newing
ton in my life with any manâ€”I never went to an improper place there in my lifeâ€”I was not walking outside the Alhambra Palace aloue on 23d December, or any other day.

Cross-examined. Q. You had not seen Mr. Pearson for some time, had you? A. Not for nine or ten yearsâ€”I am not dressed to-day as I was when the trial took placeâ€”I had a drab, winter bonnet on then, but I have the same dress and shawlâ€”I went np to my uncle the day before, and shook hands with himâ€”I said, "Uncle, whose side are you on are you on my sister's side, or Mr. Wheddon's?"â€”he said, "You may depend, Sarah, I am not on Mr. Wheddon's side"â€”I do not know what object my uncle had in saying I was Mrs. Wheddon; he was so excitedâ€”I did not see much of Mr. Wheddonâ€”he wanted to claim me as his wifeâ€”everybody round said I was Mrs. Wheddonâ€”I never spoke, I never opened my monthâ€”I was walking with my husband at the timeâ€”my veil was downâ€”I was not dressed in the least like my sisterâ€”we were not dressed a bit alikeâ€”she

was not in Courtâ€”I was not taken there as Mrs. Wheddonâ€”I am quite sure of thatâ€”I never went for Mrs. Wheddonâ€”I do not know whether my uncle assists Mr. Wheddonâ€”he is our own uncleâ€”he has been living in Bath all his lifetimeâ€”he is not hereâ€”there is no Mrs. Pearsonâ€”I do not know whether he came up to espouse my causeâ€”I did not know that he had a quarrel with Wheddonâ€”I saw him previously in the Courtâ€”I was asked at the trial whether I had represented myself as Mrs. Wheddon, and I said, "No, neverâ€”I did not know what to say when they said I was Mrs. Wheddonâ€”I did not intend that they should fell into the mistakeâ€”I did not mean that they should take me for Mrs. Wheddonâ€”I might have said I was Mrs. Wheddonâ€”I do not remember itâ€”I might have said itâ€”I might have said, "I am Mrs. Wheddon," in the excitement.

COURT. Q. The question put to you is as to what you said at the trial, whether, in answer to some question put to you at the trial, you said, "I may have said I was Mrs. Wheddon?" A. I might have said so.

MR. METCALFE. Q. Was not Mrs. Wheddon kept out of the way on purpose, and was it not the intention that you should be taken for Mrs. Wheddon? A. I do not think it was ever the intention that I should be taken for Mrs. Wheddonâ€”we were walking down the hall when this occurredâ€”Mr. Davis was taking us along outside the Westminster Court; we were going awayâ€”I never went there with the intention of being taken for Mrs. Wheddonâ€”it was proved in Court the next day that this mistake had taken place.

MR. RIBTON. Q. Was Mr. Davis with you on that occasion? A. Yes; and in the cab with usâ€”nothing was said to me about going there to per
sonate Mrs. Wheddonâ€”I went there as a witness with the attorneyâ€”I never said to anybody on the trial that I was Mrs. Wheddonâ€”I am quite sure of thatâ€”I never went as Mrs. Wheddonâ€”I know that my uncle was trustee for my sister about some moneyâ€”my uncle introduced Mr. Wheddon to my sister; my aunt brought Mr. Wheddon up to my sister; she is Miss Pearson, my uncle's sisterâ€”she was not living with Mr. Pearsonâ€”my sister had 140l. when she was marriedâ€”I do not know whether, at the time of the marriage, Mr. Wheddon was indebted to my uncleâ€”I know that my uncle was assist
ing Mr. Wheddon at the trial, because he was with himâ€”I did not see him with him frequentlyâ€”he was called as a witness for Mr. Wheddon.

DANIEL GEORGE ROBERTS . I am a hair dresser, of Well's-street, Oxford-streetâ€”I am bound over to prosecute by the Judge of the Divorce Courtâ€”I am the husband of the last witness, and brother-in-law of Mrs. Wheddonâ€”Mrs. Wheddon came to live in the same house with me and my wife in 1858 and 1859, in Carnaby-streetâ€”her conduct has always been proper during the time I have known herâ€”she showed me some letters, and I went with her, in consequence of an appointment, to the Alhambra, on 23d De
cember, 1859â€”we expected to meet the writer of those letters, Joseph Smithâ€”we were there some time, waiting about, and walking up and down, ex
pecting to see this party; we saw no oneâ€”I was in attendance at the Divorce Court, on 5th March, the day the persons rushed round my wife, I was with her, and Mrs. Wheddon, Mr. Davis, and the attorneyâ€”my wife went away after she was insultedâ€”they called her Mrs. Wheddonâ€”we were coming home: Mr. Davis was on one side, and I was on the otherâ€”after walking along, Mr. Wheddon came up, put his hand on my wife's shoulder, and said, "That is my wife, I will swear," then Mr. Pearson came up, and said, "That is my niece, Mr. Wheddon," we then put her into a cab and went offâ€”there was no intention of representing her as Mrs. Wheddonâ€”I never

had the slightest notionâ€”we were attending there at witnesse and we were going away when this happenedâ€”I saw Martin there; he came up to the cab door, and said, "That is her; that is Mrs. Wheddon, I will swear"â€”that was the first I saw of him that dayâ€”I did not hear him on that occasion, say anything about Newington-causeway, or what he had seen Mrs. Wheddon doâ€”he only said, "That is Mrs. Wheddon, I'll swear"â€”I saw pretty well all the witnesses before the hearing of the trialâ€”I saw Martin and Smith in company before the trial, on Thursday, the 6th, the day after the wrong identificationâ€”there was a man with them who has since been pointed out to me, named Everard, and another man whom I do not know; they were all drinking in a public-house facing Westminster-bridgeâ€”I did not see them talkingâ€”I heard the noise of some talk, but being a little afficted, I could not hear themâ€”I saw the glass passed from one to the otherâ€”I cannot say that they were all talking togetherâ€”I heard the murmurs of their voicesâ€”they were in company and drinking togetherâ€”I did not see Martin and Smith together on any other day except thatâ€”I only saw one of them on the day of the trialâ€”I know nothing about any debt from Wheddon to Mr. Pearson.

Cross-examined. Q. What do you mean by glasses passed round from one to the other? A. They were passing glasses from one to the other, drinkingâ€”it was at a public-barâ€”I did not drink with them; I went in and had something for myselfâ€”the reason I went in there it this, after the Wednes
day, I was so watched about, and having my wife and sister to look after, I wanted to see whether my coast was clear, that I should not be followed to have them insulted again, and I went into the midst of them, to see if any
body followed meâ€”I was in the bar, and I saw themâ€”I did not go in amongst themâ€”I went in to see whether they were there, so that I could get away homeâ€”there might have been other people in the public-house, but not in that departmentâ€”I cannot tell you how many there were in that department; I was in one department, and they were in anotherâ€”I was not in there three minutesâ€”I did not leave Mrs. Wheddon at all when I went to the Alhambraâ€”we did not go in and get any refreshment thereâ€”we left about 10 or half-pastâ€”I cannot judge the time, it is so long ago.
MR. RIBTON. Q. Did you remain with Mrs. Wheddon the whole time? A. Yes; from the time I went out of my door till the time I took her back again, without leaving her for any purpose.

WILLIAM WHITEHEAD CHARNOCK . I am an attorneyâ€”I was consulted about this case on 1st December, 1859â€”the prisoner came to my chambers three times in Decemberâ€”he was accompanied on the first occasion by a party who represented himself as Mr. Wheddon, and two other persons, who I do not knowâ€”I fancy I had seen one of them beforeâ€”I fancy his name was Brushfieldâ€”I do not know whether the other was a person of the name of Hayesâ€”I should not know himâ€”they consulted me about the divorce suit, "Wheddon v. Wheddon," before it was a suitâ€”Martin was with them on each of these three occasions; I think he was alone on the last occasionâ€”on the first occasion, Wheddon, Martin, and two others, were presentâ€”on the second, I think Martin and some other party, and on the third, I think only Martinâ€”they remained some little time with meâ€”they came on the 1st, the 2d, and the 9th.

Cross-examined. Q. Did any of the parties come to you before Martin came? A. I think notâ€”I saw none of them if they didâ€”I did not advise them to employ a police-officerâ€”when Martin came on the first occasion he said he had been in the police forceâ€”he told me the way he had been going
to workâ€”I told him I thought it was the wrong way, and pointed out to him the way I thought was advisable.

WALTER HAMILTON DAVIS . I was solicitor for the respondent, Mrs. Wheddon, in the divorce suitâ€”I Attended, with some of my witnesses, on 8th May, at Westminster-hallâ€”Mrs. Wheddon was not there on that day; Mrs. Roberts wasâ€”I have heard this morning a description of the way per
sons came round her and said she was Mrs. Wheddonâ€”there was not the slightest intention on my part to pass her off as Mrs. Wheddon, or as far as I know on the part of any one elseâ€”I think we were leaving the Court when these relatives rushed round herâ€”it was after the Court had risenâ€”we had got outside Westminster hall, when the mob came roundâ€”Martin said, looking into the cab, "That is her"â€”the woman was very frightened, and I got her into a cabâ€”I did not hear Martin say "Mrs. Wheddon,"â€”he said, "That is her"â€”I did not hear him sty anything about what he had said on a previous occasionâ€”I saw the witnesses about together before the hearing, and Martin with them.

The prisoner received a good character.â€”
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: The jury expressed their regret that Smith had not been put on his trial, and their disgust at his conduct.

div1.p:
574.
CAROLINE HODSON (29), and
HENRY CLARK (29)
, Steal
ing 2 blankets, 2 sheets, 1 toilet-cover, 2 towels, 11 spoons, and 6 forks, the property of
Charles Davey, the master of Hodson.

EMMA DAVEY . I am housekeeper to my brother, Charles Davey, of 4, Castle-court, Lawrence-lane, licensed victualletâ€”the female prisoner was in our employ on 22d April, as housemaidâ€”on that day, about 2 o'clock, I saw her drawing gin from the bar into a soda water-bottleâ€”she had no right to do, that, or to be thereâ€”I went and asked her what she hadâ€”she secreted it under her dress, and at first said, "Nothing"â€”I said, "You have some
thing," and she said that it was only a little ginâ€”she was soon afterwards given into custodyâ€”her boxes were searched in my presence, and a quantity of articles were found there belonging to my brother, tea, sugar, table-cloths, and other things (produced)â€”the officer took a key from her at the station, and returned to our house with one, and in my presence he unlocked a box, in which some more keys were found, one of which fitted my brother's drawer where plated spoons and forks were keptâ€”these things were kept in my brother's bed-roomâ€”the prisoner as housemaid had entrance there.

WILLIAM JARVIS . I am a detective officer in the City-policeâ€”from in
structions I received, I went with Mr. Charles Davey to Great Westmore-land-street, Pimlicoâ€”Clark's wife answered the doorâ€”I asked if Mr. Clark was at homeâ€”she said, "He is not, but I expect him home in a few minutes"â€”I west in and waitedâ€”the prisoner Clark came, and I asked him if he knew a person named Caroline Hodsonâ€”Clark and his wife both answered, yes, they did very wellâ€”I said, "She is in custody, on a charge of felony,

and in her possesssion is found a letter purporting to be written by you, Clark, in which you acknowledge the receipt of a certain panel and some smokes, and other articles; and asking for a bottle of gin"â€”this (produced) is the letterâ€”I then showed it to him, and asked bin if it was his writing, and he said it wasâ€”it is dated 3rd February, 1861â€”it Last no reference to this matter, but it led to my calling on Clarkâ€”I then informed him that I was an officer, and wished to search his houseâ€”he said, "You are welcome to do so"â€”I searched, and in a box I found a towel marked "Davey," and, in, a work-box, eleven spoons, German silver, I think; also six forks, one marked "Citizen"â€”in a bed-room I found two sheets, one marked "Davey," and the other not markedâ€”in consequence of further information we searched on the following day, the 29th, and found in a bed-room two blankets, and in a bed-room occupied by the prisoner Clark's brother, I found a fast containing three duplicates of articles pledged in the name of Mary Ann Clarkâ€”they related to a cruet-stand and glasses, a coat, and a toilet-cover marked Davey, which was given up by the pawnbroker, and identified by the prosecutor.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. (For Clark). Q. What sort of a box was it is which you found the towel? A. A large wooden box, like a servants boxâ€”that was in Clark's house, in the room he was living inâ€”the first-floor front room, I think; a sitting-roomâ€”they occupied two rooms on that floor.

ROBERT SPRAGUE (City-policeman, 411). I was called in one Saturday in April, to take Hodson into custody for stealing this bottle of gin (produced)â€”I took her to the station, and the female searcher searched herâ€”I received from the searcher two keys, went back to she house where Hodson lived, and fitted one key to her boxâ€”in that box I found three keys, one of which fitted Mr. Davey's drawersâ€”I also found in the box, tobacco, cigars, dupli
cates, and other things, which have been produced.

CHARLES DAVEY . I am a licensed victualler; and keep the Fountain and Star, in Castle-court, Lawrence-lane, in the Cityâ€”Hodson was my housemaidâ€”while she was with me I very frequently saw the other prisoner come to my house with his wife, Mrs. dark; perhaps about once a mouthâ€”this property found in her beat is mineâ€”the towels found at Clark's house are all mineâ€”there is a toilet-cover, some towels, sheets, and blanketsâ€”the toilet-covers were kept in drawers in my sister's roomâ€”a key was found which fitted all the drawers in my roomâ€”these plaited goods are my property; "Citizen" is on one; my house is the "Citizen luncheon-house"â€”I identify all these.

Cross-examined. Q. Is that towel marked Davey? A. Yesâ€”I have no mark on these spoonsâ€”I have missed two or three dozen of those spoons, and these exactly resemble them, and exactly correspond with others which I have in my houseâ€”probably they may be a common sort of spoonâ€”I say the same thing of the forksâ€”they exactly correspond with others I have in my houseâ€”I can speak positively to the one which has "Citizen" on it, and to the others alsoâ€”I have kept the Citizen five years, or rather moreâ€”these spoons were not on the premises; when I wentâ€”I bought, them after I went thert, and I had the "Citizen" ones markedâ€”there were none with "Citizen" on when I went thereâ€”I can speak to the sheet marked Davey, and to the other alsoâ€”they correspond exactly with others that I haveâ€”I am a very good judge of sheetsâ€”I have not the slightest hesitation in saying that this one is mine, because I have lost sheets exactly corresponding with these in size and qualityâ€”there is no mark of mineâ€”I say the same with regard to the blanketsâ€”the mark was not likely to remain on themâ€”
there was a mark originally, but it has been taken outâ€”there are no traces on these blankets of marks ever having been upon themâ€”the toilet-cover is marked "Davey."
MR. COOPER. Q. Have you brought any of your forks resembling these here? A. Noâ€”they are in daily use.
Hodson's Defence. I did not know the things were in my box; I never went to Mr. Davey's drawers at all.

(The Court considered there was
no evidence against Hodson.)
NOT GUILTY .

575.
CAROLINE HODSON was again indicted
for stealing 2 hand
kerchiefs, I table cloth, 1 pint of gin, and other articles, the property of
Charles Davey, her master.

EMMA DAVEY . The prisoner was in my brother's service as housemaidâ€”on the morning of 22d April, I found her putting some gin into a soda water-bottleâ€”in consequence of that she was given in custodyâ€”her boles were searched in my presence, and this tobacco and other things taken outâ€”there were several parcels of tea and sugar done up in this way, and a table-clothâ€”my name is on this handkerchiefâ€”the tablecloth is my brother'sâ€”she had no business with it in her box.

CHARLES DAVEY . I saw the things taken from the prisoner's boxâ€”I know the table-cloth; this tray-cloth, and these gloves are mineâ€”I had some cigars, and tea, and sugar, like theseâ€”she had no business with these things in her boxâ€”she used to get the breakfast of a morningâ€”I have worn these gloves once, and pulled the buttons off themâ€”there were thirteen cigars, I thinkâ€”these are of an exactly similar kind to what I had.
Prisoner's Defence. The gloves were given to me.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Four Months.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. Ald. FINNIS; and ROBERT MALCOLM KEER, Esq.

div1.p:
576.
MICHAEL DEVINE (22)
, Robbery on
William Hill and stealing from his person 4d. his property; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY. â€ â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

577.
MICHAEL BRENNAN (26)
, Robbery, with three other persons, on
Nicholas Rochford, and stealing from his person 2s. 2d., his money.

NICHOLAS ROCHFORD .
