I am a hawker of toysâ€”on 22d April, about a quarter to 1 in the morning, I was in Golden-lane, going home, and saw five or six men standing at the corner of a courtâ€”one of them said, "Hallo, old fellow, what have you got in that box?"â€”I had a box of toys, with a strap round my neckâ€”I went across the road to avoid them, but four of them followed meâ€”one put his arm round my throat, and clasped it tight, and I fell on my knees, and lost my senses for a few minutes, and when I recovered I heard them rummaging my boxâ€”they loosened my throat to rummage my box, and I drew one of the sticks out of my box, and tried to hit themâ€”they ran away, and I walked to the middle of the road, and said, "If any of you come here I will knock you down; you have robbed me of

my few halfpence; you ought to be ashamed of yourselves"â€”they ran towards Barbican, and I followed, shouting "Police"â€”one of then came back, put his arm round my neck, and said, "I will silence you, you bâ€”," or "I will quiet you"â€”that man was the prisonerâ€”he went up to Barbi
can, and I followed him till the police took himâ€”the other three got awayâ€”I did not lose sight of the prisoner at all, but cannot say that he is one of the men who took my moneyâ€”I felt their hands in my pockets, but I kept two sixpence in my hand all the white they were assaulting me.

Prisoner. Q. Did not you say at Guildhall that you saw fire or six men, and did not like their appearance? A. Yesâ€”I cannot swear that yon were one of them, but I can swear that you came back and put your hand over my mouthâ€”when I gave you in custody you were leaning against one of the posts that protect the roadâ€”you called to somebody to come to your assistance, but he ran awayâ€”I carry my box on my back.
Prisoner. Q. How could I put my arm round your neck, then? A. You came in front of me, put your arm round my throat, and said, "I will silence you, you bâ€”," and yon put your hand over my mouth.

CHARLES MCROY (City-policeman, 116) About twenty minutes to 2, on the morning of 22d, I saw Rochford, who described a person to meâ€”I went with him up Golden-lane, and saw the prisoner with three othersâ€”the prosecutor said, "I will swear to the one with the white cap, he put his hand on my throat, and robbed me of my money; these four are the men"â€”I said, "I shall take them"â€”I took the prisoner, and the others ran up in the direction of Barbicanâ€”when I got hold of the prisoner he got his head under my arm, and his leg behind me, and tried to throw me down and get awayâ€”he said, "I won't go with you"â€”I searched him, and found fourpence in copperâ€”he gave his mother's address, 11, George-yard, Golden-laneâ€”that is about a hundred yards from where I took him in custody.

Prisoner. Q. Where did the prosecutor come to me first? A. At the end of Barbican, up Golden-lane; you were leaning Against a post, about twenty yards upâ€”three men ran awayâ€”a man you called Peter came down to the stationâ€”they let him in; not in your presenceâ€”he was not standing with you when I came upâ€”I did not see him speaking to youâ€”you had nothing in your possession belonging to the prosecutor that I know ofâ€”that is the cap, but it had lime on it at the time; you have wished it.

Prisoner's Defence. On the night in question I was up at Fanner's, a place of amusement, and we walked round with my friends to Barbican, and the prosecutor came down and said, "I give this man in charge for robbing me." I said, "Where did I rob you?" He said, "Up the lane," I have got a witness here who will give the same account of it.

GUILTY.**â€ â€”
Ten Year's Penal Servitude.

578.
JAMES BURTON (22)
, Feloniously cutting aud wounding
Eliza Burton, with intent to do her some grievous bodily harm.

ELLZA BURTON . I am the prisoner's wifeâ€”I am at present living with my mother, at 2, Jeffrey's-court, Grey Eagle-streetâ€”I have been living there about six weeksâ€”I left my husband to live there, because we could not agreeâ€”on Friday, 4th April, about 8 o'clock in the evening, I was with my sister, Jane Smith, in Phoenix-street, Brick-laneâ€”my husband came up, and asked me if I would come homeâ€”I said, "No"â€”he asked me again if I would come home, and I said, "No"â€”he then asked me and my sister to come and have something to drink, and I said, "No"â€”he asked me to come

home because of the child, and I said, "I could not keep myself, let alone the poor child"â€”I said we could not agree, and we had better go before the Magistrate and be separatedâ€”he walked round meâ€”I did not tee him put his arm round my waistâ€”I did not feel Anything, but I fell downâ€”I felt something pouring down my neckâ€”I fell to the ground insensibleâ€”when I recovered I was in my mother's house.
Cross-examined by MR. GIFFARD. Q. Had he been having anything to drink? A. Yesâ€”he was very drunk, or else he would not have done it.

JANE SMITH . I live with my mother at 2, Jeffrey's-court, Grey Eagle-streetâ€”my sister also lives thereâ€”on Friday, 4th April, about 8 o'clock in the evening, I met her and walked with herâ€”the prisoner came up to us in Phoenix-street, and asked my sister if she would go home with himâ€”she said that she would not, because he was such a wretch she would not live with himâ€”he asked her again if she would go home with himâ€”she said, No she would notâ€”he then asked us if we would go and have some
thing to drink, and she said, No she would notâ€”he asked her if she would take the babyâ€”she said, No; she could not keep herself, let alone the childâ€”he asked her again to go home with him, and she said, "No"â€”I then notioed him taking a knife out of his pocket, and he stabbed her twice in the neckâ€”she fell down insensible, and he ran awayâ€”she was taken to Mr. Gayton's, and afterwards to my mother.

WILLIAM GAYTON . I am a surgeonâ€”on Friday, 4th April, Eliza Burton was brought to my place, 85, Brick-lane, Spitalfields, between 8 and 9, in a state of collapse, quite insensible, and prostrateâ€”I found two wounds at the back of her neck; one on either side of the spineâ€”she was insensible for about an hourâ€”they were about an inch deep, and three-quarters of an inch longâ€”my linger readily entered them both-they were inficted by a sharp-pointed instrument, such as a knife.

MARY ANN SMITH . I am the mother of Eliza Burton, and live at 2, Jeffrey's court, Grey Eagle-streetâ€”my daughter is living with me now, and has been for the last six weeksâ€”on Friday, 4th April, she was brought to my house in a cab, with my other daughter, Jane Smith.
Cross-examined. Q. The prisoner is a shoemaker, is he not? A. Yes.

WILLIAM COLLARD (Police-sergeant, N 12). On 4th April, I was on duty at Robert-street police-stationâ€”shortly before 10 o'clock the prisoner came there in a very excited manner and said, "I will give myself up; Oh, take me in charge "â€”I saw he was drunk, and I did not pay much attention to him at the momentâ€”I said, "What have you done "â€”he said, "I don't know whether I have killed my wife or stabbed her"â€”I detained him and inquired, and found a woman had been stabbed in Grey Eagle-streetâ€”I saw herâ€”she was in a very weak stateâ€”I saw the surgeon, and took her on the following day to the London Hospitalâ€”the prisoner told me he was a shoe
makerâ€”I asked him, at the station, what he had done it with, whether it was done with a shoemaker's knifeâ€”he said, "No; a clasp-knife," and he had thrown it awayâ€”I made a strict search for it, but could not find itâ€”I also inquired among the neighbours, but could hear nothing about it.

GUILTY of unlawfully wounding.â€”Recommended to mercy by the Jury . Mrs. Smith stated that the prosecutrix was nearly at bad at the prisoner, and used to aggravate him very much. Two withnesses spoke to the prisoner's good character, at a sober, steady man.â€”
Judgment Respited.

579.
FREDERICK DICKERSON (37), and
JOHN HARRINGTON (26)
, Robbery on
William Tidy, and stealing from his person a gold chain, value 6l., his property.

WILLIAM TIDY . I live on my property at 11, White Horse-lane, Stepneyâ€”the prisoners were drinking with me alt night in the Mile End-raodâ€”they were in my company three hoursâ€”we left the house somewhere about I o'clock in the morningâ€”I was very drunkâ€”I do not recollect anything that happenedâ€”I saw a policeman afterwardsâ€”when I am drunk I make it a point to give my watch to the prisoners when I am in their company.

Upon this THE COURT directed the Jury to find a verdict of
NOT GUILTY .

580.
GEORGE BASS (18), and
HENRY FRANKLIN (18)
, Robbery on
Eliza Howard, and stealing from her person a bag and certain books, her property.

ELIZA HOWARD . I am a single lady, and keep a stationer's shop, at 9, Melbourne-place, Cambridge-road, Bethnal-greenâ€”about 9 o'clock on the evening of Friday, 28th March, I was at the corner of Swan-street, Bethnal-green, walking rather fastâ€”I saw serepml men standing there together, and one came from the group, and took my bag from me, and, in taking it, struck me on the chestâ€”the bag was hanging on my armâ€”he ran off with the other men, and I called outâ€”he nearly knocked, me downâ€”I staggered, and some one helped me into a shop close byâ€”I felt the blow for some days afterwardsâ€”I have quite recovered nowâ€”the bag contained twelve monthly numbers of the "Sunday at Home," some papers, a parcel, and a few halfpence, about the value of 1l. altogetherâ€”it was a very nice bagâ€”I could not distinguish the man's features, but Bass appeared to me, at Worship-street, to be the man who did itâ€”he is like the manâ€”I only saw his back as he can down the streetâ€”I did not see Franklin there.

Cross-examined by MR. COOPER (for franklin). Q. This happened all in a minute, did it not? A. Yes; I think the blow was from taking the bagâ€”the others all ran away togetherâ€”I think there were five.
MR. LANGFORD. Q. Did you see the boy Bell there? A. I did not notice him.

CHARLES ALFRED BELL . I shall be 16 next Septemberâ€”I live with my father, at 14 Swan-street, Church-street, Shoreditchâ€”on Friday night, 18th March, I was at the corner of Swan-street, between 9 and half-past, and saw Bass running with a lady's reticule under his arm, and Franklin running after himâ€”the prisoners are the menâ€”it was a kind of morocco leather bagâ€”me and some boys had been playing at "touch," and we had just left off when this was done.
Cross-examined by MR. COOPER. Q. I suppose you saw a lot of men running at that time? A. About half a dozenâ€”it was rather dusk.
Cross-examined by MR. DALEY (for Boss). Q. Were they running in the middle of the street? A. Yes; there ware no cries of "Stop thief."

EDWARD HARROW . I am twelve years old, and live 21, Swan-street, Bethnal-green, with my fatherâ€”on Friday night, 28th March, I was at the corner of Swan-street, between 9 and half-past, standing in the gutterâ€”I saw some chaps standing at the corner of Swan-street, and this lady, Miss Howard, coming by, with a kind of Morocco bag on her armâ€”I saw Bass snatch the bag off her arm, hit her a blow in the chest, and run off with the bag under his arm; he was about eight yards off, and then Franklin ranâ€”I did not hear the lady cry after themâ€”the prisoners are the men.

Cross-examined by MR. DALEY. Q. You can't read can you? A. No; nor writeâ€”no one called out, "Stop him," or "Stop thief," or anything of the sortâ€”I do not know whether Bass hit her a violent blow in the chest

â€”Bass ran first and Franklin afterwards, there were some more running After Bass, he was running alone at the time I saw himâ€”the lady was coming towards me when she was stoppedâ€”Bass's back was to me.

JOSEPH DEEBLE (Policeman, H 195). I took the prisoners on 1st May, they were not togetherâ€”I took Bass out of a public-house in Swan-street, and Franklin in the street, about a yard and a half from the public-houseâ€”I said I should take him for being concerned with Bass in knocking a lady down and robbing her of a bagâ€”they both said they knew nothing about it, and that they were working together at the time.

FRANKLINâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

BASSâ€”
GUILTY .

p.hi: He was further charged with hating been before contvicted on 18th March, 1861, at Clerkenwell, when he was sentenced to Three Months; to which he

div1.p:
PLEADED GUILTY*â€ â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

581.
EDWARD JOHN RICKETTS (20)
, Robbery on
Edward Humph
reys, and stealing from his person 1 breast-pin, his property.

EDWARD HUMPHREYS . I live at 2, Fairfield-place, Stepney, and am a book-keeperâ€”on the morning after the 22d April, about 10 o'clock, I was near the Royal Oak with my friend, Mr. Joiner, when the prisoner started out of a court by the Effingham, which is just by the Royal Oak, and struck me on the face with his fist, it was not a soft blow; he struck a cigar-tube out of my mouth, let his hand fall on my chest and took this breast-pin (produced) out of my scarf, and ran up the court; the cigar-holder fell from the effects of the blowâ€”I went up the court a little way with my friend; and waited, the prisoner came down again, we turned round on him and said we would stand by himâ€”he then shaped at me, and planted a blow at my face, but with some difficulty I warded off the blows for a few minutes; he tried to get up a fight with me; we gave him in charge within about ten minutesâ€”I kept him in sight, the prisoner is the man.

Cross-examined by MR. DICKIE. Q. Is there music and dancing going on at the Royal Oak? A. I do not know; the Effingham is a theatre and a licensed houseâ€”there is dancing there, there was not a great crowd thereâ€”there might have been perhaps one or two persons aboutâ€”I had been out for the day, it was Easter Mondayâ€”I was returning from London-bridge with my friend, we were walking arm in armâ€”the first notice I had of the prisoner was the blowâ€”we had not pushed against anybody at that time, and I am quite sure my friend did notâ€”we left home in the morning after an early dinner; we had a glass of brandy and water between us, and with the exception of a glass of ale at dinner, that was all I had all dayâ€”the prisoner shammed drunkenness before the policeman, but I should say he was not drunkâ€”I do not know a female named McClesson, by nameâ€”I have not recognised anybody here that I keep company withâ€”I do not know my young female Who is intimate with me and the prisoner, to my knowledgeâ€”I might know some one by sight if you would let me see themâ€”(Miss McClesson was here called into Court)â€”I have seen her before about the Mile End-roadâ€”I have been to the Eagle-tavern, City-road, and to Straus's, at the King's Armsâ€”the prisoner remained up the court a minute, or a minute and a half; we waited for him as we thought there was no thorough-fareâ€”I believe there is not.
MR. PLATT. Q. I there any truth in the assertion that you are a rival to the affections of that young lady? A. No.

ALBERT JOINER . I live at 39, Dempter-street, Stepney, and am a photo
grapherâ€”I was with the last witness on this morning, 22ndâ€”as we were passing by Vine-court, Whitechapel, the prisoner jumped out and struck my friend over the mouth, and knocked a cigar-tube out, and he let his hand fall on the scarf, and took his pin at the same time; we were side by sideâ€”he then ran up the courtâ€”knowing there was no thoroughfare, we waited, and he came out againâ€”he wanted to get up a fight with my friend, and struck him on the head; we afterwards gave him in charge to 300 Xâ€”I saw him examined at the station, we had a deal of trouble to search himâ€”we found a hole in one of his pockets, and following round inside the coat, the police
man found the pin inside the lining, between the lining and the coat, it was pinned inâ€”I was looking over the policeman's hand at the timeâ€”the prisoner was very rough indeed.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he strike you? A. No; he pretended to be in liquorâ€”I know nothing about Miss McClessonâ€”we had not in any way knocked up against the prisoner.
COURT to HUMPHREYS. Q. How long had you had that pin? A. Two or three years, I should think; it was a present from a gentlemanâ€”I had not given it to anybody, or taken it away from anybody.

LAWRENCE JOHN MAUNDERS (Policeman, X 300). The prisoner was given into my custodyâ€”I took him to the station and searched him, and found this pin in the tail of his coat, between the lining and the clothâ€”there was a hole in the left-hand pocket, and I took some other things out of itâ€”he was very violent, he walked quietly a little way, and then said, "You are going to take me to the station, yon will have to take me there dead"â€”I had to spring my rattle for assistanceâ€”a little farther on he said, "I will give you 5s. if you let me go"â€”I said, "I intend taking you to the station," and I got him there.

Cross-exained. Q. Did you find a tobacco-box in the lining too? A. A small box; I don't remember finding a pipeâ€”the hole had no marks of a burnâ€”I thought it was there to let things slip downâ€”I found 2s. on him at the station, he offered me 5s.â€”he denied knowing anything about the pin when he was chargedâ€”the Effingham is a theatre and a bear shopâ€”the Royal Oak is a public-house; they are near each other; Vine-court is between the two.

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p:
GUILTY.â€”Redcommended to mercy by the Jury, believing it was his first offence. â€”
Confined Six Months

582.
JOHN DESMOND (20), was indicted
for stealing part of a chain, the property of
Johannes Sterer.
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”MR. RECORDER and Mr. Ald. ROSE.

div1.p:
583.
JOHN JARVIS (42)
, Unlawfully causing to be publicly exposed for sale, in
Newgate-market, 400 lbs. of beef; 300 lbs. of mutton, and 200 lbs. of veal, the same being unfit for human food.
CHARLES FISHER . I am an inspector of meat at Newgate-market, and

have been so thirteen yearsâ€”I have been a butcher all my lifeâ€”on the morning of 6th March, I was in Warwick-lane, and followed the defendant's waggon into the interior of the market; it was loaded with means and other goodsâ€”the name on it was "John Jarvis, Toaster, Northampton-shire"â€”I noticed the carcase of a sheep, which I had taken from the waggonâ€”I had it taken out, found it unfit for human food, and it was condemnedâ€”the defendaut was on the waggon, unloading it to the porters belowâ€”I then asked him to let me see the contents of another, hamper; he hesitated, and said that he had no more of that sort of meatâ€”I insisted on seeing it, and took out of it the carcases of two sheep and a calf, which were unfit for human food, and I condemned them accordinglyâ€”he said that they were his own, and that he intended to sell them to the knackers, for boiling; they were not intended for the marketâ€”I had them further inspected by Dr. Letheby, and they were condemned and destroyedâ€”they ware dressed as butchers dregs good meat for marketâ€”it would not be worth while to dress it in that way for the knackers; but sometimes after meat is dressed it is found to be too bad, aad then it is sent to the knackersâ€”he also had four quarters of beef in a hamper; it was inferior meat but I passed itâ€”I saw the defendant again, at 10 o'clock, at Mr. Burroughs' shop, who is a meat-salesman, in Warwick-lane; a man who was with him took a hamper off a truek and brought it into the shopâ€”I inspected the meat in it, found it unfit for human food, and condemned itâ€”I asked him who he brought it from; he said, "From Mr. William Powell, of Toaster"â€”I took it to the Justice-room it was examined by Dr. Letheby, and condemned by Sir R. Cardenâ€”the prisoner said that it was the same four quarters which I had passed in the morning, but they were not; these were the carcase of an animal which had died, they were wet and flabby, the other was drier beefâ€”I have known the defendant as a carrier for some years, bringing meat to the market, and I have had the duty of inspecting itâ€”the four quarters weighed fifty-five stones.

Cross-examined by MR. COOPER. Q. Will you take upon yourself to say that meat which you have passed, has not been subsequently condemned by a Magistrate? A. Yes, it has, but not in London; one was a case at Woolwich; a man bought some meat in Newgate-market, and it was con
demned afterwards at Woolwich, but, in my opinion, it was perfectly fit for human food, and I am still of that opinion the case of Smith, of Brick-lane, was meat from Leadenhall-market, which I am not connected withâ€”the inspector there paased the meat as perfectly wholesomeâ€”it was seized in Brick-laneâ€”I was called in to pass my opinion upon it, and gave my opinion that it was perfectly wholesome; Mr. Lewis had the case to defend, and, I think, he will say the sameâ€”it was afterwards condemned by the Magistrate, but I should have been glad to have had any part of it for my own family.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. How long ago was this condemnation? A. Three or four yearsâ€”I have always been of opinion that I was right in my judgment in passing that meat, and I was backed in my opinion by the other inspectors.

WILLIAM WILDE . I am a meat-inspector of the Corporationâ€”on 6th March, about 10 in the morning, I was with Mr. Fisher, in the market, and inspected the carcases of three sheep and a calf which had been seized by him; they were in a very bad state, and bad evidently died some time before being dressedâ€”I never knew cattle which have died to be dressed, for the knackers, or for dogs-meatâ€”the whole three were decidedly unfit

for human foodâ€”the defendant was present at Mr. Burroughs, at 10 o'clock, when I inspected the four quarters of a cow; the flesh was in very wet state; it was quite unwholesome, and unfit for human food.

DR. HENRY LETHEBY . I am medical officer of health to the Corporation of Londonâ€”I examined the meat seized, three sheep and the four quarters of a cow, the whole of which appeared to be the bodies of animals which had died from disease, and had not been slaughteredâ€”they were dressed in the usual manner in which meat is dreessed for the London markets, and I con
sider they were quite unfit for human food.

GEORGE RUSSELL . I am a detective-officer of the Cityâ€”on 2d April, I went to Toaster, and saw the defendantâ€”I told him I had come from London to make inquiries about the carcase of a cow which he had taken to Mr. Burroughs, of Newgate-market, and which had been seized as unfit for human food, and that most likely a prosecution would follow my inquiries, and he would be one of the parties prosecuted; that if he chose to give me any explanation concerning it be could, but if he did I should use it against himâ€”I took down his statement in writing, and afterwards read it over to him; this is it (produced)â€”he said, "On Monday, 3d March last, I went to Mr. Powell, a butcher, of Toaster, who had sent for me; he asked me to buy the carcase of a cow which was hanging in his shop; I bought it, and gave him 2l. 7s. 6d. for it; Powell told me that the cow had been tossed in a ditch by the other cows, and pulled out directly, and her throat cut, and taken to his shop and dressed; "that he considered it quite fit for human food, and he should have no objection to eat part of her; that he did not tell Mr. Fisher that Powell had sent the carcase, but it came from there, and that Mr. Fisher saw the carcase of the cow, in the hamper, in his waggon and said that he should pass that.

BENJAMIN THOMAS BURBOUGHS . I am a meat salesman, in Newgate-marketâ€”I have known the defendant three or four years, I should thinkâ€”he has brought me meat from himself and from other peopleâ€”on 6th March, at 7 o'clock, or a little after, a porter brought into my shop the four quarters of a cow, and at 10 o'clock a porter came with the four quarters of a cow on a truck, the defendant following immediatelyâ€”it was unpacked outside my door by one of the porters of the marketâ€”Mr. Fisher and Mr. Wilde were in my place at the timeâ€”they examined the carcase and seized it in the defendant's presence, as unfit far human foodâ€”if they had not been there I should have seat for the inspectorâ€”it was, in my judgment; unfit for human food; it was in a very wet stateâ€”I did not hear the inspector speak to Jarvis, but I heard Jarvis say in the shop that Mr. Fisher had passed it at 7 o'clock in the morningâ€”Mr. Fisher said, "If I did pass it at 7 o'clock, it looked different then to what it doss now; I shall take it"â€”I sold the four quarters which were brought at 7 o'clock, and accounted for them to Jarvis.

THOMAS BAKER . I am the landlord of the Red Lion, South Mimms, and have been agent to G. A. Hillier, of York-road, Belle Isle, Islington, for a long timeâ€”on 5th March, the defendant came to me about 8 o'clock at night, and told me he had a quantity of meat unfit for market, could I do any
thing with it; he could not leave it there, because it was in the body of the waggon, and would I meet him at the White Hart, St. John-street, where he pulls upâ€”I have had meat of him before, to boil up for dog's meatâ€”meat brought up for animals to eat is sometimes dressed as other meat.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Q. Where is South Mimms? A. Four
teen miles from London, on the high road from Northamptonshireâ€”he would

go through Islington to get to Newgate-Market, but not near our boiling establishment, and he was not going to take it there, as I promised to meet him at the yard in St. John-street, near Smithfield, where he puts upâ€”that is before you get to Newgate-marketâ€”I should have had Jarvis' meat at my place, if he could have taken it out of the waggon, as I had two dead horses to send upâ€”I had had dealings with him about 22nd and 23rd Januaryâ€”he comes up on Thursdays, and baits his horses at my place on his wayâ€”I have been to the yard to get meat from him, but never to New
gate-marketâ€”I have had it from him at the yard from 9 to 12 o'clock, but that morning I went at a quarter or half-past 9â€”I have been to Newgate-market several times, but do not know whether the business there is princi
pally done between 4 and 8 o'clockâ€”I was here yesterday as a witness for a man named Crawley, who was tried for a similar offenceâ€”Jarvis came up with Crawleyâ€”Jarvis did not tell me the night before, what meat he wanted me to take at the yard, whether it was pork, mutton, or beef; he only said that he had a quantity of meatâ€”he did not tell me that he was going to Mr. Burroughs; I swear thatâ€”I do not know what meat-salesman he has been in the habit of going toâ€”I have had no communication with himâ€”I have learned more since I have been here than I ever knew beforeâ€”when I have bought meat of him in the yard in Clerkenwell, he has brought it there in his own conveyance, and I have received it into my cart, and taken it to the boiling establishmentâ€”that has been between half-past 9 and 10, after he has been to market and come back againâ€”I have to come there almost every morning with things from Mr. Hillier; I am his agent, as you will find on one of the cards about the Courtâ€”I am paid by commissionâ€”I was before the Alderman, but was not asked to go in, neither should I have been here if I had not been pressed to come.
MR. COOPER. Q. You gave evidence here yesterday for a man, was he acquitted? A. Yesâ€”Jarvis had no lawyer before the Magistrateâ€”I was busy when Jarvis came with his waggonâ€”it appeared full.

JOSEPH GRIFFIN . I am a meat porter, of Gunner's-court, St. John-streetâ€”I was at Newgate-market, helping Jarvis to unload his waggonâ€”I cannot say the day of the monthâ€”I remember Mr. Fisher coming upâ€”meat had not been delivered before thenâ€”Mr. Fisher looked into the hamper, and said that he passed thatâ€”I do not know what was in itâ€”it then went to the yard with the waggon, and I brought the same meat back again, it never was unpacked nor taken out of the hamperâ€”I took it in a truck to Mr. Burroughs, I am sure it was the same meat which Mr. Fisher had passed, and the same hamperâ€”it was never shifted out of the hamper.

Cross-examined. Q. Was it taken out of the hamper when Mr. Fisher looked at it. A. No; it was never shifted till I took it to the front of Mr. Burroughs' shopâ€”it was in the waggon when Mr. Fisher looked at it; he got up the side of the waggon, and looked into itâ€”I did not get up, I was on the groundâ€”after Mr. Fisher had looked at it, I took it to White Hart-yard, Clerkenwell, and brought it back again on the same dayâ€”I drove the horses home, and my master followed behindâ€”we got to Clerken
well about 8 o'clock, or half-pastâ€”I cannot say exactly how long we stayed thereâ€”we put the horses in, and then we brought the meat backâ€”I do not know what on earth we took the meat to Clerkenwell for, when it was at the market

MR. COOPER. Q. You went to the yard, and took the waggon home? A. Yes; the same as I always doâ€”Jarvis remained in the market, and told me to bring that back again, and directly he came I did as he told meâ€”
I did not bring the waggon backâ€”I brought it on a truck to Mr. Burroughs, By Jarvis' order.

COURT. Q. Did you ever before carry meat back to Clerkenwell, after it was in the market ready to be delivered? A. Not that I know of, but I have brought meat from Mr. Jarvis' waggon back again, because he sends meat into the country by rail as well.

JAMES HAWKER . I am a porter, of 8, Lower Queen-street, New North-road, Islingtonâ€”I was in the market when Mr. Fisher came up to Jarvis' waggonâ€”it was as nigh 7 o'clock as I can sayâ€”the cloth was taken off the hamperâ€”he looked in, and said, "I shall not touch that, that may pass"â€”the hamper was then shut down, and put into the waggonâ€”I went with the waggon to the White Hart, in St. John's-street; where I saw the hamper taken out again, and placed on a barrow, and I want with it part of the way to Newgate-market with the other porterâ€”it was the same hamper, and the same meat, which Mr. Fisher had looked at.

Gross-examined. Q. You do jobs about the market? A. Yesâ€”I stood by the waggon from the time Mr. Fisher said it, till it was drawn right out from the marketâ€”I do not know whether it is a usual thing after meat has been passed by the inspector, to take it up to Clerkenwell to give it an airing.
MR. COOPER. Q. Have you done it? A. Noâ€”there was nothing else in the waggon but empty hampers and a few boxesâ€”this was the only hamper that contained anything.
COURT. Q. At 7 o'clock you did not see any delivered to Mr. Burroughs? A. No; if it had been, I should have seen it.

MR. COOPER to THOMAS BAKER. Q. Were you at the White Hart? A. Yes; about a quarter or half-past 9â€”I saw the two last witnesses thereâ€”I did not give them any orders, but I spoke to Mr. Jarvisâ€”I looked at the meat, and they said that it had been passedâ€”it was from something which I said that it was returned.
COURT. Q. Did you look at the meat? A. I did, and gave directions for it to be taken to the market; I said, "It is worth more there than what I should give, if it has been passed by the inspectors.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. Have you been in Court since you were last re
examined? A. Yes; all the time.
COURT to CHARLES FISHER. Q. What was the weight of the last four quarters? A. Fifty-five stone, at eight pounds to the stone.
GUILTY .â€”MR. SLEIGH stated that durimg the last three months 143,934 pounds of diseased and putrid meat had been sent to the market.

584.
JAMES WALL (24)
, Breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Brown, and stealing therein 111lbs. of rags, his property.

THOMAS JONES . I am foreman to Mr. John Brown, of 110 1/2, Aldersgate-streetâ€”is warehouse is in Red Lion-yardâ€”the prisoner was in his employ as a labourerâ€”he left on 14th Decemberâ€”Mr. Brown has a small private yard, which opens into Bed Lion-yardâ€”there are gates which separate the two, and which were fastened on 28th December with an iron bar on a swivel, which shuts into a haspâ€”there are two doors from the warehouse into this private yard, side by sideâ€”when I left the premises the bottom door leading to the warehouse was lookedâ€”I shut the door next to it, on the left-hand side, and put two bags of rags against it to

keep it closedâ€”one door leads into the bottom of the warehouse, and the other into the first floorâ€”the doors are not above one another, but you go up stairs to the upper floorâ€”I left the two bags of rags outside to keep the door shut; it was not much security; we placed our security in the outer gatesâ€”on Monday morning, at 6 o'clock, I found the outer gates exactly as I had left them on Saturday night, and the small wicket-gate lockedâ€”I missed nothing that morning, as I did not go into the upper warehouse that day, but on Tuesday morning I went up, and missed two bags of white rags, which were safe on Saturday nightâ€”that is the warehouse of which the door was looked, not that against the door of which the bundles of rap were placed.

COURT. Q. Can you say by what means anybody had got in? A. Yesâ€”they had removed the bags from the bottom door, forced the flap up, and got inâ€”they must have got over the other goods, which are eight feet highâ€”I missed ten bags altogether; two of fine rags, and eight othersâ€”they were all there on Saturday night.
Cross-examined by MR. COLLINS. Q. Do you keep a great quantity of rags in the warehouse? A. Yesâ€”I do not look over the bundles every day; they are put into stacks.

EDWARD SWEETMAN . I live in Red Lion-yard, close to' Mr. Brown's ware-houseâ€”it is generally closed at 6 o'clock on Saturday eveningâ€”on Saturday evening, 28th December, about 7 or half-past 7, I saw a van under Mr. Brown's loft, under the loop holeâ€”that is a part which does not communi
cate with Red Lion-yardâ€”I saw nobody in the van, nor any goods put into itâ€”I fancied I heard somebody in the loft, but I saw nobody, and saw nothing come downâ€”I left between 7 and half-past, to go up stain to supper, and when I came down, at ten minutes to 8, the van had gone, and my fathter's gates were opened againâ€”I had shut them before I went to supperâ€”those are the gates in Red Lion-yard, not the private gates.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you ever seen a van there at any other time? A. Yes; in the day time, and of a nightâ€”I spoke about this when they came to me; that was in April.

COURT. Q. You did not say anything about it before that? A. No; not till I heard that Mr. Brown had lost something, and then I told him there was a van that Saturday nightâ€”I think that was on the Tuesday morning.

WILLIAM RICHARDSON . I am a rag-sorter, of 9, James-street, Bethnal-green, and am in the employ of Mr. Ward, a carmanâ€”I formerly worked with the prisoner at Mr. Webster'sâ€”I have known him three or four yearsâ€”on 28th December, between 12 and 1 in the day, I saw him at the top of James-streetâ€”he asked me if I could tell him where to get a horse and vanâ€”I said I did not know whether he could get one at Mr. Ward'sâ€”he asked me if I could get it for himâ€”I told him he had better go and get it himselfâ€”he asked me if I would go with him to get some ragsâ€”I asked him whereâ€”he said, "At a man's named Mr. Brown"â€”I refused, because I had some work to do at home, and left him.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you say one word about this, till you heard that the prisoner was in custody? A. Yes; to a man named McCullockâ€”I do not think he is hereâ€”I told no one elseâ€”he was my employer thenâ€”I told him word for wordâ€”I know that the prisoner bought some rags after Christmasâ€”I never knew him to buy any before.
MR. MATTHEWS. Q. How soon after the conversation with the prisoner, did you hear of the robbery? A. Two or three weeks; it was before I heard of the robbery that I told McCullock.

WILLIAM WARD . I am a carman, of 5, James-street, Bethnal-greenâ€”I let vans on hireâ€”on Saturday, 28th December, the prisoner came about 2 o'clock, and said he should want a ran in the evening, to remove some rags from Old-streetâ€”I asked him 5s. for itâ€”he said that he thought 4s. was enough, as it was a light load, and we agreed on 4s.â€”I did not see it leave in the evening, as I was at Chelsea, but when I came home I found that the van had done its jobâ€”I only sent out one van that evening.

Cross-examined. Q. Has the prisoner hired vans of you before? A. No; but his brother hasâ€”the prisoner has not hired a van of me, or my son, during the last twelve months, according to this book, and we generally put everything down.

ROBERT KNIGHT . I am a carman, in Mr. Ward's employ, and have been so for three yearsâ€”on Saturday, 28th December, between 5 and 6 o'clock, or it might be later, I was waiting in Mr. Ward's yard, with my van, a young man, with a moustache, and a little bit of hair on his chin, who I do not know, came up to me, and in consequence of what he said, I got up in the van and drove away with him to Kingsland-road, where another man joined us, and from there we went to Mr. Brown'sâ€”they told me to stop the van at a public-house, just round the corner, when they gave me some beerâ€”the one who came to me first, left me there with the second man, and when he came back, in consequence of what he said, we all three went to Mr. Brown's, Red Lion-yardâ€”they told me to turn round, and put the van under the loop-holeâ€”they then chucked some bags in: one man, who was in the loft, shoved the bags out, the other man was in the vanâ€”there were about 5 bags altogetherâ€”I cannot say exactlyâ€”I did not see what was in themâ€”we were there about ten minutesâ€”we went straight from there to Mr. Green's, in Church-street, close to Brick-lane, where we left the rags, and then went to the Lamb public-house, where we got some beer, and the man who first came to me, paid me 4s. for my master, and 6d. for myselfâ€”I do not know whether the prisoner is the man or notâ€”he wore a round hat, something like mine.

Cross-examined. Q. He gave you 6d. and lots of beer? A. Yes; three times beerâ€”I did not know that it was Mr. Brown's yard, but I went there the other day and recognized itâ€”I have been very ill with a fever since this occurenceâ€”I have not also been in a lunatic asylum, but pretty handy thereâ€”I was not quite right in my head, but I remember where I went toâ€”I did not know that it was Red Lion-yard, till I went there the other dayâ€”I had not had much beer before I went thereâ€”it was dark, the gas was alightâ€”I had never seen the prisoner hiring vans of Mr. Ward before.
MR. MATTHEWS. Q. Although you did not know it was Mr. Brown's yard, did you know the place when you saw it? A. Yes; I am quite sure it was Mr. Brown's yard that I was taken to.

WILLIAM GRIMES (Policeman, K 291). I took the prisoner, on 17th April, at a marine store shop, in High-street, Poplar, where he was employedâ€”I told him he was charged with stealing a load of rags from Aldersgate-streetâ€”Mr. Brown was standing on the opposite side of the way, and I said, "From his place?"â€”the prisoner said, "That is right, I will go with you"â€”I took him to Smithfield police-stationâ€”on his way there, he was about making a statementâ€”I told him that what he said I should have to repeat to the Magistrateâ€”he said that all he had to say, was that somebody else ought to be there as well as him.
Cross-examined. Q. Will you swear he did not say "Somebody else instead of me"? A. No; he said, "Somebody else ought to be there as well as me."

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Eight Months.

585.
JAMES HILL (45)
, Stealing 123 lbs. of lead pipe, 11 door-keys, and 3 brass door-handles, value 12s. the property of
William Aveney, having been before convicted; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

586.
THOMAS BARKER (18), and
JAMES SCOTT (34)
, Stealing 9 tame rabbits, value 1l. 5s. the property of
Edwin Chittock; to which

SCOTTâ€”
PLEADED GUILTY . *â€

BARKERâ€”
PLEADED GUILTY . â€

587.
THOMAS COOK (29)
, Stealing 38 lbs. of lead, the property of
Ephraim Burford, fixed to a building.

ISAAC GAY (Policeman K, 486). About a quarter past 3 o'clock on the morning of 31st January, I was on my way home, and saw the prisoner near the Albion public-house, Stratford-bridge-road, near the premises of Mr. Burford the dyerâ€”a line of railway separated him from itâ€”he was coming from Mr. Burford'sâ€”he turned back away from me as if avoiding meâ€”upon that, I concealed myself in a place belonging to the Albion public-houseâ€”presently he came up, pretended to be very drunkâ€”he rolled against a wallâ€”I said, "Cook, what do you do out at this time in the morning?"â€”he said, "I have been having a drop of beer"â€”I said, "Have you got anything?"â€”he said, "What would I have?"â€”I put my hand on to the left side of his jacket, took out a piece of lead rolled tightly upâ€”I asked him if he had any more, and at that time a second piece droppedâ€”that was in a half circle, as if it had been round his bodyâ€”I said, "You must consider yourself in custody on suspicion of stealing that"â€”I held him with one hand, and sprang my rattle with the otherâ€”he seized me by the neck with both his hands, and threw me to the groundâ€”we struggled some time, and he escapedâ€”on the morning of 24th April at half-past 8, I went with Toff a constable, to the East India-docks, and found the prisoner there outsideâ€”I told him to consider himself in custody as an escaped prisoner, on a charge of felonyâ€”he immediately threw me on the ground and pummelled my head on the pavementâ€”it required six constables to hold himâ€”I, with Mr. Burford, have compared the lead with the roof of Mr. Burford's dye-houseâ€”it matches in every particularâ€”one piece of the lead which the prisoner dropped, looked as if it had been used for some yearsâ€”another piece was quite bright at the edge, as if fresh cut.

Cross-examined by MR. COOPER. Q. Had you known Cook before? A. Yesâ€”I met him on the footpath from West Ham-abbeyâ€”he did not tell me that he had come from West Ham-abbeyâ€”I could not get a word out of himâ€”these premises are on the other side of the railwayâ€”there is a ditch between the prosecutor's place and the other side, but it does not prevent any one going thereâ€”it is four or six feet deep; I should rather say six feet than tenâ€”I will not swear that it is not tenâ€”there is water in it alwaysâ€”you can get to the prosecutor's premises without crossing the ditchâ€”you must go over the railwayâ€”there is a wall on the other side of the railway,

but there is a gate in a wooden fence that is always openâ€”the railway fence should protect the prosecutor's place from the railwayâ€”that is a wall and a wooden fenceâ€”the wall it about six feet high, and the wooden fence is defended by sharp sails and spikesâ€”I have seen it sinceâ€”the wall is intended for a red wall; it is not white, and it is not red, but an ordinary wall; you may call it redâ€”it was a dreadfully rough night, and I cannot describe the state of the prisoner's clothes at the timeâ€”it was very dark indeedâ€”I will take my oath it was the prisonerâ€”there was a gas-lamp on the pathâ€”I don't know that it was too dark to look at his dress; I was too much engaged to do soâ€”I was never a carpenter, nor a plumber and glazierâ€”this (produced) is the leadâ€”it had been nailed on the roof.

MR. HORRY. Q. How do you get to Mr. Burford's premises? A. There is a right of wayâ€”I had not hold of the prisoner more than about two minutes the first time, but I saw him coming to me first, and I saw him returningâ€”the gas-light was shining.

EPHRAIM BURFORD . I am a printer and dyer, at Stratfordâ€”on February 1st, I examined the roof of my dye-house, having had my attention called to it, and found that some lead had been taken from the gutter eavesâ€”lead like this was afterwards shown to me by the policeâ€”I have compared it with the roof, and it corresponds with the lead that is leftâ€”this lead is my propertyâ€”it is a peculiar bending eave, and here are the peculiar marks where it came over the water-spoutâ€”I can tell from those circumstances that it is mine.

Cross-examined. Q. Is there a wide ditch separating your grounds? A. Yes, from Mr. Kay'sâ€”it is ten or twelve feet wide, and there is water in itâ€”the banks are grass and dirtâ€”there has been a sewer madeâ€”the ground it soft as it generally is by the side of a ditch; a kind of oozy groundâ€”between my property and the railway there it a fence of wood and wall, about six or seven feet in heightâ€”my land is all grass landâ€”it is not grass directly under the eavesâ€”there is a pathway along, and then you come to the railway, and then there is the high wall oppositeâ€”the path where the man was met by the policeman runs from Abbey-hillsâ€”the eaves of the dye-house are about six feet from the ground.

MR. HORRY. Q. Which is the usual approach to your place? A. The high road to Stratfordâ€”the place where the prisoner was seen is from the urinalâ€”I know the place very wellâ€”he got round the railway fence, which he could do easily, and then he might go through the gate without jumping the ditch, or getting over the wallâ€”I have complained to the railway company since, and they have altered it.
COURT. Q. Was your dye-house all right the day before? A. Yes.
GUILTY .
He was further charged with having been before convicted at this Court in May, 1857, of stealing lead and confined Twelve Months: to which he

PLEADED GUILTY.**â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

588.
JAMES WOOD (26)
, Embezzling the sum of 8l. 7s. 10d., the money of
George Burr.

FREDERICK SPROSTON . I keep the Bird-in-Hand public-house at Stratford,â€”on Tuesday evening, 25th March, the prisoner called at my house, and asked me to change this cheque (produced) for 8l. 7s. 10d.â€”I said the cheque was no good, because it was crossed and payable to order; and I said, "You are not the Burr, I know; it is drawn in favour of Mr. Burr"â€”he said, "No; it it Walter, you know; I am his brother"â€”I said, "If you write

your name at the back I will cash it for you"â€”he said, "I can't write; it you will write my name, I will cross it;" and I did soâ€”I paid him 8l. 7s. 10d. for the chequeâ€”I afterwards paid the cheque through the spirit merchants; they send it through the bank.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Have you ever cashed cheques before? A. Not for this Mr. Burr; I have for other persons; I have for his brother repeatedlyâ€”I had seen him before, but I did not know his name.

GEORGE BURR . I am a straw dealer, and live at Thorley, in Hertfordshireâ€”the prisoner was in my employ as carterâ€”on Tuesday, 25th March, I sent him to London with a load of straw, the value of which was 8l. 7s. 10d.â€”it was his duty to take money for me when he went to sell straw in the marketâ€”on the Tuesday in question he did not come home with his horsesâ€”he came home on the Wednesday night, and gave me 3l. 7s. in cashâ€”I asked him at the time if Mr. Mumford did not give him a chequeâ€”the straw was to be sold to Mr. Mumford, a straw salesmanâ€”he said he did not give him a cheque, he gave him hard cash, and he had lost the 5l. coming homeâ€”I afterwards went and saw Mumford, and, in consequence of what he told me, I gave the prisoner into custody.

Cross-examined. Q. How long had he been in your employment? A. About three monthsâ€”he was living with Mr. King before thatâ€”he had brought money to me before from the salesmenâ€”my place is about twenty-seven miles from Whitechapel Churchâ€”he started on the Monday to deliver the straw in Whitechapel on the Tuesday morningâ€”he was to come back on the Wednesday morning with his horses, and he did not come back till Wednesday nightâ€”he had two baiting houses on the way; the Thatched House at Leytonstone is one, and he would stay three or four hours at Eppingâ€”he would not stop anywhere on the Tuesday night to sleep; he was to come straight homeâ€”I gave him the regular money at starting, 9s. 6d. for the two horsesâ€”if there were any other expenses, he would not be authorized to use the moneyâ€”I wished him to have a cheque, so as he should not use the money.
MR. ROWDEN. Q. The horses came home first, did they not? A. Yes; they came down to the Thatched House, and I was there, and I took them away at 10 o'clock at night.

MATTHEW JAMES MUMFORD . I am a straw salesman, at 7, Stepney-greenâ€”on 25th March last I gave the prisoner that cheque for 8l. 7s. 10d. on account of his master, for straw delivered that dayâ€”on 27th March I stopped the cheque at the bankâ€”I had always paid him in cash; and his master came up that morning, and said I was to pay him in a cheque, as he had been deficient once or twice with his money when he had had cash.

WILLIAM VANE (Policeman, K 89). The prisoner was given into my custodyâ€”I told him he was charged with converting a cheque of his master's to his own useâ€”he said, "Yes, George, I did do it; but I meant to work it out; I lost it between Maryland-point and the Thatched House."

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

589.
FREDERICK JAMES CROW (22), and
CHARLES TURNBULL (27)
, Stealing 3 bales of tobacco of
Richard Phillips and others, in a
barge on the Thames.

HENRY YATES . I am a lighterman in the service of Richard Marshall Phillips and others, master lightermen, of Rood-laneâ€”they have a barge called the Richard Nestle, which I loaded on Saturday, 8th March, with 161
bales of tobacco from the ship Diana at Brewer's-quay, Thames-streetâ€”I kept my tally, and left the barge in charge of Mr. Monday, the Custom-house officer, about half-past 3 in the afternoon.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. How do you know there were 161 bales? A. I counted themâ€”we always keep tally of themâ€”we count every laneâ€”the number of bales in a tier is according to the size of the bargeâ€”I can't say how many bales there were in these tiersâ€”I have not got the accountâ€”I cannot say where it isâ€”I am speaking from memoryâ€”they were three tiers highâ€”there was a different number of bales in each tierâ€”I made no entry at the time; I only chalked it down on the barge's sideâ€”I expect the order would specify the number of bales, but the routine of the Custom-house is, that they would not deliver me one bale over.
MR. METCALFE. Q. Might they deliver less? A. Yesâ€”I did not ask Munday about his tally; I only studied my ownâ€”the value of a bale of tobacco is 30l. odd, free of duty.

HENRY BIRCH MUNDAY . I am a Custom-house officerâ€”on the after
noon of 18th March, I tallied 161 bales of tobacco into the Richard Nestleâ€”I continued in charge of the barge until she got into the Victoria Docksâ€”I left her between 4 and 5 on Sunday morning, leaving a lighterman of Phillips' in charge of herâ€”I do not know his nameâ€”the 161 bales were safe when I left.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you count them? A. Yes; they were in tiersâ€”I cannot tell how many there were in each tierâ€”I tallied them from the ship into the bargeâ€”I did not say at first, that there were 151, I said 161â€”I was responsible for the whole number in my careâ€”I am in the habit of tallyingâ€”I had not tallied any bales of tobacco on that same dayâ€”I made an entry of what was in the barge in my official bookâ€”this is it (producing it)â€”this entry was made by me at the timeâ€”here is not a 5 changed into a 6â€”I swear that.
MR. METCALFE. Q. Are you sure that 158 bales were subsequently found? A. Yes.

WILLIAM DYSON . I am a lighterman in the employ of Messrs. Phillipsâ€”on Saturday, 8th March, I took the Richard Nestle to the Victoria Docksâ€”I got there between 11 and 12 o'clockâ€”I left her between 6 and 7 on Sunday morning.

ROBERT WILSON . I am foreman to Messrs. Phillipsâ€”on Monday morning, 10th March, about 10 o'clock, I saw the Richard Nestle unloadedâ€”158 bales were tallied ashoreâ€”I counted them after they were on the shoreâ€”I saw them landed, about a quarter of an hour before I counted themâ€”I did not count them till they were landedâ€”I made 158â€”I was told something by the Custom-house officer, in consequence of which I went to the placeâ€”the bales were each covered with a wrapper; part of them with wrappers like this one (produced).

Cross-examined. Q. You say they were a quarter of an hour ashore before you tallied them, where were you in the meantime? A. Doing other work in the docksâ€”I did not count two or three of them, two or three times over, because they were standing on their endsâ€”I have got my book (produced)â€”here is 161 bales from the Diana, and 158 in herâ€”I made that entry the same night when I made up my booksâ€”I made it from memory.
CHARLES HARTLAND . I am tally man at the Victoria Dockâ€”I remember the Richard Nestle being unloadedâ€”on 10th March, I tallied the bales of tobacco taken out of herâ€”there were 158.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you make any entry? A. Yes; here it is (produced)â€”I made that at the time they were landed; all these numbers make up 158.

JAMES JEWETT . I work for Messrs. Phillipsâ€”on Sunday, 9th March, at 10 o'clock I was sent for to the Victoria Docksâ€”I saw the Richard Nestle thereâ€”I remained on board of her from 10 o'clock till 12â€”I then went away, and remained away until 7 or 8 in the evening, when I came back, and remained on board all nightâ€”about 3 o'clock, the men who work in the mud craft, came and took their craft away, and I shifted the bargeâ€”I went and got my breakfast and stopped there till she was unloaded alongside the warehouse.
COURT. Q. Did you find her adrift? A. Yes; there was nobody on board; she was floating about promiscuously; the wind was blowing hard and I could do nothing with her.

THOMAS POWELL . I live at 63, Chambers-street, Goodman's-fields, and am apprentice to Mr. Clark, lighterman, the owner of the Mary Anneâ€”on Sunday, 9th March, I took her into the Victoria Docks between 4 and 5 o'clockâ€”she was emptyâ€”I left her in the basinâ€”I went back for her on Monday morning and missed herâ€”I did not see her again till next Wednesday morning, when I found her at Ducker's-wharf, Bow-creekâ€”I do not know Crow; he was not employed by my masterâ€”he had no right to take the Mary Anne out of the docks.

Cross-examined. Q. Is the Mary Anne given to roving? A. Not unless people take herâ€”it is not the custom to take barges for two or three days; she was never taken beforeâ€”she had a little water in her and was lying on the ground when I found her.
MR. METCALFE. Q. Was there any tobacco in her when you found her? A. No; the prisoner had no authority to take her away.

THOMAS WAITE . I live at 23, Bell-and-anchor cottages, Victoria-dock-roadâ€”I am lockman at the Victoria Dockâ€”on Sunday, 9th March, between 4 and 5 o'clock, I let the barge Mary Anne into the dockâ€”I let her out again on Monday morning, between 4 and 5â€”a young man between 18 and 19 was with her; I cannot swear to himâ€”he had a brown coat on and blue cloth capâ€”I did not see his faceâ€”the water was nineteen feet below meâ€”I am sure it was the Mary Anneâ€”it was the first barge I came in contact with, and I put my bull's eye on and said, "Hallo! is this barge going out again?" and the person in her said, "She is in the wrong dock, I am going to put her in the London Dock," or "in the river," I can't say whichâ€”there were six or seven tarpaulins on her, and one of them was traced up on the gunwale.

Cross-examined. Q. Then you spoke to the man in the barge? A. Yes; but I was nineteen feet above himâ€”it was not light; I had my bull's-eyeâ€”the barge stopped in the lock, and this conversation took place there.

COURT. Q. Is there anybody to take any note of the barges which go out, and what they contain? A. Yes; there is a tide surveyor and three watchmen belonging to the Customs; they are supposed to overhaul every barge which comes in or goes outâ€”there was nothing in this bargeâ€”the tide surveyor and watchmen are on the look out during tide timeâ€”as soon as they commence to lock, they come on duty, and are on duty twenty-four hours.

MR. METCALFE. Q. Were they on duty when you let out this barge? A. Yes; they are supposed to overhaul every bargeâ€”assuming that there were stolen bales of tobacco in this barge, they ought to have known it and to have stopped them.

WILLIAM ORMES . I am apprentice to a lighterman, and live at 5, Francis-street, Plaistow-marshâ€”on Monday, 10th March, between 12 and 1 in the night-time, I was at the Victoria Dockâ€”I know Crowâ€”I saw him there in the barge Mary Anne, which belongs to Mr. Clarkâ€”he was going out towards the entrance of the dock, and I was going down ready to go outâ€”he said, "Where are you going with that barge?"â€”I said, "Down to the boom; is that you Crow?"â€”he made no answerâ€”I repeated it, and he made no answer; so when his barge came alongside mine, I stepped on board it and said, "I thought it was you, Fred; why did not you answer?"â€”he made no reply, but said, "Who are you at work fort?"â€”I said, "Corrie; where are you going to?"â€”he said, "Up to the quay"â€”on getting on board, I saw something resembling bales of tobacco in the cabin of the bargeâ€”I went on shore and saw nothing more.

Cross-examined. Q. How did you know that these were bales of tobacco; had you ever seen bales of tobacco before? A. Yes; I know them by the matting outsideâ€”I did not go into the cabin, I only looked down into itâ€”they were lying on the floorâ€”I only saw oneâ€”the matting was the same sort of stuff as I now see.

COURT. Q. When you say you saw something resembling a bale of tobacco, do you mean to say that you thought it was tobacco at that time? A. Yes; I know that there is a tide waiter and watchmen in the dock, and that they ought to overhaul every bargeâ€”I did not notice the barge over
hauledâ€”I have never known a barge go out of the dock with a bale of tobacco in itâ€”I did not think it odd, because I had been at work for the same partyâ€”I know that tobacco pays dutyâ€”this was between 4 and 5 in the morningâ€”there was no reason for its being put in the cabin, but some
times when you have a small parcel you put it in the cabin for safetyâ€”I thought this barge was being taken out for the removal of this one bale.
MR. METCALFE. Q. Did the man tell you that he was going to the quay? A. Yes; as soon as I heard there had been a robbery, I gave information of what I had seen.

JOSEPH TAYLOR . I am a bricklayer, of 3, Arthur-street, North Wool
wich-roadâ€”on Monday morning, 10th March, I was employed on the roof of a stable, close to Bow-creek, and, between 7 and 8 o'clock, saw a cart drive up over the footpath, which is an unusual thing where there is a roadâ€”the driver got out of it and took it up to the side of the wall as close to the bank as he could get, and two men came from a barge alongside the creek, with a sack; one held the bottom, and the other the mouth, and they carried itâ€”one of them ran up the bank, and the prisoner Turnbull assisted in put
ing it into the cartâ€”the other man was Crowâ€”they then fetched another sack; there were four sacks altogether, and two bales, which were covered with matting, something like thisâ€”they resembled bales of tobacco which I have seen in the docksâ€”I cannot say whether the four sacks would contain a bale if it was split up, but they were three-bushel sacksâ€”I saw a little bit of tobacco hanging out of the mouth of one of the sacksâ€”besides the pri
soners, there were three men in the barge and one at the cartâ€”having put them into the cart, they covered them up with some sacks, and Turnbull drove awayâ€”Crow remained about there a short time, and I went in to get my break
fastâ€”when I came back he was goneâ€”I did not look then to see where the barge wasâ€”Crow were a brown coat like he has now, and a blue, Navy cap, cloth.
Cross-examined by MR. H. GIFFARD. Q. When did you say anything about this? A. Next morningâ€”there was a bill offering a rewardâ€”I had
spoken at home about it in the afternoon, as I saw the cart at 6 in the morning.

JOHN SANDERSON . I am in the employ of Mr. Gray, a lighterman, of Water-lane, Tower-streetâ€”on Monday morning, 10th March, about 10 o'clock, I saw the prisoners together; one was crossing over a fence to get down into Canning-town, and the others were close to himâ€”from the entrance of that place, Bow-creek may be a quarter of a mileâ€”Canning-town is close to the railway; that would be a ahort cut to itâ€”I saw several carts, but not with themâ€”the chay carts that I saw were emptyâ€”about six or seven days after
wards Crow challenged me about seeing him with some tobaccoâ€”I said that I never saw him with anyâ€”he said, "Did not you see me?"â€”I said, "I know I did."

DANIEL FOSTER . I live at Orchard-lane, Blackwall, and am apprentice to Mr. Lucas, a watermanâ€”I found the Mary Ann barge adrift in Bow-creek; my mate made her fast, and she stopped there till Wednesdayâ€”I went on board and found a small portion of leaf tobacco in her.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know anything of the custom of hiring barges at 5s. a day? A. Well, they do hire them in that way, but they come and ask if you can let them have them.

COURT. Q. Do not they take them without asking sometimes? A. They doâ€”I found the small portion of tobacco rather towards the foremost part of the barge, but near midshipsâ€”the berge had been lying there from Mon
day to Wednesdayâ€”I found a piece of tobacco about two inches long and an inch wide, and several smaller pieces, but the water being in it, we could not make anything of it; it was all wetâ€”I dried it and gave it to the inspectorâ€”the other pieces were too small to dry.
MR. METCALFE. Q. Did what you saw on the barge, shew symptoms of tobaoco having been there? A. Yes.

ROBERT MAJOR (Thames-police Inspector). I took Crow on 3d April, and told him it was for stealing two bales of tobacco from the Richard Nestle, in the Victoria Docksâ€”he said that he knew nothing about; he was at home at the time.

HENRY DYER (Thames-policeman, 52). I received Crow from the last witnessâ€”on the way to the station he said he was not at the Victoria Docks either on the Sunday night or Monday morning; he was at home in bedâ€”on Saturday, 5th April, I took Turnbull at his house, 65, Richard-street, Com
mercial-roadâ€”a female answered the door, and I inquired in what room Mr. Turnbull livedâ€”she said, "The first-floor front room"â€”I went up, knocked at the door, and received no answerâ€”I put my little finger in the key-hole and found the key insideâ€”I asked them to admit me, but received no answerâ€”I said that I should force the door open if they did notâ€”I shoved against it, looked through the top part of it, and saw a fire alight and Turn
bull's cap on the tableâ€”after waiting some considerable time, Mrs. Turnbull asked me what I wantedâ€”I said. "I want your husband"â€”she said, "I have not seen him for these three days"â€”I said, "Well, open the door, and let me see"â€”she said, "Well, wait till I am dressed, and I will open the door"â€”during the time she was dressing, Turnbull asid, "What is it you want me for?"â€”I said, "Well, open, the door and I will tell you"â€”the wife then opened the door, and I told him the chargeâ€”he said that he knew nothing about it.

CROWâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

TURNBULLâ€”
GUILTY .â€”He was further charged with having been before convicted at Clerkenwell, in May, 1858; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY. *â€”
Ten Years Penal Servitude.

590.
MARY SHIELDS (27)
, Stealing a coal-scuttle and a kettle, the property of
Charles Pearson, having been previously convicted; to which she

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

591.
EDWARD HANMORE (22)
, Stealing 2 lbs. of tobacco, the pro
perty of
William Doughty.

WILLIAM DOUGHTY . On Thursday, 10th April, I had two pounds of tobacco in a box in my cartâ€”it was safe there at ten minutes to 8 that eveningâ€”at a quarter-past 8 it was missingâ€”Policeman R 34 brought it to me about 12 o'clock the same eveningâ€”I do not know the prisoner.

Prisoner. Q. When at Greenwich you said that you never missed the tobacco since you put it in the ears, and took it out? A. Yes, I didâ€”my man was on the cart from the time I left home till the time I returned, except at the Beehive at Eltham, where we both went in to have a little refreshment at about five minutes to 8â€”we did not leave the cart for more than a quarter of an hour.

BARTHOLOMEW LYNCH (Policeman, R 34). I stopped the prisoner on 10th April, at a quarter to 10 o'clock, in the high road to Leeâ€”he had this parcel (produced)â€”I asked him what it containedâ€”he said he did not knowâ€”I said, "How is that?"â€”he said that he picked it upâ€”I asked him whereâ€”he said, "This side of Fordstree village"â€”there was another constable stand
ing by, who asked him whether it was this side of Sidcup-gateâ€”he said it was the other sideâ€”I said, that unless he could give a more satisfactory account of it, I should take himâ€”he said, "I can give no other account of it"â€”I took him to the police-station, went and made inquiry, and ascertained that it had been taken from the prosecutorâ€”I showed it to the prosecutor, and he identified it.

Prisoner. Q. What did you find on me when you searched me? A. Nothing, except a tobacco-box and a sixpence, and this turnpike ticket (produced)â€”you were on the footway when I stopped youâ€”there was no donkey or cart near you at the time.
WILLIAM DOUGHTY (re-examined). I did not go within two miles and a half of Sidcup-gate.

SAMUEL MANSFIELD . I am a fish-hawkerâ€”on Thursday, 10th April, I went my round, and saw the prisoner several times in the course of the day with another man who was selling fishâ€”about half-past 8 I was coming home and saw the prisoner alone along the pathway before me, a very little distance from Sidcup-gate, and saw him pick this parcel up between the pathway and the hedgeâ€”I asked him what he had got there, what sort of a priseâ€”he said, "It is either tea or tobacco," and he showed it to meâ€”I said, "When are you going to take it to?"â€”he said, "To Deptford station"â€”one corner of it was undone when he showed it meâ€”next morning I was in Billingsgate by 6 o'clock, or else I should have been before the Magistrateâ€”his missus came and told my missusâ€”I have seen him working at the sewers many a timeâ€”that is all I know about himâ€”I gave him a ride along the road that night, and then I was going to bait my donkey, and he got out and walked on and said he should take it to the Deptiford stationâ€”he did not take the
donkey on with himâ€”I stopped an hour and a half or three quarters to bait the donkey, as it was tired.

BARTHOLOMEW LYNCH (re-examined). The prisoner was about five miles from Sidcup-gate when I stopped himâ€”according to his own statement, he had passed three police-stations, and two constables besides me, and said nothing to them about itâ€”he was going towards Deptford.
NOT GUILTY .

592.
ROBERT RICHARDSON (26), and
MATTHEW BALLS (20)
, Feloniously killing and slaying
Mary Ann Huddle; to which they

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
To enter into their own recognisances to appear to re
ceive judgment when called upon, and in the mean time to be of good behaviour to all her Majesty's subjects.

593.
WILLIAM LOOKER (39)
, Unlawfully and forcibly entering and expelling
William Richardson from certain premises, then being in his possession.

p.hi: This case had been under the consideration of another Jury four days before, who were discharged without giving any verdict, being unable to agree.

div1.p: WILLIAM RICHARDSON . I live at 96, Powis-street, Woolwich, and am a cabinet-makerâ€”I have been tenant of those premises between fourteen and fifteen yearsâ€”Mr. Barnett has been my landlord for the last sixteen monthâ€”I formerly held it under other landlords; from the temperance society, and a Mr. Boothâ€”during the whole fifteen months I have occupied the back shop and the yardâ€”this is the yard on the south (referring to a plan)â€”this it my gateway, and round here is my other little workshop, and this is my yard all roundâ€”that extends to this boundary wallâ€”there is a partition between a cigar-shop and my yardâ€”I built this coke-shed six or eight years agoâ€”I am in possession of the passage on the west, and this small strip of ground on the east of the workshopâ€”that comes right round, but lately Looker has put a doorway and stopped me from thereâ€”Powis-street is northâ€”the coke-shed cost me 7l. or 8l. to buildâ€”I also built the water closet at the same timeâ€”I think Looker came to the cigar-shop in Decemberâ€”a person named Russell was a tenant before himâ€”Austen was the last man before Lookerâ€”Looker took it from himâ€”Russell was there before that, and a person named Clout before himâ€”all the time I have been there I have been in possession of the yard up to the boundary wall, which is eighteen inches thick, and about seven feet high, with a gate between the premises and the wall which divides the twoâ€”there is also a window looking out of my premises into this yard, near the coad-shedâ€”up to 8th March nobody has ever claimed a right to this piece of yardâ€”about a fortnight before the defendant took possession, he said, "I am going to be a neighbour of yours"â€”I said, "Are you?"â€”he said, "Let me see, you have the whole of this yard; I suppose you will have no objection to my wife drying a few clothes in there?"â€”I don't think I said "Yes" or "No" to itâ€”I allowed him to do itâ€”I had been laid up with abscesses under my arm-pit before thisâ€”on 8th March, Looker came to my workshop before I was up, and said to Mrs. Richardson, "I want to see the master"â€”I came out and asked what he wantedâ€”he said, "If you don't move the coke out of that shed, I will move it for you, and chuk it in the yard"â€”he had not said anything

about that beforeâ€”I said, "The yard is mine, I have a right to it; what do you want with the yard?" in fact, I laughed at himâ€”he said, "Oh, I'll let you know; I will have the yard"â€”he then went away, and about half-past 1 he came again and said, "I see you are in the same mind about that coke-shed as you were before"â€”I said, "What is it to you about the coke-shed; the coke-shed is mine, and there is an end of ifâ€”my wife and servant were there thenâ€”he also said, "You are determined not to pull it down; I will pull it down and chuck it into the yard, if I go to Maidstone Gaol for six months for it"â€”I cautioned himâ€”he went away, and about a quarter of an hour afterwards the girl heard a knocking; the door of the shed was locked; I saw him break it open, and break the lockâ€”the girl immediately came to me, and called my attention to it; I looked out of the window, and Looker was the man who did itâ€”when he broke the door open he began shovelling the coke into a barrow, and wheeled it into the middle of the yardâ€”my wife persuaded me, not to go out, as I was illâ€”he took the coke all out; it took him pretty well all the afternoon, and then he took the front of the shed down and threw it on the cokeâ€”since then he has put up a door against the water-closet, which has shut us out altogether, and kept us out ever sinceâ€”about three weeks or a month after that, on Good Friday morning, I had an iron bedstead in the yard, and Looker threw the barrow from the part he claims into my yard, and grased the bedstead very muchâ€”I went out and moved the barrowâ€”he was in the water-closet then, and said, "Thank you, Mr. Richardson"â€”I said, "You are quite welcome, Mr. Looker"â€”we have access to the water-closet nowâ€”he said he would let me see that the yard belonged to him, and that he had a right to it, and threatened to break my neckâ€”he invited me inside his gate, and said he would break my neck for meâ€”this (produced) is my agreement with Barnett for the premises.
JURY. Q. Does the agreement contain the yard? It is not called a yard in the agreement, I thinkâ€”I have always had possession of it; nobody else has.

Cross-examined by MR. DALEY. Q. You did not tell us on Monday as much as you did to-day; did you say anything on Monday about this barrow being thrown in? A. Yes; you tried to prevent my paying itâ€”I never had a quarrel with Looker about furniture being left opposite my doorâ€”I swear I had no disagreement with him that I am aware ofâ€”there is only one water-closet for both housesâ€”it is used by the inhabitants of both housesâ€”he had to come out from his yard through this narrow strip into mineâ€”the width of the two yards is about five or six feetâ€”I knew Susannah Clout as living thereâ€”I let the place to her; I was trustee at the timeâ€”she left the cigar-shop in December, 1860â€”part of the shed was there at that timeâ€”I made it larger while she was thereâ€”it was a coke-shed beforeâ€”I took up more of the groundâ€”there was a pan-tile roof to itâ€”part of it was off and part on at this timeâ€”it was made up against the wall in a proper manner; it is a lean-to shedâ€”it was built of wood, and pan-tiles on the roof when it was first builtâ€”I presume Mr. Barnett is Looker's landlord; he is my landlordâ€”I am not in a position to swear that Looker holds the premises under Mr. Barnettâ€”the premises all belong to Barnett nowâ€”I have had conversations with Barnett about this coal-shedâ€”my arm was in a sling thenâ€”it was about 8th March, in the eveningâ€”he did not tell me to take away the coal-shedâ€”I told him what Looker had said, and he said, "Bother the fellow! I don't want to have any bother about it; it is a pity the coal-shed is not away"â€”I said, "I can't do anything"â€”he did not tell

me to take it awayâ€”I did not tell him I would take it away when my arm was betterâ€”when I went back Looker was chucking the coke about and pulling the shed down; and I said that he, as the landlord, ought to have come and stopped himâ€”he said, "The yard belongs to yon, Richardson; go and get out a summons, for he is doing wrong"â€”I said, "I would make peace when my arm was better"â€”I told Mr. Barnett that I would take it away when my arm got betterâ€”I did it to make peace and quietness between me and the landlordâ€”the servant was out at the back when she heard the noise, and she came to the front and told me of itâ€”I and Mrs. Richardson and the girl ran up stairs, and looked out of the window and saw him at itâ€”I had not seen him at it before the serrant called my attention to itâ€”I saw him in the act of breaking the door openâ€”that was at the time the girl spoke to meâ€”but for my arm, I think I should have gone out and prevented himâ€”I do not think I should have been frightened on my own premisesâ€”I should hare gone out if I had been in good health, and got somebody to help meâ€”I think there are some receipts to prove that I have been paying rent from fourteen to fifteen years thereâ€”I was there longer than eight yearsâ€”I was a tenant in 1852â€”I was in the premises in 1847â€”a Mr. Hugh was not there before meâ€”he was not tenant of my premises in 1852â€”I believe he was tenant of the next door.

MRS. RICHARDSON. I am the wife of the last witness, and have been at this house between fourteen and fifteen yearsâ€”during all that time, up to 8th March, we hare always bad possession of this piece of yard; nobody ever disputed itâ€”I heard Mr. Looker say that he would have it, if he went to Maidstone Goal for six months for it, and he called God to witness.

Cross-examined. Q. What year did you become tenant of that house? A. I can't tell; between fourteen and fifteen years agoâ€”the coke-shed was there in 1858â€”it was there when Susannah Clout was in the premises.

JESSIE LAMONT . I am serrant to Mr. Richardson, and have been so for the last four or fire yearsâ€”during the whole time I have been there, until 8th March last, my master always had possession of this yardâ€”I called his attention about 2 o'clock on that day to Mr. Looker, who was pulling the shed downâ€”I heard about Maidstone Gaol.

WILLIAM AUSTIN . Up to the 28th Jane last, I occupied the premises which Looker now hasâ€”after I left, he took themâ€”I was there seven southsâ€”at the time I was there, my neighbour, Mr. Richardson, always had possession of this yard, up to the boundary-wallâ€”my premises extended to the boundary-wallâ€”the coke-shed was on the prosecutor's premises, not on my property.
Cross-examined. Q. When did Looker come in? A. I left on 28th June, and he then came in, on the quarter-day.
COURT. Q. Did you use the water-closet? A. Yes; we just went through the gate, and shut the gate after usâ€”there was a lock and key to it.

JAMES DAVIS . I am shopman to Mr. Fitzgerald, of Powis-street, Wool-wich, and was formerly one of the managing-directors of the Temperance Society, who had a lease of these premisesâ€”I have known Mr. Richardson as holding the property for many yearsâ€”we got the house from Mr. Booth, and took Mr. Richardson as a tenantâ€”during the time I have known him as a tenant, he had bad a right to this yard, and it was in his possession.

Cross-examined. Q. How do you know that? A. By being one of the directorsâ€”I know now that Mr. Barnett is the landlordâ€”I do not know whether he has made any difference in the agreementâ€”I only know Richardson had possession of that yard when we had the property.
JURY. Q. Was there any closet to the house which the defendant occupied? A. No; the one mentioned was to supply the two houses.

JOHN BARNETT . I am the landlord of these disputed premisesâ€”Looker became my tenant last Juneâ€”this is the agreement under which I let to Mr. Richardsonâ€”it was not a personal letting on my partâ€”Levy, an agent, let itâ€”I do not know what was let to Mr. Lookerâ€”I was not present when the thing was doneâ€”I signed the agreementâ€”(This was an agreement be
tween Barnett and Richardson for all that portion of the premises known as the Temperance Hall, namely, two rooms and a workshop, part of which was partitioned of, and appurtenances, at a rent of 14l. Another Agreement was read, stating that Mr. William Austin occupied all the other part of the premises, and appurtenances thereof.

Cross-examined by MR. ORRIDGE. Q. From whom did you take the premises? A. From the trustees of the masonic bodyâ€”I let to Richardson what he had formerly heldâ€”I believe that was the understanding Mr. Levy had with him.

EDWARD JAMES LEVY . I am agent of this property, under Mr. Barnettâ€”I know the premisesâ€”I think this is a correct plan of themâ€”I know what the appurtenances were that were let to Mr. Lookerâ€”I have the agreement before me.

COURT. Q. Do you know what were occupied by Mr. William Austin? A. I let the premises, in the first instance, to Russell, and afterwards to Austin; I also let the appurtenances, which were a straight line from the back-yard, as far aa the water-closet.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you heard Mr. Austin give evidence? A. I have notâ€”I should be surprised to hear that he claime that piece of the yard.
GUILTY .

p.hi:
The Jury, considered that the defendant had been led into error by the agent, Mr. Levy.â€”
To enter into recognisances to appear and receive judgment at the next Sessions.

div1.p:
594.
MARY BARKER (39)
, Stealing I wooden tray, value 1s. 6d. the property of
John Williams.

WILLIAM WARRINGTON (Policeman, R 279).
