On Sundny, 4th May, about half-past 2, 1 saw the prisoner take a potato-tray from a court leading from Wellington-street to Hugghe's-fields, the property of Mr. Williams, which was standing at the side of his houseâ€”she carried it down the court about thirty yards, and then laid it downâ€”I was about two yards from her at the timeâ€”the ran away about six or seven yardsâ€”I atopped her, and asked her what she was going to do with that potato-trayâ€”she said she had not taken it; what was she to do wiih it?â€”I said it might do to light firesâ€”that was all that occurredâ€”I took her to the staton-house.

COURT. Q. Had she been drinking? A. I believe she had; but she knew very well what she was aboutâ€”this potato-tray always stands out
side.

JOHN WILLIAMS . I am greengrocer, at Wellington-street, Deptfordâ€”on Sunday morning, 4th May, I lost a potato-trayâ€”the constable told me of itâ€”I have seen it sinceâ€”it is mineâ€”it was outside my shop.
COURT. Q. You leave your trays outside, do you? A. It is a very small shop, and I cannot get it madeâ€”I did not wish, to press the charge, but Mr. Traill mads me come here by a summons.
NOT GUILTY .

595.
ELLEN GOUGH (16)
, Stealing, on 23d March, 1 locket, 1 chain and 1 thimble, of
Frederick Henry Smith, her master.

ELIZABETH HAMILTON . I am a nursemaid, in the service of Dr. Smith, of 4, Union-place, Blackheath-roadâ€”I know the prisonerâ€”she was in the same service as general servant, from 7th March to the 24thâ€”she has left the service nowâ€”while I and the prisoner were there, Mrs. Smith told me she had missed a gold locket and chainâ€”the prisoner was present, and said she had not seen it, and knew nothing about itâ€”on 29th March I accompanied police-constable Watson to the prisoner's lodging, and saw him search her box, and take from it the locket and chain, Mrs. Smith's propertyâ€”it was pawned, and the officer has got it.

Cross-examined by MR. ORRIDGE. Q. You say you saw him find the locket and chain in the box? A. No; the pawn-ticket for some articlesâ€”the ticket for the chain and locket was in the drawerâ€”I have not seen it sinceâ€”I was on good terms with the prisoner when she left, not on the morningâ€”she had not done some work for meâ€”neither for me or any of the servantsâ€”she did not make a petticoat for meâ€”she said that I gave her the locket and chain, and she made a petticoat for me, but I did notâ€”she said that when it was found.
MR. WOOD. Q. Can you now inform me whether you saw the locket and chain again? A. I saw it in the pawnbroker's handsâ€”he is hereâ€”this is it (produced)â€”it is Mrs. Smith's property.

CHARLES BOWMAN . I am shopman to Mr. Crossley, a pawnbroker, of Blackheath-hillâ€”on 29th March the prisoner came into our shop, and offered this locket to pledgeâ€”I asked her whose property it was, and she told me she had been sent by a party in South-street to pledge itâ€”I asked her how much she wanted, and she said, "3s."â€”I said she might have more than 3s.â€”she said, "I do not want any more; I have had more, but do not want it now"â€”I let her have the 3s,
Cross-examined. Q. Is it worth 4l.? A. No; from 15s. to 1l.

THOMAS WATSON (Policeman, R 124). In consequence of information I received, I accompanied Elisabeth Hamilton to the prisoner's lodgings in South-streetâ€”I searched her box, aud found these duplicates; one of them related to a gold locket and chainâ€”that was in a drawer with othersâ€”it was not concealedâ€”I went to the pawnbroker's, and found it pawned there.

GERTRUDE ADELAIDE SMITH . I am the wife of Frederick Henry Smith, and reside at 4, Union-place, Blackheath-roadâ€”this locket and chain are my propertyâ€”I saw them two or three days previous to the prisoner's leavingâ€”I never saw it after she leftâ€”I asked her about it, and she said she had not seen it.

Cross-examined. Q. When was that you spoke about the locket and chain? A. Just before she left; after she had unpacked her boxesâ€”she unpacked her boxes in my presence, and they were packed againâ€”she left them behind her, and sent for them.

COURT. Q. When she was going away, you requested that her boxes should be opened? A. Yes, and she opened them, and I saw all that was in themâ€”the nurse was present at the timeâ€”the nurse had been with me about four months, I think.
MR. WOOD. Q. I suppose you did not examine these boxes so carefully at to have noticed everything that was in them? A. No.
The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate was here read as follows: "The nurse gave me the locket and chain for a petticoat I made for her."

MR. ORRIDGE (to ELIZABETH HAMILTON). Q. Are you wearing a magenta and black petticoat now? A. Yes; the prisoner was not sitting up on the Saturday night making it for meâ€”I have had it a long timeâ€”I made it up myself.

Prisoner. Q. Did I not do it, as you had got a baby's frock to make, did not you say you had some clothes of your own to make, and you gave me a magenta and black petticoat, and did not I sit up till 3 o'clook on Sunday night to make it for you? A. No; I am sure you did not.
NOT GUILTY .

596.
ELLEN GOUGH was again indicted
for stealing, on 20th January, 1 scarf, the property of
John Richard Lloyd, her master.

JAMES RICHARD LLOYD . I live at Lee, in Kentâ€”the prisoner was in my service for a fortnight in Januaryâ€”when she left several small articles were missedâ€”she sent some ladies for a character, and I declined to give itâ€”a policeman afterwards brought a scarf to my houseâ€”I think that was in Marchâ€”I was not at homeâ€”I saw that scarf produced at the Greenwich Police-courtâ€”this is it (produced)â€”to the best of my belief it is mineâ€”two of them were given to my children previouslyâ€”they are very peculiar scarves; very curious textureâ€”they are silk, I think, and were originally of considerable value, I should imagineâ€”the value of them is about 8s. (A person in Court here stated that he had been in the trade twenty years, and he valued the scarf at 1s.)
NOT GUILTY .

597.
STEPHEN THOMPSON (30)
, stealing 3 quarts of brandy and 4 bottles, the property of
Richard Scales; also 4 bottles of brandy, the pro
perty of
Isaac Brittain; also 4 bottles of brandy, the property of
John Brown, having been before convicted; to all which he

PLEADED GUILTY . **â€”
Ten Years' Penal Servitude.

598.
HENRY GRENVILLE (24)
, Unlawfully attempting burglariously to enter the dwelling-house of
Ebenezer Edward Phillips Doudney, with intent to steal; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

599.
JOHN WILSON (43)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

JAMES MILES . I am barman at the Grapes public-house, High-street, Southwarkâ€”on Saturday, 29th March, the prisoner came and asked for 1 1/2 d. worth of ginâ€”I served himâ€”he gave a bad shilling, which I bent, told him it was bad, and returned itâ€”I am quite sure it was badâ€”he made no reply, but pulled out some copper money, paid me, and then left, taking the bent shilling with himâ€”the next Saturday, April 5th, he came in againâ€”I knew him the moment he came inâ€”he asked for 1 1/2 d. worth of ginâ€”I served him, and he gave me a bad sixpenceâ€”I sent privately for a policemanâ€”while waiting, the prisoner asked for his changeâ€”I told him I had. no coppers, but that as soon as they came he should have themâ€”upon that be went towards the doorâ€”I jumped over the counter, detained him till two

policemen came, and then gave him in custodyâ€”I told the constable he had been passing bad money at the place on the previous Saturday, and on this nightâ€”the prisoner made no replyâ€”I gave the bed sixpence to the police
man, and the prisoner was taken to the stationâ€”I am positive he is the man.
Prisoner. Q. Did you tell me I had given you a bad sixpence? A. No; I told you I had no halfpenceâ€”there were three others serving in the bar besides me.

GEORGE STENT (Policeman, M 188). The prisoner was given into my custody on 5th Aprilâ€”the last witness gave me this broken sixpence (pro
duced)â€”I searched the prisoner and found on him two good shillings, seven good sixpences, and 7d., good money.

WILLIAM WEBSTER . I am inspector of coin to her Majesty's Mintâ€”this sixpence is bad. (The prisoners statement before the Magistrate was here read as follows: "I was not in the house the Saturday before as stated by the witness.")

Prisoner's Defence. If I was there on the 29th March, and offered a bad shilling, and the young man tarred me in the way he says, is it likely I should go on the next Saturday night and give him another; if I did I could expect nothing else but that I should get into the station. I get my living by exchanging articles of hardware for old clothes. I was coming home and went into the public-house, not with the intention of changing Anything, but I thought I had three halfpence in my pocket, and when I got in I found I only had an old and new halfpenny, and thought it was three halfpence. I gave the sixpence for the gin. He never told me that I had given him a bad sixpence, and I did not know it; so I had no occasion to go out My wife came to the door to speak to me, and that is why I turned round. I am not the man who was in the house at all on the 29th, and I never offered him the bad shilling.
NOT GUILTY .

600.
JAMES FLACK (30), alias
John Richards , was indicted
for a like offence.

LOUISA BRODIE . I am barmaid at the King's Arms public-house, at Suffolk-street, Southwarkâ€”on Saturday, 12th April, the prisoner came in with two women and asked for half-a-quartern of ginâ€”I served himâ€”he gave me a florinâ€”I put it in the till where there was no other money, and gave him changeâ€”he remained a few minutes at the bar, and then asked for another half-quartern of gin, which I served him with, and he gave me another florinâ€”I also put that in the till, and gave him changeâ€”he re
mained at the bar, and shortly afterwards called for a pot of beerâ€”I served him with that, and he gave me a shillingâ€”I took it to my master, spoke to him about it, and gave it to himâ€”went to the till and saw the two two-shilling piecesâ€”he took them out and kept themâ€”my master asked him to pay himâ€”he told him they were badâ€”the prisoner ran sway, and my master after himâ€”he was taken in custody the same night.

Prisoner. Q. Had not I been drinking in front of the bar for about two hours? A. I did not see you thereâ€”you went round to two women and they asked you to stand some gin, and you put threepence on the counterâ€”it did not bounce off the counter and I pick it upâ€”you gave me all the money into my hand.

GEORGE ALDERSON . I am the landlord of the King's Armsâ€”on the evening, 12th of April, the last witness brought me a bad shilling, and pointed the prisoner out to meâ€”she said that she thought it was badâ€”

I said, "It is, who gave it you?"â€”I took it back to him, and said, "This won't do here," and threw it down on the counterâ€”after he took it up he was going to pay me with a sixpenceâ€”one of the females mid, "You have got his change out of a florin"â€”by the way they spoke I thought something was wrongâ€”I opened the till, took out the florins, and examined thenâ€”there was no other money in the tillâ€”I saw they were bad as soon as I took them outâ€”the prisoner ran out of the house directly he saw me touch the tillâ€”he was afterwards taken in custodyâ€”I gave the constable the two florinsâ€”the prisoner took the shilling away with himâ€”I am quite sure it was had.

Prisoner. Q. Did not you come to me at the corner where I was standing, and say, "Come back, I want you?" A. You were not standing at all; I ran and overtook youâ€”I did not say, "Give me 4s. and I will let you go"â€”you said, "What do you want?"â€”I said, "You had better come back"â€”my brother came up, and we brought you back to the houseâ€”I said, "I don't want to have any trouble; if you pay me the mone I will return you the 2s. pieces, and let you go"â€”I should have dis
figured them firstâ€”you have left tin and solder at my place on a Saturday night, and called for it on the Monday morning.

JOHN SHEHAH (Policeman, M 119). The prisoner was given into my custodyâ€”Mr. Alderson gave me these two florins (produced)â€”I searched the prisoner and found on him 6s. 6d. good money, and 9d. in coppersâ€”I did not find the bad shilling.
COURT to GEORGE ALDERSON. Q. Did the woman leave? A. They went with me to the station, and the inspector wanted me to detain herâ€”I said I would not, because she had not passed any bad money to me.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These two florins are bad.

Prisoner's Defence. I am a bard working man; if I had known the things were bad when he offered to lei me off on paying 4s. does it not stand to reason that I should have done so? As I worked hard I did not like to give 4s. I have a wife and four children, and it would have been a great loss to me.
GUILTY .

He was further charged with having been convicted at this Court in May, 1860, of unlawfully having counterfeit coin his possession, and confined Eighteen Months; to which he PLEADED GUILTY. **â€”
Four Years' Penal Servitude.

601.
SAMUEL WILSON (19)
, Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
William Johnson, at
Lambeth, and stealing therein 28 watches, 6 chains, and other articles, value Â£500, his property; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

602.
THOMAS LAKE (34), and
JOHN GUNNER (20)
, Stealing 40 lbs. of mutton, the property of
William George Holloway.

CHARLES EDWARDS . I am in the service of George Holloway, a butcher, of Deptfordâ€”on Friday, 11th April, about 6 o'clock, I was in the shop and saw half a sheep hanging outside the doorâ€”I missed it about 7 o'clockâ€”I went round King-street, which is near the shop, and saw some one go over a wallâ€”I met another butcher coming back with the muttonâ€”it weighed between 40 and 50 lbs. and was worth about 2l.
CHARLES STEER . I am shopman to Mr. Cartwright, of Deptford, Broadwayâ€”I was at the shop door on 11th April, about a quarter to 7, and

and saw the two prisoners coming down the High-streetâ€”they had been pointed out to me by a constable to watch themâ€”they went to Mr. Hollway's shopâ€”Lake took the mutton downâ€”Gunner threw a coat over it, and then ran round King-street, and in a minute I saw Gnnner run down Church-streetâ€”I informed the policemanâ€”I am positive the prisoners are the menâ€”I was within a yard of them, and never lost sight of them.

HENRY ONLEY . I am in the service of Mr. Markham, of Deptford Bridge, on Friday evening, 11th April, I saw Lake go to Mr. Holloway's shop, take down a pair of hind quarters of mutton, and put them into a fish hamperâ€”Gunner put a coat over them, and as they turned down King-street it dropped outâ€”they picked it up and put it in againâ€”Gunner went one way and Lake the otherâ€”I caught Lake and said, "Give me the mutton"â€”I brought it backâ€”Williams came up at that timeâ€”they had a struggle, and Lake hit Williams in the chest and got awayâ€”I went back to Mr. Holloway's with the mutton, and told him about it

JOSEPH WILLIAMS . I am an auctioneer, of Green-lane, Royal-hill Gardensâ€”I was in Mr. Holloway's shopâ€”a female came in and gave me some information, and I saw Holloway's man, who asked me to come with himâ€”I went into King-street and saw Lake with some meat on his armâ€”I followed him down a turning, and saw it taken from himâ€”I tried to catch himâ€”he struck me on the chest, got over the wall, and I held him thereâ€”a person said, "That is Daddy Lake, he is a dangerous customer, let him go, or he will drop a brick on your head"â€”I let him go, because I could hold him no longer.

THOMAS BELCHER (Policeman, R 234). On Saturday evening, between 7 and 8 o'clock, I took Gunner at Lewishamâ€”I told him the chargeâ€”he said he was at home at his father's at 7 o'clock, and had left Lake at Deptford at 5 o'clock, and he knew nothing about it.

Lake's Defence. I was in-doors, having my tea. I looked out at the window, and saw some people. The constable saw me and took me in charge; the reason is that I have been convicted of stealing a pair of boots. I have worked at Deptford twelve years now, but am now out of work on account of my deafness. Every time I come to Deptford I am followed by this constable, taken up, detained, and let go again. I had not been out two days before I was taken and locked np for an hour.
Gunner's Defence. I am innocent; I was at my father's.
GUILTY .

p.hi: They were both further charged with having been convicted, separately, at Greenwich Police-court; to which they

div1.p:
PLEADED GUILTY.**â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude each.

603.
WILLIAM CLARINGBOLD (61)
, Feloniously forging and uttering a lease of a certain house in Counter-street, Southwark; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Four Years' Penal Servitude.

604.
CHARLES PATTERSON (22)
, Feloniously uttering a forged 5l. Bank of England note, with intend to defraud.

WILLIAM WRIGHT . I Am a cheesemonger of High-street, Camberwell.â€”on Monday, 7th April, about 12 in the day, the prisoner came into my shop and spoke to my shopman, who referred him to meâ€”he asked me if I would oblige him with change for a 5l. note, for Mr. Searleâ€”I know Mr. Searle; he is an auctioneer, living 60 or 70 yards from meâ€”the prisoner

gave me the noteâ€”I looked at it, and not liking its appearance, said, "Mr. Searle is not in the habit of sending strangers for change; I will go and see"â€”he said, "You need not be afraid," and we walked to Mr. Searle's shop together, I still keeping the noteâ€”I saw that there was nobody in the shop, and was going to ring the bell, the outer door being shutâ€”the prisoner said, "You need not ring the bell, you can open the door"â€”I put my hand on the latch, and he immediately ran awayâ€”I ran after him, calling "Stop him"â€”I saw Walters stop himâ€”I had not lost sight of himâ€”I gave him in custodyâ€”I took the note with me to the station, and gave it to the constableâ€”I marked itâ€”this is it (produced)â€”I taw another note taken from the prisoner's hand at the stationâ€”he said that he picked them up that morning on Denmark-hillâ€”my shop is nearer to London than Denmark-kill on the Walworth side.
Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. Did be say that he bad picked up this note? A. Not till he got to the stationâ€”he did not say whether to was in Mr. Searle's service.

WILLIAM WATERS . On 7th April, about mid-day, I was in Camberwell New road with a man named Cartwright, and saw the prisoner running towards me, with a mob after himâ€”that is the road from Camberwell-green to Kennington-commonâ€”I heard somebody call "Stop thief"â€”I caught hold of the prisoner, and he tried to throw me, but Cartwright helped meâ€”the prisoner drew his hand out of his pocket clenched, and Cartwright said, "Look out Bill, he has got something in his hand"â€”Cartwright laid hold of his handâ€”Mr. Wright came up and said that the prisoner must be taken to the station, and we took him there, Cartwright holding the hand that was closed, so that he could not open it.

MARMADUKE. CARTWRIGHT . I am a gardener and live at Troy-town, Peckham-riseâ€”on 7th April, I was in Camberwell-new-road, heard some one call "Stop thief," and saw the prisoner runningâ€”Walters stopped him, and I saw him put his hand in his trouser's pocket, take it out, and shut it directlyâ€”I took him by the wrist, and kept hold of his hand till we got to the station, where I tried to take out what he had in it, but he got my thumb in his mouth and bit itâ€”the Serjeant said, "Put his hand on the bar"â€”I did to and got it outâ€”his hand was afterwards forced open, and there was a 5l. Bank of England note in itâ€”the prisoner then said, "Now I am done for."
â€”QUIN (Policeman, 23 P). The prisoner's hand was forced open by Cartwright and myselfâ€”he had the 5l. note (produced) in itâ€”he said that he found the notes opposite the church on Denmark-hill.

ASTLEY SEARLE . I am an auctioneer of Camberwell-green, about a hundred yards from Mr. Wright's, who I know perfectly wellâ€”I do not know the prisonerâ€”I did not authorize him, on 7th April, to go to Mr. Wright's for change for a 5l. note, nor did I send any oneâ€”I am in the habit of lending to him for change, but principally for cheques not notesâ€”I send one of my clerks.

JOSEPH BUMSTEAD . I am inspector of notes to the Bank of Englandâ€”these notes are both forged in every respect, paper and printingâ€”they are both printed from the same plate on the same kind of paperâ€”the numbers are different: they would be put on afterwards.

GUILTY .â€”
Six Years' Penal Servitude.

p.hi: There was another indictment against the prisoner.

div1.p:
605.
JOHN LAMBERT (21)
, Feloniously assaulting
Catherine Eliza Mann, and stealing from her person a watch and chain, her property.

CATHERINE ELIZA MANN . I reside at 7, Bucklersburyâ€”on 24th March, between 7 and 8 in the evening, I was passing along Blackman-street, Borough, on the same side as St. George's-churchâ€”I was suddenly seized by somebody round the waistâ€”the person tried to catch my throatâ€”my dress was torn open, and every fastening brokenâ€”my watch was taken from inside my dressâ€”it was worth 18l.â€”there was only one person who attacked meâ€”there were a number of people passing, but I think at that instant then were fewer than usualâ€”when I lost my watch, a man ran across the road and down Lant-street, which is just oppositeâ€”I called out "Stop him," and he was pursued by somebody else, but I did not see him stoppedâ€”I believe the prisoner is the manâ€”I saw him pretty clearly; we were face to faceâ€”he first seized me from behind; then he seized me round the waist, and when he made the attempt at my throat, he was before meâ€”the next morning I went to the station-houseâ€”I then saw the prisoner mixed with other men, and pointed him out as the man I supposed had done it.

Cross-examined by Mr. BEST. Q. What kind of a night was it? A. A fine, but darkâ€”I could not form a correct idea of the time the transaction occupiedâ€”I think it was more than a few secondsâ€”my watch was snatched very quickly after the attempt at my throat; it was almost instantaneouslyâ€”the man had time to take my umbrella and break the handleâ€”he carried off part of the umbrellaâ€”the attempt at the umbrella was after the watch was takenâ€”I did not see what was done with the watchâ€”I called out im
mediately I saw a portion of the chain, that was left round my throat, hangingâ€”I saw the prisoner next morning with several othersâ€”I think neither of them were so tall as heâ€”I think there were four othersâ€”I am firmly convinced he is the person, and I have always beenâ€”I only refused to swear itâ€”I am speaking to the best of my beliefâ€”I saw two men run across the roadâ€”the prisoner was pursued by another manâ€”I do not mean two men beside the prisonerâ€”I knew at the time it was the man who had first attacked me.
COURT. Q. The man, whoever it was, ran directly across into Lant-street? A. Directly across.

EDWARD IZARD . I reside at 30, Henry-place, Old Kent-roadâ€”on 24th March, about half-past 7 in the evening, I was at the corner of Lant-streetâ€”I was looking across the roadâ€”I saw two men running, and the pro
ecutrix on the other side of the streetâ€”I went over to her, and I saw her dress was torn openâ€”the two men had then passed the corner of the street; the prisoner was on one side of me, and the other man on the otherâ€”I was at the corner nearest the "Elephant and Castle"â€”the prisoner passed so close I could have touched himâ€”he is the man; I have no doubt of itâ€”I picked him out from among a down peopleâ€”he faced me as he was coming over, and the lamp threw a light on his laceâ€”the young lady was very much distressed, and I accompanied her to the stationâ€”it was nearly a fortnight after that I again saw the prisonerâ€”I then picked him out from among ten or a dozen peopleâ€”I am certain he is the man I saw running.

Cross-examined. Q. How many of the dozen were policemen? A. There were no policemen, I think, or they were in plain clothesâ€”I believe the men were all in one cell togetherâ€”I only saw two men runningâ€”I was looking straight across the road all the time.

WILLIAM JOHN COUPARD . I am a machine maker, residing at Albany-road, Camberwellâ€”on 24th March, I was in Blackman-streetâ€”I saw some man leave the footway, and run towards the corner of Lant-street, towards

the side I was on, and come within three or four yards of meâ€”I did not see his' faceâ€”I should think the prisoner is the man by his' general appearanceâ€”when he neared the pavement I heard a cry of "Stop thief"â€”I pursued him up Lant-streetâ€”he turned the corner of a streetâ€”I was there stopped by two men, who took hold of me by the shoulders and said, "What it lost?"â€”that prevented my running further after the prisonerâ€”I thought it not safeâ€”I next saw him at the police-court when he was being examined, I believed him to be the manâ€”I could not swear to him.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see two persons cross the road? A. I saw two men running across, I followed one of them; both went up Lant-street I lost sight of the other, and ran after the one who was running quickestâ€”I was running very fast when I was stoppedâ€”I am quite certain the other man ran up Lint-streetâ€”I lost him at the corner of Lant-street; I did not look for him, I paid no attention to him, but took up the chase after the one who was running quickest.

SYDNEY PARKER . I am a baker boy at Mr. Winchester'sâ€”I was coming down Lant-street, on the 24th March, about half-past 7; I was going towards Blackman-streetâ€”I saw the prisonerâ€”I am quite sure I saw himâ€”I saw his lace distinctly; he was running as hard as ever he couldâ€”I turned round and followed him into Harrow-street, and he turned into a court and went into a houseâ€”I saw him again at 2 o'clock the same morning, and picked him out of a number of prisoners.

Cross-examined. Q. What part of the road or pavement was he running upon? A. In the middle of the roadâ€”I turned round and ran after him, because I heard a cry of "Stop thief"â€”I knew him at once when I picked him out at the police-station, Stone's endâ€”I knew him because I saw his face and dressâ€”I do not know the witness Izardâ€”I did not see any other person besides the prisonerâ€”I was about half-way down Lant-street, between Harrow-street, and Blackman-street, on the right-hand side, when I heard the cry of "Stop thief"â€”the prisoner ran into a house in Suffolk-courtâ€”I turned round and followed directly I heard the cry of "Stop thief"â€”I took the police to the house he went intoâ€”I only saw one man running.

THOMAS GARDNER (Police-sergeant, M 25). I was at the police-station when the prosecutrix came, on the 24th March, about 8 o'clockâ€”from infor
mation I received, I accompanied the last witness to a house in Suffolk-court, which leads out of Harrow-street; that street is about 100 yards from Blackman-streetâ€”I went to the house, but I did not see anything of the prisonerâ€”the following morning another officer brought him to the stationâ€”I afterwards brought him out with five othersâ€”they were brought into the room where the prosecutrix was, and were placed in a rowâ€”she pointed out the prisoner, but said, "I will not positively swear to him"â€”she then laid her hand on his shoulder, and said, "Turn round"â€”he did turn round, and then she said, "I believe him to be the man, but I am not positive"â€”she put her hand as if trying his measure.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you go to the house a second time? A. Noâ€”I do not know what the prisoner was brought to the station forâ€”he was brought on another charge during the nightâ€”the constable is here who brought himâ€”I was not present at the timeâ€”he was sober when I fetched him out in the morning.

WALTER FISHER (Policeman M 285). On 26th March, between 1 and 2 in the morning, I took the prisoner in custody in Blackman-street, for being disorderlyâ€”the inspector liberated him upon that charge, and he came out into the receiving-room, and I took him back, placed him in the

bar, and told him I charged him with stealing a gold watch and chain, and a portion of a parasol, of Miss Mannâ€”he said, "I know nothing at all about it; you know the difference to that, because you saw me in the Borough two or three hours ago, and I should not walk about there if I had done that"â€”I had seen him in the Borough that evening before the robbery took placeâ€”he said, "I was in Black man-street two hours before that," meaning two hours before the robbery, I believeâ€”I did not understand him to mean two hours before I took him up.

Cross-examined by MR. BEST. Q. Were you present when Izard saw the prisoner? A. Yesâ€”he identified him from among twelve persons, some shorter and some tallerâ€”that was about a fortnight afterwardsâ€”it was about 6 in the evening when I saw him in Blackman-streetâ€”I was not on duty; I was going to the stationâ€”I did not go into Blackman-street again till my 10 o'clock dutyâ€”I walked up and down Blackman-street after 10â€”I did not go to a house in the court, but I searched round the back premises, to see if I could find anythingâ€”when he was liberated, on the charge of being disorderly, an entry was made in a book, and when I took him up again it was enteredâ€”he was as sober as I am.

COURT. Q. You gave evidence against him for being disorderly? A. Yesâ€”he was with a lot of boys, pushing against the people, and annoying them in every wayâ€”I asked him to keep back, because there was a fireâ€”I then took him in custody for being disorderly, and the inspector discharged himâ€”I then gave him in custody on this charge.
WALTER FISHER (re-examined). I had a description of the prisoner from Miss Mann, at wearing a' black frock coat and a Hack waistcoatâ€”it was from that description that I took the prisoner.
NOT GUILTY .
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, JUNE 16, 1862.
